fields.headline: Vialli will play only in 'emergency'
fields.trailText: Gianluca Vialli said yesterday he hoped never to play again despite coming out of retirement this week and he was registered for domestic and European action purely in case of emergency.
fields.body:
A forward line of George Weah and Gianluca Vialli would make defenders' knees go trembly even at a combined age of 68. But Vialli said yesterday he hoped never to play again despite coming out of retirement this week.

The Chelsea player-manager said he was registered for domestic and European action purely in case of emergency. And no, the total of two goals scored by Chris Sutton and Gianfranco Zola in the Premiership this season did not constitute that.

"I'm not making myself available because I have a problem with my strikers," the 35-year-old said. "We don't need another striker. It was the last chance to register for the Champions League or the Premier League and I did it just in case. If something happens and I had not registered myself it would have been stupid.

"I hope I won't be playing because that would mean nothing strange has happened. I'm looking forward to staying on the bench as a manager. I'm not going to push myself into the team or play for the sake of it."

Vialli puts himself behind Gabriele Ambrosetti, a left-winger, and the youngster Mikael Forssell in the pecking order of strikers. But with Weah ineligible for the Champions League he decided to leave nothing to chance.

The departures of Bjarne Goldbaek to Fulham and Mark Nicholls on loan to Reading left a free berth in the Champions League squad list because only Emerson Thome has been added.

"I'm not sure I would do a very good job," said Vialli, who felt extremely tired after his first game in eight months for the reserves on Monday. "I've tried to keep myself fit, but to be successful you need to think and train as a player."

He prefers to think as a manager these days. "I gave up at the right time, scoring a goal against Derby," he said. "I didn't hear anybody shouting, 'Please stop, you are getting too old'. That's a success. And I don't want to come back for the sake of it.

"The feeling of getting kicked is something you might miss. It's a physical game and it makes you feel a man. A sore ankle, a swollen knee or a bruise makes you feel alive. But I think I get enough kicks from the players in training.

"The feeling of scoring goals is also something you miss. But as manager you see the players and supporters are happy after a win, and that's a great feeling too."

Denis Smith has returned to Oxford United as manager, 26 months after leaving for West Brom. He replaces the temporary manager Mickey Lewis, who will remain as a coach.

Huddersfield have signed the 24-year-old midfielder Chris Holland from Birmingham for an undisclosed fee on a 3-year contract.

Three English referees, Graham Barber, Paul Durkin and Graham Poll, and Scotland's Hugh Dallas are in a list of 30 from whom Uefa will choose the officials for Euro 2000.

webTitle: Safety-first Dons to let Sullivan go

fields.headline: Safety-first Dons to let Sullivan go
fields.standfirst: Olsen ready to cash in on his goalkeeper once Premiership status is secure
fields.trailText: Wimbledon are preparing to sell their goalkeeper Neil Sullivan for £1m rather than lose him for nothing in the summer. He is out of contract at the end of the season and Wimbledon's manager Egil Olsen is loth to see the 29-year-old leave on a free when his market value is about £3m.
fields.body:
Wimbledon are preparing to sell their goalkeeper Neil Sullivan for £1m rather than lose him for nothing in the summer. He is out of contract at the end of the season and Wimbledon's manager Egil Olsen is loth to see the 29-year-old leave on a free when his market value is about £3m.

"If we reach something like 40 points quite early, letting Neil go might be something we could do if someone makes an offer," Olsen said.

"It is a possibility, and I'm not necessarily looking for a new keeper if he does go because Kelvin Davis and Paul Heald are both very good."

Celtic and Arsenal have been linked with the Scotland international, who joined Wimbledon as a trainee and has turned down a new contract.

Terry Phelan has strongly criticised Everton's manager Walter Smith after joining Fulham on a free transfer until the end of the season.

The former Republic of Ireland defender, 32, had been a peripheral figure at Goodison Park since recovering from a knee injury in the summer and spent three months on loan at Crystal Palace.

"I won't go back to Everton," he said. "I'm not even going to go and get my boots. I've slogged my guts out to get fit during pre-season and I didn't get a chance."

George Graham has said he will not enter Tottenham in the InterToto Cup if they fail to qualify automatically for Europe. "I haven't even asked the club's opinion but I would definitely be against it," he said. "It looks like the clubs who finish fifth and sixth this season will again be invited to take part. But that means playing the first match on July 16 or 17 if you are the higher finisher, or July 2 if you are the lower one. When do the players get a break?"

Danny Murphy has signed a two-year extension to his Liverpool contract, keeping him at Anfield until 2003.

Nigeria will play Senegal in the quarter-finals of the African Nations Cup after beating Morocco 2-0. Tunisia also qualified for the last eight by defeating the Republic of Congo 1-0; they will play Egypt.

Celtic's Olivier Tebily and his Ivory Coast team-mates were released from a military training camp in the country where they were held after their elimination from the competition. Fifa's president Sepp Blatter pleaded with Ivory Coast's football authorities to broker a deal with their government.

Europe's 14 biggest clubs, the G14 group which includes Manchester United, have made a series of demands of Fifa and Uefa, including financial compensation for releasing players for international duty.

They also want to release players for three days rather than four for internationals and want national team games to be scheduled only between mid-May and June and in the second half of October.

Ole Gunnar Solskjaer has denied reports from Norway that he is keen to leave Manchester United. "Anyone who wants to leave the biggest club in the world must be stupid. I never said that and it's given me the greatest shock. It could not be further from the truth."

fields.headline: Bold Pollock pinches victory
fields.standfirst:
England 231-6
South Africa 233-8
South Africa win by 2 wickets
fields.trailText: England, who under lights have looked as vulnerable as vampires in this triangular series, lost their third day-night match out of three here last night in thrilling circumstances.
fields.body:
England, who under lights have looked as vulnerable as vampires in this triangular series, lost their third day-night match out of three here last night in thrilling circumstances.

South Africa, needing 19 from the last three overs, 12 from the last two and eight from the last six deliveries, finally edged home with two wickets and two balls to spare. The match was in England's favour when South Africa needed seven from four balls. But Mark Ealham's next two deliveries were full tosses and the unflappable Shaun Pollock crashed them to leg for four.

England achieved the highest score in the competition so far when they made 231 for six from their 50 overs, but they looked a little uncertain whether to be pleased with themselves or not. Given their early impetus, they should certainly have scored 250. The conditions offered South Africa's bowlers little encouragement and when the captain Hansie Cronje surprisingly decided to bowl he may have been remembering that the team batting second had won seven out of 10 previous games here.

England went into the match with their batting weakened, while South Africa had reinforced theirs. The tourists brought in Alan Mullally for Craig White, who was reported as only 95% fit with a hamstring injury and was rested as a precaution; South Africa replaced Henry Williams with Pieter Strydom.

England appeared anxious to make the most of their opening overs when Nasser Hussain pulled Nantie Hayward through midwicket for four and Nick Knight, with an absence of style, cudgelled Pollock through the same area for another boundary.

But in the fifth over, Hussain made a premeditated charge against Pollock and was caught behind. It was not the last rash stroke played in the England innings.

Graeme Hick, having cover-driven and square-cut with relish, then spooned Hayward to cover for 11; 35 for two in the eighth. Hick has now scored just 50 runs in five innings.

Vikram Solanki had looked in horrid nick in the nets and his disappointing series continued when he was third out at 61, caught at slip for 10.

Darren Maddy, with a busy 22, then added 44 with Knight before flicking Cronje into the hands of Strydom at deep midwicket. Knight, whose 64 came from 111 balls and included six fours, was fifth out at 144, offering a gentle return catch to a ball from Strydom that bounced more than he expected.

Then came the most explosive batting of the innings. Mark Alleyne, whose place had been under threat and whose previous one-day best was 38, scored a violent 53. Fifteen came from one Lance Klusener over as Alleyne hit him over mid-off for six and then, next ball, straight for four.

But his crashing innings ended after only 68 balls when he was caught in the covers, having added 74 in 13 overs with Ealham, whose 29 came from 39 deliveries.

England had reached par. But their rather sheepish expressions betrayed the feelings of a side who feared they had not scored enough.

They started poorly in the field. Darren Gough, looking as out of touch as he has been for most of this winter, opened with two wides and when his first three overs disappeared for 18 he was replaced by Mullally.

It was Mullally who made the breakthrough in his second over, but he needed some good fortune; Herschelle Gibbs did not appear to have touched the ball when he was given out caught behind.

Mark Boucher was promoted to No3 but the ploy failed. He had added only 10 runs with Louis Koen when he was caught at first slip off the bowling of Andy Caddick, after the catcher Knight -fearing he had thrown the ball up too soon - caught it a second time.

Chris Read was well on his way to a nightmare when he twice dropped Jaques Kallis, on 12 and 21. But the mistakes did not prove unduly expensive. Kallis had advanced to 36 when he edged Alleyne and Read, low down, accepted the most difficult of the three chances.

With the match in the balance at 110 for four in the 26th over, the dangerous-looking Neil McKenzie was joined by Cronje. But Crone was again unable to resurrect his faltering form. He slashed two desperate fours but then skied Alleyne to mid-off. His 10 had taken 25 balls and South Africa were half out for 126 in the 32nd.

McKenzie, meanwhile, was batting with total assurance and it took a misunderstanding to dislodge him. When he and Jonty Rhodes confused each other with their running, Solanki produced a direct throw at the bowler's end to run McKenzie out for 37 from 56 balls.

That wicket looked a mixed blessing when the new batsman Lance Klusener hit the first three balls of Caddick's next over for 10 runs, his muscular drives bringing fours from the first two deliveries.

webTitle: Leicester rage over FA ticket charges

fields.headline: Leicester rage over FA ticket charges
fields.trailText: Leicester City reacted with anger last night as their celebrations at reaching Wembley were marred by the news that five players and three backroom staff have been charged with misconduct after the Football Association's inquiry into ticket distribution for last year's Worthington Cup final.
fields.body:
Leicester City reacted with anger last night as their celebrations at reaching Wembley were marred by the news that five players and three backroom staff have been charged with misconduct after the Football Association's inquiry into ticket distribution for last year's Worthington Cup final.

Less than 24 hours after the 1-0 victory over Aston Villa earned Leicester a third final in four years, the FA announced it was pressing charges in connection with the "alleged irresponsible distribution" of hundreds of tickets.

Steve Guppy, Neil Lennon, Graham Fenton, Arnar Gunnlaugsson and Stuart Campbell have been charged along with the chief scout Jim Melrose, the academy director David Nish and the physiotherapist Ian Andrews. Tony Cottee and Andy Impey already faced similar charges, and the "Leicester 10" have been summoned to a specially convened FA hearing at Filbert Street on March 15.

It follows the FA's investigation of the crowd violence that marred Tottenham's 1-0 win at Wembley last March after Spurs supporters obtained tickets for sections reserved for Leicester fans. But the timing of the announcement annoyed Leicester, whose manager Martin O'Neill was described as "furious".

Sir Rodney Walker, chairman of the club's plc board, said: "I am astonished that there should be a lapse of several months without us hearing anything from the FA and now they drop this on our toes the morning after we have reached a Wembley final. It is totally inexplicable.

"If it is a coincidence it is truly amazing. But if it is a deliberate act it is something that needs to be explored at the highest level.

"To choose this of all moments is an extraordinarily bad piece of timing and I will be letting the FA know my feelings on the matter."

The FA charged Cottee and Impey in September and 25 players and staff were accused of failing to assist its inquiry. Those allegations have now been dropped, although advisory letters from Lancaster Gate have been sent to everyone who was investigated.

Leicester's spokesman Paul Mace said: "They should never have been charged in the first place and we would expect a full apology from the FA for the embarrassment and worry they have caused.

"We also find it hard to believe that, having qualified for a second successive final, the FA should still be nowhere near completing this inquiry. The eight concerned are extremely angry and upset and will be taking independent legal advice. It goes without saying they will be protesting their innocence most strongly. This club has nothing to hide whatsoever."

The FA's spokesman Steve Double retorted: "The club were kept fully informed that we were deliberately holding back on today's statement so as not to interfere with their preparation for last night's game and the other big matches they have played in the last few weeks. So to be accused of insensitivity is a little strange."

The FA will allow every Leicester player the standard quota of tickets for this year's final against Tranmere Rovers on February 27. However, the Football League has ruled that no player may buy more than 25 tickets and each receiving club must make a written commitment that their allocation will not fall into the wrong hands. The changes came after the inquiry revealed that 20 Leicester players had had 1,500 tickets between them.

fields.headline: Hussain prays for final judgment
fields.standfirst: Victory today over South Africa is crucial to the England captain's plans
fields.trailText: As Paul Weaver reports, victory today over South Africa is crucial to the England captain's plans.
fields.body:
There was a moment in practice here yesterday when the England captain Nasser Hussain struck a singularly pious pose, with eyes closed and hands clasped together as if deep in prayer.

Perhaps he had just glanced at the latest table showing all the teams in this triangular series level on points after Zimbabwe's dramatic last-ball victory over South Africa in Durban on Wednesday.

He might have been wrestling with the make-up of his own side, though if there are any changes for today's day-night game against South Africa they will be minimal.

Or, and this is most likely, he might have been speculating on the possibility of England not making the final of this tournament tomorrow week and how he might be judged after his first winter in charge.

The current series against South Africa and Zimbabwe has little intrinsic value. Its essential importance is to give players experience and to allow the coach Duncan Fletcher and Hussain himself to make judgments and formulate a strategy.

But Hussain is all too aware that if he returns to England having lost the Test series 2-1 and failed again here, some critics might judge the whole winter wasted. He badly wants to be wearing the crown next weekend even if it does have the texture of cardboard.

"I really want to win this tournament, to go home to England feeling proud. Winning is the most important thing. And it gives players confidence.

"Then, back home, I want to get a plan together, where for both Tests and one-day cricket we get a regular set of players together and stick with them. A few old names, a few new ones, some from this tour. Just 12 or 13 or 14 names to constantly select from. That would be ideal.

"And then I think we'll get gradual improvement, as I think we're getting at the moment. I know we will get the occasional Newlands evening. But then we will have to react to it.

"Only Australia have got it sussed. They play good cricket at the right time. They stand out. They represent the benchmark. They play well not only in the key games but they are able to identify the key moments in those games.

"I can't really harden up a side. It's up to the individuals concerned to react. This is really an individual game."

Hussain is inclined to stick with the side that beat Zimbabwe so comfortably in their last outing. If there is a switch, another specialist bowler such as Alan Mullally could come in for the utility player Mark Alleyne. After losing the toss for the last four matches it is important the captain wins it here and chooses to bat.

Hussain added: "If you look at the scores sides have been making against us, 180, 150, 210, 200, you will see that we have been bowling and fielding well. And apart from one occasion we have generally batted well."

One worry for the captain is that not many batsmen, apart from the opening pair of himself and Nick Knight, have had the chance to show much form in the middle.

"We have played four games and only once have we had a typical one-day situation of needing 120 off 20 overs with six wickets in hand or whatever."

Each team has two games to play and at this stage England do not know whether one win would earn them a final place. It probably would. Their last game is against Zimbabwe at Centurion Park on Wednesday.

If all teams finish level on points the finalists will be decided on net run rate - and South Africa currently have the worst of the three.

South Africa: WJ Cronje (capt), HH Gibbs, LJ Koen, JH Kallis, ND McKenzie, PC Strydom, JN Rhodes, MV Boucher (wkt), L Klusener, SM Pollock, HS Williams, M Hayward.

England: N Hussain (capt), NV Knight, GA Hick, VS Solanki, DL Maddy, C White, MW Alleyne, MA Ealham, CMW Read (wkt), D Gough, AR Caddick, AD Mullally.

They play well not only in the key games but they are able to identify the key moments in those games. "I can't really harden up a side. It's up to the individuals concerned to react. This is really an individual game." Hussain is inclined to stick with the side that beat Zimbabwe so comfortably in their last outing. If there is a switch, another specialist bowler such as Alan Mullally could come in for the utility player Mark Alleyne. After losing the toss for the last four matches it is important the captain wins it here and chooses to bat. Hussain added: "If you look at the scores sides have been making against us, 180, 150, 210, 200, you will see that we have been bowling and fielding well. And apart from one occasion we have generally batted well." One worry for the captain is that not many batsmen, apart from the opening pair of himself and Nick Knight, have had the chance to show much form in the middle. "We have played four games and only once have we had a typical one-day situation of needing 120 off 20 overs with six wickets in hand or whatever." Each team has two games to play and at this stage England do not know whether one win would earn them a final place. It probably would. Their last game is against Zimbabwe at Centurion Park on Wednesday. If all teams finish level on points the finalists will be decided on net run rate - and South Africa currently have the worst of the three. England: N Hussain (capt), NV Knight, GA Hick, VS Solanki, DL Maddy, C White, MW Alleyne, MA Ealham, CMW Read (wkt), D Gough, AR Caddick, AD Mullally.

fields.headline: Atherton's view in the minority
fields.trailText: Mike Atherton's criticisms of the county system are evidently not endorsed by the majority of his professional colleagues after the PCA came out in support of the changes aimed at making the county game more competitive next season.
fields.body:
Mike Atherton's criticisms of the county system are not endorsed by the majority of his professional colleagues.

The former England captain caused consternation at Lord's recently by claiming that the present structure was largely irrelevant in providing a grounding for the Test-match stage. But the Professional Cricketers' Association has come out in support of the changes aimed at making the county game more competitive next season: a two-division championship and national league and the reintroduction of the Benson & Hedges Cup.

The findings come from a questionnaire given to all professional cricketers at the end of last season and compiled in a 64-page document described by the PCA chief executive David Graveney as "the most exhaustive and complete study ever undertaken".

The report, which will be handed to the England and Wales Cricket Board for its observations, claims that 75% of cricketers agree to 16 County Championship and National League games and 70% back the return of the Benson & Hedges Cup. This finding flies in the face of reports that those who play the game believe there is too much cricket.

A further 84% favour England players being centrally contracted to the board, but other measures to improve the domestic game remain unidentified; 66% are against regional cricket but 62% are against the system staying as it is.

Graveney said the major issue was substandard pitches and practice facilities, which were hampering the development of younger players.

fields.headline: Rear Window
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Among the Hitchcock classics, this is the most bafflingly overrated: often dull, static, undramatic, and marooned on one single, giant set
fields.body:
This week sees the re-release, in a new print, of Alfred Hitchcock's Rear Window of 1954, the story of Jeff (James Stewart), an action photographer laid up with a broken leg, who has nothing to do but grumpily complain to Lisa, his beautiful society girlfriend (Grace Kelly) and voyeuristically watch his neighbours from his window - until he becomes convinced that he has seen one of them commit a murder.

Among the Hitchcock classics, this is the most bafflingly overrated: often dull, static, undramatic, and marooned on one single, giant set, which we are permitted to inspect from a very limited number of camera set-ups. It is certainly an intriguing and quintessentially urban idea, and there is something pleasingly ascetic in the way Hitchcock allows us no soundtrack other than the music Stewart actually hears and we only see what Stewart can see - but this is often frustrating and literal-minded.

Just 46 when the picture was released, Stewart looks and sounds like an old man, and his relationship with the ethereal Kelly is stilted; with nothing like, say, the simmering eroticism she had with Cary Grant in To Catch a Thief. And there are some small, but noticeable line-fluffs from both Stewart and Kelly. Rear Window is always worth watching, but hardly one of the greats.

fields.headline: A Room for Romeo Brass
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: a curious picture, which leaves an odd taste in the mouth
fields.body:
A Room for Romeo Brass is the new film from British director Shane Meadows, who with the help of a Harvey Keitel-ish goodwill appearance from Bob Hoskins, made his mark in 1997 with his racy, zeitgeisty first feature TwentyFourSeven.

This is a curious picture, which leaves an odd taste in the mouth. It begins with two young boys, and a sweetly comic, naturalistic evocation of their bantering childhood friendship, and ends in the dark world of an emotionally sub-normal adult who comes between them. This is a narrative trajectory which gives Meadows's film a rather literary feel, like a dark short story or a novella, and perhaps this medium would have more satisfactorily absorbed the unedifying and scalp-tinglingly unpleasant flourish of violence that is this film's conclusion.

The two boys are Romeo (Andrew Shim) and Gavin (Ben Marshall); Meadows and his co-writer Paul Fraser endow them with a funny, lucid, unsentimental existence. But then a very strange guy called Morell befriends them and forms a romantic obsession with Romeo's sister Ladine (Vicky McClure) - which leads to his terrible humiliation and revenge.

There are some strong performances; the boys have insouciant charm, and Frank Harper as Romeo's seething dad is really excellent. Bob Hoskins, however, returns with a pointless and baffling cameo. As Morell, Paddy Considine is making his professional debut, and does his best with a role in which, like Charlie Creed-Miles in The Last Yellow, he has to play a nerdy, borderline-handicapped guy with a malign obsession with guns and violence. Meadows perpetuates a lazy and faintly repellent stereotype, and the resulting performance is, inevitably, implausible and sometimes embarrassing.

Morell is supposed to have been abused by his father, a gesture towards sympathy which sits uncomfortably with the fact that he ends up demonised as a Dangerous Retard, and his violent come-uppance is simplistic and questionable.

fields.headline: The Big Tease
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: Very funny, amiable and well-written film ... with a genial lightness of touch and a big heart
fields.body:
Nothing could sound more dismayingly naff than a mockumentary about a gay Glaswegian hairdresser making it big in Hollywood, and yet The Big Tease is a very funny, amiable and well-written film, smoothly directed by Kevin Allen, with a genial lightness of touch and a big heart: a variation on the Spinal Tap theme.

Craig Ferguson plays Crawford, a Scottish crimper who travels to Los Angeles, under the impression he has been asked to take part in the world hairdressing championships. But his ego endures some cruel knocks. Ferguson - this picture's co-writer and executive producer - is a comic once known to comedy buffs at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe as "Bing Hitler" who has now started to make it big in American TV, and this tale of tough breaks in tinseltown is probably autobiographical.

Either way, it is bolstered by Chris Langham's very amusing hangdog performance as the docu-director following him around. It shows that with the right script, the right director and the right lead, a British comedy can compete with the best - and in spirit, a British comedy is what this is, though produced by Warner Bros. Could it be that the production machine there has submitted the script to a much tougher regime of re-writes than that imposed by our lax lottery-funded system?

fields.headline: Football 1, Hollywood 0
fields.trailText: Releasing your movie over the Superbowl weekend is the cinematic equivalent of that barbarous ancient habit of leaving sickly newborn babies on the hill outside the city to be torn apart and eaten by wolves. January is already Hollywood's month for abandoning its orphans and weaklings to the savage dictates of the public's midwinter depression and post-Christmas poverty. If a week's worth of well-placed mid-price TV and print ads are all you need to secure the box office number-one spot, you might as well go for broke and reclaim some of your misspent investment.
fields.body:
Releasing your movie over the Superbowl weekend is the cinematic equivalent of that barbarous ancient habit of leaving sickly newborn babies on the hill outside the city to be torn apart and eaten by wolves. January is already Hollywood's month for abandoning its orphans and weaklings to the savage dictates of the public's midwinter depression and post-Christmas poverty. If a week's worth of well-placed mid-price TV and print ads are all you need to secure the box office number-one spot, you might as well go for broke and reclaim some of your misspent investment.

It happened last week with the worthless romantic comedy Down to You - down to number six this week, now that the moviegoing public has wised up to its non-existent merits. I can imagine Down to You's makers, who were probably at Sundance last week when the weekend's receipts were totalled up, clinking their champagne flutes together and chuckling darkly to each other about "pulling that piece of shit out of the furnace".

Superbowl weekend is even worse - a Bermuda Triangle for new releases. They sink without trace while a bloodthirsty nation is drunkenly exhorting squadrons of overpaid young athletes to beat the tar out of each other. And this year's game was one of those nailbiting, down-to-the-line giant-killer contests, capped by a "they-think-it's-all-over-it-is-now!" finale that caused hot dogs, popcorn and obscenities to be flung at TV screens in living rooms and sports-bars the length and breadth of the Republic. With all that primitive blood lust to enjoy at home or amongst friends, and with snow and ice blanketing much of the nation, who wanted to go out and brave the new releases?

No one, apparently. The top slot was secured by the dreary thriller Eye of the Beholder with only a meagre $5.9m in receipts, and the only other new release, the Jacqueline Susann comedy biopic Isn't She Great, made a risible $1.3m and failed even to crack the top 10. Compared to the same weekend last year, when the offerings were the equally depressing Patch Adams and Varsity Blues, takings were down by a whopping 28%. Having endured them both I can testify that I would have been much happier shovelling snow out of my driveway. Sadly it doesn't snow much in Los Angeles.

Eye of the Beholder was cannily primed to exploit Ashley Judd's recent ascent into the Tinseltown firmament with the success of Double Jeopardy. It was shot in Montreal and completed nearly two years ago, since when it has languished unloved and unwanted on some film laboratory shelf. Now it's out in public and embarrassing everyone involved. Judd will weather the critical storm because only one thing matters: it's her second number-one opening in four months.

For her co-star Ewan McGregor though, things aren't nearly so rosy. In Britain he's a household name, Mr Trainspotting and so on. Over here he barely registers - and no wonder. Because of delayed American releases and dodgy career choices like Rogue Trader and A Life Less Ordinary, McGregor's name gives out weak and contradictory signals to American moviegoers, the vast majority of whom have never heard of Irvine Welsh or Renton. His profile here is like that of Oasis, one blip in the charts a few summers ago with Wonderwall - and not a peep since. (One should bear in mind that from Hollywood's perspective Britain is just some tiny little north European market with a primitive, closed-shop distribution network and a jumped up sense of its own importance in the scheme of things.)

Those films of McGregor's that have seen daylight in the US have all been in the Be Here Now column of the ledger, ie, the veriest crap. And he lost his biggest opportunity for a comeback when his Trainspotting pals jumped ship on him and cast Leonardo DiCaprio in The Beach, which gets its US release next week.

Instead we have Eye of the Beholder, written and directed by Stephan Elliot, who gave us Priscilla, Queen of the Desert. It channels memories of Vertigo, The Conversation and Laura, and makes you wish you were watching one of them instead.

McGregor is some sort of surveillance officer for the British embassy in Washington DC, haunted by memories of the wife and daughter he hasn't seen in seven years. He becomes obsessed with one of his targets, Judd's nameless femme fatale who, for reasons that are well nigh impossible to decipher, leaves as many dead men in her wake as Hansel and Gretel left breadcrumbs in the forest. Ah, but does she? Or is it all in the eye of the beholder? You may find the answers as uncompelling as I did.

Elliot seems to think he's written one of those epoch-making films about scopophilia, the treacherous gaze, and the fallibility of our perceptions, a rich tradition of movies that includes the ones I mentioned above, as well as Peeping Tom and Rear Window. And certainly there are some intriguing moments early on in Eye, as one begins to doubt first the motives and then the sanity of "The Eye", as oor Ewan's character is pretentiously dubbed in the credits. Thereafter, however, things become increasingly more incoherent and ridiculous. Judd seems happiest killing men when all she's wearing are white suspenders and a bustier.

She changes her appearance throughout the movie, donning a Louise Brooks bob here, a Kim Novak beehive over there, in any number of giveaway nods to movies that have trodden this path more elegantly before. The seriousness of McGregor's well-modulated performance is undermined by the overabundance of technology at his fingertips - he seems to have access to more surveillance equipment than the CIA and the National Security Agency combined, including a rifle-like camera that turns out, in one of the film's many ridiculous moment, to fire bullets too. When it ends, you are utterly adrift, just like the movie.

And somehow the distributors were able to find no less than three breathless reviewer endorsements - which I suspect were purchased or coerced at gunpoint from their authors. Either that or the reviews were in fact written by somebody in a deep coma. A movie about perception, with a beam in its eye? It will offend thine eye for sure, so pluck it out - or stay home and watch Vertigo.

fields.headline: Toy Story 2
fields.trailText: CGI has finally come down from its virtual heaven to touch base with the scuzzy world the rest of us inhabit
fields.body:
A toy, states my dictionary, is 'anything used or designed for a child to play with; plaything; something of no importance.'

As definitions go, this is only half-right at best. The cowboys, space-men, Potato Heads and Slinky Dogs rattling around Toy Story 2 are indeed 'playthings' - their sole purpose in life to be pulled, prodded and pushed into imaginary adventures by their knee-high master. But 'something of no importance'? On the contrary, the toys (Woody, Buzz Lightyear, et-al) are the stars of John Lasseter's expert animated movie, and it is their very playability - the essential toy-ness of their nature - that gives them life. Without that magic extra ingredient (namely, a kid) our heroes are either rummage-sale junk or dead exhibits on a museum shelf. A toy that nobody plays with, in other words, is no toy.

If there is one message behind the Toy Story sequel, this is it. It is the sweet, subtle subtext which colours the film, as cowboy doll Woody (again voiced by Tom Hanks) finds himself abducted by a geeky memorabilia dealer (Wayne Knight) who wants to flog him as part of a valuable 50s toy collection to a Tokyo toy museum.

Before long Woody is cooling his heels alongside his fellow captives: a gambolling horse, a spunky cowgirl (Joan Cusack), and the grizzled prospector (Kelsey Grammer) who stares from behind the cellophane of a box that's "never been opened".

Meantime, Woody's old cohorts - led by Buzz Lightyear (Tim Allen) - are springing a desperate rescue mission. Cue dashing escapades through the vast aisles of a toy shop, the cavernous pit of a lift-shaft and the shifting bags on the luggage carousel. Toy Story 2 may namecheck Raiders of the Lost Ark in its arcade-game introduction, but even Indiana Jones would have his work cut out navigating the snares that Lasseter throws in the path of his hapless protagonists.

As a series of zesty, cliffhanger adventures, then, Toy Story 2 works a treat. Lasseter has clearly built on the benchmark he set on the first Toy Story picture. There is a grace and fluidity to the action setpieces (most notably the dash across the open road and Woody's trip through a minefield of spilt cheesy puffs) and a new sophistication to the digital animation as a whole. In a sense, Toy Story 2 has refined the whole computer-generated genre to the point where you can barely see the joins.

Even as recently as last year, digital-cinema still seemed a shade superficial and unformed. Movies like Antz or A Bug's Life heralded a vast improvement on the migraine-inducing blur of 1982's Tron (Disney's first, fumbled attempt at CGI), but compensated with a phoney, airbrushed sheen. Their astroturfed visuals presented a landscape that was just too clean to convince: a place that satisfied the head but not the heart.

By contrast, Toy Story 2 is quite wonderfully grungey. Its rotund toy-collector villain slumps snoring on the couch and you can almost smell the odour of his cheesy belch. Our heroes commandeer a rusting pizza-delivery van and burn rubber towards a cavernous, echoing airline terminal. CGI has finally come down from its virtual heaven to touch base with the scuzzy world the rest of us inhabit.

Best of all is the way this warts-and-all authenticity is mirrored in the picture's plot. Joan Cusack's cowgirl is unceremoniously dumped when her owner hits puberty. Woody's arm is torn by his over-exuberant master. "Toys don't last forever," cautions the kid's mum, and it's a warning that Woody takes to heart. For him, the Tokyo toy museum offers a way of cheating his sell-by date. It is the place where an old cowboy doll can be re-painted, re-stitched and re-branded as retro-chic. He can sit in a glass case and watch the world go by outside.

Except, of course, that life isn't about that. Not for toys and (by implication) not for human beings either. So in its knockabout, mainstream way, Toy Story 2 is finally rather poignant. It exhorts its characters to live in the moment, to reject the pristine place on the museum shelf in favour of the dirty rough and tumble of everyday existence. Fashions change, toys break, kids grow up; and yet to opt out of the equation is to opt out of life itself.

Such a moral may fly over the heads of Toy Story 2's target demographic (young, green, footloose fools that they are), yet it connects like a gut-punch with the rest of us. What's startling is seeing this flesh-and-blood life lesson acted out by a bunch of digital muppets. What's strange is that it takes a computer to tell this most fundamentally human of stories.

Meantime, Woody's old cohorts - led by Buzz Lightyear (Tim Allen) - are springing a desperate rescue mission. Cue dashing escapades through the vast aisles of a toy shop, the cavernous pit of a lift-shaft and the shifting bags on the luggage carousel. Toy Story 2 may namecheck Raiders of the Lost Ark in its arcade-game introduction, but even Indiana Jones would have his work cut out navigating the snares that Lasseter throws in the path of his hapless protagonists. As a series of zesty, cliffhanger adventures, then, Toy Story 2 works a treat. Lasseter has clearly built on the benchmark he set on the first Toy Story picture. There is a grace and fluidity to the action setpieces (most notably the dash across the open road and Woody's trip through a minefield of spilt cheesy puffs) and a new sophistication to the digital animation as a whole. In a sense, Toy Story 2 has refined the whole computer-generated genre to the point where you can barely see the joins. Even as recently as last year, digital-cinema still seemed a shade superficial and unformed. Movies like Antz or A Bug's Life heralded a vast improvement on the migraine-inducing blur of 1982's Tron (Disney's first, fumbled attempt at CGI), but compensated with a phoney, airbrushed sheen. Their astroturfed visuals presented a landscape that was just too clean to convince: a place that satisfied the head but not the heart. By contrast, Toy Story 2 is quite wonderfully grungey. Its rotund toy-collector villain slumps snoring on the couch and you can almost smell the odour of his cheesy belch. Our heroes commandeer a rusting pizza-delivery van and burn rubber towards a cavernous, echoing airline terminal. CGI has finally come down from its virtual heaven to touch base with the scuzzy world the rest of us inhabit. Best of all is the way this warts-and-all authenticity is mirrored in the picture's plot. Joan Cusack's cowgirl is unceremoniously dumped when her owner hits puberty. Woody's arm is torn by his over-exuberant master. "Toys don't last forever," cautions the kid's mum, and it's a warning that Woody takes to heart. For him, the Tokyo toy museum offers a way of cheating his sell-by date. It is the place where an old cowboy doll can be re-painted, re-stitched and re-branded as retro-chic. He can sit in a glass case and watch the world go by outside. Except, of course, that life isn't about that. Not for toys and (by implication) not for human beings either. So in its knockabout, mainstream way, Toy Story 2 is finally rather poignant. It exhorts its characters to live in the moment, to reject the pristine place on the museum shelf in favour of the dirty rough and tumble of everyday existence. Fashions change, toys break, kids grow up; and yet to opt out of the equation is to opt out of life itself. Such a moral may fly over the heads of Toy Story 2's target demographic (young, green, footloose fools that they are), yet it connects like a gut-punch with the rest of us. What's startling is seeing this flesh-and-blood life lesson acted out by a bunch of digital muppets. What's strange is that it takes a computer to tell this most fundamentally human of stories.  Watch exclusive behind the scenes footage from the movie

fields.headline: Toy Story 2
fields.standfirst: Toy Story returns with wit and charm unimpaired. It makes old-style children's adventures prehistoric, says Peter Bradshaw
fields.trailText: Toy Story returns with wit and charm unimpaired. It makes old-style children's adventures prehistoric, says Peter Bradshaw
fields.body:
Toy Story 2 is not a sequel. It is an upgrade. It is a manufacturer's improvement - of staggering ingenuity. It is a software refinement. It is a species leap, a higher order of being.

This film combines a witty and charming children's fantasy in a tradition going back to the Grimm brothers and Hans Christian Andersen, with computer animation above and beyond "state-of-the-art". Its bright, hyperreal light, its sleek, impossibly clean planes, its laser-sharp pixellation and its extra-terrestrial landscaping will take you, in the stirring words of Buzz Lightyear himself, to infinity - and beyond! The sheer technical magnificence of Toy Story 2, harnessed by a sweetly, seductively human script, rolls over you like a tank.

It reveals with pitiless clarity the inferiority of what has gone before. The dull storylining of The Phantom Menace, the berk characterisation in Jurassic Park - movies to which Toy Story 2 playfully and generously alludes - together with their clunking, Stephenson's Rocket "effects", are shown up, very badly. And as for Babe, with meaningless moving mouths imposed on impassive animals, or Bob Hoskins trying to focus on toons in Who Framed Roger Rabbit?_ they are prehistoric.

After Toy Story 2 - the brilliant invention of director John Lasseter and Pixar Animation studios - watching its predecessors is like trying to use a 60s washing machine. In fact, it is tempting to say that it makes reality itself look a bit shopworn and obsolete, were it not for the fact that the film addresses its own built-in technical and cultural obsolescence with such daring.

Buzz Lightyear is back, supremely virile and questing, voiced by Tim Allen, a Master of the Universe rattling around in the playroom, among a rag-tag army of toys owned by a kid called Andy. His comrades have need of Buzz's toybox heroism when his cowboy buddy Woody - perhaps the most perfect casting of Tom Hanks's career - is kidnapped by a hideous toy magnate, the proprietor of Al's Toy Barn, itself a sinister corporate variant of Toys R Us. This is because Woody turns out to be supremely collectible, the hero of a long-forgotten 1950s TV serial, and part of its spin-off merchandise, and he is reunited with his TV "family": Jessie (Joan Cusack), Bullseye the Horse and Stinky Pete the Prospector (Kelsey Grammer).

They tell him to forget his owner and his old friends, and come with them to live a pampered life behind glass in a museum, because kids are by nature cruel and fickle, moral illiterates who cannot return the passionate love unquestioningly lavished on them by toys. Andy, his beloved owner will one day casually discard him: "Didja think he'd take you with him to college? Or on his honeymoon?"

Thus, Toy Story 2 conjures a brilliant dilemma out of nowhere, making the toys' dependent relationship with children a disturbing analogy to children's fearful relationship with adults. It enacts the child's deepest fear of abandonment, weakness and vulnerability. And it is at this crux that the picture unveils its showstopping moment: the heartrending song from Jessie the Cowgirl, written by Randy Newman - When She Loved Me - telling of how Jessie was thrown aside by her owner, Emily. This is a tear-jerker to be classed with the imprisonment of Dumbo's mom.

This cosmic juxtaposition of adult and child, of large and small, is replicated in our vision of the toys themselves: in close-up (to use a metaphor drawn from old-fashioned spatial reality) they are big, substantial heroes, battling resourcefully with complex and considerable foes. But seen from adult height, scampering along the sidewalk, almost crushed by shoes and tyres, they are absurdly little - especially macho Buzz. The effect is very funny and the script the toys are given by screenwriters Doug Chamberlain and Chris Webb, is wonderfully sharp and rich in gags.

It is customary to complain that movies of this sort are simply feature-length ads for the merchandise. That is still true, but Toy Story 2 audaciously pre-empts and goes beyond this complaint. There is a scene in the toy warehouse where Buzz wanders into a whole aisle full of Buzz Lightyears, ready for sale - because, explains the Barbie tour-guide, short-sighted merchandisers failed to anticipate demand the first time around back in 1995! And the picture has already covertly established the cultural substance and value of toys with the enchanting Woody memorabilia of the 50s.

In a sense, Toy Story 2 attempts to collapse not merely the distinction between reality and animation, but between enjoying the product in the cinema and enjoying it in the toyshop: conflating it into one happy retail experience. But it simultaneously embraces the temporariness and disposability of the experience, as part and parcel of growing up.

For some, that might be all too slick, convenient, and machine-tooled. But it is an awe-inspiring display of special effects, and its characterisation, particularly that of the all-American hero Buzz, is very funny. As well as being a landmark of sorts in commercial cinema, Toy Story 2 really is that mythical beast: an extremely enjoyable picture for all ages, and far superior to anything George Lucas has given us lately.

fields.headline: England fiasco ends Smithies era
fields.trailText: Karen Smithies resigned as captain after the England women's cricket team were annihilated by 220 runs in the fourth one-day international of a series that finished 4-0 to Australia.
fields.body:
In 1989 the New South Wales town of Newcastle was hit by an earthquake that measured 5.1 on the Richter scale and caused widespread destruction. Something similar happened here yesterday when the England women's cricket team were annihilated by 220 runs in the fourth, and thankfully last, one-day international of a series that finished 4-0 to Australia. In an immediate aftershock, Karen Smithies resigned as England captain.

Everything the Aussies did was a record. Everything England did was a disaster and even their urbane manager Paul Farbrace was moved to say: "We were inept.

That was so sad. It undid all the good work we have done and all the improvements we have made so far on this tour. Everything was second-best - the batting, the bowling and the fielding."

Australia's score of 299 for two was their highest ever against England, though they did once make more against Denmark. The player of the match, Belinda Clark, made 146 not out and though she did hit 229 in that game against the Danes, it was still a record against England.

So were the figures of Charmaine Mason, the opening bowler, who took four for five in 4.5 overs in reducing England to 11 for four - dire when a chasing side needs a run a ball for 50 overs. They were out for 79 with Mason taking five for nine - an Aussie record against anybody.

Afterwards, England's players attended an end-of-tour dinner and Smithies announced her decision. "I don't feel I can in all honesty carry on after a defeat like that, especially as it comes on top of poor performances in the first three games," she said. The captain had scored 47 runs in her four innings, including a duck here.

Smithies, 30, had led the side since 1993, when she captained England to victory in the World Cup, for which she was awarded the OBE.

The new captain is Clare Connor, 23, who takes over for five games in New Zealand.

fields.headline: THE BEST PET SCENE
fields.standfirst: TOY STORY II
fields.trailText: In an apocalyptic struggle for inter-galactic supremacy, the heinous Emperor Zurg dispatches Buzz Lightyear to his death. He lets loose a terrible cackle.
fields.body:
In an apocalyptic struggle for inter-galactic supremacy, the heinous Emperor Zurg dispatches Buzz Lightyear to his death. He lets loose a terrible cackle.

Cut to Andy's bedroom, where plastic dinosaur Rex (voiced by Wallace Shawn), sits disconsolately over his computer game.

"No, no, no," he wails, "I'm never going to defeat Zurg..."

Buzz (Tim Allen) places a hand on his shoulder.

"Sure you will, Rex. In fact, you're a better Buzz than I am."

"But look at my arms!" cries Rex, waving his inch-long limbs in the air. " I can't push the buttons properly, and... and..."

He holds his enormous scaly head in his small scaly hands.

Woody (Tom Hanks), about to leave for cowboy camp, approaches.

"Listen, Buzz, here's a list of things to do while I'm gone - oh, and make sure everyone attends the seminar on what to do if you are wholly or partially swallowed. OK?"

"Woody, you have no hat."

Woody's stetson is indeed missing.

"No!"

Buzz takes command of the situation.

"Listen everyone - let's find Woody's hat!"

After a brief, maniacal search for the lost stetson, Slinky (Jim Varney) arrives.

"Fellas, I got some good news and some bad news. The good news is I found your hat."

Woody is beside himself.

"Oh thank you, thank you, thank you - what's the bad news?"

Andy's new puppy, Buster, bounds in, chasing Woody's hat, scattering every toy in the room.

See also: Austin Powers

Don't see also: Beethoven

Pointless trivia: Toy Story 2 scriptwriter Andrew Stanton provides the voice of Emperor Zurg.

webTitle: Norman bows to pressure to ends links with Asda

fields.headline: Norman bows to pressure to ends links with Asda
fields.trailText: February 4 2000: Shadow environment secretary denies conflict of interest
fields.body:
Archie Norman yesterday bowed to pressure from Liberal Democrats and Labour to sever his business links with Asda, as Tory rumblings of discontent continued over the ousting of John Redwood, his predecessor as shadow secretary for the environment, transport and the regions.

Mr Norman, former Asda chairman, said he had ended a consultancy with the supermarket group five months before his contract expired.

In his first interview since his appointment on Tuesday, he rejected other parties' claims that his past business links, spanning transport and planning issues, represented a conflict of interest with his new portfolio, arguing that his experience would be valuable.

In the face of claims that he is a lacklustre Commons performer, he rejected sugges tions that he would land few punches on the secretary of state, John Prescott, insisting that he was `right up for it'.

Mr Norman, speaking on Radio 4's World at One, said his appointment had been `wholly unexpected', but he had acted swiftly to eliminate any potential conflicts of interest. He no longer owned shares in Railtrack, from which he resigned as a non-executive director, or in Asda-Wal Mart.

`If you want people with experience and a track record of achievement then you have to accept that we all come with a past,'he said.

The shadow agriculture minister, Tim Yeo, said on Radio 4's Today that Labour was in no position to criticise the appointment, given the controversy over former paymaster general Geoffrey Robinson's business dealings.

Tory officials played down internal discontent over the sacking of Mr Redwood, whose Wokingham constituency party passed a motion `deeply deploring'' it. Rightwing Tory MPs joined the criticism of Wiliam Hague's decision at a dinner held by their 92 Group.

Laurence Robertson, Tory MP for Tewkesbury, yesterday demanded an explanation from Mr Hague.

He said the decision had Labour MPs celebrating. `John Redwood had the recognition factor ... He was the one who had made the most hits on Labour. He had the intellect and the energy, which is much needed in the shadow cabinet.'

A senior Tory source last night rejected the suggestion that a lesser known, and less competent, member of the shadow cabinet could have been sacrificed instead. `This was a reshuffle at the top,' he said. `These jobs have different ranks: you are either there at the top or you are out.'

fields.headline: Students owe £3.5m tuition fees
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Universities yesterday reported £3.5m in bad debts from students failing to pay tuition fees of up to £1,000 for the last academic year.
fields.body:
Universities yesterday reported £3.5m in bad debts from students failing to pay tuition fees of up to £1,000 for the last academic year.

The Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals said 97% of fees were collected in 1998-99, the first year of the means-tested system.

Baroness Warwick, the chief executive, said universities made every effort to help students to cope with the charges by offering flexible payment methods. "Higher education staff have worked hard to ensure their institutions were able to collect tuition fees, and these have paid off in large measure."

Universities were allowed £20m to cover administering the fees, and the bad debt will be written off out of that provision. But the CVCP said it was "important that students who have not paid do so".

fields.headline: Radical or reactionary?
fields.standfirst:
How the student leader became home secretary

Early life | student leader | law, television or politics? | entering parliament | climbing the ladder | front bench | shadow home secretary | government
fields.trailText: How the student leader became home secretary
fields.body:
Early life

John Whitaker Straw was born on April 3, 1946, one of five children brought up by a single mother on a council estate in Brentwood, Essex, on the north east edge of London. After primary school in Loughton, he became a boarder at Brentwood School. Mr Straw has admitted to bullying fellow pupils in the dorms (which he regrets) but says "I emerged a better person from school than when I began".

Politics was an early interest: he was on the Aldermaston ban-the-bomb march in April 1959, aged 12, and was only 13 when he made his first political speech, at a Labour candidate's meeting. He joined the Labour Party at the age of 15.

Student leader

Leeds university was the next step for Mr Straw who became union president when he finished a law degree in 1967. Within the university he was regarded as something of a conservative (he opposed, and still does, all soft drug use) but outside developed the reputation of a "radical who plans militancy whenever he considers it necessary".

He was elected president of the National Union of Students, age 22, in a minor coup which saw the previous president, Trevor Fisk, ousted midway through his first year of the job. Mr Fisk was the first NUS president not to see out his term.

As president, Mr Straw politicised the NUS and warned it would come into conflict with the government on four key issues: the union's belief in comprehensive education; its opposition to racism; the fight against social deprivation; and the egalitarian growth of higher education.

In the mid-1970s, when newspaper diarists asked "Where are they now?", they remembered Mr Straw as Britain's hard-left student leader.

Law, television or politics?

At the beginning of that decade Mr Straw was completing his legal training. He left the NUS in 1971, attended the Inns of Court law school and was called to the bar in July 1972. He was in practice as a criminal barrister until 1974. In 1977 he joined the staff of Granada Television's World in Action.

Mr Straw returned to politics in the years in between. He was special adviser to Barbara Castle from 1974-76 and later to environment secretary Peter Shore. At the same time he was deputy leader of the inner London education authority and served on Islington council. As vice-chairman of the housing committee, Mr Straw was tough on pets - under his regime council tenants in possession of dogs, pigeons, large caged birds or poultry were liable for eviction. "I am sure that people will welcome the fact that they are now allowed to keep cats," was Mr Straw's response at the time.

Entering parliament

Mrs Castle stepped down from parliament in 1979 and the Blackburn seat she had held since 1944 passed to her quick-witted former adviser. Mr Straw had unsuccessfully stood for parliament in 1974, in the safe Tory seat of Tonbridge and Malling, but the Blackburn electorate voted him to Westminster with a 5,490 majority. Mr Straw remains loyal to Blackburn (he supports first division Blackburn Rovers) and takes on all-comers in speaker's corner sessions once a month in the street outside Marks and Spencer.

Climbing the ladder

As Mrs Thatcher and her chancellor Geoffrey Howe ushered in the era of monetarism, Mr Straw was appointed opposition treasury spokesman. He fought hard against a 4p rise in the duty on a pint of beer in the 1981 budget, which may surprise anyone who thinks New Labour are a bunch of chardonnay swilling luvvies. "It would be better to load the tax on to wine because, on the whole, wine is consumed by the higher income people," he said.

Next he was local government spokesman, matched again against the thrust of Thatcherism as the prime minister abolished the greater London council, took powers away from the town halls and introduced the poll tax. Mr Straw said the scheme was a "tax on votes" which would force the poor to take themselves off the electoral register. It was "immoral and unthinkable" he said.

Front bench

Education beckoned in 1987, where Mr Straw was an enthusiastic supporter of Tory policies such as the national curriculum, parental choice and moves to give greater financial powers to head teachers and governors. In another surprise move he distanced himself from Labour's 1960s education policies that had approached education as a means to resolve the nation's economic problems. "The justification for educational provision is, as far as I am concerned, much more fundamental this is a different emphasis from treating people as pawns in running UK Ltd," he said.

Mr Straw took up the environment brief after the 1992 election as the Green movement made industrial pollution and depletion of the ozone layer issues of the day. His concerns, however, lay in regional assemblies and escalating private sector housing rents.

Shadow home secretary

Controversy dawned as he took up home affairs in the dying days of the Major government. Whatever home secretary Michael Howard did to draw in the Tory voters, Mr Straw did double. His support for zero tolerance towards "aggressive beggars, winos and squeegee merchants" may have given New Labour the middle England appeal they were looking for but - early on - his policies retained a progressive edge.

The Royal family, section 28 - the local government clause that criminalises the promotion of homosexuality - and privatised jails were all in need of change, he said. Later on he planned to impose an after-dark curfew on young children. The kids were less than happy and shortly before the 1997 election a Sunday newspaper revealed that school children were staging late night football matches in the street outside Mr Straw's south London home.

Government

Soon after the election, Mr Straw incorporated of the European Convention of Human Rights into British law but after a quiet first 18 months his troubles mounted up and judgement was questioned. In one week he was "minded" to send General Pinochet back to Chile, allow Mike Tyson into the country, deport a Nazi war criminal and battle with the reformed House of Lords over the right to trial by jury.

Despite attacks on the mysterious "Hampstead liberals" he reaffirmed his own liberal leanings with the Stephen Lawrence inquiry and orded the police to confront the institutional racism in their ranks - ensuring that his department is as schizophrenic as any other under this Labour administration.

fields.headline: John Hannah
fields.trailText: What was the first film you saw?
fields.body:
What was the first film you saw?

Herbie the Love Bug with my dad in Scotland.

What's your favourite film?

Herbie the Love Bug. You can keep your Marlon Brandos - there aren't many talking cars in movies these days.

When did you last walk out on a film?

Eyes Wide Shut pissed me off. It had a very bizarre form of delivery and from an actor's point of view, every word seemed emphasised, probably because there's was no means of communication in terms of why they were doing take 97. It didn't feel like a film to me.

What's your most erotic cinematic moment?

Betty Blue's opening sequence was horny.

What's the most annoying habit in the cinema?

People having sex or fixing their motorbike. Seriously, I like in America how they take part, boo the bad guys. It's interesting culturally how we deal with it, the whole sense of English superiority to remove it from an event for everybody.

When did you last snog in the cinema?

I remember taking a girl to see Last Tango in Paris, thinking that would be a good one for a snog up the back. Instead we got engrossed in the film.

When did you last hide under your cinema seat?

I'm not a big horror movie fan but I did see The Blair Witch Project which played well on the basic fear of being lost.

When was the last time you cried?

Every time I see It's a Wonderful Life.

What's your favourite line of dialogue?

Fast and witty dialogue from classic films such as The Big Sleep. They didn't treat audiences as stupid in those days.

Which actor would you most like to be?

Johnny Depp for his fantastic career. He's made interesting choices and has the options to do so. Other actors do too but he's made the best, which is incredibly admirable.

Which actress?

Kate Winslet. To follow Titanic with Hideous Kinky shows she's following her own path and true to herself.

Which film character would you like to be?

George Bailey in It's a Wonderful Life. He goes on a philosophical journey of doubt and insecurity and where he ends up is knowing that the life he has is perfect.

Why is the monster in your film more like a zombie flesh eater than the traditional Mummy?

It's been branded with the crappy Hammer House of Horror idea and become part of this psyche of a guy who chases you at two miles an hour. You could have a glass of wine, dinner and brush your teeth before he'd even got to you. One of the reasons why this film was so successful and connected with people is because it created a very human monster, everything he did was for love.

You've worked with Oxfam in campaigns against the arms trade. Are you doing any more campaign work against the weapons trade?

Not at the moment, I still support it and certainly admire those who keep banging against the wall.

 John Hannah is in The Mummy, now available to buy and rent on video.

fields.headline: Ebookers spreads European wings
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Ebookers.com, the discount flights specialist, plans to acquire travel operations in four countries and spend $32m (£20m) on advertising despite reporting widening losses.
fields.body:
Ebookers.com, the discount flights specialist, plans to acquire travel operations in four countries and spend $32m (£20m) on advertising despite reporting widening losses.

Chief executive Dinesh Damija said Ebookers was in talks with travel operators in Holland, Denmark, Spain and Italy, and anticipated acquisitions in all four markets might be completed within the next three months.

"We are already in eight European markets and said when we floated last year that we would be in 12 by the end of 2000," he said.

"The strategy is moving ahead of schedule and within budget. Acquisitions are essential to allow us to sell negotiated airfares at a local level in each country."

The company might even look for a "bridgehead" acquisition in the United States.

Marketing spend would be funded from cash balances of $46m, focused on outdoor advertising, and would be one of the biggest by a dot.com company, Mr Damija said.

Ebookers will also look to strike traffic agreements with major European portals. It already has marketing partnerships with Asda, Virgin Group and Capital Radio.

Mr Damija was speaking as the Nasdaq and Neur Markt-listed company announced full-year results which were ahead of expectations.

In the year to the end of December, consolidated sales rose 234% to $23m. Fourth-quarter sales were up 15% to $9.28m. In the week ending January 30, Ebookers completed 2,000 on-line bookings, double the number it was making in mid-November.

Losses before tax were $3.46m, compared with $2.42m on the previous quarter and a profit of $132,000 a year ago.

Ebookers does not expect to make a profit until the end of 2002 or start of 2003.

fields.headline: Digital grocers cater for wealthy
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Supermarket chains such as Tesco and Asda will become the equivalent of domestic servants for wealthy, double income families in coming years, delivering to their doors everything from groceries to dry cleaning and take-out food.
fields.body:
Supermarket chains such as Tesco and Asda will become the equivalent of domestic servants for wealthy, double income families in coming years, delivering to their doors everything from groceries to dry cleaning and take-out food.

A new report by Insight research predicts that internet shopping will undermine the profitability of traditional retail outlets and says lower income families are likely to be excluded from the convenience of home shopping and delivery services.

"Doing the superstore run is low down the busy family's list of fun weekend activities", said Insight director Dan Munford. "More specifically, home shopping represents an increasingly popular helping hand to many women who work long hours but still find themselves responsible for domestic tasks which include shopping."

Better off families with children who buy large quantities of groceries "are exactly the sort of shoppers that internet retailers want", says the report, because they can be serviced at a profit.

As superstore profitability is hit, the grocers will diversify further into non-food lines and offer a wider range of home delivery services, including pizzas and videos.

According to the researchers the UK leads the world in online grocery shopping. "Chains like Tesco and Iceland have been much faster than their US counterparts in exploiting the immense potential of new virtual shopping markets."

They estimate that the online grocery market is already worth £200m a year and will reach £1bn within two years.

A new internet brand, Wowgo, is targeting teenage girls across Europe with £6m backing from companies including the toiletries group Unilever and internet investment specialist Durlacher. Wowgo's chief executive, David Peller, said teenage girls are difficult to reach through traditional conventional media and are underserved in the digital environment.

fields.headline: Singh picked to lead CRE
fields.trailText: The new chief executive of the commission for racial equality has been confirmed as Gurbux Singh, currently the chief executive of Haringey council in north London.
fields.byline: Vikram Dodd and News Unlimited staff
fields.body:
The new chief executive of the commission for racial equality has been confirmed as Gurbux Singh, currently the chief executive of Haringey council in north London.

The home office officially announced the decision at 12.30pm today, as predicted on News Unlimited this morning. Mr Singh takes over from Sir Herman Ouseley, who stepped down earlier this year after seven years as head of the race watchdog.

Mr Singh, 49, beat off two other candidates who made the final shortlist, barrister Peter Herbert and Beverley Thompson of the national association for the care and resettlement of offenders.

Mr Singh has been chief executive of the London Borough of Haringey since 1989, having previously been the borough's director of housing. He also worked as a senior housing officer at the CRE from 1977 to 1983.

The four-year appointment was sanctioned by Downing Street and Mr Singh will come to the CRE's top post at a time when racial justice has a high profile in the wake of last years landmark Stephen Lawrence report.

Home secretary Jack Straw said he was taking over at a key time for race relations in Britain and paid tribute to the work of Sir Herman whom he said had effectively challenged leaders of all business and public sector organisations to "get our houses in order".

"The government is determined to realise our vision of Britain as a nation which celebrates its diversity, which utterly rejects racial hatred and discrimination, and which truly embodies the principles of justice and opportunity for all its citizens," Mr Straw said.

"There is simply no excuse for tolerating a culture which holds people back, or offers them anything less than the rights and respect they are entitled to."

fields.headline: School suspends race abuse victim
fields.standfirst:
Education Unlimited
Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: A teacher who was called a black maggot by an 11-year-old in front of 60 other pupils has been suspended for refusing to allow the boy back into his class.
fields.body:
A teacher who was called a black maggot by an 11-year-old in front of 60 other pupils has been suspended for refusing to allow the boy back into his class.

Colleagues at Kingswood high school in Hull, which was closed and reopened last year in an attempt to change its failing image, are backing 33-year-old Chris Hassan.

More than 70 pupils with placards also demonstrated in support of the teacher, who has been suspended on full pay and warned in writing by the headteacher, Kevin Beaton, that he must not enter the school's grounds until the end of disciplinary proceedings, which are expected to last about two weeks. The pupil, who has also been accused of insulting other staff, was briefly suspended but has not apologised.

"I'm being made to look like a criminal," said Mr Hassan, who was abused after he told the pupil not to swing on an electric gate.

Mr Hassan said the boy had only been suspended after he complained twice to Mr Beaton.

He added: "All I asked for was for him to be moved to another class because I refuse to teach someone who racially abuses me and feels no remorse for what he did. I find it incredible that I am forced to stay at home, living as a virtual prisoner."

Mike Whale, joint secretary of Hull National Union of Teachers and a teacher at Kingswood, said set procedures had been invoked and "a lot of important issues need resolving".

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Buzz Lightyear goes beyond infinity ¥ DiCaprio takes control of his image ¥ Hilary Swank tipped to play Frenchwoman ¥ Kieslowski script to be filmed
fields.body:
Buzz Lightyear, the space ranger star of Toy Story, is going "beyond infinity" to star in his own cartoon television series.

Disney have revealed that our lantern-jawed hero will not just be a toy but a real space hero who can fly and use lots of gadgets to battle his arch enemy Emperor Zorg. It is not known yet whether the animation will be traditional or digitally recreated by Pixar but it must be the first time that a cartoon character has gone from a film to a television series.

Hopefully, there will be no toy rivalry: in Toy Story 2, which is released today, it is Woody who has his own television series, not Buzz Lightyear.

 In recent interviews Leonardo DiCaprio has described how unhappy he was with Titanic and all the media attention he received afterwards. With his latest film, The Beach, however, the Hollywood superstar has taken events into his own hands and is attempting to assert complete control over his image.

At the premiere of the movie in America only DiCaprio's personal media were allowed to cover the event which they did by streaming the premiere arrivals on DiCaprio's

 Hilary Swank, the tipsters favourite for an Oscar nomination for her portrayal of a gender-bending murder victim in Boys Don't Cry, is in final negotiations to play an 18th century Frenchwoman in an indie film called The Affair of the Necklace. Swank will play Jeanne de la Motte-Valois, who, in her quest to trace her blue-blooded ancestors, brings down the French aristocracy. Filming is expected to start in Prague in June just after Swank finishes filming on Sam Raimi' s The Gift. Charles Father of the Bride' Shyer will direct.

 Polish director Jerzy Stuhr has announced that he is making a film based on a script by the late director Krzysztof Kieslowski. According to Stuhr, Kieslowski, whose Three Colours trilogy won him international acclaim, gave him the script in 1976 during a period when he wasn't thinking of making any more films.

 Bruce Feirstein who wrote The World is not Enough and the previous three Bond pictures, is to script a remake of The Professionals, the tough 1966 Western about a wealthy ranch owner who hires a group of mercenaries to find the man who kidnapped his wife. Starring Lee Marvin and Burt Lancaster the original film won three Oscar nominations.
