webTitle: The whole world in his hand

fields.headline: The whole world in his hand
fields.standfirst:
In the 80s David Potter created the hand-held computer that everyone wanted. Now his company is developing the technology that will fuse mobile phones and PCs - and revolutionise all our lives. Andy Beckett explains why Bill Gates is worried

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: If, these days, you are a busy person, or a keenly-organised one, or a business executive who travels and likes gadgets, you may find yourself acquiring strange typing habits. Perhaps you only use your little fingers; or the edges of your fingertips; or a pen or a pencil, even, to peck more precisely at the keys. You probably type in public: on trains, at cafe tables, on streetcorners. You may feel nicely modern, bent over your personal organiser, great mineshafts of information and pulses of global communication beneath its slot of a screen. And just next to your tiny keyboard, the manufacturer's logo, most likely, will be an apparently unpronounceable word in yellow capitals: Psion.
fields.body:
If, these days, you are a busy person, or a keenly-organised one, or a business executive who travels and likes gadgets, you may find yourself acquiring strange typing habits. Perhaps you only use your little fingers; or the edges of your fingertips; or a pen or a pencil, even, to peck more precisely at the keys. You probably type in public: on trains, at cafe tables, on streetcorners. You may feel nicely modern, bent over your personal organiser, great mineshafts of information and pulses of global communication beneath its slot of a screen. And just next to your tiny keyboard, the manufacturer's logo, most likely, will be an apparently unpronounceable word in yellow capitals: Psion.

It sounds Californian - another anonymous-but-crucial Silicon Valley conglomerate, like Sun Microsystems or 3Com. Or maybe East Asian. When Psion (pronounced "Sion") commissioned research about its country of origin two year ago, most of its customers thought it was Japanese. But Psion is British. Its name stands for "Potter Scientific Instruments Or Nothing", its founder was a physics professor, and its history has been as charmed and erratic as any aficionado of these islands' famed inventiveness could hope for. What is more, in the great profitless deserts of British computing and innovation, Psion has actually made money. It could be about to make a great deal more.

Since the early 80s, improbably at first but with steadily growing credibility, Psion has been selling an idea of the electronic future based on computers the size of pencil cases. While everyone else has been building faster, flasher machines, with features to please the nerds and prices to match, Psion has been producing far simpler, cheaper, more genuinely portable models. Until quite recently these were barely considered computers at all - a sort of electronic Filofax. On the business pages, Psion was praised, but modestly, as an "innovative" niche enterprise.

Now, rather suddenly, it is being compared to Microsoft. And not just by over-excited financial journalists: in October 1998, Bill Gates himself "leaked" a Microsoft memo to the US media identifying Psion as his vast corporation's "Number One Global Threat". Since then, other computing and communications conglomerates have been queueing up to collaborate with Psion, like sixth-formers begging for a glimpse of the upcoming exam questions. On Tuesday, Motorola announced a joint manufacturing deal. Nokia, Ericsson, Oracle, and Matsushita, among others, have already joined a project started by Psion, called Symbian, to create the operating system for the next great advance in computing: fusion with the mobile phone.

There are currently at least 380m mobile phones in the world. There are only 330m personal computers. Within two years, Nokia estimates, mobile phone numbers will have breached one billion. Day by day, it seems to be becoming clearer that people prefer their electronics small, cute, and pocketable - the way that Psion, more than anyone, has always built them - rather than desk-bound, boxy, and designed for offices. By next year, according to the publicist for Symbian, there will be "30 or so" mobile "communicators" or "smartphones" or "wireless information devices" for sale. They will combine telephone functions with email, internet access, and word processing.

The publicist looks up from his laptop computer, where his presentation program is unfurling in a giddy whirl of rhetoric and dollar symbols. "This is not a computing industry any more," he says, his smile suddenly gone. "Consumers will not tolerate what they've lived with up to now." On the table, his slim new laptop, which is not a Psion, suddenly looks like a lump of stone. He purses his lips. "I don't see this as an evolution."

The company was more modest at the start. In 1980, after two decades teaching at Cambridge and Imperial College and the University of California, an expatriate white Zimbabwean with restless eyes and a love of London called David Potter decided to take a punt on computers. He was already a successful semi-professional investor, and had £70,000 in spare profits. His curiosity had been stirred by the beginnings of Silicon Valley: "A couple of my colleagues [in California] went off and built a mini-computer in 1974," Potter remembers. "That impressed me hugely."

He founded Psion as a software company, writing computer games. Across Britain, other people were inventing hungry hardware; early on, Psion provided software for some of the personal computers sold by Sir Clive Sinclair. And as most of the new computer firms began to fail, cut down by recession and naive marketing, Psion managed to prosper. "We were very lucky," says Potter. "We made huge profits very early on." He hung on to these windfalls to sustain Psion when things got worse. "They made their own luck," says Sinclair.

In 1984, Potter unveiled his first Organiser. It cost £100, and was little more than a computerised filing system, plus a calculator. But unlike the rival products that soon followed - such as the Microwriter and the Agenda, which asked users to learn an entirely new way of typing - it was practical. By the mid-80s, Psions were being used, very publicly, by British Rail staff and Marks & Spencer. Potter the ex-academic, "analytical by nature", seemed to understand how to exploit novelty better than most entrepreneurs. "If you look at the computer industry over 40 years," he says now, a professorial boom entering his voice, leaning back in one of the many chairs in his office at Psion's London headquarters, "you get these disruptive transitions. Each time, the controllers of the technology, the high priests, lose power." A shark-like smile splits his long, tanned face. His eyes light with mischief. "This is all solid-state physics, ultimately."

In 1987, he confidently floated Psion on the Stock Exchange. Within a year, the share price had quadrupled; profits were surging up the graphs too. Two years later, both had collapsed. Psion, for all its cerebral self-awareness, had not yet learned a fairly obvious lesson about business: the more innovative a company is, the more it can suffer from its own "disruptive transitions". Each time Psion had a new product out, its customers would get excited and sales and profits would climb; but then, as the novelty eroded, and expectations about the next new gadget began to grow, people would stop buying and wait. In the meantime - which might be several years - Psion would be spending millions on research and development. The stock market, not known for its patience, would panic. At the memory, Potter's face abruptly tightens - from playful inventor to beleaguered pioneer. "The major transition periods have been very difficult," he says.

Currently, Psion is enduring another. As it makes promises about Symbian, and all its associated miracles of minaturisation and communication, so some of the items Psion sells now - its latest range of silvery slim Organizers, its standard software packages - already seem old-fashioned. On Tottenham Court Road, London's ceaselessly competitive electronics bazaar, Psion's recently-launched organiser for the younger, "switched-on" market, the Revo, has already been marked down from £300 to £260.

Psion's shares have been lurching sharply up and down for months. The company website warns that "On-going investment in Symbian will continue to constrain... short-term profitability." Senior Psion staff, some long-term, have been leaving in greater numbers of late than feels comfortable. Since 1996, Potter, who is 56, has suffered heart alarms and surgery. He has given up the day-to-day running of the company to become chairman.

"My role is more of a guiding one these days," he says. His office at Psion is on the top floor, facing away from the ferment of central London; a glass wall gives onto dozing Mayfair rooftops, a terrace, drifting clouds. "In 1988, when we were about 120 people, I absolutely knew everyone," Potter continues. "A larger organisation becomes more... process-driven." He has been acquiring projects outside Psion. He has recently been invited to Downing Street to give a lecture on entrepreneurship. He is a regular on education quangos.

Meanwhile, across the corridor from his office, the new chief executive of Psion is plotting reform. David Levin is 20 years younger, a former management consultant, and has a background, not in electronics or new inventions, but in "venture capital" and "abrasives". He likes to whizz around his office on his chair castors. The view from his windows is of building sites, business premises being transformed or torn down.

Levin wants to turn Psion from a deviser of gadgets into "a platform for content". He fixes his eager gaze: "The category of organisers... is going to come to an end." The company needs to become more "market-driven", and less "technology-driven"; it must be "nimble", accept the need to "reinvent" itself. What all this means, in practical terms, remains a little unclear, for all Levin's chair-rolling and tumbling syllables. But he does mention one concrete initiative: he has sold off some of the company's factories.

Such reinventions have not always suited Psion. In 1996, it tried to become a high-street favourite by buying Amstrad, the consumer electronics firm. The deal failed. The plans for Symbian are a similar gamble. The alliance could quickly raise Psion from a vigorous but commercially-vulnerable company of middling size to something much bigger and more stable. Potter and Levin anticipate receiving a large and constant income, via licence agreements, from the makers of the new devices that use Symbian software. Or the great collaboration could crumble. Some of Psion's current allies seem to be hedging their bets: last December, Motorola and Nokia became investors in the Palm Pilot, an American rival to the Psion Organiser; the same month, Ericsson announced a link-up with Microsoft to develop mobile email.

Victor Basta, the managing director of Broadview, a consultancy specialising in the merger of computer firms, thinks this phoney war could last "a year or two". After that, as in many sorts of e-commerce, one or two conglomerates may be left standing. "Psion's got a pretty good shot," he says. "People have been saying Microsoft will kill them for a while now, and they haven't yet."

High above Mayfair, behind his glass wall, Potter disagrees that such all-consuming competition will ever loom. "No one company can manage the whole wireless future. You've got to be interdependent." He cites Europe's greater sophistication than the US, when it comes to mobile phones: in America, the network remains patchy and uncooperative because, he says, the telephone companies refuse to pool their resources. At board meetings for Symbian, by way of a contrast, Potter says he acts as "the Kofi Annan".

It all sounds very civilised. That the electronic future might be partly constructed, not by some pale perpetual teenager from the cold school of capitalism, but by "an old-fashioned liberal" who "believes in things", and finds the time to advise the South African government, for example, on how to better educate poor people, is a reassuring notion. Perhaps we will all become more like Psion users: keen on our machines, more practical in our use of them, more resistant to pure marketing, a bit patriotic or political even in the brands we favour.

There may be a few problems to sort out first, though. When the man from Symbian runs his demonstration program, the portable computer he shows is twice the likely actual size. Yet its screen is barely bigger than two matchboxes. He talks, quickly and a bit vaguely, about folding screens and putting the screen down the back and offering "not internet, but internet-type content".

Sir Clive Sinclair knows about such difficulties. "Whenever I'm at a meeting and we're deciding about dates," he says, "the people with diaries are always 10 times faster. But the people with Psions get terribly cross if you say so."

fields.headline: Blair announces countryside cash-machine network
fields.trailText: Prime minister Tony Blair continued his efforts to win the support of the countryside lobby today with an announcement that cash machines are to be installed in rural post offices.
fields.body:
Prime minister Tony Blair continued his efforts to win the support of the countryside lobby today with an announcement that cash machines are to be installed in rural post offices.

On his second day of a tour of Devon and Cornwall, Mr Blair said a deal had been struck between banks and the Post Office to introduce machines into 3,000 post offices around the country.

The agreement will bring help to village shops which have lost business since social security benefits started being paid directly into bank accounts.

"This big new expansion of the cash machine network will take cash points into many communities which don't have the service at the moment," said Mr Blair, "including many rural villages, so that if you need to take out more money, you won't have to travel to a town to do it.

"And you'll be able to support your local post office by using money there," he added.

Mr Blair was speaking at the Eden Project near St Austell, Cornwall, an environmental scheme which organisers hope will attract money into the region.

Mr Blair's campaign to show Labour cares about the country follows the hostile reception given to the government's report earlier this week on rural life.

The report recognised that income from farming had fallen by 60% since 1995 but said it had doubled in the previous five years. It pointed out that nearly 60% of farmers had other sources of income and the population of rural England had risen by nearly 25% in the last 25 years, four times the growth in the country as a whole.

Most people regarded the quality of life as better in the countryside and two-thirds of people would move there if they could, the report said.

Mr Blair's itinerary had been kept secret in order to avoid the protests which met his visit to Exeter yesterday. He later visited the post office and village store in Polgooth, Cornwall, run by Dawn and David Geeves for 14 years.

Mr Geeves told the Prime Minister how vital social security payments had been to their business: "People come in to get their benefit and allowances and then spend money in the shop."

He said about 30 to 40% of his business was made up of paying benefit and allowances. Mr Blair said: "So we are going to have to find another way to get people in. What we want to do is sit down with you guys and work out what we can do.

"We can't let rural post offices down. It's an important element in the community."

fields.headline: Chosen, Replaced and Ignored
fields.trailText: WORLD IN BOWEL MOTION
fields.body:
WORLD IN BOWEL MOTION

There's still another five months to go until the final decision is made, but the competition to host the 2006 World Cup ain't half heating up. This morning's more right-leaning papers (the sort who, if they went any further to the right would come up left again) this morning claimed that England had stolen to the head of the race after "chaos" in Nigeria at the African Nations Cup tarnished the bid of favourites South Africa. "Chaos" mainly referring to the Ivory Coast lock-in, of course.

The Fiver would like to point out that this suggestion is a bit like saying that England's bid has been ruined by Jorg Haider and the Austrian Freedom Party. But the FA didn't. Instead they chose today to start boasting about how they've detected a "definite shift" away from SA in the passages of power (ie: the bowels of a few footballing bureaucrats). Said sprightly FA bid chief Alec McGivan: "I feel the England campaign is in an excellent position at the moment. We are very encouraged by the way things are going."

Nobody would be stupid enough to suggest that the occurrences in the press and in Alec McGivan's mouth are in any way connected, but contrast those whispers with the State of the Nation address given by South African president Thabo Mbeki today. "It is clear that fairness and the development of soccer... demand that, for the first time in the year 2006, the World Cup should take place in Africa," he said. "There can be no better venue than the land of human hope... which our country is." Sounds fair enough to us. Not that we're after a free holiday in the sun or anything.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

BONKERS IN BARCA

When you're manager of Barcelona you do tend to have the pick of the world's players at your disposal. And if you don't, well you can always go out and buy them. So it might not be that surprising to find that Louis van Gaal is ready to sell, amongst others, Barjuan Sergi, Luis Enrique and Pep Guardiola this summer in order to bring in the next generation of stars. You might be more surprised that this next generation includes Marc Overmars and, er, Savo Milosevic.

According to reports in Barcelona-based sports paper Sport (where do they get their names from?) 'Operation van Gaal' will seek to get rid of more than one crowd favourite and replace them with Europe's best performers. The Fiver can understand how the nippy, and suitably Dutch, Overmars might fit the bill. But we're somewhat bemused by the appearance of Savo - the former Aston Villa striker after all being the man who enabled Big Ron to use the phrase "couldn't hit a cow's arse with a banjo" during a Wembley final.

Savo's popuarity extends from the fact that he is currently second in the Primera Liga goalscoring charts, having already 'notched' 18 times for his club Real Zaragoza this season (the same number claimed by Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink, but that's slightly more predictable). But the Fiver for one refuses to believe that the Yugoslav has matured into a world-beating forward. Either that or Iain Dowie will soon be looking for a move to Milan.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I'm always very careful when I mention two different players in the same breath, but I do think Hicham Zerouali has the potential to be as good a player as Brian Laudrup." - Aberdeen manager Ebbe Skovdahl puts absolutely no pressure at all on his Moroccan striker.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

WEEKEND WORLD

Here's our pick of the weekend's Premiership clashes. And if you're annoyed because we've left your team out, don't worry - we've deliberately ignored Manchester United's match in order to calm you down.

Liverpool v Leeds United
Not much choice for Gerard Houllier up front - injuries mean big lumbering Erik Meijer must line up alongside small lumbering Titi Camara. At least Gerard has midfield options, though - it's a toss-up between free-scoring Vladimir Smicer and hair-free Danny Murphy for a place alongside £8m success story Didi Hamann. Meanwhile, David O'Leary O'Leeds has so many strikers he doesn't know what to do with them all. Should he play Alan Smith alongside Michael Bridges? Or Darren Huckerby? Or Harry Kewell? Whatever.

Derby County v Sheffield Wednesday
Stefano Eranio is back after a serious leg break, so he'll get picked ahead of Georgi Kinkladze for this relegation six-pointer. But who to partner regular striker Branko Strupar? Dean Sturridge, Malcolm Christie and Deon Burton are all fit and available - the jealous seethes can be heard all the way from Anfield. Meanwhile, Danny Sonner and Alan Quinn both return for Wednesday. And despite a groin injury, their front line may be led by Andy Booth... hey, has that seething sound turned into raucous laughter?

Southampton v West Ham United
"The West Ham game is not about Glenn Hoddle, it's about Southampton FC," said Glenn Hoddle, talking about himself in a press conference about a football match. But it is, because it's very much a first game in charge situation. Sunderland v Newcastle United
One thing you won't see here is a bedraggled Dutchman standing in a torrential rainstorm muttering "I don't just Alan, I hate Rob also" while sucking on a necklace. Rangers want Barcelona's unsettled Dutch midfielder Ronald de Boer. Dick Advocaat will pay £7m.

Paolo Maldini, AC Milan's 33-year-old left-back, wants to join Chelsea. He has been offered a free transfer by the by Milan at the end of the season.

Manchester United may bid £18m for Bari's teenage striker Antonio Cassano.

Atletico Madrid, Celta Vigo, Real Betis and Roma are all interested in Teddy Sheringham.

Aston Villa have taken 25-year-old Argentinian Gustavo Bartelt on loan from Roma for the rest of the season. Ukraine have been confirmed as England's opponents for their final match before Euro 2000. The game will take place at Wembley on May 31, four days after England play Brazil at the same venue.

Alan Wilkie will referee the Worthington Cup final between Leicester and Tranmere.

Burnley have signed centre-half Ian Cox from Bournemouth for £500,000.

Cambridge have rejected West Bromwich Albion's bid for striker Trevor Benjamin.

Dunfermline have signed Hibernian forward Stevie Crawford for the remainder of the season for a nominal fee.

St Johnstone captain Jim Weir has extended his current contract at the club until 2003.

Guatemala. Azerbaijan. Belgium. It's exotic.

Brian Woolnough. Steve Curry. Martin Samuel. It's erotic.

This morning's more right-leaning papers (the sort who, if they went any further to the right would come up left again) this morning claimed that England had stolen to the head of the race after "chaos" in Nigeria at the African Nations Cup tarnished the bid of favourites South Africa. "Chaos" mainly referring to the Ivory Coast lock-in, of course. The Fiver would like to point out that this suggestion is a bit like saying that England's bid has been ruined by Jorg Haider and the Austrian Freedom Party. But the FA didn't. Instead they chose today to start boasting about how they've detected a "definite shift" away from SA in the passages of power (ie: the bowels of a few footballing bureaucrats). Said sprightly FA bid chief Alec McGivan: "I feel the England campaign is in an excellent position at the moment. We are very encouraged by the way things are going." Nobody would be stupid enough to suggest that the occurrences in the press and in Alec McGivan's mouth are in any way connected, but contrast those whispers with the State of the Nation address given by South African president Thabo Mbeki today. "It is clear that fairness and the development of soccer... demand that, for the first time in the year 2006, the World Cup should take place in Africa," he said. webTitle: Direct rule: back to the future

fields.headline: Direct rule: back to the future
fields.trailText:
The re-imposition of direct rule in Northern Ireland is not just a reversal of 
very recent events, but an uncanny echo of ancient history.
fields.body:
The re-imposition of direct rule in Northern Ireland is not just a reversal of very recent events, but an uncanny echo of ancient history.

Put very simply, English domination of the British Isles began in early medieval times, when the Norman and later the Plantagenet dynasties claimed suzerainty over Scotland, Wales and Ireland. That claim was given substance by the conquest of Wales, the slower subjugation of the Irish, and centuries of warfare against Scotland, ending with the dynastic union of 1603.

Wales was fully incorporated into the English realm in the early 16th century, in the reign of Henry VIII. The last effective remnants of Irish native resistance to English rule were crushed by the end of that century, though Ireland retained its own nominally independent parliament.

The united kingdom of Scotland and England became a full Union with the dissolution of the Edinburgh parliament in 1707. In 1800 the Irish parliament voted itself into oblivion, and Westminster lorded it over the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland.

In 1921 the long process of political integration went into reverse, with the partial separation of Ireland, carved into two parts. The 26 counties of the south started with devolution, which developed into complete independence and republican status. The six counties of the north had the same initial standing as the south: a separate parliament and government under the crown, but remained part of the Union.

That continued until 1972 when the system collapsed under the pressure of nationalist boycott and republican violence. Direct rule was imposed by the Heath government, which appointed Willie Whitelaw as the first secretary of state.

Whitelaw and his successors, both Tory and Labour, upheld the local laws accreted under the old Stormont administration, but were accountable only to Westminster. There was an ill-starred attempt to reintroduce devolved, power-sharing government in 1973/74, but it evaporated in the face of diehard unionist resistance.

The Good Friday agreement is designed to restore self government to Northern Ireland, with the additional ingredient of new institutional links between Belfast, Dublin, and Westminster. It coincides, but has little in common, with the separate devolution processes in Scotland and Wales.

Now, just two months after Westminster relinquished its local powers to the new power-sharing government headed by Unionist leader David Trimble, it is preparing to take them back again. The re-imposition of direct rule means that secretary of state Peter Mandelson and his junior ministers will resume charge of the day-to-day administration of the province, in addition to their overall responsibility for security matters.

Unlike in 1972, when the 50-year-old Stormont regime was swept away for good, the government now hopes to retain the Trimble administration, albeit in suspended animation, until it can resolve the dispute over paramilitary disarmament. If that day dawns, Northern Ireland will once again control its own affairs, and the 900-year-old political evolution of the islands will continue.

webTitle: Minister pledges shakeup to pave way for digital TV

fields.headline: Minister pledges shakeup to pave way for digital TV
fields.trailText: Proposals for a complete overhaul of the regulations governing broadcasting and telecommunications will be published this autumn, the culture secretary, Chris Smith, announced yesterday.
fields.body:
Proposals for a complete overhaul of the regulations governing broadcasting and telecommunications will be published this autumn, the culture secretary, Chris Smith, announced yesterday.

The wide-ranging changes are being prepared in partnership with the department of trade and industry and aim to free up British media companies so that they can compete globally as the industry goes digital.

Rules on programme content, the remit of public service broadcasting, and the laws restricting ownership of media companies will all be covered in the white paper. The terrestrial broadcasters, including ITV, Channel 4 and Channel 5, have long argued for a relaxation of the detailed regulations which govern their programmes, and which currently force them to show a certain number of hours of arts, current affairs, children's and religious shows a week.

Although Mr Smith has said he aims for a "lighter touch" regulation of television channels now that digital television has greatly increased the number of channels available, he insisted that viewers' and consumers' interests would be fully protected.

He emphasised the importance of safeguarding children from unsuitable programmes and upholding the core public service duties of broadcasters.

Mr Smith said yesterday that the white paper signalled the way forward for the consolidation of ITV.

The companies which own most of the ITV network, Carlton Communications, United News and Media, and Granada Group, are already immersed in merger plans which most believe will inevitably lead to the creation of one ITV company if media legislation is changed.

Mr Smith said that his consultation period and proposals for the white paper would run parallel to the ongoing investigations by the office of fair trading into the proposed ITV mergers.

He confirmed he would be consulting broadcasters, regulators and viewers' interest groups, and warned the ITV companies that he felt the regional nature of the ITV companies should be protected.

Reports that the prime minister has approved plans for a £15 increase in the BBC's licence fee to cover the corporation's digital plans were "complete nonsense", he said. The across the board increase in the licence fee would be a turnround for the government, which has been investigating recommendations from the Davies committee to impose a supplementary fee on digital viewers. Broadcasters Sky Digital and ONdigital have vehemently opposed a supplement.

Mr Smith said: "No decision has yet been taken and we are still considering a range of options." An announcement is expected before the end of the month.

fields.headline: Designers at ...
fields.trailText: In the olden days, there was a clear distinction between "designer" and "high street". Designer buys set you back an average monthly pay packet; high street clothes were easier on your wallet but far more shoddily made. Now, though, it's gotten all confusing. There are so many designers creating diffusion collections for high street chains that every Tom, Dick and Harriet can hang a little dress in their wardrobe and say it's exclusive.
fields.body:
In the olden days, there was a clear distinction between "designer" and "high street". Designer buys set you back an average monthly pay packet; high street clothes were easier on your wallet but far more shoddily made. Now, though, it's gotten all confusing. There are so many designers creating diffusion collections for high street chains that every Tom, Dick and Harriet can hang a little dress in their wardrobe and say it's exclusive.

The trend started back in 1994, when Debenhams had the bright idea of introducing BDL, a diffusion range of eveningwear by high end designer Ben Di Lisi. Though this was successful, it wasn't until 1996 that Dorothy Perkins hooked on to the idea as a tonic for ailing sales; they brought in British design duo Clements Ribeiro, who for two seasons spun their magic, creating affordable knitwear pieces. Now everyone is getting in on the act.

Debenhams is the main player this spring: the Designers at Debenhams portfolios include Jasper Conran, Pierce Fionda and Antoni and Alison designing womenswear; Philip Treacy, Lulu Guiness, Pip Hackett, Van Peterson and Orla Kiely providing accessories; John Richmond and Ozwald Boateng rooting for men; and even Junior by Jasper Conran and the newly launched Sweetpea by Elspeth Gibson for offspring.

Hot on the heels of Debenhams is the Arcadia Group, which has quickly sussed that it's the way ahead. When the Top Shop megastore relaunched in Oxford Circus in 1998, Arcadia snapped up designers Hussein Chalayan and Sherald Lamden to up the ante, both creating a small collection of up-to-the minute pieces young girls would want and could also afford. Two years on, Top Shop has added to its rails Clements Ribeiro, Tracy Boyd and Markus Lupfer; Dorothy Perkins is fighting its corner with Whistles Express (a cheaper version of Whistles) and Liza Bruce; Principles has Amanda Wakeley; and Bhs has signed up Owen Gaster and Paul Frith.

In March, Marks & Spencer are getting in on the act, too. With ailing sales and falling profits, they are joining the gang with their Autograph Collection, designed by Betty Jackson, Julien MacDonald and Katharine Hamnett. Will it help? I should think so: everyone loves a designer bargain.

fields.headline: Coat tales
fields.standfirst: Attention, film and fashion fans: the inimitable silk and tweed number worn by Richard E Grant in Withnail And I is about to go under the hammer. Susannah Barron meets its maker
fields.trailText: As iconic screen garments go, it's right up there with Dorothy's ruby slippers. The Withnail coat - a long, sweeping, heathery-hued number made from soft Harris tweed - has become imbued with all the cult appeal of the film in which it appeared, Bruce Robinson's 1987 comedy Withnail And I.
fields.body:
As iconic screen garments go, it's right up there with Dorothy's ruby slippers. The Withnail coat - a long, sweeping, heathery-hued number made from soft Harris tweed - has become imbued with all the cult appeal of the film in which it appeared, Bruce Robinson's 1987 comedy Withnail And I.

Set in the 60s, it follows the antics of two out-of-work actors who decide to take a country break. Thirteen years on, it still has legions of fans around the world, who like nothing better than to settle down with a big spliff and recite, word for word, the "fine wine and cakes" bit.

On Monday, movie buffs have the chance to bid for the original Withnail coat, as worn with such stylish nonchalance by Richard E Grant. It is coming under the hammer, along with other Withnail memorabilia, to help raise money for the Waterford School in Swaziland. Back in the 70s, Grant attended this multi-racial school for gifted children, along with Nelson Mandela's daughters, and he has organised the auction to follow a celebrity screening of the film.

The coat was the creation of costume designer Andrea Galer, who wanted it to look as though it had come from the family attic. She based it on a 19th-century riding coat, to allow Grant ease of movement as he gallivanted around the countryside. "When shooting fish, he had to be able to tie it up," she explains. "Or in the scene where he rubs in Deep Heat, he had to push the sleeves up and make it look like an entirely usual activity."

The result, in tweed lined with striped Indian silk dupion ("Some hippie friend had decided to give it a lift into the 60s") is suitably louche. "Withnail needed to look decadent," Galer says. "It's a coat that has a life."

Over the years, she has fielded countless requests from Withnail fans who want to buy a replica. A couple of years ago, she produced a limited edition Withnail coat to mark the 10th anniversary of the film; today, you can buy a replica for the relatively bargain price of £295.

Fashion and film have long been linked, but Galer pushes the relationship to its logical conclusion. A fashion, bridalwear and costume designer, she develops her film clothes into full-on fashion collections then made available to the public. Until a year ago, she had a shop in London's Belsize Park. "It drove me nuts," she admits. Having all her samples stolen 18 months ago didn't help: "It was very traumatic."

These days, she takes the modern approach of putting her collections on the web. "I can't understand why I didn't do it earlier," she enthuses, genuinely excited about the creative opportunities. "You can have moving images, something to art-direct."

Log on (www.andreagaler.co.uk) and you will find clothing inspired by Withnail, plus bridal and eveningwear from more recent film projects: Channel 4's Cinderella, shown on New Year's Day and starring Kathleen Turner, for which Galer created a look based on 50s couture; the new film version of Mansfield Park, which premiered at the London Film Festival and opens here next month; and the 1998 period drama Firelight.

As well as the film collections, Galer produces women's suits and eveningwear. Based on corsetry and traditional tailoring, her look translates well into film: a model of cross-fertilisation, Galer's contemporary clothing influences her costume, which in turn has an impact on her main collections. Look at the rails of clothes in her Belsize Park studio and you can see how it works. A curvy bridal jacket, made up in a different fabric, shortened and tweaked, fits right into the world of Jane Austen. A raspberry empire-line dress, also designed for Mansfield Park, wouldn't look out of place in a ballroom today. "That's a dress for now," Galer says, pointing at it with some satisfaction.

When designing the costumes for something like Mansfield Park, she will research a period thoroughly, then alter the look slightly to appeal to the modern eye. A slip dress, for example, will be cut on the bias and slimmed down at the sides for a more contemporary look - in Jane Austen's day, women wanted to look slightly rounder than they do now.

"I'm sure that in a few years' time, you will be able to look back and see when a dress was made," Galer acknowledges. But, as she says: "Stars want to look attractive. Everything looks better if it flatters somebody."

Throughout her career, Galer has fused fashion and costume. She started out making theatrical outfits, which led to her dressing the likes of Julie Christie, as well as various pop stars of the 70s. It was through Christie that she received her first film commission, designing the costumes for Nicolas Roeg's 1973 movie Don't Look Now. After taking 10 years out to have children, Galer returned in the mid-80s, clothing the likes of Paul Young and Dire Straits for their videos.

Then, of course, came Withnail. "It's a bit like the Rocky Horror Show," Galer says, reflecting on its enduring appeal. "I still find it funny."

fields.bodyText: As iconic screen garments go, it's right up there with Dorothy's ruby slippers. The Withnail coat - a long, sweeping, heathery-hued number made from soft Harris tweed - has become imbued with all the cult appeal of the film in which it appeared, Bruce Robinson's 1987 comedy Withnail And I. Set in the 60s, it follows the antics of two out-of-work actors who decide to take a country break. Thirteen years on, it still has legions of fans around the world, who like nothing better than to settle down with a big spliff and recite, word for word, the "fine wine and cakes" bit. On Monday, movie buffs have the chance to bid for the original Withnail coat, as worn with such stylish nonchalance by Richard E Grant. It is coming under the hammer, along with other Withnail memorabilia, to help raise money for the Waterford School in Swaziland. Back in the 70s, Grant attended this multi-racial school for gifted children, along with Nelson Mandela's daughters, and he has organised the auction to follow a celebrity screening of the film. The coat was the creation of costume designer Andrea Galer, who wanted it to look as though it had come from the family attic. She based it on a 19th-century riding coat, to allow Grant ease of movement as he gallivanted around the countryside. "When shooting fish, he had to be able to tie it up," she explains. "Or in the scene where he rubs in Deep Heat, he had to push the sleeves up and make it look like an entirely usual activity." The result, in tweed lined with striped Indian silk dupion ("Some hippie friend had decided to give it a lift into the 60s") is suitably louche. "Withnail needed to look decadent," Galer says. "It's a coat that has a life." Over the years, she has fielded countless requests from Withnail fans who want to buy a replica. A couple of years ago, she produced a limited edition Withnail coat to mark the 10th anniversary of the film; today, you can buy a replica for the relatively bargain price of £295. Fashion and film have long been linked, but Galer pushes the relationship to its logical conclusion. A fashion, bridalwear and costume designer, she develops her film clothes into full-on fashion collections then made available to the public. Until a year ago, she had a shop in London's Belsize Park. "It drove me nuts," she admits. Having all her samples stolen 18 months ago didn't help: "It was very traumatic." These days, she takes the modern approach of putting her collections on the web. "I can't understand why I didn't do it earlier," she enthuses, genuinely excited about the creative opportunities. "You can have moving images, something to art-direct." Log on (www.andreagaler.co.uk) and you will find clothing inspired by Withnail, plus bridal and eveningwear from more recent film projects: Channel 4's Cinderella, shown on New Year's Day and starring Kathleen Turner, for which Galer created a look based on 50s couture; the new film version of Mansfield Park, which premiered at the London Film Festival and opens here next month; and the 1998 period drama Firelight. As well as the film collections, Galer produces women's suits and eveningwear. Based on corsetry and traditional tailoring, her look translates well into film: a model of cross-fertilisation, Galer's contemporary clothing influences her costume, which in turn has an impact on her main collections. Look at the rails of clothes in her Belsize Park studio and you can see how it works. A curvy bridal jacket, made up in a different fabric, shortened and tweaked, fits right into the world of Jane Austen. A raspberry empire-line dress, also designed for Mansfield Park, wouldn't look out of place in a ballroom today. "That's a dress for now," Galer says, pointing at it with some satisfaction. When designing the costumes for something like Mansfield Park, she will research a period thoroughly, then alter the look slightly to appeal to the modern eye. A slip dress, for example, will be cut on the bias and slimmed down at the sides for a more contemporary look - in Jane Austen's day, women wanted to look slightly rounder than they do now. "I'm sure that in a few years' time, you will be able to look back and see when a dress was made," Galer acknowledges. But, as she says: "Stars want to look attractive. Everything looks better if it flatters somebody." Throughout her career, Galer has fused fashion and costume. She started out making theatrical outfits, which led to her dressing the likes of Julie Christie, as well as various pop stars of the 70s. It was through Christie that she received her first film commission, designing the costumes for Nicolas Roeg's 1973 movie Don't Look Now. After taking 10 years out to have children, Galer returned in the mid-80s, clothing the likes of Paul Young and Dire Straits for their videos. Then, of course, came Withnail. webTitle: Let it snow, let it snow, let it snow

fields.headline: Let it snow, let it snow, let it snow
fields.standfirst: About to slope off for a winter break? Fashion editor Laura Craik advises on how to look cool in the cold
fields.trailText: Really, there was no need for the Countess of Wessex to resort to that silly fur hat on her recent skiing trip to St Moritz. Foxy? Only in the literal sense. There are far more stylish - and humane - ways to look elegant on the slopes.
fields.body:
Really, there was no need for the Countess of Wessex to resort to that silly fur hat on her recent skiing trip to St Moritz. Foxy? Only in the literal sense. There are far more stylish - and humane - ways to look elegant on the slopes.

Agnès b's bold black and white snood would have kept her ears warm just as well. Now that the 80s is the latest decade to be considered hyper-chic, snoods are good and headbands are happening, whether you're skiing or merely walking your modishly mono English bull terrier in the park.

Some might call it indulgent to be thinking of taking a holiday so early in the year, but I know people who have been planning their skiing trips since last summer. Nor are they rich and privileged, just in need of a lift after the trough of January and willing to save up for the experience. "It's the feeling of the wind, the air, the freedom," one friend explained in a reverie. "Bollocks. It's the gorgeous instructors and the après-ski," said another. "And you come home with a better butt."

Whether you're ploughing or pulling, to be truly fashionable on the slopes this season, your skiwear should be graphic and simple. Luminous orange go-faster stripes and garish "fun" patterns are out, in favour of black, white, grey and just the odd splash of colour. Ditch heavily padded salopettes for All Saints' far svelter cream ensemble (it's still fully waterproof) or Killy's black all-in-one ski suit. For true one-upmanship, bag yourself some skis by Prada Sport.

As for eyewear, well, that depends on how brown you want your face to be. Smoked-glass shades might be the height of fashion but a good, solid pair of goggles is more likely to stay in place and, more importantly, to protect your eyes properly from the glare. You can always use fake tan to get rid of the panda look once you get home.

One further word of advice: don't be a cliché and fall for your ski instructor. He says that to all the girls.

fields.headline: Most everywhere:  easy access underwear
fields.trailText: Hairy arses apart, there can be no greater passion-killer than the bumbling hands of your lover as he tries to undo your bra while wearing an expression of contrived "I can do this" nonchalance. Who'd have thought two small hooks could be such an obstacle on the path between desire and fulfilment? Poor old 20th-century man.
fields.body:
Hairy arses apart, there can be no greater passion-killer than the bumbling hands of your lover as he tries to undo your bra while wearing an expression of contrived "I can do this" nonchalance. Who'd have thought two small hooks could be such an obstacle on the path between desire and fulfilment? Poor old 20th-century man.

It seems, however, that 21st-century man will have no such stumbling blocks. "Smooth fingers" will be his middle name. For this is the age of easy access underwear, where a simple tug of two ribbons is all it takes.

It all began with Gabrielle Ross, a former lawyer who decided to design a new kind of bra after overhearing two men complaining about how long it took them to disrobe their prey. She launched Beau Bras in 1998 and has never looked back. Find her bras and knickers, held together by strategically placed bows, in major stores or visit www.easyshop.co.uk. Top Shop and Miss Selfridge are also awash with versions.

But smooth as the effect might be in the bedroom, it's anything but when worn under tight-fitting clothes: all those bows cause some nasty lumps. And watch how you tie them or the effect will be more knotty than naughty.

fields.headline: Most wanted
fields.trailText: What do you get if you whizz around the world on a motorbike? Why, inspiration for a fantastic fashion label, of course. Custo Barcelona has been around since the early 80s, but it isn't nearly as famous as it should be. Designed by two biking brothers who draw on everything from Californian surf style to the psychedelic traditions of northern Spain, the collections of bright screen-printed and embroidered T-shirts, dresses and cropped trousers are a sight to be seen. Stocked in Selfridges in Manchester and London, and priced from £30, the clobber apparently sells out before it hits the floor. The perfect pop-art playwear for spring.

fields.headline: Solve your Valentine's Day blues
fields.standfirst: Win copies of Romeo + Juliet or Ever After on video or DVD
fields.trailText: Imagine the worse case scenario. Valentine's Day dawns and the welcome mat is bare of pink envelopes and your answerphone flashing a big red zero. Fear not. Film Unlimited offers some solace in the form of a double-bill of very modern romantic videos or DVDs to while the night away, courtesy of 20th Century Fox Home Entertainment.
fields.body:
Imagine the worse case scenario. Valentine's Day dawns and the welcome mat is bare of pink envelopes and your answerphone flashing a big red zero. Fear not. Film Unlimited offers some solace in the form of a double-bill of very modern romantic videos or DVDs to while the night away, courtesy of 20th Century Fox Home Entertainment.

Ten lovestruck winners will receive a copy of either William Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet - a brilliantly customised, reinvented take on the Bard starring Claire Danes and Leonardo Di Caprio - or If Only, an acclaimed Cinderella update with a decidedly feminist flavour plus some on-song acting from Drew Barrymore and Anjelica Huston. So dry those tears and consign that elusive Mr/Ms Right to the dustbin of history. It probably wouldn't have worked out anyway.

To win a copy of either William Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet or Ever After, email feedback@filmunlimited.co.uk with 'video competition' in the subject line, stating which video you would like to win, (and whether you would like it in DVD format) and with your full name and postal address.

Winners will be notified by email on Tuesday 15 February, and videos will be sent out the same day.

 Romeo + Juliet and Ever After are also available to buy on DVD from February 7, 2000.

fields.headline: Bumpy ride
fields.standfirst: The checkout where you can get a workout, and Dunstable's baby boom
fields.trailText:
A trolley too far
Current debate about whether or not shoppers pay too much at supermarkets has become academic at one store in Cumbria, where customers can't even get to the checkouts to pay in the first place. The problem is that new trolleys introduced at Safeway, in Millom, are too wide to get through the checkout aisles. A two-inch rubber buffer added to the trolleys to improve safety means that they have to be forced in and out of the aisles, with one person pushing, and another pulling from the other end. "It sounds like a gymnasium in there," commented one customer, "everyone puffing and grunting trying to get their trolleys through."
fields.body:
A trolley too far
Current debate about whether or not shoppers pay too much at supermarkets has become academic at one store in Cumbria, where customers can't even get to the checkouts to pay in the first place. The problem is that new trolleys introduced at Safeway, in Millom, are too wide to get through the checkout aisles. A two-inch rubber buffer added to the trolleys to improve safety means that they have to be forced in and out of the aisles, with one person pushing, and another pulling from the other end. "It sounds like a gymnasium in there," commented one customer, "everyone puffing and grunting trying to get their trolleys through."

Safeway managers have promised to rectify the situation as soon as possible, although one man has actually welcomed the current state of affairs. "I can shop and get fit all at the same time," he enthused. "Buying my frozen cod slices and marrowfat peas has given me muscles in places I never knew they existed."
Cumbria online

It's something in the water
The term "bouncy baby" took on new significance this week when a Dunstable woman gave birth to a child so huge the hospital didn't have nappies big enough to fit it. Although she was, by her own admission, "massive" during pregnancy, even mother Helma Patel was shocked when, following a caesarean section, son Owen tipped the scales at a gargantuan 13lb 9oz, one of the biggest babies ever delivered in Dunstable.

"They didn't have any nappies to fit him," said proud dad Brian, an injection welder, "so they had to use a sheet instead." Both mother and child are doing well, and Ms Patel insists she still wants to have more children. "With a child that big, a caesarean is the only option," opined one specialist. "Giving birth normally would have been like passing a watermelon with three pineapples attached to it."
Luton and Dunstable Herald and Post

Rabbit hell
Quiet, unassuming Daventry is fast turning into a black spot for household pets. Last week we reported on how dogs living near a Daventry reservoir have been driven to tranquillisers by the constant explosions from special bird-scaring rockets. Now the town seems to be experiencing an epidemic of abandoned rabbits. Precisely why Daventry should suddenly have become the orphan rabbit capital of Britain is uncertain. What is clear, however, is that it has more rabbits than it can comfortably deal with, and the RSPCA have launched an urgent appeal for foster-owners.

"We have a real problem with rabbits in Daventry at the moment," said one RSPCA official, "and we're not rehoming them anything like as quickly as we'd like to." Any readers who feel they'd like to help the rabbits, or Daventry, or both, should contact local rabbit fostering coordinator Rebecca Gore on 01327 706825. "I'll happily take as many as they can give me," offered one local butcher. "Provided they're nice plump ones, with lots of meat on them."
The Daventry Express

Drink tinkering
DIY alert! A recent report from Scotland's Forth Valley health board revealed that the most common cause of home injuries in the region was people carrying out home improvements whilst under the influence of alcohol. According to Dr Malcom McWhirter, the region's director of public health, of the 20,000 people who in 1998-99 attended Falkirk Royal Infirmary as a result of residential accidents, a significant percentage had been drinking. "People handling tools at home under the influence of alcohol is a major problem," he admitted. "Especially power tools like drills and saws."

The health board have warned people never to undertake home improvement work if they've been drinking beforehand - a warning that one local man, hospitalised after a mishap whilst re-tiling his roof, has urged people to heed. "I'd had about eight pints of heavy and could really have hurt myself," he said. "Although in the event, I just got hypothermia from working in the nude."
Falkirk Herald

Poobox
Letters have been meeting an unpleasant, not to say malodorous, end in the market town of Easingwold, West Yorkshire, where a red dog-poo disposal bin has been repeatedly mistaken for a postbox. The bin was erected by construction company Persimmon, and has, as well as its intended contents, been attracting a regular flow of letters from confused locals. "I must admit that from a distance it's misleading," admitted councillor Geoff Richardson. "The colour indicates it's a postbox, and it's even mounted on a pole. Anyone with impaired vision could easily mistake it."

The town's other dog-waste bins are all green, but because the land is owned by Persimmon, the council has no power to make them change their bin's colour. "When I found out what it was I was actually quite relieved," admitted one woman. "I'd been posting my responses to lonely hearts adverts there, and thought the reason I hadn't heard anything back was that no one fancied me."
York Evening Press

Letter of the week
I resent bitterly the private members' bill in the unelected House of Lords to introduce a compulsory question on a person's religion in the next census in 2001. This is absolutely no business of the state! Only dictators such as Hitler or Stalin would have need of such information.

I can see why the government has to ask about income, ethnicity, housing facilities etc. to ensure proper allocation of resources. There is, for example, no point in having an Asian language centre in an area with very few Asians. Religion or lack of religion, however, is purely a matter for the individual's conscience and nothing to do with the state. It is ironic that this question will not be on the census form in the two parts of Great Britain where it could possibly be relevant, Ulster and Scotland.

I have written to my MP to protest about this intrusion and hope he will vote against it, or have it made a voluntary question, and would urge others who also object to this prying into a most personal matter to do likewise. If we don't make a stand against this, what will come in the 2011 census? Questions about a person's sexual orientation?
Steve Foley Reading Chronicle

fields.headline: Did you hear the one ....?
fields.standfirst: Jokes that were once funny, and those that never were
fields.trailText: Jokes that were once funny, and those that never were
fields.body:
Doctors

Doctor doctor! I think I've got hermes!

Surely you mean herpes?

No doctor, you see, I'm a carrier.

Hobbies

I used to be a bestial sado-necrophilliac, until I realised I was flogging a dead horse.

Family

Q What's pink and wrinkly and hangs out your pants?

A Your mum.

Academics

Did you hear the one about the constipated mathematician? He worked it out with a pencil.

Nuns

Two nuns are driving down the road when a great big vampire leaps on their bonnet. "Quick! show your cross! show him your cross!" says the first nun. The second nun leans out the window saking her fist:"Oi! you! get off my car!"

Birds

Two parrots sitting on a perch. One says to the other "Can you smell fish?"

Cars

A mechanic, a businessman and a computer programmer are sharing a car journey into town when the old wreck breaks down.

The mechanic says: "Give me half-an-hour and I'll have it working again" The businessman says: "Nonsense! Let's get a taxi and I'll buy a new car when we get to the city"

The programmer says: "If we all get out, and then all get in again, it should start."

Politics

Q Why do Marxists drink herbal tea?

A All proper tea is theft.

fields.headline: Prince Edward's building dispute
fields.trailText:
Why is Prince Edward arguing with builders?
The Earl of Wessex is has withheld £600,000 from the London-based building company CJ Sims, which carried out work on his new home, the Bagshot Park mansion in Surrey. The builders have gone into receivership, naming Prince Edward as a debtor.
fields.body:
Why is Prince Edward arguing with builders?
The Earl of Wessex is has withheld £600,000 from the London-based building company CJ Sims, which carried out work on his new home, the Bagshot Park mansion in Surrey. The builders have gone into receivership, naming Prince Edward as a debtor.

Why won't he pay up?
The Earl is said by friends to have paid £1.8 million, the value of the original contract, minus a 1.5% forfeit for work not satisfactorily completed, after the renovations were finished in August last year. The source claims the builders then agreed to the assessment and valuation of £1.8m for the work done. But CJ Sims later presented a 30% higher bill to the Earl. While Edward offered to pay more, his proposed settlement was rejected.

Does he have the right to withhold payment?
For a job of this size, the Earl will undoubtedly have had architects supervising the work who would have drawn up a detailed written specification for the builders. Quotes would have been submitted for each item. Any changes and any increase in prices would have to be agreed by both sides during the course of the work. An estimate is not binding but if a contract was signed based on a written quote, the builders would not have been entitled to increase the cost.

Why was the bill so big?
Specifications frequently change during the course of building work. The client often changes his or her mind; it is not always possible to quote in detail until building has started - how much structural work is needed for example may only become clear once surfaces have been removed.

How can you protect yourself?
Before entering a contract with a builder, the Federation of Master Builders recommends you:

  • Ask for references and names of previous clients. Speak to them and look at the work if possible.
  • Get estimates from two or three different builders.
  • Ask for work to be covered by an insurance backed warranty.
  • Be very clear about what you want done and ask for a written specification and quotation
  • Use a contract - the FMB has simple forms of contract for small building work.
  • Don't pay for more than a proportion of the work in advance. Agree any staged and final payments before work starts. Avoid making cash payments.
  • Avoid adding to the job or changing your mind halfway through - it will usually cost more and cause delays. Confirm any changes you make in writing.
  • If any problems arise while work is in progress or you're unhappy about anything, talk to your builder straight away.
What happens if things still go wrong?
The Consumers' Association offers a legal service to members and advice on finding a good builder. If you feel work has not been completed properly, you can go to the small claims court to recover costs less than £5,000.

fields.headline: England enter last-chance saloon
fields.trailText: England are still babies at floodlit cricket and again fell at the final hurdle. This was no dismal defeat but they are running out of chances to make good the errors of the past.
fields.body:
England's all-rounders are lighting up this tournament in a way that they singularly failed to do during the World Cup. Last Sunday was the day of that "pasty-faced pie thrower" Mark Ealham, today it was the turn of Mark Alleyne. He shovelled his way to 53, the second-highest score of the match, took three (albeit expensive) wickets, and one astonishing, diving, sliding catch to get rid of the pesky Jonty Rhodes. Even more importantly, he managed to rile Lance Klusener - hitting him for ten in two balls and bowling him (after he had looked like he might completely ruin Andy Caddick's evening) with a low, slow, full-toss.

But for all Alleyne's efforts, England again fell at the final hurdle. Not that it was a dismal defeat; on the contrary it was a rip-roaring, bodice-ripper of a match which brought the East London crowd to life. But it revealed that the problems that have dogged England throughout this tour, rest with them still.

All of the top five made it to double-figures, but only Nick Knight got more than 22. England aren't going to win games like that. Vikram Solanki, for all his wristy grace (and he did hit two stunning fours in his ten), has perhaps only one more match to stake a permanent claim, before he returns home to face Mark Ramprakash, Graham Thorpe and the vaguaries of domestic selection. Let's hope he's on the phone to Michael Vaughan tonight, getting tips on how to pull it off at the last mintute.

This was the third one-dayer England have played under lights during this tournament, and the third they have lost. And they can't blame the fact that they had to bat in the dusk this time. For all the cohesiveness, eagerness and quick-silver fielding of Hussian's England, they are babies at floodlit cricket and have to play at 110% to beat a full-strength South Africa or even Zimbabwe - for whom day-nighters are old hat. Unfair, but a legacy of misdemeanours by past England administrators.

England can, of course, still make it to the finals. Their last game is on Wednesday against Zimbabwe. And, whisper it, they have a chance - it is played under the sort of light they like, the sun.

fields.trailText: Beowulf, son of Ecgtheow, helps Hrothgar, son of Halfdene, against Grendel, a God-cursed brute. Beowulf gets old, gets killed. Wiglaf, son of Weohstan, cremates him, as ordered.
fields.body:
Hrothgar, son of Halfdene, was favoured in war,
and ordered men to build a great mead hall.
It was named Heorot, but a grim demon, Grendel was his name, a descendent of Cain,
a God-cursed brute, struck the hall again and again, grabbed men and butchered their corpses.
One day from across the sea, Beowulf, son of Ecgtheow, came from the land of the Geats, owing allegiance to Lord Hygelac, to help fight this grim demon.
Unferth, son of Ecglaf, being contrary said:
"Are you the Beowulf who took on Breca
in a swimming match on the open sea,
risking the water just to prove you could win?"
Beowulf, Ecgtheow's son, replied, "Friend,
you're letting the beer do the talking.
The truth is this, I'm a strong swimmer,
and although it wore me out I landed safe.
I cannot recall any fight you entered, Unferth,
son of Ecglaf, that bears comparison,
not that I'm boasting."
God-cursed Grendel came, but Beowulf was granted the power of winning, and Grendel gave a God-cursed scream. No one regretted
his fatal departure. Grendel's mother,
monstrous hell-bride, came for revenge.
Alas, Aeschere, Yremenlaf's elder brother and Hrothgar's soul-mate, was killed.
Beowulf, son of Ecgtheow, promised to
avenge the death. The hero went to the lairs
of water-monsters, observed that swamp-thing from hell, a lifeless corpse.
Beowulf cut the corpse's head off.
Hrothgar, elated, praised the Geat:
"Oh flower of warriors, do not give way to pride.
Choose eternal rewards." And so, the grey-haired Dane, the high-born king, kissed Beowulf,
gave him gifts, and Beowulf, glorious
in his gold regalia, journeyed home.
Fifty years passed, as time does. The wide
kingdom, reverted to Beowulf, son of Ecgtheow.
He ruled well, until the treasure of a dragon,
was disturbed. The dragon, was angry, was destructive. Beowulf spoke, boasted
for the last time: "I risked my life often
when I was young. Now I am old."
Time had not taught the son of Ecgtheow.
Beowulf fought and fate denied him
glory in battle. The glittering sword,
infallible before that day, failed him.
Wiglaf, son of Weohstan, went to his aid.
The king dealt the dragon a deadly blow,
but poison suppurated inside him, killed him.
In his final breath, he gave to Wiglaf,
the last of the Waegmundings, his helmet.
With no heir, the son of Ecgtheow, by the son
of Weohstan, was cremated, as ordered.

webTitle: Dome struggles to meet visitor targets

fields.headline: Dome struggles to meet visitor targets
fields.standfirst: But it is still on course to break even say bosses
fields.trailText: The Millennium Dome attracted 366,420 visitors in its first month, just 3% of the original break-even figure of 12 million for the whole of 2000.
fields.body:
The Millennium Dome attracted 366,420 visitors in its first month, just 3% of the original break-even figure of 12 million for the whole of 2000.

Dome organisers were anxious to put a positive spin on the figures, although the New Millennium Experience (NMEC) also confirmed it had applied to the Millennium Commission for an additional repayable grant of "up to £60 million" to deal with a cash-flow shortage.

It attributed the cash shortfall to sponsors failing to pay up as scheduled rather than the disappointing visitor figures, which included 21,800 schoolchildren on free visits and other non-paying guests.

"Not a bad result," was NMEC managing director Liam Kane's verdict. He said the number of admissions in January was something "that any leisure attraction in the UK would cut off its right hand for".

Given the sluggish January tourist season, the Dome could have been expected to attract between 2.5% and 3% of its annual total in its first month and had, in fact, reached just over 3%.

"This, and the published polls on demand, show that the Dome remains on course to attract 12 million visitors in the year," said Mr Kane.

The Dome could break even with 10 million admissions, the NMEC now calculates, if each visitor spent £4 in retail outlets at the Dome, £4 on eating and drinking and paid an average of just over £13 for an admission ticket.

Mr Kane said he expected business at the Dome to pick up along with other tourist attractions in the summer months with a further peak in the autumn as people rush to visit it before it closes.

Dome organisers also took heart from a new Mori poll which showed that 82% of visitors were either very or fairly satisfied with their day out.

However, only 16% of people said they would definitely return to visit the attraction again. In addition, 11% of visitors were either very or fairly dissatisfied with their visit and 19% thought the trip was either very poor or fairly poor in terms of value for money.

The poll showed that residents of London and the south-east of England accounted for 55% of visitors, while overseas tourists accounted for 11%. Just 2% of visitors were from Wales, 2% from Northern Ireland and 7% from Scotland.

fields.headline: No surrender
fields.standfirst:
Derek Brown explains why the IRA is unlikely to hand over its weapons any time soon
Plus: New Labour losers
fields.trailText: Derek Brown explains why the IRA is unlikely to hand over its weapons any time soon
fields.body:
Tim Pat Coogan, ex-editor of the Irish Press and elder statesman of the Irish pundit fraternity, has spend much of his adult life in earnest study of the Republican movement in general and the IRA in particular. He has written one of the best accounts of that army, and knows what he is talking about.

On Channel Four last night, he offered a characteristically coherent explanation of why the Provisionals are adamantly refusing to disarm. First, he said, the IRA considers that since it has not been defeated, there is no reason to give up its weapons. Second, they are afraid of a potentially bloody schism. Third - following on from the last point - they want to protect themselves.

All these arguments are very logical. But where we must differ from Coogan is that he, like the IRA, evidently considers them to be reasonable - which is not as other parties involved would see them.

The barrack-lawyer issue of defeat and surrender is irrelevant, because the Good Friday deal is not couched in those terms. Nobody is suggesting that the IRA hands over its arsenal to the British or for that matter the Irish authorities. Rather, it is required to put the weapons out of harm's way, in neutral hands. Hence the convoluted language of decommissioning.

The argument about splitting the movement is also silly, for it has already happened. The IRA is an infinitely divisible beast. The Provisionals, self-anointed in 1970, are themselves a breakaway movement.

Since their ceasefire, two new little backstreet armies have formed: the Real IRA, responsible for the Omagh atrocity, and its more obscure cousins, the Continuity IRA. Lurking in the Ulster mists are the Irish National Liberation Army and, no doubt, a handful of wrinkly adherents of the old Official IRA. The potential for internecine strife is alarming, but it is inevitable.

The case for self-protection is therefore self-evident. But nobody in their right minds expects the Provisionals to declare, let alone give up, all their weapons. It cannot be enshrined in writing, but of course the IRA will retain the means to protect itself and even, God forbid, resume its campaign. That's the real world.

What is intolerable is that the IRA does nothing at all. The same goes for the ragbag of loyalist private armies. They may sift through the fine print of Good Friday all they like, but the plain fact is that peace cannot coexist with self-appointed paramilitary armies. The continuance of an armed ceasefire is simply not enough.

Related documentary
Northern Ireland: special report

New Labour losers

Labour's stunning defeat in yesterday's Ceredigion byelection is a timely reminder that its stranglehold over the House of Commons is both artificial and vulnerable. In 1997 it secured a majority of 179 with just 44% of the votes cast. That is a searing indictment of our electoral system. It is also a measure of how desperate the voters were to dismiss the Conservatives. Labour and Liberal supporters alike voted for whichever candidate was most likely to defeat a sitting Tory. That is not going to happen again.

Ceredigion is hardly a typical constituency, but the message it has sent to Downing Street and Millbank is plain: Labour is going to fight the next election not as an irresistible force, but more as a desperate defensive exercise. The victory of Plaid Cymru's Simon Thomas is a signal of a surging nationalism which could cost the ruling party dearly in Scotland as well as Wales. Labour's miserable fourth place, behind the Liberal Democrats and Conservatives, is also the clearest possible confirmation that the ruling party will lose massively in rural constituencies.

It is healthy for democracy for governments to be reminded from time to time that their authority is temporary. It would be healthier still if some at least of those Labour MPs, who must know now that their time in the Commons is limited, would use that time to remind their front bench that their party is supposed to represent Labour, and not Capital.

Devolution in Wales: special report

webTitle: Human rights breakthrough as African ex-dictator is indicted

fields.headline: Human rights breakthrough as African ex-dictator is indicted
fields.trailText: Human rights groups broke new ground with yesterday's indictment of Hissene Habre, the former president of Chad, in a case with close parallels to that of General Augusto Pinochet of Chile.
fields.body:
Human rights groups broke new ground with yesterday's indictment of Hissene Habre, the former president of Chad, in a case with close parallels to that of General Augusto Pinochet of Chile.

Mr Habre was placed under house arrest and charged yesterday in Senegal with acts of torture and barbarity, the first time a former African head of state has been indicted in another country for human rights offences.

"This is a stunning victory for the Chadian people and for torture victims all over the world," said Reed Brody, advocacy director of Human Rights Watch, one of the organisations which initiated the criminal action last week.

"The indictment is a wake-up call to dictators in Africa and elsewhere, that if they commit similar atrocities they could also be brought to justice one day."

Judge Demba Kandji of the Dakar regional court indicted the former Chadian leader after hearing the testimony of six of Mr Habre's victims and receiving information regarding hundreds of other crimes. The move opens the way for Mr Habre's trial, possibly later this year.
