fields.headline: Obituary: Francis Stuart
fields.standfirst: Irish novelist caught between forces of nationalism, communism, Protestantism and the Catholic church
fields.trailText: Irish novelist caught between forces of nationalism, communism, Protestantism and the Catholic church
fields.body:
Henry Francis Montgomery Stuart, writer, born April 29 1902; died February 2 2000.
The Irish writer Francis Stuart, who has died aged 97, was a complex and controversial figure, whose devotion to imaginative fiction led him to live against the tide of convention. Pursuing, as he saw it, the primacy of the interior, private experience over the wider civic responsibility, he spent adventurous times, including working for both the IRA and the Nazis, and - as a much older man - flirting with extreme Protestantism in Ulster.

He believed in getting close to the action and was attracted to the energising inspiration of political violence as a spur to creativity - a character trait he shared with Graham Greene. He wrote 20 novels, two plays about political violence and many fine poems.

Stuart was born in Queensland, Australia, of sheep-farming immigrant parents from Ulster Protestant stock, and his father died in a mental asylum. An education at Rugby left him with a detestation of imperial manners and trappings, although he went on to study at Trinity College, Dublin, then a staunchly pro-British and Protestant university. At 18, he was in the company of the painter and mystic George Russell and WB Yeats, who thought him "a dunce". In 1919, he married Iseult Gonne, daughter of Maud Gonne, the inspiration for many of Yeat's poems of unrequited love, and a militant suffragette and republican.

During the Irish civil war, he edited leaflets and ran messages for De Valera's republicans, and was subsequently imprisoned. One of the compelling scenes in a later novel is that of an attempted break-out from his concentration camp. As the guards fire over the prisoners' heads, one stands up and survives the fusillades. It was an image that would become a metaphor for Stuart's own life.

On release, he published his first poetry collection, We Have Kept The Faith, which gave him status among revolutionary intellectuals - although Yeats continued to snub him. He worked underground for De Valera's cause, only to experience disillusion when his leader acceded to power and suppressed his former comrades - leaving Stuart and a handful of dissidents without a political base.

Stuart pursued his artistic ambitions in rural County Wicklow, where he lived with Iseult Gonne and their children, writing 10 novels in as many years. Few made money, though one, The Pillar Of Cloud, was critically acclaimed. He became a keen devotee of country life and a follower of steeple-chasing, losing money in gambling.

When his marriage crumbled in 1939, Stuart moved to Berlin as a lecturer, a post facilitated by a German academic talent-spotting for the Abwehr, or German military intelligence. Stuart, in many respects so absorbed with his own interior journey as to be politically naive, also doubled as a courier for the IRA, then being directed by the Abwehr to become a fifth-column unit in the war against Britain.

Though ostensibly lecturing on Anglo-Irish history for German radio, Stuart became part of the Nazi war effort, and wrote scripts for Lord Haw Haw (William Joyce). His other mission, to buy arms for IRA units in Ireland, allegedly fell foul of his own temperament, when, according to one version, the money was spent on champagne and flowers for a Russian dancer.

In fact, Russian sympathies were to be his undoing. Initially attracted to Hitler's promise of a new social order, Stuart was dismissed by the radio service when he refused to write anti-Soviet propaganda after the collapse of the Hitler-Stalin pact. He was later to say that communism was the only cause he could respect at the end of the war because of the sufferings of the Russian people. He was interned again, this time by the Allies.

Out of the war came more novels, notably The Pillar Of Cloud and Redemption - and the latter name became a theme for much of his subsequent work, in which the protagonist is often in a dream-like state, encountering random violence followed by salvation, in a threatening landscape, usually by the love of a strong woman.

During the 1950s, Stuart lived in London with his new German wife, Madeleine. In 1957, they returned to Ireland, where he struggled for a literary livelihood. But his German years continued to dog him. Reviews of reprints of his earlier work and media profiles were laudatory, but eventually focused on his war experiences and led to controversy. A play he submitted to the Abbey Theatre was rejected. The award, by the Irish Arts Council, as a saoi, or visionary, provoked a resignation from the award- giving body.

Even in his 90s, Stuart refused to recant his Hitler sympathies, although he did modify his previously published views, saying that he wished no offence to relatives of Holocaust victims. Of the novels, Black List: Section H is likely to survive as a work of Kafkaesque darkness. It mixed elements of the German years with forays into fantasia, and is probably the truest reflection of Stuart's own meandering, instinctive life journey.

Madeleine died in 1986, and the following year, aged 85, Stuart married the artist Finola Graham. He is survived by a son and daughter by his first wife.

Richard Pine writes: As a writer, Stuart was predominantly a novelist, with fiercely and uncompromisingly autobiographical works such as Black List: Section H (1971) to his credit, but he was also distinguished as a poet and essayist. His credo was: "Better to be carried away in any direction, and become a prodigal son or lost sheep, than not be carried away at all." He prized individual conscience yet craved the "natural and recognised roots" that fate and his own penchant for disaster denied him.

The ambiguous title of his early poems, We Have Kept The Faith, characterised his career as a non-joiner who converted to Roman Catholicism, as a thrice-married man who had numerous affairs, as a gambler in search of a home. Yet everything Stuart wrote came out of his own life, painfully chronicling his relationships, his addiction to the turf and his dismay at the downward curve of civilisation.

Certainly, if Stuart was at all attracted by fascism, he was in the same company as Yeats, Eliot and Pound in their concern for a unity of culture, for an élitist concept of civilisation in the age of the masses. His main platform was for Irish neutrality, which made him anti-British from an Irish nationalist point of view, but never pro-Nazi.

His reputation will rest on the fate of five books: the remarkable trilogy of Pillar Of Cloud (1948), Redemption (1949) and The Flowering Cross (1950), Black List: Section H, and The High Consistory (1981). The honesty and courage with which they are written, and the intensity with which he approached the themes of faith, conscience, deviance and submission, single him out as a writer who acknowledged that the artist is an outsider, not only because society excludes him, but because he has rejected society's values.

He worked underground for De Valera's cause, only to experience disillusion when his leader acceded to power and suppressed his former comrades - leaving Stuart and a handful of dissidents without a political base. Stuart pursued his artistic ambitions in rural County Wicklow, where he lived with Iseult Gonne and their children, writing 10 novels in as many years. Few made money, though one, The Pillar Of Cloud, was critically acclaimed. He became a keen devotee of country life and a follower of steeple-chasing, losing money in gambling. When his marriage crumbled in 1939, Stuart moved to Berlin as a lecturer, a post facilitated by a German academic talent-spotting for the Abwehr, or German military intelligence. Stuart, in many respects so absorbed with his own interior journey as to be politically naive, also doubled as a courier for the IRA, then being directed by the Abwehr to become a fifth-column unit in the war against Britain. Though ostensibly lecturing on Anglo-Irish history for German radio, Stuart became part of the Nazi war effort, and wrote scripts for Lord Haw Haw (William Joyce). His other mission, to buy arms for IRA units in Ireland, allegedly fell foul of his own temperament, when, according to one version, the money was spent on champagne and flowers for a Russian dancer. In fact, Russian sympathies were to be his undoing. Initially attracted to Hitler's promise of a new social order, Stuart was dismissed by the radio service when he refused to write anti-Soviet propaganda after the collapse of the Hitler-Stalin pact. He was later to say that communism was the only cause he could respect at the end of the war because of the sufferings of the Russian people. He was interned again, this time by the Allies. Out of the war came more novels, notably The Pillar Of Cloud and Redemption - and the latter name became a theme for much of his subsequent work, in which the protagonist is often in a dream-like state, encountering random violence followed by salvation, in a threatening landscape, usually by the love of a strong woman. During the 1950s, Stuart lived in London with his new German wife, Madeleine. In 1957, they returned to Ireland, where he struggled for a literary livelihood. But his German years continued to dog him. Reviews of reprints of his earlier work and media profiles were laudatory, but eventually focused on his war experiences and led to controversy. A play he submitted to the Abbey Theatre was rejected. The award, by the Irish Arts Council, as a saoi, or visionary, provoked a resignation from the award- giving body. Even in his 90s, Stuart refused to recant his Hitler sympathies, although he did modify his previously published views, saying that he wished no offence to relatives of Holocaust victims. Of the novels, Black List: Section H is likely to survive as a work of Kafkaesque darkness. It mixed elements of the German years with forays into fantasia, and is probably the truest reflection of Stuart's own meandering, instinctive life journey. Madeleine died in 1986, and the following year, aged 85, Stuart married the artist Finola Graham. He is survived by a son and daughter by his first wife. Richard Pine writes: As a writer, Stuart was predominantly a novelist, with fiercely and uncompromisingly autobiographical works such as Black List: Section H (1971) to his credit, but he was also distinguished as a poet and essayist. His credo was: "Better to be carried away in any direction, and become a prodigal son or lost sheep, than not be carried away at all." He prized individual conscience yet craved the "natural and recognised roots" that fate and his own penchant for disaster denied him. The ambiguous title of his early poems, We Have Kept The Faith, characterised his career as a non-joiner who converted to Roman Catholicism, as a thrice-married man who had numerous affairs, as a gambler in search of a home. Yet everything Stuart wrote came out of his own life, painfully chronicling his relationships, his addiction to the turf and his dismay at the downward curve of civilisation. Certainly, if Stuart was at all attracted by fascism, he was in the same company as Yeats, Eliot and Pound in their concern for a unity of culture, for an élitist concept of civilisation in the age of the masses. His main platform was for Irish neutrality, which made him anti-British from an Irish nationalist point of view, but never pro-Nazi. His reputation will rest on the fate of five books: the remarkable trilogy of Pillar Of Cloud (1948), Redemption (1949) and The Flowering Cross (1950), Black List: Section H, and The High Consistory (1981). The honesty and courage with which they are written, and the intensity with which he approached the themes of faith, conscience, deviance and submission, single him out as a writer who acknowledged that the artist is an outsider, not only because society excludes him, but because he has rejected society's values.

webTitle: Neil Jordan, Ralph Fiennes and Stephen Woolley - part three

fields.headline: Neil Jordan, Ralph Fiennes and Stephen Woolley - part three
fields.standfirst: Questions: Added value | Julianne's character | Universal themes | Bendrix's suffering | Certification | The love scenes | Irrationality | Chronology | Working relationships | Ralph and production | Improvisation | Catholicism | Filming churches
fields.trailText: Part three of the Neil Jordan, Ralph Fiennes and Stephen Woolley interview at BFI Southbank
fields.body:
Question 1: I didn't like the movie. I found it melodramatic and boring. What added value did you bring to the book?

NJ: I didn't want to add anything, I thought it would be taxed afterwards. I thought I'd get VAT [Laughter]. It's hard to say, you want to make a movie because you respond to it instinctively. I can only disagree with you but your opinion is... valuable... definitely. [Laughter] But it's hard to say... when I see the movie I obviously like it otherwise I wouldn't be releasing it.

Questioner: But what did you add that is new?

NJ: The scene in Brighton! [Laughter]

Question 2: How do you feel about Julianne's character being the only woman in the book?

NJ: For me it was interesting to be dealing with a portrait of a woman who was uninformed by any contemporary ideas and is uninformed by any ideas of sexual politics or of empowerment, everything that goes with the gender conversation these days, but I just felt that Greene's portrait of that lady was actually very accurate and it was incredibly simple in a deep way and very true and what interested me was the way she went from this world of sexuality into this world of something other after this traumatic event.

I found it very true and I responded to it very much and that's what I was looking for in the casting of the film and I've always found Julianne in the roles that she's played - there's such an honesty and a directness to the way she approaches the material whatever it is - something as raw as Boogie Nights or as subtle as what she played in the Louis Malle film, Vanya on 42nd Street.

She always seems to get beyond the surface aspects of the character into something quite simple and quite deep and that's what I wanted for that role.

Question 3: What is the universal theme that makes the film so moving?

RF: What I'm going to say is a bit of a truism, but I think there is something about white light shining through celluloid and showing actors' faces, human emotions coming through faces. When they are emotions that you recognise, when you believe in them and when they are phrased and put in a certain order they have the power on the screen to conjure up some quite unusual responses. That is why there is a cult of film, there is something unique about film.

And I think that telling stories in films, even if we've seen them before, we might have seen love affairs before, we might have seen murder stories before, but there seems to be something inherently addictive about it and I think that when all the bits of it are put together, music, text, image, light, when they're in a harmony through the director they can move you.

I think that it's a phenomenon, I don't think it's very easy to put succinctly why it has a universality. People fall in love, people have affairs, people die, people make war, people are jealous and I think that if the film has worked for you I would suggest it's because you recognise some fundamental truths in it yourself through it being projected on a screen.

NJ: There is something deeply uncontemporary about the affair and that's what I loved about it. The way in which they were forced to confront something that they couldn't explain. I don't think anybody who's had any deep contact, sexual or otherwise, with a human being ever loses it. I think a lot of people never survive the depth of affection, whether it be a parent, or a lover or a wife, and the way in which Greene pushed the question of the whole meaning of those relationships to bring up an idea as unfashionable as a God, or a destiny, I found very moving and worth re-examining. I think there is something quite true in what he wrote and I hope we've got something of that truth onto the screen.

SW: On a simple level I think that all of us would like to turn the clock back and look at the events that happened around relationships where you could chart back and say, "Oh my God, that was the point when it worked, when it didn't work, when it could have gone on, when it stopped". Why I feel rewarded by this fantastic film that Neil has made is that moment when you start to read the diary, you start to see the same scenes repeated and with a different aspect, for me that's dream-like and that's why it's very universal.

All of us would love to look back on a moment in their lives when someone has acted in some way untoward or seemingly cruelly and we don't get a chance to do that, to step back and re-see something that's gone wrong from the other person's point of view. I think that's what's absolutely fascinating about the film, and what makes the film absolutely moving for me is that you're suddenly in this other person's head after we've spent all this time in Bendrix's head. Suddenly the emphasis shifts to Sarah's head and her story. The story is written twice from two different perspectives and I think that's why people tend to go back to see it again and again.

Question 4: Is there a parallel between Onegin's suffering and Bendrix's suffering?

RF: I keep being asked why I'm always playing these tortured lovers [Laughter], and I can see honestly that there is an emotional constipation in both parts maybe. Certainly Onegin doesn't want to acknowledge his emotions, he's very detached to begin with from his feelings and they seep through during the course of the story but Bendrix - in my head anyway - he's someone who is venting his feelings onto the page, but he's not demonstrative of them to other people.

He's wearing a kind of mask when he meets Henry, he's playing another role of the benign friend and in that sense there is probably a connection in that they both carry a mask to a certain extent. But I do think that Bendrix privately is very connected to his feelings and Onegin isn't.

Question 5: Will the ruling on the certification of the film be overruled?

SW: I think that this has been such an issue now that I don't think so. I remember seeing Polanski's Macbeth at school for my English O-level. It had a fantastic effect on me. I loved it, I just thought it was incredible and I couldn't believe how great it was. I was studying this brilliant, sexy violent... all the things that were great about Macbeth are in Polanski's movie and it really fired me on. I think that it's so high-profile, this censorship thing, that this current board are going to walk away from this, they're not going to step down because they would look very foolish now.

So I think the only chance now is when this film is released on video there might be a way of cajoling, but I think that unless we cut the film there's going to be little chance of us getting anything below an 18. And it's ironic because Shakespeare in Love had a 15 certificate and yet that seemed to have the same combination of things that we have. But if you're 16 or 17 you can get into a 18 film. [Laughter] But it's not really about that, it's about the messages that that certification sends.

Question 6: Why did you make the love scenes so explicit when they weren't like that at all in the book?

NJ: It's a deeply erotic book. One of the things that surprised me was when I re-read it was that most erotic novels are written by women and very young men and this was an erotic novel written by a 42-year-old Englishman. That was part of the attraction for me for this thing and Greene has written an extraordinary thing. There is an enormous amount of sex in the book, it's perhaps not described in terms that you get in the book, but actually there is an enormous amount of quite graphic description in the novel itself.

That line, "You wouldn't recognise the sound" that we have a start of the film, that's straight from the middle of the book and in her diary in the novel she talks about how he touches her the way no-one else touches her, and Greene talks about orgasm quite beautifully with this terrible sense of loss. We had to show things I think otherwise it wouldn't have been an affair. And I think we had to show them quite bleakly in a way, because there is something bleak about that kind of passion somehow.

Question 7: Neil said that the irrational is very relevant to contemporary life and that's what drew you to the book. Would you elaborate on that?

NJ: I don't know what I meant by that [Laughter]. But I do know that I am drawn to stories where people do not fully understand the reasons for their actions and I don't know why that is. It's probably because I don't believe people do fully understand the reasons for their actions. I always think of Thomas Hardy. When his second wife died he lived to be a very old man and then he suddenly got this tremendous sense of longing for the woman he married when he was 19 or 20.

It's one of the most irrational bursts of poetry in the whole of literature really and I think that the emotions that affect us, particularly to do with sexuality, I do not believe that anyone understands them - President Clinton definitely doesn't understand them [Laughter] and I don't think Sigmund Freud understood them. I think that they exist in that strange realm somewhere beyond understanding and art in a way. I do think Greene touched on it. I'm not as tortured about religion as he was, I described it to myself as a battle between rationality and something else.

Question 8: Does the complexity of the chronology, particularly in the first half distance you from an emotional involvement with the characters?

NJ: There is a danger when you deal with two time frames and particularly when you deal with two different perspectives, of totally confusing people. But I don't think distance is a bad thing, people speak about lack of emotional engagement with characters as a bad thing but I'm not sure it's a bad thing. Some of the films that I really do love deeply are quite austere movies. I'm also tired of the over-emotionalism of, particularly, Hollywood cinema. I don't think that it's a bad thing that you can sit and make your mind up about these characters, that you can sit and have some distance from them. That was part of what I wanted about this film. Some people won't like it but...

SW: That wasn't an issue with the studio absolutely not, but I think the point of the movie is that you have to unravel it and I think that one of the things that is a joy about the film is that when Bendrix reads Sarah's diary the penny drops, it's true people who like the movie keep going back to see it again because they realised they've missed an aspect of it.

Question 9: Did you shoot the movie in the same way events are recorded in the book?

NJ: We didn't shoot it any kind of sequence at all. On films there's often basic facts of production, like we had to build an enormous set for Henry's interior so we basically shot everything that was in that interior first, in this case the entire relationship as it's played out in the series of drawing rooms and bedrooms of Henry's house. We went through the film from beginning to end without approaching an exterior so it was almost a tiny play of the entire movie.

SW: It's just financially and logistically impossible to keep returning to locations, because on a film like this, you're constantly seeing the same location and the same set but the action is taking place in a different way. You can't just keep closing the streets of London down, they don't like you closing them down anyway, they hate you to be honest - quite rightly in some respects I suppose. Middleton Square, where we shot the Smythe exterior, in which we come back to in many different ways. We shot all that at once so that's how you have to make films, unfortunately.

Question 9: How do you work so well?

NJ: I met Stephen after I'd made Angel. I was a novelist, I hope I still am. Angel was the first movie I made and it was about political violence in the north of Ireland. I didn't know what I'd made and Stephen saw it at Cannes and he rang me up and I came over here to meet him and at that time he'd set up Palace Pictures and his enthusiasm for film I found quite overwhelming and we then went and made A Company of Wolves together. We just kept working together really...

SW: The interesting thing was, we never had a contract. It wasn't like I signed Neil up for a three-picture deal or anything like that, or we said we'd make films together. The things Neil liked I tended to like, Angela Carter for instance. That was a great thing for us to work with Angela and to make that film, it was a wonderful experience for me. Similarly with Mona Lisa, the kind of subjects we were attracted to were quite similar so it never felt like uncomfortable, it wasn't as if, "Oh I have to make the horrible Butcher Boy or the terrible Michael Collins".

It was great, what a joy that we can make these quite strange, somewhat subversive pieces of entertainment and how lucky we are to do that. We have a new company now called A Company of Wolves which DreamWorks are funding. It's basically a development company where we're looking for projects and now we do have a signed deal so I should think that the next announcement is that it's all over. [Laughter]. We've actually signed a piece of paper for the first time to produce and direct future projects so I... I've just read that Neil's signed a deal to do a project with Salman Rushdie so that's the end of it anyway [Laughter].

AW: You dipped your toes into production with Onegin. Are you going to do any more producing?

RF: Yes, but I wouldn't undertake it lightly. I think as an actor I was quite protected from putting a production on, you have no idea unless you've been on the production side. I was quite ignorant about the level of work and time that had to go into nurturing a film and to put the elements of production together. I have a completely different regard for producers and directors and I don't think the public really know the hours and the detailed structuring that has to go on. I think I would have to feel very strongly about something to want to do it again.

Question 10: How much freedom did Neil give Ralph to improvise?

I suppose we didn't improvise much if at all. It never came up. I always felt that the dialogue was superb and it was beautifully written and I think in the early stages I suggested that one or two lines didn't seem right but that was a very subjective response but actually in shooting... if Neil had said to me "Improvise" or "Change it" or "That doesn't sound good" then I would have done it, but I think I took my cue from him.

If I had felt that the dialogue wasn't sitting I would have probably have asked to change things in the moment of shooting it, but it never really came up. I have improvised on films before and I've been encouraged to do so by the director and quite enjoyed, but I think that if he or she and the actor doesn't want you to I think it has to be set up by the director in the first place. In this case it was a path Neil never chose to go down and I went with him.

AW: Is the theme of Catholicism what appealed to you in The End of the Affair?

NJ: Of course, Greene being an English Catholic convert - which means Protestant [Laughter] and me being a Irish Catholic - which means doomed [Laughter] it's for me who grew up with that stuff. Irish Catholicism is more to do with magic - it's a very superstitious set of lessons you learn when you're a child. It's quite easy to abandon them but they never leave your sensibility, so for me to see someone grappling with these problems of faith and believability which he had encountered in his early 20s - and he had a very dubious relationship to them all his life - I think he liked the cruelty of Catholicism in a strange way.

He liked the way it implied punishment but it was a punishment deferred. And I found it fascinating to encounter his encounter with those set of ideas which I had encountered as a child but I think they were with him for his life as an intellectual construct and they've not been with me since I was 19 to be honest.

Question 11: Did Bendrix's repellent character appeal to you?

RF: They don't appeal to me as things I try to emulate in my own life. [Laughter]. I think dramatically, as an actor responding to a part, they're strong meat to play, they're what the part demands of an actor, they're just fantastic, just in terms of what you show, what you don't show, which scenes you get to play.

I take your point completely, he is manipulative, he is duplicitous, there is a smear of snobbery with the Smythe thing but I think he's an unhappy man and I think at the end, I don't think he's redeemed but I think something is opened up for him that he has never considered before. I think this friendship with Henry - and there's this tender moment of giving the milk and biscuits - I think that very slowly something is unlocked in Bendrix and I always feel that in the moment of looking at Lance's face at the end.

However much he's resisting it he can't ignore it and indeed the very last moment is "I hate you God, leave me alone forever", but the conceit of that is I think that for ever on Bendrix has a dialogue even if he's saying he hates him. So I think it's complicated but I don't think he's all the things you describe. There's other things moving on but I think Greene probably delighted in making him a bit repellent.

A friend of mine was reading the novel and saying "God, he is repellent" and this friend was laughing as she was reading so maybe we enjoy a villain taking us into our confidence. I don't think he is a villain but he is full of a negative quality yet he takes us - the viewer or the reader in - and I like that about it just from a dramatic point of view.

Question 12: You described your portrayal of sex as quite bleak, but the churches are quite sumptuous and seductive. Why did you do this?

NJ: I don't know... What I found interesting is the portrayal of passion in the novel itself, and as I made the movie, [I was thinking of] how spiritual transport in, say, Renaissance painting is portrayed - showing the human body in a state of sexual transport as well.

There is a logic to that, and if you go round churches you see these beautifully modelled torsos - mainly male. And to my mind they're not two sides to the same coin, but they belong together somehow in some way I'd like to understand. But I didn't actually mean to make the church beautiful.

We were actually looking at a very grey church. It was one of these huge grey interiors somewhere in Islington and I went downstairs and I found this tiny little chapel and it was full of all this gold and I just wanted a photograph there. Perhaps it is a bit too beautiful but I actually do like churches.

SW: It's just financially and logistically impossible to keep returning to locations, because on a film like this, you're constantly seeing the same location and the same set but the action is taking place in a different way. You can't just keep closing the streets of London down, they don't like you closing them down anyway, they hate you to be honest - quite rightly in some respects I suppose. Middleton Square, where we shot the Smythe exterior, in which we come back to in many different ways. We shot all that at once so that's how you have to make films, unfortunately. Question 9: How do you work so well? NJ: I met Stephen after I'd made Angel. I was a novelist, I hope I still am. Angel was the first movie I made and it was about political violence in the north of Ireland. I didn't know what I'd made and Stephen saw it at Cannes and he rang me up and I came over here to meet him and at that time he'd set up Palace Pictures and his enthusiasm for film I found quite overwhelming and we then went and made A Company of Wolves together. We just kept working together really... SW: The interesting thing was, we never had a contract. It wasn't like I signed Neil up for a three-picture deal or anything like that, or we said we'd make films together. The things Neil liked I tended to like, Angela Carter for instance. That was a great thing for us to work with Angela and to make that film, it was a wonderful experience for me. Similarly with Mona Lisa, the kind of subjects we were attracted to were quite similar so it never felt like uncomfortable, it wasn't as if, "Oh I have to make the horrible Butcher Boy or the terrible Michael Collins". It was great, what a joy that we can make these quite strange, somewhat subversive pieces of entertainment and how lucky we are to do that. We have a new company now called A Company of Wolves which DreamWorks are funding. It's basically a development company where we're looking for projects and now we do have a signed deal so I should think that the next announcement is that it's all over. [Laughter]. We've actually signed a piece of paper for the first time to produce and direct future projects so I... I've just read that Neil's signed a deal to do a project with Salman Rushdie so that's the end of it anyway [Laughter]. AW: You dipped your toes into production with Onegin. Are you going to do any more producing? RF: Yes, but I wouldn't undertake it lightly. I think as an actor I was quite protected from putting a production on, you have no idea unless you've been on the production side. I was quite ignorant about the level of work and time that had to go into nurturing a film and to put the elements of production together. I have a completely different regard for producers and directors and I don't think the public really know the hours and the detailed structuring that has to go on. I think I would have to feel very strongly about something to want to do it again. Question 10: How much freedom did Neil give Ralph to improvise? I suppose we didn't improvise much if at all. It never came up. I always felt that the dialogue was superb and it was beautifully written and I think in the early stages I suggested that one or two lines didn't seem right but that was a very subjective response but actually in shooting... if Neil had said to me "Improvise" or "Change it" or "That doesn't sound good" then I would have done it, but I think I took my cue from him. If I had felt that the dialogue wasn't sitting I would have probably have asked to change things in the moment of shooting it, but it never really came up. I have improvised on films before and I've been encouraged to do so by the director and quite enjoyed, but I think that if he or she and the actor doesn't want you to I think it has to be set up by the director in the first place. In this case it was a path Neil never chose to go down and I went with him. AW: Is the theme of Catholicism what appealed to you in The End of the Affair? And I found it fascinating to encounter his encounter with those set of ideas which I had encountered as a child but I think they were with him for his life as an intellectual construct and they've not been with me since I was 19 to be honest. I think dramatically, as an actor responding to a part, they're strong meat to play, they're what the part demands of an actor, they're just fantastic, just in terms of what you show, what you don't show, which scenes you get to play. I take your point completely, he is manipulative, he is duplicitous, there is a smear of snobbery with the Smythe thing but I think he's an unhappy man and I think at the end, I don't think he's redeemed but I think something is opened up for him that he has never considered before. I think this friendship with Henry - and there's this tender moment of giving the milk and biscuits - I think that very slowly something is unlocked in Bendrix and I always feel that in the moment of looking at Lance's face at the end. However much he's resisting it he can't ignore it and indeed the very last moment is "I hate you God, leave me alone forever", but the conceit of that is I think that for ever on Bendrix has a dialogue even if he's saying he hates him. So I think it's complicated but I don't think he's all the things you describe. There's other things moving on but I think Greene probably delighted in making him a bit repellent. A friend of mine was reading the novel and saying "God, he is repellent" and this friend was laughing as she was reading so maybe we enjoy a villain taking us into our confidence. I don't think he is a villain but he is full of a negative quality yet he takes us - the viewer or the reader in - and I like that about it just from a dramatic point of view. Question 12: You described your portrayal of sex as quite bleak, but the churches are quite sumptuous and seductive. Why did you do this? NJ: I don't know... What I found interesting is the portrayal of passion in the novel itself, and as I made the movie, [I was thinking of] how spiritual transport in, say, Renaissance painting is portrayed - showing the human body in a state of sexual transport as well. There is a logic to that, and if you go round churches you see these beautifully modelled torsos - mainly male. And to my mind they're not two sides to the same coin, but they belong together somehow in some way I'd like to understand. But I didn't actually mean to make the church beautiful. We were actually looking at a very grey church. It was one of these huge grey interiors somewhere in Islington and I went downstairs and I found this tiny little chapel and it was full of all this gold and I just wanted a photograph there. Perhaps it is a bit too beautiful but I actually do like churches.

fields.headline: Unknowns take centre stage
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: The immediate reaction when the names of most of Jörg Haider's ministers was made known last night was not one of astonishment or dismay: "Who?"
fields.byline: John Hooper  and  Kate Connolly  in Vienna
fields.body:
The immediate reaction when the names of most of Jörg Haider's ministers was made known last night was not one of astonishment or dismay: "Who?"

Even by the standards of a party which prides itself on its upstart status, the Freedom party contingent holding the balance of power in the new cabinet is distinguished principally by its obscurity and youthfulness

This immediately gave rise to a suspicion that Mr Haider had put forward second-rankers to guarantee his personal ascendancy over the incoming administration.

By far the best known of the new ministers is Suzanne Riess-Passer, who will be Austria's first woman vice-chancellor. Born in 1961, she has a PhD in law and has for some time played a key role in the Freedom party as press spokeswoman, administrative boss and Mr Haider's private secretary. Among colleagues she is known as "the king's cobra".

Karl Heinz Grasser, who will sit with Gordon Brown in the EU finance ministers' frequent meetings, is 31. The scion of a rich Carinthian family, he has an MBA and is said to be a specialist in EU affairs.

He is seen as being among those responsible for the Freedom party's modernisation in recent years. In 1993, he was made its general secretary. Soon afterwards, he became deputy governor of Carinthia province. But he fell out with Mr Haider after criticising him and left to join the management of a car supplies firm.

Herbert Scheibner, born in 1963, takes over the defence portfolio, and was the leader of the Freedom party's group in parliament. He first rose to prominence as a leader of the party's youth wing, which is widely regarded as being more extreme than the party itself. He is best known nationally as the man who organised Mr Haider's notorious anti-immigrant petition in the late 1980s. But he is now regarded as belonging to the more progressive wing of the party.

Elizabeth Sickl, who takes over the powerful social affairs ministry, is the third-ranking Freedom party member in a regional assembly. Michael Schmid, who gets the big-spending infrastructure department, is another virtual unknown from the provinces. Michael Krüger, the new justice minister, is a lawyer who was formerly cultural spokesman for the party.

The cabinet members in full are: Chancellor Wolfgang Schüssel (PP); vice-chancellor Susanne Riess-Passer (FP); foreign minister Benita Ferrero-Waldner (PP); finance minister Karl-Heinz Grasser (FP); economics minister Martin Bartenstein (PP); interior minister Ernst Strasser (PP); social affairs minister Elisabeth Sickl (FP); defence minister Herbert Scheibner (FP); education minister Elisabeth Gehrer (PP); infrastructure minister Michael Schmid (FP); justice minister Michael Krüger (FP); agriculture minister Wilhelm Molterer (FP).

The state secretaries are: Chancellery, Ulrike Baumgartner-Gabitzer (PP); finance, Stephan Koren (PP); health, Reinhart Waneck (FP); tourism, Mares Rossmann (FP).

fields.headline: Europe rallies against Haider coalition
fields.standfirst:
Austria in crisis Sanctions begin as far right enters government in Vienna, but signs of division emerge in EU

The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Austria began to pay the price for a government involving Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party last night as it faced immediate punitive measures from Europe and beyond.
fields.body:
Austria began to pay the price for a government involving Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party last night as it faced immediate punitive measures from Europe and beyond.

Even before the coalition was formed, Israel announced that Mr Haider would not be allowed to visit the Jewish state, and repeated that it was withdrawing its ambassador from Vienna.

Belgium warned that it too might recall its envoy - going beyond the headline-grabbing but limited diplomatic gestures threatened by Austria's 14 European Union partners on Monday.

"It's too simplistic to say we must keep Austria in Europe at all costs," argued the Belgian foreign minister, Louis Michel. "Europe can very well do without Austria. We don't need it."

In Brussels, the European parliament urged the EU to be ready to suspend the membership of any Austrian government if it made a "serious and persistent" breach of basic EU principles, as defined in the 1997 Amsterdam treaty.

But with signs of divisions emerging among the 14, and concerns about the future functioning of the EU, some diplomats suggested that the quarantine on Austria could be lifted in six months if the Freedom party behaved itself.

France announced it was postponing a visit to Vienna by senior defence officials who had been due to discuss the European defence initiative. Danish diplomats pulled out of a dinner scheduled by the Austrian embassy in Copenhagen.

The largest bank in the Netherlands, ABN Amro NV, said it was freezing its offer to help finance a controversial child support programme in Mr Haider's home province of Carinthia.

The project has already been criticised because it reportedly favours children of native Austrian parents and women who stay at home.

Britain broke its silence with comments from Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, who advocated a wait-and-see approach to decide how long the Austrian government would remain in quarantine. Its participation in the EU, he insisted, would not be affected by the bilateral moves.

He defended a "carefully measured signal" by the 14, which had helped produce yesterday's "declaration of European values" by Mr Haider and Wolfgang Schüssel, the People's party leader.

Tony Blair is understood to have agreed to the move by the 14 after a personal appeal from Thomas Klestil, the Austrian president, though the foreign office was concerned about the effect on the workings of the union.

Nicole Fontaine, president of the European parliament, dismissed the Schüssel-Haider declaration. "The fact that President Klestil is getting a declaration from this government on the fundamental values of the European Union will clearly not be able to make us forget the insulting, xenophobic and racist statement of Jörg Haider," she said.

"I can assure you that the parliament ... will be intransigent as regards respect of the principles of liberty, democracy, human rights and the rule of law."

The resolution was adopted by 406 votes for and 53 against, with 60 abstentions.

But one abstainer, the Irish Green MEP Patricia McKenna, told the house: "I wonder at the wisdom of trying to combat intolerance with intolerance. Is the Haider party getting more support because of the opposition of outside governments? You just wonder, is this actually feeding the flames of xenophobia?"

Glyn Ford, the British Labour MEP, said: "Some say that it is not right for us to interfere in Austrian politics. They are wrong. Some say we have to accept the outcome of democratic elections - but elections do not always make democrats."

Jewish groups were outspoken in their criticism of the Vienna agreement. The Nazi-hunting Simon Wiesenthal Centre said it was pulling out of a joint project with Austria on tolerance among youth while a group of Auschwitz concentration camp survivors called on President Klestil not to let the Freedom party into government.

In Paris, the Representative Council of Jewish Institutions in France called the development "intolerable" and a "political shame without precedent in Europe since the end of the second world war".

Leah Rabin, widow of the assassinated Israeli prime minister Yitzhak Rabin, said Mr Haider was "a sign that Austria had not yet come to terms with its fascist past".

She said: "Germany has done all it could to compensate, repair and remedy, and has faced up to that chapter in its history philosophically, psychologically and historically."

In Bulgaria, which is anxious to join the EU, the foreign minister, Nadezhda Mihailova, said the government "would not support an Austrian government which would close Europe's door and would stand against EU eastward enlargement."

But there was support for Mr Haider too. French rightwingers rallied outside the Austrian consulate in Lyon and attacked critical comments by the president, Jacques Chirac, and the prime minister, Lionel Jospin.

Swiss nationalists opposed to the government's plans for closer ties to the EU, declared that the campaign against Haider proved that the union was undemocratic.

In a brief ceremony in front of parliament in Berne, two small rightwing parties and other anti-European groups handed in a petition with some 70,000 signatures - more than enough to force a referendum - against a package of bilateral accords between Switzerland and the EU.

In Belgrade, the Serbian authorities also condemned the EU position on Austria. "All that is happening around Austria is only another example of interference in the internal affairs of other countries because it is obvious that anything is possible today in a Europe that serves America and not itself," said Ivica Dacic, a spokesman for Slobodan Milosevic's Socialist party.

fields.headline: Welsh poll blow for Labour
fields.trailText: Labour suffered a setback last night in the Ceredigion byelection, finishing fourth behind Plaid Cymru, the Liberal Democrats and the Conservatives respectively.
fields.body:
Labour suffered a setback last night in the Ceredigion byelection, finishing fourth behind Plaid Cymru, the Liberal Democrats and the Conservatives respectively.

The nationalists, as expected, held the Welsh-speaking rural seat where the turnout was 47%, a drop of 27.8% from 1997.

The seat was left vacant after sitting MP Cynog Dafis quit to concentrate on his work as a member of the Welsh assembly.

But Labour, which came second to Plaid Cymru at the general election, suffered after a campaign in which opposition parties sought to make the government's record on the rural economy a key issue.

The poll, in which Simon Thomas became the first new MP of the millennium, coincided with a prime ministerial "rural ride" to the west country amid escalating calls for more support from farmers.

In Wales, meanwhile, opposition parties have sought to capitalise on growing disarray in the new assembly, where Alun Michael's minority regime is facing accusations of selling the country short on European funding for its poorest areas. The first secretary faces a motion of no confidence.

Labour played down suggestions that the result amounted to an anti-government protest vote by the largely agricultural community.

Mr Thomas, 36, a rural community development manager, succeeds Mr Dafis, who had a 6,961 majority over Labour in 1997.

The result

  • Simon Thomas, Plaid Cymru: 10,716
  • Mark Williams, Liberal Democrat: 5,768
  • Paul Davies, Conservative 4,138
  • Maria Battle, Labour 3,612

webTitle: Hope of arrests in Lawrence case

fields.headline: Hope of arrests in Lawrence case
fields.standfirst: Race issues in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The detective responsible for pursuing the racist gang that murdered Stephen Lawrence raised hopes of fresh arrests yesterday after he hinted that his investigators were mining a seam of significant new information.
fields.body:
The detective responsible for pursuing the racist gang that murdered Stephen Lawrence raised hopes of fresh arrests yesterday after he hinted that his investigators were mining a seam of significant new information.

Detective Assistant Commissioner John Grieve, head of Scotland Yard's race and violent crimes task force, revealed officers had received a call after an appeal on last week's Crimewatch UK programme which had been "very useful".

Although Mr Grieve refused to go into details, he said the person who telephoned was "of great value and interest to us". In an unusual step, the breakthrough was made public and a statement released.

The open approach underlines the Met's commitment to find a way of securing convictions in a case which Sir Paul Condon, the outgoing commissioner, said had brought the force to near "meltdown".

Mr Grieve has been given resources to "explore all possible avenues and alternatives".

But the Met cannot afford another failed investigation into the death of the 18-year-old student, stabbed in Eltham, south-east London, on April 22 1993.

Three of the original suspects, Neil Acourt, Gary Dobson and Luke Knight, were cleared of his murder in 1996 when a private prosecution brought by Stephen's family failed. Proceedings against two others, David Norris and Jamie Acourt, were dropped at an early stage.

Mr Grieve said: "There are still people out there who have information and who could still get in touch with us. Whatever anyone says it is still possible to re-visit these offences. I do not hold the view that it is impossible legally to prosecute people with events connected to the night of Stephen's death and the surrounding circumstances."

Neil Acourt, Dobson and Knight cannot be prosecuted again for Stephen's murder. However, it might be possible to bring charges against several individuals in relation to Duwayne Brooks, who was with Stephen the night he died. Mr Brooks fled from the white gang which killed Stephen. He returned to the scene and watched helplessly as his close friend died from his wounds.

Mr Brooks's solicitor, Vicky Guedalla, said charges relating to Duwayne could prove the Met's best strategy. She said Duwayne had escaped a "potentially murderous attack".

"This would be more of a runner than a murder charge as it is not contaminated by the failure of the private prosecution. Our complaint throughout has been that [Mr Brooks] was stereotyped from the off. And that prevented anyone perceiving him as a surviving victim." Ms Guedalla said it was also possible that a sixth person was part of the gang that stabbed Stephen.

Sir William Macpherson's report into the failed murder inquiry concluded that Mr Brooks "was a primary victim of the racist attack. He is also the victim of all that has followed, including the conduct of the case and the treatment of himself as a witness and not as a victim."

webTitle: Personal mentors to be offered to all teenagers

fields.headline: Personal mentors to be offered to all teenagers
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Every teenager will be offered a personal "mentor" to advise them on issues that concern them, such as A-level choices and personal problems, in a multi-million pound government scheme launched yesterday.
fields.body:
Every teenager will be offered a personal "mentor" to advise them on issues that concern them, such as A-level choices and personal problems, in a multi-million pound government scheme launched yesterday.

An army of advisers will staff Connexions, a support service for those aged 13 to 19. It will help the estimated one in three teenagers who drop out of education or find themselves on the wrong career path.

It will create a single point of access for teenagers, who at present have to deal with up to eight agencies. Eventually Connexions could be on every high street and in every secondary school. It will tap the staff and resources of existing youth and career services, which cost about £450m a year.

Theresa May, shadow education secretary, said: "While schools are faced with sacking teachers, all David Blunkett can do is spend millions on a new army of bureaucrats. It is time he woke up to the real needs of schools and spent the money where it should be spent: in our classrooms."

At the scheme's launch at Tower Hamlets college, east London, Malcolm Wicks, lifelong learning minister, denied it was an extension of the nanny state. Ministers wanted to streamline the welfare state, to "oil the wheels of that complex structure and make it work".

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said schools had long been carrying out the roles of the new advisers. "The Connexions service needs a lean structure and minimum bureaucracy, and schools must be at the centre of delivering it."

webTitle: Performance pay plan set to split teachers

fields.headline: Performance pay plan set to split teachers
fields.standfirst:
Leaked draft reveals bonuses to turn on hard evidence of progress

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government was last night poised to split the teacher unions by tabling guidelines for performance pay, offering a £2,000 salary increase to experienced staff whose pupils got satisfactory marks over the past two or three years.
fields.body:
The government was last night poised to split the teacher unions by tabling guidelines for performance pay, offering a £2,000 salary increase to experienced staff whose pupils got satisfactory marks over the past two or three years.

According to confidential documents from the department for education and employment, teachers with at least seven years service will not pass the performance test if they cannot provide hard evidence of pupil progress, taking account of the type of children in their class.

The performance pay proposals are intended to trigger the most radical reform of the teaching profession for more than 50 years. In the first wave, at least 110,000 teachers are expected to qualify for a 10% pay rise, eventually lifting the maximum to £30,000 a year

DfEE officials are still working on the scheme, which is expected to be published next week and will start feeding through into pay packets in September. But according to the almost final draft, teachers will be expected to show pupils "attain good marks or grades in any relevant national tests or examinations, or school based assessment..."

Headteachers assessing whether staff should move up to a higher salary scale will be told to measure pupils' results against national and local yardsticks "for pupils in similar settings and circumstances".

Teachers will be expected to show they have made progress with pupils of different behaviour, background and ability. There should be "a pattern of consistent progress for the great majority of pupils relative to [their] prior attainment". But teachers will be able to plead extenuating circumstances if children are absent from tests or there is a high level of pupil turnover.

Measurement of pupils' progress is one of eight standards that teachers will have to meet. These include:

 Examples of how teachers help to set high expectations, build commitment, and work with pupils and colleagues "to make high expectations a reality".

 Evidence of up-to-date knowledge of their subject area and good practice in teaching it, showing they keep abreast of wider developments in teaching.

 Evidence of skills in teaching and assessment, including feedback from lessons and target-setting for pupils.

 Representative examples of pupils' progress "in relation to their prior attainment and expected progress".

 An account of how continuing professional development over the past two to three years has been applied at work and evidence of how their professional effectiveness helps the school achieve its targets.

The National Union of Teachers, the largest of the classroom unions, was last night preparing an all-out assault on the proposals. Doug McAvoy, the general secretary, said: "The government promised this would not be payment by results, but that is exactly what it is. It is a disastrous scheme and it is entirely unrealistic to expect teachers to compare their pupils' performance with national and local averages."

The union would try to get David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, to change his mind. "If not, our next step will be to join with the other teacher unions in a TUC campaign to stop this."

But Peter Smith, general secretary of the Association of Teachers and Lecturers, said: "This is a huge opportunity for teachers - the best in more than half a century. Schools exist to teach pupils and targets that had nothing to do with pupils' progress would appear bizarre to anyone in the out side world. Those who say they are going to boycott performance pay are not living in the real world."

Nigel de Gruchy, general secretary of the National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers, said Mr Blunkett was creating an unacceptably bureaucratic scheme requiring teachers to compile a mountain of evidence about their effectiveness, instead of demonstrating their competence in the classroom. It was "utterly absurd" that staff would get extra money "for being expert bidders instead of being good teachers".

But although some teachers would refuse to volunteer for assessment, it was unlikely the union would boycott a process that could bring extra money to members, Mr de Gruchy said.

Headteachers' leaders said they supported the plans, but worried about administrative overload. They think it might take a teacher three or four hours to make an application, but senior staff would need weeks to process the documentation for a large secondary school.

A DfEE spokesman said: "These are draft documents on which we are seeking informal views as part of our policy of involving the profession."

fields.headline: Down on the farm
fields.standfirst:
Romantic notions of rural hardship have been promoted by greedy landowners - but they are bogus

Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: Who started this "them and us" between town and country? The mis-named Countryside Alliance when they marched on London last year and later brayed outside the Labour party conference in Bournemouth.
fields.body:
Who started this "them and us" between town and country? The mis-named Countryside Alliance when they marched on London last year and later brayed outside the Labour party conference in Bournemouth.

Yesterday the prime minister went to Devon and blew their cover. They are not "the countryside". They are a bunch of Tory hunters and farmers who no more represent most country dwellers than red-braced commodity brokers in City champagne bars represent townies.

Blair has the facts on his side and he delivered a barrage of them yesterday: the countryside is doing pretty well. There is a farming crisis, there is real rural poverty (though proportionately less) but life for most people in the country is better than in towns. They are healthier, happier, safer, better educated and richer. Not surprisingly townies tell pollsters they wish they lived there too.

The traditional left likes to stress the two nations of the north/south divide while the right tries to capitalise on a rural/urban split, both playing to their own electoral heartlands. William Hague was stoking up that old anti-townie sentiment in his speech to the NFU this week: "The rural way of life is under threat from urban values, Islington pressure groups and a metropolitan elite who know nothing about the countryside."

Tony Blair is attempting to dismantle the banality of these national semi-myths: the north is also rich, the south also poor, town and country share most common concerns. In Devon yesterday he rightly sought to disentangle the tiny farming industry from most of rural life. Agriculture is only 1% of GDP and only employs 2% of the workforce in England. Even in rural areas it only employs 4% of the workforce. Like everyone else, most people work in services or in small businesses. There is no "rural crisis".

But yes, there is indeed a farming crisis and this is the worst agricultural recession since the 30s. What should be done? "Income can go down as well as up and is not guaranteed," says the very small print at the bottom of all financial service ads. Most of us live with that possibility because it is part of the human condition to know that disaster can strike.

But farmers seem to consider themselves outside the cut and thrust of the normal market processes they so heartily endorse when they go into the polling booths to vote Tory. In real terms farmers' incomes rose by 100% between 1990 and 1995. But now they have dropped by 60% since then. There's every reason to feel especially sorry for the 20% who are tenant farmers with nothing to sell up, but most farmers own valuable land, the price of which has soared recently.

Yet even farmers sitting on a fortune think they should be bailed out. Why? Walk into the bankruptcy court any day of the week and case after case will bring tears to your eyes at the sight of so many decent people wiped out by bad luck or bad judgment. Two out of three new business start-ups fail. Farmers are not the only hard-pressed businessmen to commit suicide. Should the state step in and bail them all out?

Images of the harsh treatment meted out to the miners colour all our current attitudes towards compensating lame-duck industries. Mrs Thatcher said we couldn't and shouldn't pay people to dig out coal no one wanted, so now it's hard to see why farmers should be paid to breed unsaleable cattle, pigs and lambs. Global markets change and in over-producing meat, farmers misjudged their markets. It happens. We can feel very sorry for them, though their political attitudes don't always make it easy. Letting the Countryside Alliance be their advocate is about as helpful to their cause as Arthur Scargill was to the miners'.

Cleverer leadership would have had the farmers' tractors rolling down Whitehall long ago to protest at the high pound which is the gravest single cause of their distress. Other industries get some benefit from cheaper imported raw materials, but for farmers who import nothing the high cost of exporting is pure calamity. The NFU has always been pro-euro, but they haven't rolled out their tanks to demand early entry.

Where are the green Barbours on platforms up and down the land demanding we join and that everything is done to lower interest rates, bring down the value of the pound and make euro entry possible? (Now we have missed entry on day one, the only way to lower interest rates without inflation is to raise taxation instead. Are they for it?) Instead the NFU conference applauded William Hague's strange pleas for more EU subsidy and didn't query his admission that "the strong pound has hit all livestock farming with unprecedented ferocity".

The farming lobby is powerful and emotive because it taps an atavistic national fantasy that everyone's roots or their retirement destination is the countryside of Hovis dreams. It was brave of Blair to face the farmers down with some home truths: adapt or die is his hard message. Labour has handed out £435m extra in direct aid to farmers, but from now on there will only be more for those things that are socially useful. Ten million - not enough - is to subsidise the cost of converting to organic or semi-organic methods. (Absurdly we import 70% of our organic produce as we don't grow enough here: there are long waiting lists of farmers wanting to convert.)

Other funds will help turn farmers into countryside stewards: we may not need sheep to eat, but we need them as lawn mowers on barely profitable hill farms, to preserve those much loved patchwork landscapes with dry-stone walls. There are grants for developing new industrial crops to generate energy, make plastics and grow hemp for manufacturing. But all these are small funds for small schemes. In the end the market is let rip. Except, of course, for the continuing disgrace of the CAP, whose snail's pace reform still hands out a monstrous £3bn farming subsidy mainly to those who need it least: 80% goes to 20% of the farmers, many of them the richest.

The future, the government suggests, lies in tourism, to which some farmers reply arrogantly that they don't want to be park-keepers. But for some it's that or nothing: 90% of the people live in towns and they want access to the country. They are the market and farmers had better learn to smile at them instead of blocking footpaths and setting dogs on them. They may be townie sentimentalists but they want fewer pesticides polluting the soil and more live birds. (The RSPB has more members than all the political parties put together - and they are, incidentally, outraged that Blair's one pointless sop to the farmers this week was an unexpected pledge not to introduce a proposed pesticide tax to make farmers cut down on their use.) The Countryside Alliance's opposition to the right to roam was just another example of their disastrous leadership on rural matters: if they want to survive they are going to have to learn to love ramblers, picnickers and even people from Islington. No more of this "them and us" romance.

webTitle: Labour accused as report 'washes over' hard times

fields.headline: Labour accused as report 'washes over' hard times
fields.standfirst: Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: The government's assessment that the countryside is "prosperous, contented and reasonably well-served" caused a storm of protest last night among opposition parties, pressure groups, and even its main rural quango.
fields.body:
The government's assessment that the countryside is "prosperous, contented and reasonably well-served" caused a storm of protest last night among opposition parties, pressure groups, and even its main rural quango.

As a cabinet office report for Tony Blair concluded that rural Britain overall was not in the same state of crisis as some parts of agriculture, the Tories attacked the prime minister's "contempt" for rural voters and the Liberal Democrats said the research ignored the suicide rate among farmers.

The government's countryside agency said it "washed over" rural poverty.

The report, designed to show that urban and rural areas were sharing general prosperity, said that while there were "pockets of deprivation" and areas where pressure on land and wildlife caused concern, life in the countryside was better than in towns and cities.

Most areas "are broadly prosperous, with lower than average unemployment, higher than average prosperity, less congestion, better health, less crime and fear of crime, and better performing schools."

The report recognised that income from farming had fallen by 60% since 1995 but said it had doubled in the previous five years. Agriculture accounted for 7.5% of rural jobs, lower than service industries, new technologies and local and national government. Tourism was catching up, too.

Nearly 60% of farmers had other sources of income and the population of rural England had risen by nearly 25% in the last 25 years, four times the growth in the country as a whole, the report said.

Most people regarded the quality of life as better in the countryside and two-thirds of people would move there if they could, polls have found.

There were "many real problems and much genuine hardship", but country areas benefited from government measures including the New Deal on employment, the minimum wage and the working families' tax credit.

Most areas in England with the lowest income per head may be rural - the worst of all was Cornwall and the Scilly Isles - but this "masks the true standard of living, which includes the quality of life and the cost of living".

The report also said the government did not believe hunt ing with dogs was the biggest issue facing rural Britain, "nor should it define debate".

About £3.75bn was spent on special programmes for rural areas on top of normal education, health, transport and housing budgets.

Tim Yeo, the shadow agriculture minister, claimed Mr Blair's "obsession" with modernisation would turn the countryside into "a gigantic theme park". He said the report "glazes over all that is bad and is designed to suit Mr Blair's message, not reality. He seems to have written off any chances of winning rural votes at the next election."

The Countryside Alliance of pressure groups accused the government of "glossing over" real problems.

Its chief executive Richard Burge said: "At least 10% of rural households are officially in poverty. Rural parishes struggle with almost non-existent levels of transport, schooling and healthcare. If that is not a crisis, I do not know what is."

Ewen Cameron, chairman of the countryside agency, said: "The impression that life in the countryside is rosy for all but a few farmers ignores disparities in many areas."

Town life: Pauline Moran

Lives: Heywood, a suburb of Rochdale, Greater Manchester

View: Housing estate

Transport: Commutes to city centre by car - a 10-mile trip that takes 45 minutes each way. "Every year the traffic gets worse. The bus service stops at 7pm."

Shops: Most high street names have pulled out.

Medical services: The local hospital, Birchill, is under pressure to close.

Crime: The biggest concern in Heywood. "There's a lot of car theft and break-ins. We had a buglary in my street only last week. Heywood police station is only open for limited hours and there seem to be fewer officers on the street."

Schools: Two of Mrs Moran's children were taught at a local school but because exam results declined there, she sent her youngest to a school in Bury.

Country Life: Rachel Rycroft

Lives: Village of Thornley in the Trough of Bowland, rural Lancashire

View: Beautiful emptiness

Transport: "Almost every day I have to spend a long time in the car - just to get to the bank or go shopping." In winter, roads may be blocked by snow.

Shops: Nearest is three miles away, but main shopping means a 10-mile trip.

Medical services: Local GPs are generous with house calls to treat Mrs Rycroft's back problem but a hospital visit to see a specialist is a big exercise.

Crime: "We are isolated and burglaries are common. We have alarms, guard dogs and neighbourhood watch."

Schools: "Fortunately the local school is very good, but parents have little choice over where they send their children."

fields.headline: Blair begins seduction of country folk
fields.standfirst:
PM's message is farming may be in crisis but most people in the countryside face same problems as the rest of us

Countryside in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: One of the more confusing, even surreal, days of Tony Blair's thousand-odd in power involved him having to contend with the affairs of Britain's most troubled region while simultaneously traipsing round its gentlest.
fields.body:
One of the more confusing, even surreal, days of Tony Blair's thousand-odd in power involved him having to contend with the affairs of Britain's most troubled region while simultaneously traipsing round its gentlest.

The prime minister was starting a two-day tour of Devon and Cornwall, a faraway country mostly comprising Tory-Lib Dem marginals, of which he appears to know little. At any rate, he called the river Tamar the "Tammar".

This trip is part of a series of regional tours that constitute the very first move in the seduction of the electorate scheduled for consummation next year. He is, in effect, undoing the electorate's top shirt button. In December he went to the north-west. Scotland comes soon. Wales is rather dodgy at the moment.

Mr Blair spent the day in Exeter and Plymouth. He cares very deeply about the farmers, of course, but not so deeply that they can't wait another 24 hours.

The focal point of the day was a speech to about 200 businessmen and women at Exeter university. He also visited a ceramics factory and on two separate occasions stared - in his "gee-whizz-but-gosh-what-do-I-do-with-this-mouse-thingy?" kind of way - at a couple of internet projects, one run by the yachtsman Pete Goss.

One aspect of this, put bluntly by the CBI regional vice-chairman, Steve Hindley, is that agriculture is responsible for only 4% of GDP even in the south-west. It is only 1% in the country as a whole. This was helpful to Mr Blair, who was trying to ram home the message contained in the mega-report on the rural economy prepared by the cabinet office: while farmers are suffering, many other people in the countryside are not.

Uneasy coalition

As the report says, far more people in the countryside work in services, IT and public administration. (Indeed, in many places, local councils are the largest employers.) Rural tourism could soon overtake agriculture as a source of employment.

"Farming is in crisis," Mr Blair admitted in his speech. "But there are villages, towns and cities in very rural parts of Britain that in fact face the same problems as the rest of Britain." This appears to be code for saying they don't really face that many problems at all.

"The answer is not to divide the country up," he went on, "but to bring it together. I am a one-nation politician and this is a one-nation government." This was partly directed at critics inside his own party. But farmers were also intended as recipients.

Arguably, this is the worst of all messages to give farmers who, at the best of times (which these aren't), are prone to sit in their tractors brooding. Tell them that, whatever their troubles, the people down the road - who have probably just moved in from town, anyway - are doing really well, seems about the worst strategy of all.

What Mr Blair seems only to half grasp is the extent to which the countryside is an uneasy coalition between locals and in-comers. The balance of power varies: from home counties villages overwhelmed by expanding concrete, to tracts of the Cotswolds dominated by weekenders, to remote corners where only the old are left or move in. This may fit in with the prime minister's idea of a fluid society, but when the economic disparities are as huge as they are now the consequences are deeply unsettling.

There is a better technique and it worked on two of Mr Blair's most vigorous opponents. As he prepared to leave the university after his speech, Robert Persey, a pig farmer from Honiton, was leading a group of protesters and kept up a non-stop barrage of abuse over a mega phone: "Tony, tell us why you are murdering the British pig industry."

So Tony took up the challenge. Mr Persey and one of his allies, Ben Pullen, a Gloucestershire dairy farmer, were called in for tea and sympathy. Twenty minutes later, Mr Persey reeled out, transformed: "He understands our problems - he was very sympathetic - I was greatly impressed." Mr Blair told Mr Persey he would like to give pig farmers some money, but there were problems with the exchequer. Mr Persey appeared to accept this. This man could sell sand to Saudis.

Mr Blair travelled by train from Exeter to Plymouth. Improbably, it was on time. On the journey two television personalities marched into his carriage past the security and, like the farmers, got 15 minutes of his time. He had been expecting Mr Ahern. He got Richard and Judy, on the way to their house in Cornwall. "It was just chit-chat," said Richard. It sort of made the prime minister's point, though: the south-west is not just about poor farmers - it has rich TV presenters too.

Poor relations?
A regional guide

North-east

Lowest proportion of population living in rural areas (9.8%). Legacy of coal mining has left villages without access to modern transport systems. GDP from farming, hunting, forestry and fishing: £535m

North-west

Cumbria and Pennines are remote, sparsely populated and heavily dependent on a vulnerable agricultural industry. West Lancashire and Cheshire are traditionally more affluent but under pressure from declining farm commodity prices.

GDP from farming, hunting, forestry and fishing: £575m. Population in rural areas: 17.7%

Yorkshire and the Humber

Diverse rural problems: dependency on agriculture, low pay, ageing population, pockets of unemployment. Also significant strengths: entrepreneurial skills of new migrants and growth of tourism.

GDP from agriculture, hunting, forestry and fishing: £1.1bn. Population in rural areas: 20.4%

East Midlands

Rural pay lower than average. Poor transport infrastructure a major problem, but the urban population's demand for access means rural areas are sustainable.

GDP from agriculture, hunting, forestry and fishing: £1.14bn. Population in rural areas: 45.7%

West Midlands

Heavy fall in livestock income in the last 10 years. Remote areas face particular challenge but wider picture less gloomy. Some rural wealth above English average. GDP from agriculture, hunting, forestry and fishing: £1.14bn. Population in rural areas: 20.8%

South-west

Third most prosperous region in UK, with some "economic disparities". Some rural jobs lost but businesses relocated from London.

GDP from agriculture, hunting, forestry and fishing: £1.85bn. Population in rural areas: 53.3%.

South-east

Relative affluence with pockets of rural deprivation. GDP from agriculture, hunting, forestry and fishing: £1.4bn. Population in rural areas: 46.6%

Eastern

North of region dependent on vulnerable agricultural industry where farm incomes declined by 75%. Substantial developmental pressures in commuting areas.

GDP from agriculture, hunting, forestry and fishing: £1.1bn. Population in rural areas: 43.3%.

Wales

77% of agricultural land less favoured status, 52% severely disadvantaged. Significant number of farms below level viable to support a family. Many pressures on sustainability of rural communities.

Scotland

Rural unemployment rates below Scottish level with growing population. Pleasant place to live, agriculture still cornerstone of rural economy.

Northern Ireland

Faces severe financial difficulties. Farming income declined by 79% compared with 60% across UK.
