fields.headline: Austria out on its own
fields.standfirst:
The EU must turn its words into actions

The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Today's ascent to power in Austria of Jörg Haider's Freedom party poses a fundamental challenge to the European society to which we all belong. It is, as the Portuguese prime minister says, "a question of principles and values". The shabby deal in Vienna between the two losers of last October's elections, Wolfgang Schüssel's conservative People's party and Mr Haider's far-right movement, has a significance reaching far beyond Austria. It will give a boost to extreme rightwing groups in other European countries, including Britain. It potentially threatens the identity and cohesion of the European Union and of other pan-European institutions which arose from the ashes of Europe's fascist era.
fields.body:
Today's ascent to power in Austria of Jörg Haider's Freedom party poses a fundamental challenge to the European society to which we all belong. It is, as the Portuguese prime minister says, "a question of principles and values". The shabby deal in Vienna between the two losers of last October's elections, Wolfgang Schüssel's conservative People's party and Mr Haider's far-right movement, has a significance reaching far beyond Austria. It will give a boost to extreme rightwing groups in other European countries, including Britain. It potentially threatens the identity and cohesion of the European Union and of other pan-European institutions which arose from the ashes of Europe's fascist era.

Mr Haider's mendacious repackaging of the old agenda of hate, racism, and fear challenges every individual, too, to say clearly what he or she believes, and to act on it. For if we accept the possibility of human progress, then we must accept and draw on the lessons of the past. There can be no prevarication, no fudging - no blasé, comforting pretence that the threat is overstated and will soon recede. Nor can there be any accommodation. We all know, or should, where that historically leads. For Mr Haider, emboldened by his success, makes no secret of the fact that he hopes to take the chancellorship outright next time around.

In this context, the swift decision of 14 EU member governments to quarantine the 15th, Austria, is welcome. This is not a case of bullying by Brussels, despite the self-serving claims of eurosceptics. The démarche was undertaken without prior reference to Romano Prodi or his commission. Nor is it a right-left issue or in any sense an ideological battle, for no party holds exclusive rights to bigotry. The criticism which today rains down upon the wretched Mr Schüssel, whose ambition to become chancellor overwhelmed his responsibility to his country, comes from democrats of all persuasions, appalled by a grotesque distortion of the people's will. It is a great shame that the Freedom party's 27% share of the vote has translated into more than half the government posts. It is a great pity that Viktor Klima, leader of the largest party, the Social Democrats, which belatedly called for fresh elections, failed to show more nous. It is chilling that after all that has passed since Anschluss, so many Austrians, ignoring history, appear to prefer a smug, revisionist chauvinism.

The assertion that external, anti-Haider pressure constitutes a gross interference in Austria's internal affairs does not bear scrutiny. For Austria does not somehow inhabit a moral universe all its own. "It is an expression that we stand for a Europe based on shared values (which) Mr Haider has constantly violated," says Gerhard Schröder, Germany's chancellor. It was plain that, in the end, outsiders could not dictate to Austria the composition of its government. But it remains equally plain that as a member of the western democratic community of nations as much as the EU itself, Austria, like a wayward child, had to be left in absolutely no doubt what the logical consequences of its actions would be. Now those warnings have been effectively ignored, and the deserved isolation and ostracism of Austria will begin.

Despite Mr Haider's grandiose, unbelievable last-minute pledges to clean up his act, there should be no wavering. For individuals, companies, and governments who would uphold the values of a free society, there must be no business-as-usual with Austria while Mr Haider and his cohorts hold sway. This imperative is both a personal and collective responsibility. It is a question of principle.

webTitle: Jorg Haider's rise will soon enough be followed by a fall

fields.headline: Jorg Haider's rise will soon enough be followed by a fall
fields.standfirst:
Europeans should be concerned, not pessimistic, about Austria

The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Europeans should be concerned, not pessimistic, about Austria
fields.body:
Ghosts are not the best guides to the present, which is why there there is a danger now of misinterpreting what is happening in Austria. That country is surely not on the road back to fascism. But, with the Freedom party's entry into government with most of the top ministries under its control, Austria has opened itself up to an unpleasant variant of the opportunistic, unprincipled, and negative politics that have arrived, in one form or another, in most western democracies in the past few years.

The Austrian conservatives, the People's party, who engineered this deal, have been blinded by desperation and ambition, and imagine, almost certainly wrongly, that they can control their partners. They will come to rue the day.

But Austria's problem is not old Nazi politics, but the lack of substantial new politics. The Austrian formula had many virtues for a bewildered and frightened society on the front line of the cold war. Neutral status gave it external security at low cost, while a permanent social coalition between unions and business, usually reflected in a political coalition between the two main parties as well, gave it internal stability.

People lived their lives and made their careers within these two separate orders, which divided up and distributed jobs, welfare, contracts, and other desirable things. The formula brought prosperity - or, anyway, prosperity accompanied it and seemed to be connected with it. Into this comfortable corset, post-war Austria gratefully relaxed a half century ago, and when the stays began to snap in recent years nobody knew what to do.

In every European country there was some kind of post-war political dispensation that came under pressure. But Austria's was a particularly highly organised dispensation, and one particularly dear to its citizens.

The failed coalition negotiations between the Social Democratic and the People's parties revolved around how much of it could be retained. Would the People's party, itching to be "proper" European conservatives, cutting and privatising with the rest of them, be allowed to impose an austerity programme, including welfare reductions, and have the unions sign up to it, even though they would have been the junior partner in government? Could the Social Democrats countenance that, and could they also countenance moves away from neutrality? On the way to this impasse, the Social Democrats significantly lost support, and the People's party slumped to an extraordinary degree. One recent poll suggests that it would win only 17% of the vote if elections were held now.

Haider and his Freedom party waxed as the main parties waned. He drew his support both from those who felt excluded by the old system, and those who did benefit, but felt those benefits threatened. Increasingly he got the young, who were impatient at waiting in the queue for advancement, particularly as the queue seemed to be breaking down. Hella Pick, formerly the Guardian's diplomatic editor, says in her new book on Austria that the old way, sensible enough in the past, "has served to stultify Austria's democratic institutions and to make political patronage an all pervasive and corrosive phenomenon. It has reached the point where the democratic system, as operated in Austria, has run into the buffers."

The Austrian sociologist Adolph Holl suggests that the old duality is being eclipsed by a new one. "On the one hand, you have a middle-aged, well educated group that wants reforms of a certain kind, and they tend toward the Green party," he says. "On the other you have many of the young, as well as blue collar people of all ages, and workers who have lost their jobs . . . and they tend, at the moment, toward Haider."

In this realignment there is hope. Haider hardly has policies, offering instead only vote-getting attitudes. He demands action in areas where he knows it has already been taken, as with immigration, or in areas where he knows Austria has no serious chance of changing things, as on restricting European Union expansion. Voters may well see through him in time, and even now the statistics suggest that in a year or so a coalition of the Social Democrats and the Greens would be the most likely government, with the People's party and the Freedom party not only out but with their support perhaps permanently reduced.

The measures taken by EU member states have angered many Austrians, dismayed others who see them as strengthening Haider, and pleased those such as Joachim Riedl, editor of Format magazine, who are glad to see that they are not alone in their opposition to Haider. But it deserves emphasis that their opposition to the Freedom party leader does not focus on his flirtatious remarks about the SS or Hitler's employment policies. It focuses instead on the man, a fabricator, a clown, and "a shameless exploiter of cheap feelings", as Riedl puts it, and on the vacuous and negative nature of his politics.

"Austrians," Riedl argues, "suffer from a false vision of the past and a false vision of the future." The false vision of the past still sees Austria as a victim of the Nazis rather than to some considerable degree an accomplice. Although the Waldheim affair caused some limited reflection, there has never been, in Austria, an accounting with the past like that in Germany. That allows some Austrians to believe Austria was an occupied country like Belgium or Norway and others, in contradictory fashion, to take an insouciant attitude toward wartime service with the German forces.

But it is the false vision of the future which most concerns Austrians like Riedl. In spite of EU membership, many Austrians seem to think they can carry on without any serious engagement with the outside world. "It's such an extremely provincial country. It just has not yet arrived in Europe. Austrians still have the feeling that there's the border and beyond it is undifferentiated foreign territory, and that we should not be at all disturbed by what goes on out there, nor should they disturb us."

It has to be said that Europe as a whole shows some "Austrian" characteristics writ large, in, for example, its attitude to immigrants. It is also true that the old dispensation in Austria, as elsewhere in Europe, had much to recommend it and that the "modernisation" which is urged as a cure has serious disadvantages. But there comes a time when political battles have to be fought in a new way and that time has arrived in Austria. Europeans are right to be concerned, but it would be wrong to be pessimistic. The rise and rise of Jorg Haider will not necessarily go on for ever.

Hella Pick's The Guilty Victim: Austria since the Holocaust will be published in English by IB Tauris.

webTitle: Far right party poised to control state patronage

fields.headline: Far right party poised to control state patronage
fields.standfirst:
The conservative leader Wolfgang Schüssel claims he will tame his ally. But can he control the beast?

The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: In the headquarters of the Austrian People's party hangs a portrait of former chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss, who was assassinated by Nazis in 1934. The party considers Dollfuss its spiritual father.
fields.byline: John Hooper and Kate Connolly in Vienna
fields.body:
In the headquarters of the Austrian People's party hangs a portrait of former chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss, who was assassinated by Nazis in 1934. The party considers Dollfuss its spiritual father.

Yesterday its leader, Wolfgang Schüssel, signed a coalition pact with Jörg Haider's Freedom party that will allow them to govern Austria jointly for the next four years.

Mr Haider also has a father figure in the background: his real father, Robert. After the murder of Dollfuss, the elder Mr Haider - a member of the Nazis' SA stormtroopers who were suspected of implication in the plot - fled to Germany.

His son has never disowned his father's past as one of Hitler's keenest supporters in Austria. Far from it.

"In retrospect, one is always wiser," he once said. "As a descendant one should not be so arrogant as to say, I would have known better."

Austria's mainstream conservatives have come a very long way from their origins to get to the point they reached yesterday. But Mr Schüssel remains confident that he can keep his new-found far-right allies in check.

"There is no doubt that Austria will prove that it will continue to be a reliable and stable partner in the European Union," he told ORF radio. Others remain unconvinced.

"Jörg Haider is a hand-grenade from which the pin has been removed. Schüssel cannot hold it down for four years," said one liberal political commentator in Vienna.

The Freedom party has not come into the prospective governing alliance as a junior partner. It won more votes and the same number of seats as the People's party in last October's general election, and will hold nine of the 16 seats on the cabinet. They include the post of vice-chancellor and the key portfolios of finance, social affairs, defence, justice and agriculture. It will also control the portfolios of health and, ironically, tourism.

The carve-up has put Mr Haider's hands on the levers of patronage in a country riddled with cronyism, in which the state employs more than one in five of the workforce. The social affairs ministry, which spends 30% of Austria's gross domestic product, will be run by Elisabeth Sickl of the Freedom party.

The chancellery has admittedly gone to Mr Schüssel. But that is not as important a gesture as it might appear from outside. In Austria, the powers of the head of government are more circumscribed than those of his counterpart in Germany, and traditionally his influence has depended on a harmonious working relationship with the finance minister.

The closeness which the two party leaders were keen to put on show yesterday is of very recent origin. During last year's election campaign, Mr Schüssel said categorically that he would go into opposition rather than form a government with the Freedom party.

The People's party has been one of the twin pillars of a corporatist model of government for the past 30 years. Mr Haider and his followers claim to want to smash it to pieces and replace it with an entirely original construction in which the market economy and a leaner bureaucracy would co-exist with curbs on immigration and financial support for non-working mothers.

On the face of it, there would seem to be every chance that this odd mix will lead to a falling-out: that its members will either bust up or make such a mess of governing that they will be voted out of office in four years' time.

Mr Haider may have decided to remain out of the cabinet. But his influence will be undiminished. Mr Haider is the Freedom party. Without him, pollsters estimate that its vote would fall to 10% or less.

Free of the requirements of collective cabinet responsibility, moreover, he will be in a position to criticise the government's less popular moves with impunity. And he shows no signs yet of toning down his rabble-rousing rhetoric.

Yesterday he refused to go back on his remark to the German weekly Die Zeit comparing the EU to a chicken coop and himself to a fox. It was scarcely the sort of language his new partners had hoped to hear in a week in which their fellow-Europeans have been close to apoplexy over their planned alliance with the Freedom party.

What worries Mr Haider's critics inside and outside Austria is that, from a position of virtual immunity, he could gradually undermine his conservative partners and end up dominating their alliance.

The People's party is already weakened. It has suffered more than any other from the gathering revolt against the cosy politics of the past 30 years. It bled votes last October and has lost support at a faster rate than any other party since then. The latest polls suggest it has no more backing than the Greens.

For the moment, Jörg Haider looks every inch the lion - and Wolfgang Schüssel less and less like a man with his hand on the whip.

The cabinet members are: Chancellor Wolfgang Schüssel (PP); vice-chancellor Susanne Riess-Passer (FP); foreign minister Benita Ferrero-Waldner (PP); finance minister Karl-Heinz Grasser (FP); economics minister Martin Bartenstein (PP); interior minister Ernst Strasser (PP); social affairs minister Elisabeth Sickl (FP); defence minister Herbert Scheibner (FP); education minister Elisabeth Gehrer (PP); infrastructure minister Michael Schmid (FP); justice minister Michael Krüger (FP); agriculture minister Wilhelm Molterer (FP).

The state secretaries are: Chancellery, Ulrike Baumgartner-Gabitzer (PP); finance, Stephan Koren (PP); health, Reinhart Waneck (FP); tourism, Mares Rossmann (FP).

webTitle: Far right takes power in Austria

fields.headline: Far right takes power in Austria
fields.standfirst:
Freedom party secures majority of cabinet posts

The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: The president of Austria, Thomas Klestil, will today swear in a government in which the majority of cabinet portfolios will be held by the party whose leader praised veterans of the Waffen SS.
fields.byline: Kate Connolly  and  John Hooper  in Vienna and Ian Black  in Brussels
fields.body:
The president of Austria, Thomas Klestil, will today swear in a government in which the majority of cabinet portfolios will be held by the party whose leader praised veterans of the Waffen SS.

Against all expectations, Jörg Haider's anti-immigration Freedom party was given six of 10 full ministerial posts, including finance, defence and justice. It also got the ministry of social affairs, whose budget accounts for 30% of gross domestic product.

Mr Haider also got his private secretary, Susanne Riess-Passer, a close confidante, into the post of vice-chancellor. This cast doubt on the claims of Wolfgang Schüssel, the leader of the conservative People's Party, that as chancellor he would be able to minimise Mr Haider's influence.

Mr Haider will not occupy a seat in the cabinet but will remain governor of the southern province of Carinthia.

Last night Antonio Guterres, the prime minister of Portugal, which holds the rotating EU presidency, said moves to politically isolate Austria from the union would begin today.

"As from today the measures agreed by the 14 countries will take effect. As long as this situation remains, we shall maintain this stance," he said.

Earlier, the European parliament warned that Austria's EU membership could be suspended if the government veers from European standards of democracy and human rights.

The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, described Mr Haider as dangerous to democracy and recalled his ambassador. Mr Haider is barred from entering Israel.

The Representative Council of Jewish Institutions in France called the Austrian developments "intolerable" and a "political shame without precedent in Europe since the end of the second world war".

Belgium's foreign minister, Louis Michel, said: "I think Europe can very well do without Austria. We don't need it."

Diplomats hinted that the new coalition could be given a period of probation to see whether it lived up to commitments on democracy.

Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, broke a week-long British silence, declaring that the coalition in Vienna would be judged by "deeds, not words". But he said that Austria's participation in the EU should not be affected.

In an effort to limit the damage, Mr Klestil had earlier wrung a humbling declaration from Mr Haider and Mr Schüssel. They sought to assure the world that Austria remained committed to basic human rights and would re-examine its Nazi past.

Political sources said the head of state had also vetoed Mr Haider's first choice for vice-chancellor, Thomas Prinzhorn. He was ruled out after reportedly threatening the president with a "bloody face" for expressing reservations about the Freedom party. Mr Prinzhorn claimed last year that foreigners living in Austria had been given free hormone treatment to boost their birth rate.

Confident that they were on the brink of taking power, Mr Haider and Mr Schüssel had earlier presented a full government programme to the media. Their declaration pledged a future government to work for "an Austria in which xenophobia, anti-Semitism and racism have no place".

The head of state and the two party leaders emerged stony faced from their meeting in the Imperial Palace. There were none of the customary handshakes.

Their extraordinary joint declaration said: "Austria accepts her responsibility arising out of the tragic history of the 20th century and the horrendous crimes of the National Socialist regime. Our country is facing up to the light and dark sides of its past and to the deeds of all Austrians, good and evil, as its responsibility".

Mr Haider told the press conference that the prospective administration planned "a lot of initiatives to show that we have learnt to move on from the dark part of history in which Austria was involved".

However, he also said that it was "not the job of an Austrian government to clear up historical questions".

Mr Schüssel reproved "unbalanced criticism" from abroad. He asked that Austria be seen as "one of the most credible nations in the world," pleading: "Please give us a chance."

Mr Haider described his party as a "democratic movement committed to human rights".

He said that a government which included his party would give Austria "an optimistic perspective on the future, ending as it would 30 years of consensus politics".

The conservatives and far right together hold 104 of 183 seats in the lower house. They finished behind the Social Democrats in last October's general election, but the Social Democrats were unable to seal a government pact with the People's Party and rejected any deal with Mr Haider's movement.

The leading international credit rating agency, Standard & Poors, said it was considering downgrading Austria's status in a move that would increase the cost of government borrowing.

Demonstrators chanting "Haider is a fascist" threw eggs at the Freedom party leader as he arrived for his meeting with the president. And last night protesters were assembling in Vienna for the second anti-right wing march in two days.

webTitle: Charming child of lies and amnesia

fields.headline: Charming child of lies and amnesia
fields.standfirst: The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Jörg Haider relishes playing the part of the cheeky, charming liar. Campaigning against EU membership in 1995, he warned Austrians that they would be forced to export their crystal-pure water on orders from Brussels.
fields.body:
Jörg Haider relishes playing the part of the cheeky, charming liar. Campaigning against EU membership in 1995, he warned Austrians that they would be forced to export their crystal-pure water on orders from Brussels.

Previously he was pro-EU when the mainstream socialist and conservative parties were against joining. He also specialises in u-turns. Now parading as a nationalist, he once described Austria as "a miscarriage of history" and campaigned to amend the constitution to allow a merger with Germany.

In his gift for the barefaced lie, he is an authentic product of a post-war political culture in Austria groomed for decades on two national lies or myths - that the country was the "first victim" of the Nazis, and that it is voluntarily constitutionally "permanently neutral".

These legends, accompanied by mass amnesia, have been central to the post-war national identity and have resulted in two international crises in the past 15 years - the Haider imbroglio and the Waldheim affair.

Just 14 years ago in May, Kurt Waldheim was elected president after suffering a severe lapse of memory about what he did as a Wehrmacht officer during the second world war.

Like many Austrians of a certain age, Mr Waldheim could not remember details of his time in what is now Bosnia, apart from recalling that he only "did his duty". Besides, the allies had deemed Austria Hitler's "first victim" in 1944 in an attempt to encourage resistance to the Nazis, despite Hitler's annexation of March 1938 being greeted deliriously by huge crowds on the streets, and despite the prominence of many Austrians at the apex of the Nazi party.

It was only in 1991 that the chancellor, Franz Vranitzky, declared officially that Austria had also been an accomplice of the Nazis.

A monument in Vienna's centre, featuring elderly Jews bent double scrubbing a city pavement with a toothbrush, took seven years to be finished against stiff resistance. Rachel Whiteread's Holocaust memorial on Judenplatz has similarly been subject to endless bureaucratic delays and widespread resistance from a public keen to forget or distort the past.

A huge memorial to the Red Army troops who helped to liberate Vienna in 1945 stands proudly on Schwarzenbergplatz, emphasising the other historical myth. It was, of course, the Russians who insisted on Austria's "permanent neutrality" as the price of the Red Army's withdrawal from Vienna across the cold war frontline into Hungary in 1955.

But permanent neutrality, it is argued, was the Austrians' free choice and is now an integral element of the national identity. Comparisons are made with Switzerland, as if centuries of stubborn Swiss isolationism were analogous to Austria's subjection to a Kremlin demand.

The Waldheim scandal brought Austria international isolation and humiliation. The president could not travel to the US, for example. But he ran on a campaign embodying the national amnesia, raging against "international slander". He took half the vote.

Mr Haider may mine a rich electoral seam by similarly playing the role of democracy's martyr. And he is a much more talented vote-getter than Mr Waldheim ever was.

fields.headline: Sign of the times
fields.standfirst:
Belgium asks its skiers to boycott Austria

The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Austrian tourism managers fear massive losses from cancellations by foreign holiday-makers protesting against the expected inclusion of members of Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party in a new coalition government.
fields.body:
Austrian tourism managers fear massive losses from cancellations by foreign holiday-makers protesting against the expected inclusion of members of Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party in a new coalition government.

The industry's alarm that European tourists might take their business elsewhere grew when the Belgian foreign minister advised his countrymen not to take skiing trips to Austria.

Martin Uitz, manager of the Salzburg province tourist authority, said that an unspecified number of cancellations had been received, particularly from Germany and Switzerland.

Officials in Leogang, in western Salzburg province, were awaiting cancellation of trips by Israeli tourist groups, an expected loss of 15,000 overnight stays this summer, one news agency reported.

Unconfirmed reports said that a major medical congress scheduled for next year in Innsbruck might not take place because US sponsors were considering pulling out.

In Britain, reaction was more muted.

Marion Telsnig the public relations manager for Thomson holidays, said that so far there had been no increase in the usual number of cancellations for holidays to Austria.

"I think people who have saved all year for their skiing holiday would not cancel for that," Ms Telsnig said.

fields.headline: MPs to question BAT bosses
fields.standfirst: BAT expose: special report
fields.trailText: The former Tory chancellor Kenneth Clarke and the chairman of British American Tobacco are to be grilled by MPs about how the company exploits cigarette smuggling.
fields.body:
The former Tory chancellor Kenneth Clarke and the chairman of British American Tobacco are to be grilled by MPs about how the company exploits cigarette smuggling.

Mr Clarke, now the deputy chairman of BAT, and Martin Broughton will be questioned about black marketeering.

The all-party Commons health committee agreed yesterday to question the pair after the Guardian disclosed the extent to which the company benefits from the illegal trade.

MPs believe Mr Broughton was less than forthcoming recently when he claimed BAT worked closely with the authorities to combat smuggling. His third appearance during the course of a select committee inquiry is exceptional.

Mr Clarke, a non-executive director of the world's second-largest tobacco firm, was "invited" after the MPs were astonished by his admission that BAT supplied cigarettes knowing they would end up on the black market.

Both men will appear on February 16 alongside the investigative journalist Duncan Campbell, whose research on BAT inolvement in Latin America, Asia and the far east has been published this week in the Guardian.

Peter Brand, a Liberal Democrat member of the committee, said Mr Broughton had previously maintained that the company worked to prevent its cigarettes ending up on the black market.

Mr Clarke admitted in yesterday's Guardian that BAT made its brands "available alongside those of our competitors in the smuggled as well as the legitimate market".

The admission supported evidence in documents obtained from BAT's Guildford depository and went way beyond the "blind eye" the company had previously claimed it turned.

Audrey Wise, a Labour member of the committee, said: "I expect Kenneth Clarke will be appreciative of the chance to explain his extraordinary views expressed in the Guardian. It's obvious that [Mr Broughton] has proved good at avoiding some of the most important issues. We will now have a chance to concentrate on the smuggling which is after all a big unsavoury racket."

BAT said last night it welcomed the opportunity for Mr Broughton to appear again.

Audrey Wise, a Labour member of the committee, said: "I expect Kenneth Clarke will be appreciative of the chance to explain his extraordinary views expressed in the Guardian. It's obvious that [Mr Broughton] has proved good at avoiding some of the most important issues. We will now have a chance to concentrate on the smuggling which is after all a big unsavoury racket." BAT said last night it welcomed the opportunity for Mr Broughton to appear again.

webTitle: Far-right party poised to control state patronage

fields.headline: Far-right party poised to control state patronage
fields.standfirst:
The conservative leader Wolfgang Schüssel claims he will tame his new ally. But can he control the beast?

The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: In the headquarters of the People's party hangs a portrait of former chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss, who was assassinated by Nazis in 1934. The party considers Dollfuss its spiritual father.
fields.byline: John Hooper  and  Kate Connolly  in Vienna
fields.body:
In the headquarters of the People's party hangs a portrait of former chancellor Engelbert Dollfuss, who was assassinated by Nazis in 1934. The party considers Dollfuss its spiritual father.

Yesterday its leader, Wolfgang Schüssel signed a coalition pact with Jörg Haider's Freedom party that should allow them to govern Austria jointly for the next four years.

Mr Haider also has a father figure in the background: his real father, Robert. After the murder of Dollfuss, Robert - a member of the Nazis' SA stormtroopers who were suspected of implication in the plot, fled to Germany.

His son has never disowned his father's past as one of Hitler's keenest supporters in Austria. Far from it. "In retrospect one is always wiser," he once said. "As a descendant one should not be so arrogant as to say, I would have known better."

Austria's mainstream conservatives have come a very long way from their origins to get to the point they reached yesterday. But Mr Schüssel remains confident that he can keep his new-found allies in check.

"There is no doubt that Austria will prove that it will continue to be a reliable and stable partner in the European Union," he told ORF radio yesterday. But others remained unconvinced.

"Jörg Haider is a hand-grenade from which the pin has been removed. Schüssel cannot hold it down for four years," said one liberal political commentator in Vienna.

The Freedom party did not enter as a junior partner into the deal that set up the new government. It got more votes and the same number of seats as the People's party in last October's general election. As such, it was fully entitled to a majority of seats in the new cabinet.

In the event it secured two of the four main posts - finance and justice. More important perhaps, the distribution of ministerial portfolios announced last night puts Mr Haider's hands on the levers of patronage in a country riddled with cronyism, in which the state employs more than one in five of the workforce.

The Freedom party gets not only social affairs, which accounts for 30% of Austria's gross domestic product, but also the big-spending infrastructure ministry.

The chancellery has admittedly been earmarked for Mr Schüssel. But that is not as important a gesture as it might appear from outside. In Austria, the powers of the head of government are more circumscribed than those of his counterpart in Germany, and traditionally his influence has depended on a harmonious working relationship with the finance minister. That cannot now be guaranteed with the treasury in the hands of a member of the Freedom party.

The closeness which the two party leaders were so keen to put on show yesterday is of very recent origin. During last year's election campaign, Mr Schüssel said repeatedly that he would go into opposition rather than form a government with the Freedom party.

The People's party has been one of the twin pillars of a corporatist model of government in Austria for the past 30 years. Mr Haider and his followers claim to want to smash it to pieces and replace it with an entirely original construction in which the market economy and a leaner bureaucracy would co-exist with curbs on immigration, and financial support for non-working mothers.

Mr Haider calls it the Third Republic. Critics have termed it "yuppy fascism".

On the face of it, there would seem to be every chance that this odd mix will lead to a falling-out: that its constituent members will either bust up or make such a mess of governing the country that they will be voted out of office in four years' time.

A great deal will depend on the behaviour of Mr Haider himself. He may have decided to remain out of the cabinet but his influence will be undiminished. Free of the requirements of collective cabinet responsibility, he will be in a position to criticise the government's less popular moves with impunity.

Jörg Haider is the Freedom party. Without him, political analysts estimate, its share of the vote would fall to 10% or less.

And he shows no signs of toning down his rabble-rousing rhetoric. Yesterday he refused to go back on his remark to the German weekly Die Zeit, in which he compared the European Union to a chicken coop and himself to a fox. It was scarcely the sort of language his new coalition allies had hoped to hear in a week in which Austria's EU partners had been close to apoplexy over the People's party's planned alliance with the Freedom party.

What worries Mr Haider's critics inside and outside Austria is that, from a position of virtual immunity, he can gradually undermine his conservative partners and end up dominating their alliance.

The People's party is already weakened. It has suffered more than any other from the gathering revolt against the cosy politics of the past 30 years. It bled votes last October, but more significantly, it has lost support at a faster rate than any other party in the months since. The latest polls suggest it has no more backing now than the Greens.

For the moment, Mr Haider still looks every inch the lion, and Mr Schüssel less and less like a man with his hand on the whip.

fields.headline: 365 buys sports infotainment site
fields.standfirst:
Statistics provider netted at £31m

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Three friends who met while playing sports as students at Bristol university have sold the rugby focused website business they set up shortly after graduating to 365 Corporation for £31m.
fields.body:
Three friends who met while playing sports as students at Bristol university have sold the rugby focused website business they set up shortly after graduating to 365 Corporation for £31m.

Nick Roberts, Alex Vile and Chris Pilling - all in their early 30s - have accepted £28m in new 365 shares and the remainder in cash for Datanet, which was established in 1995 to offer digitally delivered sports and entertainment content.

Between them and former RugbyNews editor Richard Pembroke they own around 75% of the company.

Dan Thompson, the chief executive of 365, said Datanet's more statistically based products, which include Planet Rugby, Planet F1, Planet Trivia and Cricketline, would complement 365's news coverage and editorial style. "Our expanded content offerings and the size of our combined audience provide a strong platform as we continue to develop revenue streams such as advertising sales and sponsorship, e-commerce, wireless applications and betting," he said.

Contributors to Datanet's sites include the South African cricketer, Allan Donald, and the former points world record holder of rugby, Michael Lynagh.

Mr Roberts and Mr Pembroke will remain with the company to help integrate and develop its products into the enlarged group.

In December 1999 Datanet sites attracted 300,000 unique users, according to the company. Unaudited accounts show net liabilities of £340,851 at January 31 and a loss of £638,890 in respect of the 10 months ending January 31.

Mr Thompson said that 365, which is sitting on a cash pile of around £50m following its December float, would continue to expand aggressively through both organic growth and acquisition.

The company is in the process of developing software and technology capable of delivering its content across multiple platforms.

Shares in 365 performed brightly after listing in December and hit a high of 272p, but have since struggled to live up to their pre-float hype. Last night the shares closed down 4p at 228p, following a 16% rise the previous day.

webTitle: Ford plans to put all staff online

fields.headline: Ford plans to put all staff online
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Ford's 350,000 employees worldwide, including more than 26,000 in Britain worried about their jobs, are to be offered a computer and the chance to surf the internet from home for a nominal fee.
fields.body:
Ford's 350,000 employees worldwide, including more than 26,000 in Britain worried about their jobs, are to be offered a computer and the chance to surf the internet from home for a nominal fee.

Amid widespread - and rebutted - fears of imminent plant closures in Europe, including the flagship plant in Dagenham, the world's second-largest car manufacturer said it planned to put its international staff at the cutting edge of e-commerce.

The 26,326 Ford employees in the UK, assuming their plant is still open, can expect to be offered a Hewlett Packard PC, printer and modem for about £3 a month this year.

The package, which they can upgrade at their own expense and allows incidental personal use, is said by Bill Ford, the group's chairman, to be "part of a global strategy to become the world's leading consumer company of automotive products and services".

The programme is to be rolled out from the US in the next 12 months. It is designed to raise the skills of the group's employees when a growing amount of Ford's business, including buying and selling cars, will be done online.

As one employee put it: "The whole world's way of getting information and even talking to each other has changed radically."

Ford, meanwhile, confirmed that its low-margin European operations, including UK plants, are to be subjected to another radical review and cost-cutting in an effort to raise returns from last year's paltry $28m on sales of $30bn.

The UK, with main plants in Dagenham, Bridgend, south Wales, and Halewood, Merseyside, could be the prime target for any closures because of the pound's continuing strength.

The UK operation, threatened by a strike of 3,000 white-collar staff, has been under review for some years. But union leaders yesterday insisted that the productivity record of UK workers merited continuing investment.

webTitle: 'I felt helpless' pilot tells Sharif trial

fields.headline: 'I felt helpless' pilot tells Sharif trial
fields.standfirst:
Pakistan's ousted PM is accused of risking 200 lives

Pakistan coup: special report
fields.trailText: The ousted prime minister of Pakistan, Nawaz Sharif, sat stoney faced in court yesterday as a pilot described how he had pleaded with air traffic controllers in Karachi to allow his plane carrying 200 passengers to land before it ran out of fuel.
fields.byline: Jason Burke in Islamabad and AP in Karachi
fields.body:
The ousted prime minister of Pakistan, Nawaz Sharif, sat stoney faced in court yesterday as a pilot described how he had pleaded with air traffic controllers in Karachi to allow his plane carrying 200 passengers to land before it ran out of fuel.

Mr Sharif is alleged to have ordered the plane to be stopped from landing in a deliberate attempt to endanger the life of one of the passengers, General Pervez Musharraf, the most senior soldier in the country, whom he had sacked a few hours earlier and who later assumed control of the country.

The pilot, Captain Syed Sarwat Hussein, said he was alarmed after being told by Karachi air traffic control that he could not land at the airport in the southern port city.

"I have 198 souls on board, a limited amount of fuel and if I'm not allowed to land - that will be the end of the story," Mr Hussein said he told the control tower.

Unknown to Mr Hussein, the prime minister had sacked the army chief at about the time the plane was taking off from Colombo, Sri Lanka. The pilot was forced into a desperate search for a safe place to touch down as his fuel supply rapidly dwindled.

"I felt helpless," Mr Hussein told the court. "It was a very tense situation, to say the least."

The flight from Sri Lanka was proceeding without incident until Mr Hussein made his first radio contact with the air traffic control tower in Karachi, and was immediately asked about the plane's remaining fuel supply.

"It was quite an unusual question," Mr Hussein said.

Even more unsettling, he was asked if he could find another airport to land. The plane had enough fuel to reach the airport in Nawabshah, also in southern Pakistan. But as the aircraft descended to land there, the pilot was told that it, too, was off limits.

"That created a very alarming situation because Nawabshah was available for other flights, but not to us," Mr Hussein said. "I reached the conclusion that it was because of the presence of the chief of army staff on board."

It was not until army generals loyal to Gen Musharraf made a last-ditch effort to secure Karachi airport that Mr Hussein was given permission to land, with about seven minutes of fuel remaining.

Lawyers appearing for Mr Sharif and his six co-defendants say the prime minister issued the order to divert the flight only after the coup was begun. They say the army coup was illegal and unconstitutional and that Mr Sharif was trying to defend "democracy" in Pakistan.

The former prime minister is charged with attempted murder, kidnapping and terrorism. He faces a possible death sentence.

The case is being tried in a special anti-terrorism court, set up by Mr Sharif himself to expedite trials that were being delayed in Pakistan's absurdly inefficient judicial system. The new courts were criticised at the time by senior judges and human rights activists, who said the facilities would be used to crack down on the government's political opponents. Now, however, it is the army that is being accused of manipulating the judiciary.

Last week the army forced judges to swear new oaths of allegiance by which they agreed not to take any action against the current executive. Several senior judges resigned, claiming that the new oaths were a serious assault on the independence of the judiciary.

fields.headline: Fracas over fengshui grips Taiwan
fields.standfirst:
Shamanist lends magic to Nationalist party rivalries

Taiwan and China: special report
fields.trailText: Two of the main candidates in Taiwan's presidential election next month have become embroiled in a row about their fathers' graves, in which intriguing overtones of magic have surfaced.
fields.body:
Two of the main candidates in Taiwan's presidential election next month have become embroiled in a row about their fathers' graves, in which intriguing overtones of magic have surfaced.

The Taiwanese press has been fascinated by an attempt made to destroy the fengshui, or "favourable atmosphere", surrounding a family tomb of one political aspirant, and transfer it to another.

Li Jian-jun, a self-styled master of magical arts, claims he was hired by the family of Lien Chan - now the official Nationalist party candidate - to check out Mr Lien's fengshui. His research included a visit to the family grave at Yangmingshan, in the hills above Taipei.

Mr Li says he detected a black miasma, an unwholesome or foreboding atmosphere, emanating from an adjacent tomb, which belonged to the family of James Soong.

Mr Soong is the breakaway Nationalist candidate who, in spite of some questionable financial dealings, is much more popular than Mr Lien among the Taiwanese voters.

Mr Li says he dealt with the miasma by placing nine iron nails around the tomb of Mr Soong's father. Across Asia, from Tibet to Korea, iron has habitually been used in shamanistic folk magic to expel evil influences.

Mr Soong's camp say they knew about Mr Li's claim but had no intention of using it in their election campaign. Mr Lien's followers say they were tipped off that Mr Soong's wife had the story, and they decided to move quickly with a pre-emptive denial.

Once the tale had been published, Mr Soong then used it to attack Mr Lien, saying that "he only considers his own good fortune, and pays no attention to that of the country as a whole".

Mr Lien's camp hit back with the charge that Mr Soong had funded large-scale property deals made by his son in the US during the past nine years. Details of five property transactions in California, worth a total of $1.8m (£1.1m), were brandished at a press conference.

Mr Soong has not denied that his son was involved in property speculation, but has insisted he did not put up the money, and in response launched a counter-attack.

"I want to ask where the Lien family's assets of more than $10bn [£6.2bn] come from," he demanded on Wednesday.

"Please let us know whether or not his family embezzled Japanese assets [after Japan's occupation of Taiwan was ended in 1945]."

The opposition Democratic Progressive party's candidate, Chen Shui-bian, who polls suggest is slightly in the lead, has kept clear of the row between the two Nationalist party rivals.

The affair may seem trivial compared with the central election issue of relations with mainland China, but this has not diminished its appeal.

Questions about the shadowy background of Mr Li, who is about to publish a book in the US, added to the interest.

He is an ex-mainlander who claims magical healing powers through qigong - the art of Qi. This is the same semi-mystical belief practised by the Falun Gong sect banned by Beijing.

webTitle: Alarm as Moscow swaps journalist for soldiers

fields.headline: Alarm as Moscow swaps journalist for soldiers
fields.standfirst:
Kremlin washes its hands of correspondent's fate after claiming to have traded him to Chechen guerrillas for two Russian servicemen

Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: The Russian authorities yesterday announced that a journalist missing in Chechnya for more than two weeks had been handed over to Chechen guerrillas in a prisoner swap as his family, lawyer, employers and human rights activists voiced fears for the reporter's life.
fields.body:
The Russian authorities yesterday announced that a journalist missing in Chechnya for more than two weeks had been handed over to Chechen guerrillas in a prisoner swap as his family, lawyer, employers and human rights activists voiced fears for the reporter's life.

In an eerie development that alarmed friends and family of the reporter, Andrei Babitsky, a Kremlin spokesman said the Russian authorities, which had been holding the journalist for more than a week, were no longer responsible for his fate.

"There is every reason today to be worried about Babitsky's life," said his lawyer, Genry Reznik. "This is barbarity. It's a jesuitical manoeuvre by the authorities. Journalists have been placed on the same footing as the rebels, a pen on the same footing as a bayonet."

Mr Babitsky's wife, Lyudmila, said the Russians "will later say that the Chechens killed him or something else".

According to the Kremlin's spokesman on the Chechnya war, Sergei Yastrzhembsky, the exchange of prisoners was arranged by the FSB, the domestic intelligence service and successor to the KGB, which was previously headed by the prime minister and acting president, Vladimir Putin.

Mr Yastrzhembsky said Mr Babitsky, a veteran reporter for the US-funded Radio Liberty who has been missing since January 15, was exchanged for two Russian servicemen yesterday afternoon south of the Chechen capital, Grozny. The exchange was filmed and the footage would be made available to the media, the Kremlin said last night.

It was a stunning development in a two-week drama involving Mr Babitsky. fields.headline: On hateful Haider
fields.trailText: The 14 EU states are correct in their hostility to the sinister political developments in Austria (Europe in turmoil over far right pact, February 3). Senior politicians in the original six EEC states were members of the resistance during the second world war.
fields.body:
The 14 EU states are correct in their hostility to the sinister political developments in Austria (Europe in turmoil over far right pact, February 3). Senior politicians in the original six EEC states were members of the resistance during the second world war.

If the Freedom party is allowed into the Austrian coalition, it will send out the wrong message to the states of the former eastern bloc which aspire to join the EU, especially countries such as Romania and Slovakia, which witnessed extreme rightwing parties as members of governing coalitions in the 90s.

One of the inspirations behind the European movement was the manifesto produced in April 1945 by the members of Buchenwald concentration camp, determined there should never be a return to the pre-1945 Europe.
Simon Wilson
Ampthill, Beds

 I find the rise of Haider odious, but that provides no justification for EU countries to interfere with the democratic choice of a member state. If they persist, I fear the historical parallels that will be drawn within Austria will not be with the rise of Nazi Germany, but with the Brezhnev Doctrine of limited sovereignty.
Nick Blackstock
Bradford
n.blackstock@which.net

 The Freedom party's programme contains statements such as "Every citizen has the right to decide to which ethnic group he wants to be assigned", which smack of "separate development" and discrimination. As rapporteur for the European parliament's annual debate on racism for this year, I believe that the substance of Europe's response to Haider is not an overreaction. The need now is to stress preparedness to invoke the EU treaty's Article 7, which allows for membership rights to be suspended if fundamental rights are breached.
Sarah Ludford MEP

fields.headline: Ulster sparks a new feud
fields.trailText: Professor Patterson's response to my article (Letters, February 3) is insufficiently considered, but it brings out matters of constitutional importance. Nowhere did I say the Good Friday agreement established joint authority, nor did my arguments rest on this premise.
fields.body:
Professor Patterson's response to my article (Letters, February 3) is insufficiently considered, but it brings out matters of constitutional importance. Nowhere did I say the Good Friday agreement established joint authority, nor did my arguments rest on this premise.

The Northern Irish parties, in consultation over the implementation of the agreement, embedded in the Northern Ireland 1998 act, explicitly denied the secretary of state the general right to dissolve the assembly and gave that power to themselves - which is why the secretary of state would have to act either under crown prerogatives or with fresh legislation in order to suspend the assembly. They did, however, give the secretary of state the right to propose a date for a fresh assembly election if first and deputy first ministers could not be elected. I submit that anything that alters the agreement without the consent of the parties that negotiated the agreement is a breach of the spirit and letter of the agreement - and that applies to any new power of suspension and generalised right of dissolution assumed by Westminster.

Professor Patterson and I do not disagree over the depth of the current crisis. However, he is wrong to assume that Mr Trimble cannot in future get re-elected as first minister "given the balance of forces within unionism in the assembly". True the first minister and deputy first minister have to be elected by the parallel consent procedure and presently Mr Trimble would fall at least one vote short of the necessary total within the unionist bloc.

But within the letter of the 1998 act the assembly can propose, by weighted majority, an amendment to the procedure for electing the first and deputy first minister which would then be sent to Westminster for ratification. In short, the suspension of the assembly should not be justified on the grounds that that is the only way that Mr Trimble can return to office.

I agree with Professor Patterson that republicans are to blame for the crisis and my sympathies are with Mr Trimble and Mr Empey and their colleagues, but not with their call for a suspension.
Prof Brendan O'Leary
London School of Economics

 Only the most blinkered republican would believe the current crisis is not a consequence of the unwillingness of the IRA to give one inch on decommissioning. All the other parties have bent over backwards to give the IRA the opportunity to start decommissioning "voluntarily". What credibility can the republican movement retain when it flies in the face of the clearly expressed will of the Irish people, nationalist and unionist, north and south of the border? The removal of the constitutional claim by the Republic over the six counties was made possible by the IRA ceasefire. This removal makes it clear a united Ireland will never be achieved by military means, but only when the people in the six counties want this to happen. If the IRA can't get beyond the "not one bullet" mentality then they're in danger of going down in history as not only standing in the way of democracy for the people of Northern Ireland, but also as failing to hasten the reunification of Ireland.
Joe Charnock
Boston, US

 Under the GFA the British government was supposed to publish a timetable for demilitarisation but has failed to do so. Many nationalists complain of a growing security force presence in their areas. If there were some visible sign of demilitarisation on the ground then maybe the IRA would hand over some weapons. But to expect the IRA to hand over weaponry in the absence of demilitarisation is to live in a fantasy world.
Paul Donovan
London

webTitle: Glacial response to global warming claim

fields.headline: Glacial response to global warming claim
fields.trailText: George Monbiot is right in at least one point (The seas rise, the glaciers disappear, January 27): the Indian sub-continent is of vital significance to our global future. Sadly, in seeking to make easy points about global warming he has got his "facts" wrong. Glaciers contribute virtually nothing to the flow of the Ganges, Brahmaputra and Indus rivers, which depend primarily on monsoon rain and to a much lesser extent on snow melt (not glacier melt).
fields.body:
George Monbiot is right in at least one point (The seas rise, the glaciers disappear, January 27): the Indian sub-continent is of vital significance to our global future. Sadly, in seeking to make easy points about global warming he has got his "facts" wrong. Glaciers contribute virtually nothing to the flow of the Ganges, Brahmaputra and Indus rivers, which depend primarily on monsoon rain and to a much lesser extent on snow melt (not glacier melt).

There has been no long term decline in precipitation in the Himalaya. The idea that the glaciers are retreating so fast that the rivers may dry up by the summer of 2040 displays an embarrassing ignorance of the normal hydrological cycle of all these rivers, whose low flow period is in the winter, and which in summer continue to pour water down from the Himalaya.

Nor is Bangladesh being submerged by sea-level rises with massive refugee consequences. In fact the Ganges delta is witnessing a continued net growth in its surface area. The degree to which Bangladesh alone has dramatically increased food production and industrial output in the last 20 years suggests that there are far more practical and feasible steps to tackling poverty and security than George turning off his kettle.
Robert W Bradnock
Department of Geography,
School of Oriental and African Studies
rb3@soas.ac.uk

fields.headline: Straight about being gay
fields.trailText: I didn't even know what homosexuality was when I first discovered other male bodies as a boy (My daughter is just fine, January 31).
fields.body:
I didn't even know what homosexuality was when I first discovered other male bodies as a boy (My daughter is just fine, January 31).

When I left school, like my friends, I tried to build relationships with the opposite sex. While nearly everyone I knew was successful, my attempts failed miserably once past the starting post. My body was not interested. This disposes of the "corruption of youth" argument.

I went through hell. I couldn't understand what was wrong. I thought I was the only person in the world built this way. And then I had my first adult homosexual contact. We flew. This was all I had ever wanted.

Later I met the man I am still with, nearly 30 years on. We depend totally on each other for support and succour, though we scrap from time to time. I fear deeply for the time that death shall separate us.

Will whoever is left be able to cope?

Is this a "pretend" family relationship? Worse still, had I not realised what I am, how many women would I have made unhappy? How many children might have been left without a father due to my walking out? How many divorces are founded in unrealised or suppressed homosexuality?

Do the Christians and other moralists expect all homosexuals to live in lonely misery? Or is it that they are in reality frightened of something that they suspect, or worse still know, may be inside themselves, and their being found out?
Name and address supplied

fields.headline: Lib-Lab pact on Europe agreed
fields.standfirst:
Partnership revived over EU summits stance

The European Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: Labour and the Liberal Democrats have agreed a joint stance on reform of the European Union, in a remarkable piece of co-operation that keeps alive Tony Blair's "project" of consensual politics.
fields.body:
Labour and the Liberal Democrats have agreed a joint stance on reform of the European Union, in a remarkable piece of co-operation that keeps alive Tony Blair's "project" of consensual politics.

The partnership between Labour and the Liberal Democrats has been fragile in recent months as electoral reform, the Liberal Democrats' big prize, slipped down the Labour agenda. But today's publication of the document setting out a common negotiating position for the forthcoming European summits on enlargement will revive speculation of closer ties in the future. "It is about ongoing co-operation. It is about being inclusive," a Labour source said.

The document, intended to be a counter-blast at Tory Euro-scepticism, says the two parties want to promote an agenda that is "pro-Europe, pro-enlargement and pro-reform". A common stance is set out on various issues, including surrender of the British veto (though only in a few areas), number of commissioners and role of the European parliament.

Both Labour and the the Liberal Democrats said yesterday it was a first for two political parties to reach consensus on an approach to be taken at the negotiating table - all the more unusual for the fact that one of the parties was not even in the government.

Talks between the two parties on Europe were agreed before Christmas at a meeting, chaired by Tony Blair, of a joint cabinet commitee, which is attended by a mixture of senior Labour and Liberal Democrats. It was the first such meeting since Charles Kennedy became Liberal Democrat leader.

Robin Cook, along with Mr Blair, is the main advocate of closer ties with the Liberal Democrats. The Northern Ireland secretary, Peter Mandelson, is another supporter of "big tent" politics but the rest of the cabinet, especially the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, and the chancellor, Gordon Brown, tend to be cool.

An intergovernmental conference at the end of the year in France promises to be one of the most important European summits, paving the way for an increase in member countries to 28, most of them from eastern Europe. A preliminary IGC is to be held in a fortnight to pave the way.

In their joint paper, Labour and the Liberal Democrats set out "Britain's core objectives for institutional reform in the IGC to ensure that enlargement can happen". It adds: "Our influence will be stronger if we go into the negotiations with a postive agenda of our own instead of simply threatening to veto the ideas of others, as in previous IGCs."

On the most controversial issue, the extension of qualified majority voting in the main decision making body, the council of ministers, the two are in favour, in contrast with the Conservatives who see this as dilution of sovereignty.

The document says: "Those who claim that QMV is a threat to Britain's interests ignore all the available evidence. Compared to many other member states, Britain is rarely outvoted in the council of ministers, only five times in the last two years. In the same period Germany was outvoted 20 times and France eight times.

"Those who ideologically oppose any extension of QMV often talk as though the rest of Europe wants to gang up on us. This has no rational basis. It is evidence of the paranoia and defeatism that characterises British anti-Europeanism."

Labour and the Liberal Democrats say in the document the best way forward is to look at the extension of QMV on a case by case basis, favouring it for liberalisation of transport and certain EU appointments but retaining the veto for treaty changes, taxation, social security, defence, border controls, and own resources.

Talks between the Labour and Liberal Democrat sides are scheduled to continue throughout the year.

fields.headline: The process is still alive
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: The British government, Peter Mandelson told the Commons last night, is ready to suspend the Northern Ireland executive and assembly. But the suspension has been suspended. While the legislation is framed and put through, the institutions remain - just - alive. While there is life, there is hope. The British and Irish governments were working through the night in search of enough of an IRA concession allow the suspension process to be stopped. On pessimistic assumptions, that will fail.
fields.body:
The British government, Peter Mandelson told the Commons last night, is ready to suspend the Northern Ireland executive and assembly. But the suspension has been suspended. While the legislation is framed and put through, the institutions remain - just - alive. While there is life, there is hope. The British and Irish governments were working through the night in search of enough of an IRA concession allow the suspension process to be stopped. On pessimistic assumptions, that will fail.

Power sharing will have collapsed in a matter of months, as it did before. Attempts to revive it will be dauntingly difficult: even impossible. On the optimistic assumption, so much hangs on the outcome of these latest maneouvres that they can't be allowed to fail. Such a prospect is seen as intolerable: not just by the people of Northern Ireland, in both communities, who have suffered so much and who have so much savoured these times of peace since the IRA ceasefire, but by all the politicians: in London, in Dublin, in Washington, and, in Northern Ireland itself, from the Unionists across to Sinn Fein; even by the IRA which this week declared its commitment to averting any return to violence. It would have been better had decommissioning never taken on its present importance. But it has, and it is ineradicable. David Trimble's resignation letter remains in the safe. If he goes, the chances of saving the process may go with him. There has to be, in the time now bought, enough of a gesture to keep the Unionists on board. Even stalemate is dangerous. And the prospect of a return to the bloodstained past is too awful to contemplate.

webTitle: Off the wall jokes by an old master

fields.headline: Off the wall jokes by an old master
fields.trailText: A 330-year-old joke claimed new victims at the National Gallery this week when staff hanging an exhibition of 17th century illusionistic paintings rushed to rescue a canvas left facing the wall.
fields.body:
A 330-year-old joke claimed new victims at the National Gallery this week when staff hanging an exhibition of 17th century illusionistic paintings rushed to rescue a canvas left facing the wall.

The bare canvas tacked to a wooden stretcher is the painting; everything, including the scrap of paper held in place by a blob of red sealing wax, was painted in 1670 for the King of Denmark by one Cornelius Gijsbrechts, who disappeared from history without trace after four dazzling years in Copenhagen.

Painted Illusions is the first major exhibition of Gijsbrechts' work outside Denmark. The paintings were produced between 1668 and 1672 for Frederick III and his son, Christian V, and have never left the royal collection.

Olaf Koester, the Danish curator, and David Bomford, at the National Gallery, between them know more than anyone else about Gijsbrechts - which is almost nothing. He is assumed to be Flemish. But almost all his known work was produced in the four years in Copenhagen. There is nothing in the state archives to explain why he left or where he went. "Did he die? Did he stop painting? Did he go mad?" Dr Koester said yesterday. "It is a mystery."

The paintings were produced between 1668 and 1672 for Frederick III and his son, Christian V, and have never left the royal collection. Olaf Koester, the Danish curator, and David Bomford, at the National Gallery, between them know more than anyone else about Gijsbrechts - which is almost nothing. He is assumed to be Flemish. But almost all his known work was produced in the four years in Copenhagen. There is nothing in the state archives to explain why he left or where he went. "Did he die? Did he stop painting? Did he go mad?" Dr Koester said yesterday. "It is a mystery."

webTitle: Republicans call halt to dirty tricks in districts

fields.headline: Republicans call halt to dirty tricks in districts
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: In a desperate move not to hand John McCain another campaign weapon, George W Bush's advisers have urged the pro-Bush Republican hierarchy in New York state to abandon their increasingly ruthless attempt to keep the Arizona senator off the ballot in the crucial March 7 New York primary.
fields.body:
In a desperate move not to hand John McCain another campaign weapon, George W Bush's advisers have urged the pro-Bush Republican hierarchy in New York state to abandon their increasingly ruthless attempt to keep the Arizona senator off the ballot in the crucial March 7 New York primary.

Until now, the Bush campaign had conspicuously refused to condemn efforts by the Republican party's state machine, headed by Governor George Pataki, to contest Mr McCain's right to be on the ballot in almost half the state's 31 congressional districts.

New York's primary ballot rules are among the most arcane in the US, requiring candidates to raise thousands of signatures on nominating petitions for each separate district several weeks before election day. This favours machine-backed candidates who have the foot-soldiers to collect the signatures and the lawyers to validate them.

The New York state Republican committee, controlled by Mr Pataki who would like to be Mr Bush's running-mate, has challenged 12 of Mr McCain's petitions on the grounds that they contain names of unregistered voters, non-Republicans and people who do not live in the right districts.

Mr McCain has counter-challenged, though he was unable to find a Republican party election lawyer to act for him. Judge Edward Korman is expected to rule on the case shortly.

The attempt to bar Mr McCain has attracted widespread bad publicity for the Bush camp.

The New York Republican congressman Peter King has complained that New York state and Iran are the only places in the world where governments decide whether their opponents can stand for election, while Mr McCain led a march to the local Russian consulate to congratulate them on having a more democratic election system than New York state.

Mr Bush's strategist Karl Rove told New York backers on Wednesday that Mr Bush would prefer his supporters not to appeal if Mr McCain's court challenge is successful, as experts believe it will be.

The story took an unexpected turn yesterday when a court removed Mr Bush's name from the ballot in New York's 16th congressional district, which covers the heavily Democratic South Bronx area.

The state Republican party acknowledged that its workers had forged scores of signatures on Mr Bush's election petition, including those of military personnel stationed overseas and an 85-year-old blind woman.

If the courts reinstate Mr McCain, he could end up on the ballot in more districts than Mr Bush.

fields.headline: Reward offered for stolen Lowrys
fields.trailText: A "substantial" reward has been offered for the recovery of more than 70 works, including five paintings by LS Lowry, stolen from a private collection.
fields.body:
A "substantial" reward has been offered for the recovery of more than 70 works, including five paintings by LS Lowry, stolen from a private collection.

The works, worth millions of pounds, were taken more than two weeks ago from premises in Northamptonshire where they were being stored. Although the owner has appealed to police that there should be no publicity, it emerged yesterday that the reward, believed to be a five-figure sum, has been offered.

The stolen Lowry works are Gateposts in the Snow, The Chapel, A Corner Shop, People on a Promenade, and Street Scene, valued at up to £250,000 each.

Northamptonshire police are investigating the theft. Interpol and auction houses around Europe have been alerted and advertisements placed in antiques trade publications to alert dealers.

Most of the paintings are 18th and 19th century works, many of them by skilled amateur English artists.

A fine art loss adjuster, Mark Dalrymple, said it was "hopefully a temporary loss" to the art world. "We have alerted the trade and placed details with the police and on computer databases, so these people are not going to get a good price if they try to sell them on."

Lowry's 1953 work Going to the Match fetched a record auction price for a modern British painting when the Professional Footballers' Association bought it for £1,926,500 last December.

Born in Manchester in 1887, Lowry studied at Salford school of art and achieved world renown while working as a rent collector and cashier. He died aged 88 in 1976.

He was best known for industrial scenes of the north featuring his "matchstick men".

webTitle: Family's vain fight to save girl, 5, as car sank in river

fields.headline: Family's vain fight to save girl, 5, as car sank in river
fields.trailText: The grandfather and father of a girl aged five who drowned when the grandfather's car plunged into the Thames told an inquest yesterday of the desperate battle to save her.
fields.body:
The grandfather and father of a girl aged five who drowned when the grandfather's car plunged into the Thames told an inquest yesterday of the desperate battle to save her.

Sarah Henderson drowned when the Mercedes 230E automatic rolled out of her grandfather's drive, crashed through railings and sank in the river at Shepperton, Surrey, last December.

Sarah, of Redburn, Northumberland, had been staying with her family at her grandparents' home and was setting off with her father for a flight home. Her grandfather, John Dumbrell, was driving them to Heathrow.

In a statement read out to the inquest in Woking, Surrey, Mr Dumbrell said he had moved forward about three yards in the drive, facing the road, but stopped the car when he realised he had forgotten his glasses.

He left the engine running as he went to fetch them. As he returned to the house somebody shouted that the car was moving. "I went to get back but it was moving too quickly. I got hold of the door but could not open it. The car went through the fence and tipped into the river."

His son-in-law, Ian Henderson, battled to free Sarah from the back seat. "He was half out of the car as it floated out about 12ft. Then the current turned it over, and it continued to float downstream."

Sarah's mother, Mary, a doctor, swam out to the car, said Mr Dumbrell. "She went to the offside door, and Ian was trying to get to the back door to save his daughter. At this point the car started to sink."

As it went out of sight Mrs Henderson helped her husband back to the bank, where a crowd was gathering.

Mr Dumbrell said: "There was a group of people trying to get a boat started. I ran back to the house and phoned an ambulance before running back to try to start my own boat."

The inquest heard that the car was not located for several hours, and efforts by doctors and paramedics to resuscitate Sarah failed.

Mr Henderson, a civil servant, told the inquest: "I managed to get out, but it was not possible to get my daughter out. She was strapped into the middle seat, and it was impossible to get across to her and release her."

The inquest heard that the Mercedes, which had done 39,000 miles, had a parking brake operated by a foot pedal and released by a lever.

A traffic investigator, PC David Pendleton, said the car had been serviced last July and there was "nothing apparently wrong". The brakes were "sufficiently operative".

He added: "While the engine is cold the automatic choke would operate and would tend to drive the car forward. However, if it is on a very slight incline under normal circumstances, for example waiting at traffic lights, it would need an application of the accelerator to drive it forward."

He said once the car had started to move forward it would have been impossible to apply the parking brake from the passenger seat.

A pathologist, Michael Hall, concluded that Sarah, who was a pupil at Henshaw Church of England primary school, died of drowning.

Recording the verdict of accidental death, the Surrey coroner, Michael Burgess, said: "I am sure all of us feel for the family, all generations of the family, and we extend to the family heartfelt condolences on this very sad death."

Mr and Mrs Henderson have two other daughters, Ruth, four, and Alexandra, 22 months.
