webTitle: Bush lurches to the right as supporters panic over McCain primary victory

fields.headline: Bush lurches to the right as supporters panic over McCain primary victory
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: George W Bush's campaign staff launched a desperate damage limitation exercise yesterday, seeking to reassure his stunned backers that the Texas governor was still on course for his party's presidential nomination.
fields.body:
George W Bush's campaign staff launched a desperate damage limitation exercise yesterday, seeking to reassure his stunned backers that the Texas governor was still on course for his party's presidential nomination.

Forty-eight hours after John McCain beat him soundly in the New Hampshire primary, Mr Bush's Republican nomination campaign is tottering like a boxer stung by the perfect left hook.

The question now is whether Mr Bush will be saved by the result of the February 19 primary in conservative South Carolina or whether Mr McCain has effectively destroyed the myth of Mr Bush as the great Republican hope.

Mr Bush's initial campaign response has been to lurch to the right. In a speech at the Bob Jones university in Greenville this week - a college where Ian Paisley received his doctorate and multiracial dating is banned - Mr Bush used the word "conservative" six times in one minute and accused Mr McCain of taking leftwing and Democrat stances.

This may help Mr Bush against Mr McCain but it also gives the Democrat challenger, Al Gore, a boost. On present form, the vice-president will make mincemeat of Mr Bush in this autumn's presidential debates.

"Nobody is jumping off bridges or holding guns to their heads," JC Watts, the African-American Oklahoma congressman and a possible Bush running mate, said yesterday.

But the mood of barely repressed panic that struck the grandees of the Republican party on Tuesday seems to be growing rather than abating. One Bush fundraiser said yesterday: "Every congressman is sitting there now saying, 'Holy cow! Did I do the right thing? Am I too out front with this guy?'"

Bush aides have launched "a massive campaign of reassurance", emailing and calling congress members and party donors to prevent defections. The Bush team fears their financial backers may invest in Mr McCain to cover their bets.

Mr Bush's fellow Republican governors are now likely to play a more central role in the campaign, emphasising the claim that he is not a Washington insider.

Tuesday's defeat in New Hampshire struck at the heart of Mr Bush's greatest single asset - the belief among Republicans of both right and left that the two-time Texas governor is the man to return their party to the White House.

Mr Bush set off on the campaign trail last summer in a hired plane that he jokingly dubbed "Great Expectations", bolstered by a cash-raising juggernaut that has so far brought in $69m (£43m). But despite this and widespread endorsements from party grandees, he has failed to convince Republican voters. He scored 31% in last August's Iowa straw poll, 41% in last week's Iowa caucuses, and only 30% in the New Hampshire primary. In each case, a clear majority of Republican voters rejected the man who said he was a winner.

The 19-point defeat in New Hampshire has burst a pent-up dam of doubts about Mr Bush. The Republican politicians and pundits who barely had a critical word for him before Tuesday have since layed out their doubts.

"George W Bush assembled a campaign apparatus capable of backing his candidacy with even more marketing power than the Ford Motor Company put behind the Edsel," wrote the conservative columnist George Will yesterday. "Now he has 16 days, until South Carolina votes, to prove that he is not, like the car, a product designed in disregard of changing market forces."

The New York Times columnist William Safire, a former Richard Nixon speechwriter, put it even more bluntly. "Bush can't win," he said yesterday.

An eve-of-poll New Hampshire focus group organised by the MSNBC cable channel revealed extraordinary levels of hostility to Mr Bush. Voters complained about the candidate's smirk, disliked his over-reliance on big money and were turned off by his decision to campaign with his father, the former president George Bush.

The former president campaigned with his son in Milford last Saturday, announcing at a rally: "This boy, this son of ours, is not going to let you down." Campaign aides are still wincing at that disastrous reference to "this boy".

webTitle: Pay law triggers job cuts for disabled people

fields.headline: Pay law triggers job cuts for disabled people
fields.standfirst: Charity warns of social isolation for workers with severe learning disabilities as employers shy away from paying minimum wage
fields.trailText: An estimated 1,000 people with severe learning disabilities have lost their part-time jobs or had their working hours cut as a direct result of the national minimum wage, the charity Mencap says today.
fields.body:
An estimated 1,000 people with severe learning disabilities have lost their part-time jobs or had their working hours cut as a direct result of the national minimum wage, the charity Mencap says today.

Many employers have felt unable to pay the £3.60 an hour minimum to disabled people previously paid small sums for work that had low output but high therapeutic value. Other companies are paying the rate, but have reduced people's hours to keep costs constant.

Mencap, which otherwise strongly supports the minimum wage, calls for an urgent revision of the rules to enable such low output work to be classified as "special placements" exempt from the statutory provision.

David Congdon, the charity's public affairs director, said people losing jobs or hours were facing social isolation. "Most people with a learning disability want to work and we urge the government to give them that chance."

Although representations on the issue were made when the minimum wage legislation was drawn up and approved, there has been no clarification of the status of workers whose contribution is primarily social rather than commercial.

As a consequence, most employers have felt obliged to pay the minimum rate. Some, however, have continued to pay lower rates in breach of the law as it stands.

The matter is further complicated by social security rules dictating that people who receive income support benefit, as many disabled people do, face a pound for pound cut in respect of any earnings above £15 a week - a limit unchanged for 12 years.

Mencap has carried out a national survey and believes that 1,000 people with severe learning disabilities have been hit by employers withdrawing work or cutting hours.

In many cases, the charity says, it is difficult to prove an employer has dismissed somebody because of the minimum wage. In one typical instance, a woman who had worked at a residential home in Cwmbran, Gwent, making the tea and doing other simple tasks, was said by the home to have retired. More clear cut are cases of cuts in hours: a man in Droitwich, Worcestershire, who had been a factory cleaner for 15 hours a week at £1 an hour - keeping him below the income support clawback - now works just over four hours at the £3.60 rate.

Steve Beyer, deputy director of the Welsh centre for learning disabilities at the University of Wales, said studies showed that people with severe disabilities could benefit "very considerably" from work in terms of motivation and skills development.

He said: "For many people, the alternative is going to a local authority day centre. Although good examples do exist, there is plenty of research around to show that day centres are generally segregated and that they provide at worst a lower level of activity, a lower level of development and a lower level of interest."

Mencap proposes an amendment of the statutory guidance on the minimum wage, establishing an exempt category of special placements for people whose output at work is assessed at less than 30% of that of non-disabled staff.

Assessment would be done independently and exemption would be conditional on agreement among the individual, a doctor, the local disability employment adviser and any placement agency involved that the activity was therapeutic in nature.

A spokeswoman for the department of trade and industry said it was accepted that there was a lack of clarity in the minimum wage legislation about therapeutic activity. The forthcoming first annual report of the low pay commission was expected to address the question.

"This is something the government takes very seriously and wants resolved, but if the activity is work then the minimum wage must apply," the spokeswoman said.

'He was so proud of what he was doing'

For Steven Olsen, going to the factory gave his life structure and purpose. Four mornings a week, he would set off eagerly to join his workmate.

"He was so proud of what he was doing," said his mother, Valerie Statham.

But now Mr Olsen, who has a severe learning disability, can work only one morning each week. As a result of the minimum wage, the company which runs the factory has cut his hours from 15, for which he received £15, to 4 at the statutory hourly rate of £3.60.

"I can't blame the factory," says Mrs Statham. "They're in a difficult position over all this. They've been very good to Steven and everybody there has accepted him as one of them."

Mr Olsen, who is 22 and lives with his mother, has worked for four years at the factory near his home in Abertillery, Blaenau Gwent, specialising in production of felt for snooker tables.

"He helps carrying the rolls, unloading them and putting them in the stores," says his mother.

When the company cut his hours, Mr Olsen was suddenly left with three empty days. It was six weeks before Mrs Statham could find two therapeutic activities to help get him out of the house.

"I can't come up with things to occupy him: he gets really bored," she says. "He just goes up to his bedroom and listens to his music." - David Brindle

webTitle: It's been simply Hull at the office today, dear

fields.headline: It's been simply Hull at the office today, dear
fields.trailText: One of Britain's oldest ports is preparing to bow to public opinion and abandon the royal title bestowed on it 700 years ago.
fields.body:
One of Britain's oldest ports is preparing to bow to public opinion and abandon the royal title bestowed on it 700 years ago.

A four-month study has established that only a 10th of the institutions, companies and other big players in East Yorkshire call the thriving city at the mouth of the Humber by its proper name, Kingston upon Hull.

The city's marketing department last night announced a new, re-branded era, with people learning to call their home simply Hull. Mapmakers will be asked to end the current confusion of having Hull on the map and Kingston in the index, and ferry, train and air line operators are all being lobbied to go for the single syllable consistently.

"We are not officially changing the name of the city," said Hull's marketing director, John Till, aware of the strength of tradition in Yorkshire, "but in developing a brand, we have to focus on one name to avoid confusion."

The Labour council's advisers, Wolff Olins of London, whose creations include Orange and First Direct, insisted clarity was needed before regeneration projects could succeed.

The uncluttered name will be blazoned on approaches to the city with a logo, already nicknamed the "cog" or "petal", which shows a circle with five stumps leading off it, on a background of olive, tan and pastel colours. Marketing text will focus on five rather more cumbersome words: leading, creating, challenging, discovering and innovating, which will precis into the new Hull motto of "pioneering".

"The word Hull itself has no particular branding quality," said Aidan Kirby, of Wolff Olins, conscious that linguists are divided on whether it comes from an Old Scandinavian word meaning "deep river" or the Celtic term for "muddy one". Before Edward I renamed Hull as Kingston in 1293, it was known as Wyke on Hull, from an Anglo-Saxon term meaning "village".

Hull's relative obscurity in modern times, especially following the decline of deep sea fishing, hides a lustrous history of battles and sieges, and celebrated locals such as William Wilberforce, Amy Johnson and Andrew Marvell. The city is also famous for the white telephone kiosks of its locally-owned phone service, perversely known nowadays as Kingston Communications.

Once the Hull brand has sunk in, the council plans to press ahead with 29 regeneration projects, including an after-school children's university and a £37.7m ocean discovery centre designed by the architect Terry Farrell.

Ambitions beyond that appear even more vaulting; Mr Till told last night's gathering: "We need to alter the DNA of Hull to make ourselves one of the country's top 10 cities."

Downside of going uptown

Harrogate is soon to become Harrogate Spa, in honour of its chalybeate springs, which attracted three queens one night in 1912. The spa complex is being renovated

Saffron Walden sounded a lot grander than Chipping Walden, Essex, to 14th century burghers who changed the name to honour the growing of saffron crocuses for the medicinal market. The trade died in 1768.

Rugeley in Staffordshire petitioned to change its name in 1855 because of Victorian poisoner William Rugeley. It backed down when the prime minister, Lord Palmerston, gave permission - on condition the town was renamed after him.

Buxworth in Derbyshire began as Bugsworth, and local purists have long resented the Victorian name change. But a move to restore the original, put to a referendum last year, was firmly voted down.

fields.headline: Elderly fear nursing homes
fields.trailText: Elderly women are so scared of losing their independence that eight in 10 would rather die than break their hip and be admitted to a nursing home, according to research published yesterday.
fields.body:
Elderly women are so scared of losing their independence that eight in 10 would rather die than break their hip and be admitted to a nursing home, according to research published yesterday.

Women would rather develop breast cancer, have a heart attack or suffer from arthritis than fracture their hip, the study in the British Medical Journal found.

The research focused on 194 Australian women over 75. Eighty per cent said they would rather die than break their hip and go into a nursing home.

The women said they felt they were already living on "borrowed time" and did not want to be a burden but they feared losing their homes, independence and possessions.

A recent Australian study found that 22% of women living at home before they broke their hip moved to nursing homes within a year and only 24% were walking as well as before.

Pauline Thompson of Age Concern said: "If people do need nursing home care, they should be allowed to see a number of homes and be given a choice.

"There is this myth about care homes and there have been scare stories, but they can offer people support and independence and imaginative packages can be worked out."

A spokeswoman for Help the Aged said: "Quality of life in nursing homes is possible, but it is dependent on staff giving residents choice, dignity and control over their lives."

webTitle: SAS woman who dared did not win

fields.headline: SAS woman who dared did not win
fields.trailText: The first book by a woman engaged in covert operations with the SAS in Northern Ireland has been withdrawn after complaints by the ministry of defence.
fields.body:
The first book by a woman engaged in covert operations with the SAS in Northern Ireland has been withdrawn after complaints by the ministry of defence.

She Who Dared, published last month by Pen & Sword Books, describes operations in the 1980s by the 14th Intelligence Company, a special armed anti-terrorist unit of plain-clothed soldiers.

It contains criticism of the Royal Ulster Constabulary. The author, who uses the pen name, Jackie George, also attacks the "archaic male chauvinism" of the soldiers she worked with.

The publishers said last month that after a long legal battle with the MoD they could finally release the book. It said it had been submitted to the ministry prior to publication and some changes were made. The author, it said, "became disillusioned and angry at the way situations were being scandalously manipulated by groups to meet their own ends, including the RUC who had jurisdiction over the army".

Yesterday, the ministry said it had sought an injunction to prevent further distribution of the book. A spokeswoman for Pen & Sword Books refused to comment beyond saying there was "a legal problem".

Several books about the special forces in Northern Ireland have been published over the past few years, most after being cleared by the MoD.

fields.headline: Radio 1 DJ Zoe tops 7m listeners
fields.trailText: Radio 1 DJ Zoe Ball's weekly audience has topped 7m for the first time, according to figures published yesterday by the Radio Joint Audience Research body.
fields.body:
Radio 1 DJ Zoe Ball's weekly audience has topped 7m for the first time, according to figures published yesterday by the Radio Joint Audience Research body.

Ball, 29, who is leaving the Breakfast Show at the end of March to be replaced by Sara Cox, has attracted 600,000 more listeners in the last quarter.

The report shows that, for the first time in more than a year, BBC radio is reaching more weekly listeners than all the commercial stations combined.

Nearly 31m listen to BBC national and regional stations each week - 63,000 more than are tuning in to independent channels. Radio 1 retains the highest reach of any station, netting 11.29m listeners a week.

Among main winners are Radio 5 Live, whose weekly listeners topped 6m for the first time.

Most commercial stations have remained static but Classic FM's reach has risen by 383,000, with its audience share rising by 0.2 percentage points to 4.3%.

Virgin Radio has lost 0.4% of its regular audience share, dropping from 3.1m to 3.04m weekly listeners despite Chris Evans's £1m on-air giveaway and his "fling" with former Spice Girl Geri Halliwell.

Talk Sport, until last month Talk Radio, has added on more than 1m listening hours, with two-thirds of its audience now comprising men.

A RAJAR board member, Justin Sampson, said the figures were good news showing that "listening hours are on the up".

He said that research showed radio listening was growing among internet users, especially during the evening, with TV viewing figures for that time down 25% and the number of people watching videos falling 21%.

BBC Radio Saturday manager Jo Hamilton said: "This is a superb end to a very good year for BBC radio.

"We are now reaching almost 31m people a week, edging just ahead of commercial radio."

fields.headline: Immigration scam let in 200 illegally
fields.trailText: An immigration racketeer who paid two home office officials thousands of pounds in the largest scam of its kind in Britain was warned yesterday that jail was inevitable.
fields.body:
An immigration racketeer who paid two home office officials thousands of pounds in the largest scam of its kind in Britain was warned yesterday that jail was inevitable.

With their help, Robin Engutsamy, 41, of Thornton Heath, Surrey, bypassed Britain's entry regulations, enabling an estimated 200 mainly Mauritian nationals to settle illegally.

The bribes bought the theft of potentially compromising passport office files and secured "indefinite leave to stay" stamps. But for the carelessness of the insiders, the operation may have gone undetected, Harrow crown court in Middlesex was told.

Engutsamy, who claimed he was an innocent dupe, was convicted of forgery and theft conspiracies. He will be sentenced on March 6 with Paul Lissenburg and Simon Ellis. Both turned Queen's evidence against Engutsamy.

The court heard Lissenburg, an executive officer in the nationality and immigration directorate in Croydon, south London, joined the scam in January 1996, with Ellis, an administration office colleague. The breakthrough came when Lissenburg returned a stamp to the wrong date.

Lissenburg, 31, of Biggin Hill, Kent, admitted taking part in the forgery and theft conspiracies. Ellis, 31, of Purley, Croydon, admitted the forgery count.

webTitle: JK Rowling is author of the year

fields.headline: JK Rowling is author of the year
fields.trailText: She was the bridesmaid to Beowulf at the Whitbread last week, and pipped again by Seamus Heaney at the South Bank Awards a few days later, but last night JK Rowling finally won a prize for her latest Harry Potter book.
fields.body:
She was the bridesmaid to Beowulf at the Whitbread last week, and pipped again by Seamus Heaney at the South Bank Awards a few days later, but last night JK Rowling finally won a prize for her latest Harry Potter book.

Rowling, 34, who has sold close to 30m copies worldwide of her trilogy about an apprentice wizard, crawled out of her sick bed where she had been recovering from flu to accept the author of the year prize at the British Book Awards in London. For once, Heaney and his translation of the Anglo-Saxon epic was not pitched against her, but she faced the combined muscle of Terry Pratchett, Colin Dexter and Stephen King for an industry accolade which is as much about selling power as the power of prose.

Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban - which is outselling Beowulf by a factor of 100 - had been odds-on favourite for the award, which carries no cash prize. The next instalment of his adventures is already an internet bestseller on advance orders alone, despite the fact that Rowling is not due to deliver it to her publishers until May.

Alex Ferguson's bestselling autobiography, Managing My Life, was book of the year, the first time a sports book has won the award.

Chris Stewart was voted best newcomer for Driving Over Lemons, an account of the former Pink Floyd musician's downsizing to a farm in Spain. The veteran comedian Spike Milligan, author of such classics as Puckoon and Adolf Hitler, My Part In His Downfall, was given a lifetime achievement award.

fields.headline: Museum seeks four naked apes
fields.standfirst: Volunteers wanted for ultimate exhibition
fields.trailText: Wanted: four volunteers to expose their innermost secrets to millions and crack the question of what it means to be human.
fields.body:
Wanted: four volunteers to expose their innermost secrets to millions and crack the question of what it means to be human.

The Science Museum in Kensington, west London, launched a nationwide search today for men and women prepared to undergo scientific tests to establish their identity - in every possible way.

They will be photographed nude. They will have their heads examined by brain scanners, and their DNA sequenced and put on display. Their fingerprints, tongue prints and lip prints will be taken and their heart patterns and family trees will be traced. Their body odour, iris patterns, hand and vein geometry will be measured. Their hair and their personalities will be analysed, and their faces will be morphed to show how they will age.

Finally, they - and their video identities - will talk to millions of visitors to the new £50m Wellcome wing of the Science Museum when it opens on June 27.

When the wing was announced six years ago, it was dubbed a show case for science that had yet to be discovered. Since then the internet has grown from a digital hotline for academics into a worldwide medium of communication, computing power has multiplied tenfold and industry has recruited almost 1m robots.

But some of the most astounding changes have been in biology and medicine, with the arrival of cloning and the international project to identify all 100,000 genes that make up a human. One of the new galleries will be devoted to the great riddle of human identity - and the volunteers will act as cyberguides.

"They will talk people through the issue of identity, from the scientific point of view but also the personal," said Laura Houghton of the Science Museum. "We will get the families involved in talking about whether they like football or not, and that sort of thing. It is to juxtapose the different types of identity and the way people classify you, through brain scans, but also through your own personality."

Visiting families will be able to take part in another experiment, to find the genes that make people look different.

David Hopkinson of University College London will be making scans of faces at the new wing and matching them with DNA taken from mouth swabs. The research - originally backed by the home office because it might help future forensic scientists construct a photofit from a length of DNA - is to identify the genetics behind appearance and height.

Visitors will see slices of a "digital human" in a kind of electronic anatomy lesson. They will learn about Bleadon Man, one of Britain's oldest unearthed skeletons, and look at DNA matches with his surviving relatives near Bleadon, Somerset, today. They will be able to take their own fingerprints and create their own websites, storing information about themselves learned from interactive exhibits.

John Durant, the museum's deputy director, said yesterday: "This is just one example of how we will use objects and interactives to open up the rich potential of the contemporary biomedical sciences, to reveal new things about us."

Volunteers should call 0207 942 4848, fax 0207 942 4868 or email star@nmsi.ac.uk

webTitle: Shadow-boxing in the name of peace

fields.headline: Shadow-boxing in the name of peace
fields.standfirst:
Ulster crisis optimists hope success of power-sharing executive will overcome decommissioning impasse

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: As Northern Ireland slid back towards its old ways this week, Ian Paisley took to the steps of the Stormont parliament to deliver a vintage performance.
fields.body:
As Northern Ireland slid back towards its old ways this week, Ian Paisley took to the steps of the Stormont parliament to deliver a vintage performance.

Standing within yards of the statue of his hero Edward Carson, the firebrand Unionist won loud cheers from the crowd as he berated the government for betraying the province.

Veterans of the last power-sharing executive, which was brought down by Mr Paisley in 1974, could have been forgiven for despairing at such a sight.

A quarter of a century later, however, Mr Paisley attracted support from across the political spectrum, including leading members of Sinn Fein, who nodded their approval as he spoke out in favour of Northern Ireland farmers.

The rally on Tuesday, which was overshadowed by frantic efforts to save the peace process, provided a powerful illustration of the extraordinary changes in Northern Ireland in the past year.

Since direct rule was ended in December, Sinn Fein and unionist ministers have been quietly cooperating in government in an unprecedented way.

Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness has won widespread praise for his sensitivity as education minister, while the Democratic Unionist hardliner Peter Robinson has impressed opponents with his grasp of detail as planning minister. Only last week Mr Robinson made a rare foray into the staunchly nationalist area of Toome in Co Antrim to open a bypass.

Optimists hope the success of the power-sharing executive will eventually convince Ulster Unionists and Sinn Fein to bury their differences and return to their joint work on bread and butter issues.

Such hopes appeared to be remote last night as the threat of suspension hung over the power-sharing executive.

Dublin was working hard last night to prevent the restoration of direct rule by persuading the IRA to make an 11th hour gesture on disarmament. Without such a move London knows it will have no choice but to suspend the executive - to preserve the position of David Trimble as first minister - thereby ending any chance of IRA disarmament.

The familiar stench of deadlock means that Northern Ireland is likely to be heading towards a long period of shadow-boxing.

All sides know in their hearts, however, that there will only ever be one show in town: power-sharing in Northern Ireland buttressed by cross-border links with the Irish Republic.

Paul Bew, professor of Irish politics at Queen's university, Belfast, said last night: "The inclusive model of government, bringing in the former extremists, is so deeply embedded that another solution is simply not on."

The American press yesterday poured scorn on republicans. Even the Washington Post, which is usually more sympathetic to Sinn Fein than the unionists, had an unequivocal message for republicans. "The IRA's leaders need to know that their allies in this country will not indulge them if they break up the peace process," it said.

Unfortunately for Mr Trimble, Sinn Fein leaders are not afraid of falling foul of American opinion. "Never forget that we always think long term and have never been afraid to give the appearance of slitting our own throats," one republican said.

If the IRA refuses to disarm, Mr Trimble will hope to persuade the SDLP to form a power-sharing executive with the Ulster Unionists, Mr Paisley's DUP and the non-sectarian Alliance Party, but excluding Sinn Fein.

Again, this will be impossible. The entire strategy of the SDLP leader, John Hume, has been based on binding Sinn Fein into the political process in the hope that the IRA will eventually wither.

There are also electoral considerations for the SDLP: excluding Sinn Fein would massively boost republican support at Mr Hume's expense.

The bleak future facing Northern Ireland was spelt out by Tim Pat Coogan, the author of an authoritative book on the IRA, who believes the provisionals will never disarm if the executive is suspended.

"Republicans feel as if they have been travelling in a car at 100mph which has suddenly been put into reverse without going through neutral," he said. "You can imagine what damage that would do to the car."

One Unionist observer said yesterday that both sides would have to be prepared to give ground. Unionists, he said, may eventually have to accept that the IRA will never disarm.

As a quid pro quo, he added, the government would have to water down the Patten report on the RUC.

Reaching out to Unionists in such a way would, however, horrify Sinn Fein and the SDLP.

As ever in Northern Ireland, opening a door to one side usually means slamming another in the face of their opponents.

All sides know in their hearts, however, that there will only ever be one show in town: power-sharing in Northern Ireland buttressed by cross-border links with the Irish Republic. Paul Bew, professor of Irish politics at Queen's university, Belfast, said last night: "The inclusive model of government, bringing in the former extremists, is so deeply embedded that another solution is simply not on." The American press yesterday poured scorn on republicans. Even the Washington Post, which is usually more sympathetic to Sinn Fein than the unionists, had an unequivocal message for republicans. "The IRA's leaders need to know that their allies in this country will not indulge them if they break up the peace process," it said. Unfortunately for Mr Trimble, Sinn Fein leaders are not afraid of falling foul of American opinion. "Never forget that we always think long term and have never been afraid to give the appearance of slitting our own throats," one republican said. If the IRA refuses to disarm, Mr Trimble will hope to persuade the SDLP to form a power-sharing executive with the Ulster Unionists, Mr Paisley's DUP and the non-sectarian Alliance Party, but excluding Sinn Fein. Again, this will be impossible. The entire strategy of the SDLP leader, John Hume, has been based on binding Sinn Fein into the political process in the hope that the IRA will eventually wither. There are also electoral considerations for the SDLP: excluding Sinn Fein would massively boost republican support at Mr Hume's expense. The bleak future facing Northern Ireland was spelt out by Tim Pat Coogan, the author of an authoritative book on the IRA, who believes the provisionals will never disarm if the executive is suspended. "Republicans feel as if they have been travelling in a car at 100mph which has suddenly been put into reverse without going through neutral," he said. "You can imagine what damage that would do to the car." One Unionist observer said yesterday that both sides would have to be prepared to give ground. Unionists, he said, may eventually have to accept that the IRA will never disarm. As a quid pro quo, he added, the government would have to water down the Patten report on the RUC. Reaching out to Unionists in such a way would, however, horrify Sinn Fein and the SDLP. As ever in Northern Ireland, opening a door to one side usually means slamming another in the face of their opponents.

webTitle: Mayor vote to run over several days

fields.headline: Mayor vote to run over several days
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Fears of a low turn-out for elections for a London mayor and assembly have prompted the government to allow voters to cast their votes up to a week before polling day in a historic change to UK polling tradition.
fields.body:
Fears of a low turn-out for elections for a London mayor and assembly have prompted the government to allow voters to cast their votes up to a week before polling day in a historic change to UK polling tradition.

Voters in the capital will be able to go to polling stations on a Saturday under the plans, which should pave the way for similar changes in general elections. At least two polling stations will be open in each borough on April 27, 28 and 29 before election day on May 4, after concerns that Londoners might leave the capital for a May bank holiday break.

Details of the reforms were disclosed yesterday as the minister for London, Keith Hill, signalled a pay explosion for full-time councillors by ruling that the new mayor of London should be paid at least £84,384 with the prospect of a salary boost after taking office in May and a pay review early next year. Greater London's first mayor could soon be paid more than a cabinet member - who currently earns over £94,000 - and take home almost as much as the prime minister. Although Tony Blair is entitled to £154,000, he only accepts £107,000.

It will be more lucrative for an MP, such as the mayoral front-runner Ken Livingstone, to retire from Westminister if he wins the contest, because he must relinquish two-thirds of the mayoral salary if he stays in parliament. By resigning his Brent seat he will be almost £10,000 a year better off.

Other proposals announced yesterday sparked criticism from the Liberal Democrats. The party's mayoral candidate, Susan Kramer, condemned the decision not to provide candidates with a free London-wide election mailshot to all voters, claiming the move disadvantaged smaller parties or individuals who would have to fund such mailings themselves. Mr Hill argued that the free mailshot - costing around £750,000 for each candidate - would cost too much and was open to abuse by "unscrupulous" businesspeople seeking cheap advertising for a £10,000 deposit.

London's deputy mayor will be paid £51,000 while a member of the new Greater London assembly, which will scrutinise the mayoral agenda, will earn £34,438 a year.

Local councils are certain to use the new London pay scales as a precedent to press for higher allowances in town halls around Britain. They will argue that provincial mayors in big cities will be entitled to more than London's first citizen because they will have much wider responsibility.

webTitle: Stress causes 'spirit to leave body' feeling

fields.headline: Stress causes 'spirit to leave body' feeling
fields.trailText: Near-death experiences, when patients on the operating table or close to drowning say they feel their spirit leaving their body, are caused by a normal psychological response to an intensely stressful experience, according to scientists.
fields.body:
Near-death experiences, when patients on the operating table or close to drowning say they feel their spirit leaving their body, are caused by a normal psychological response to an intensely stressful experience, according to scientists.

This perceived foray into an unearthly realm is not a psychiatric illness, say Bruce Greyson and colleagues from the university of Virginia in the US, writing in this week's Lancet medical journal.

Between 9% and 18% of people who come close to dying are thought to have such a near-death experience. It takes a variety of forms, such as accelerated thought processes, watching one's past life flash by, intense feelings of peace and joy, and transcendental phenomena such as being spirited to an unearthly realm and meeting dead relatives, say the authors.

The researchers questioned 134 people who had nearly died and asked them about the nature of any near-death experience and the length of time they experienced "dissociative" symptoms. Dissociation is the term used for the separation of thoughts, feelings or experiences from the normal stream of consciousness and memory. These can range from daydreaming to symptoms of psychiatric illness, such as sufferers feeling their bodies belong to other people.

But the 96 who described near-death experiences had milder symptoms than those associated with mental illness. The scientists concluded that their experiences were a result of intense stress, but they are not willing to argue that what happens to people close to death is all in the imagination.

"The unrelated question of the personal meaning of NDEs, of whether they permit a personal or mystical insight into the afterlife, is beyond the scope of this study," they said.

webTitle: Scots jury awards young man £100,000 damages for loss of sole testicle

fields.headline: Scots jury awards young man £100,000 damages for loss of sole testicle
fields.trailText: A man of 26 whose only testicle was removed in error after it was wrongly diagnosed as cancerous was awarded £100,000 compensation by a jury at the court of session in Edinburgh yesterday.
fields.body:
A man of 26 whose only testicle was removed in error after it was wrongly diagnosed as cancerous was awarded £100,000 compensation by a jury at the court of session in Edinburgh yesterday.

Richard Adamson, originally from West Lothian but now living in London, has to have hormone injections to prevent him developing female characteristics.

The former film production student, who was born with only one testicle, had it removed at St John's hospital, Livingston, in June 1992 after the mistaken diagnosis. After the operation it was found that he had had a blood clot which could have been easily treated.

The jury decided unanimously to award Mr Adamson the full £100,000 he claimed from Lothian health board, which admitted liability.

Mr Adamson, who attended the hearing with his girlfriend and mother, refused to comment on the decision. His solicitor, Judy Williamson, said he was relieved the case was over and grateful to all who had supported him. "He hopes that if any good can come from this it is that no one else should find themselves in the unfortunate position he is now in."

The claim included damages for the suffering caused by the loss of the testicle and the need to inject hormones every three weeks, and the loss of any chance of fathering a child - all accepted by the health board. But it disputed Mr Adamson's argument that the treatment caused him to develop obsessive-compulsive disorder, and put him at a disadvantage in getting work in TV and film production.

A psychiatrist for the health board told the hearing the obsessive-compulsive disorder could have been brought on by watching an edition of the Vanessa Show on the topic.

Roddy McDonald, QC for the health board, told the jury: "You are here to compensate Mr Adamson, you are not here to teach a lesson to the doctors that carried out the operation. Award fair compensation, no less, no more."

The jury awarded £45,000 for the suffering and distress Mr Adamson experienced up to the trial and £55,000 for future suffering, including the inability to father children. No compensation was awarded for disadvantage in the labour market.

Trial by jury for personal injury cases was abolished in 1933 in England, where the only civil cases still heard by juries are libel, slander, false imprisonment and malicious prosecution actions.

In Scotland most personal injury cases are heard by judges alone. For a jury trial to be granted, the claim must be for substantial compensation, at least £50,000, and the evidence must be easily understandable.

David Burnside, an Aberdeen solicitor specialising in personal injury cases, said jury trials were experiencing a revival. "Defenders will try not to have a jury trial because a jury will award more than a single judge. Despite the guidance given, they tend to award the top of the range. There is a perception in Scotland that damages are too low."

webTitle: Son denies plot to kill parents

fields.headline: Son denies plot to kill parents
fields.trailText: A man plotted with a neighbour to kill his parents with a meat hammer and steal their money, a court heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A man plotted with a neighbour to kill his parents with a meat hammer and steal their money, a court heard yesterday.

Ian Ayres, 23, watched as Neil Campbell, also 23, attacked Vivian Ayres with a whisky bottle and a meat tenderiser before hitting Robert Ayres, Lewes crown court heard.

Campbell has pleaded guilty to attempting to murder Mrs Ayres at her home in East Preston, near Worthing, West Sussex, and to wounding Mr Ayres with intent to grievous bodily harm. Ayres denies attempted murder.

The court heard how in the months leading up to the attack in April last year, Campbell and his mother lived opposite the Ayres. Ian Ayres had called his mother an "old cow" and was overheard saying he would like to "whack" her.

The attack happened after the two young men turned up at the Ayres' house claiming Ian Ayres had been injured in a road rage incident.

While Mr Ayres accompanied his son to the bathroom, Campbell asked Mrs Ayres for a glass of whisky before taking the bottle and hitting her twice over the head. He told her, "You should have died by now. We are going to kill you, bury you and take your money," then hit her with the metal meat hammer.

Mr Ayres, who was in the bathroom with his son, heard his wife call out for help but he too was struck six or seven times.

When Ian Ayres made a 999 call Campbell took the telephone from him and said it was a hoax, although Mrs Ayres could be heard screaming in the background.

When paramedics arrived, Ayres was rambling about how he had taken speed (amphetamine). He was also trying to suggest that his brother Neil was involved although he was in Liverpool at the time.

Ayres told police that Campbell and his brother had plotted to kill his parents for money. Campbell had left in Ayres' car, but was stopped by police and then stole the police car. He was arrested soon after.

Mrs Ayres needed 18 stitches and suffered a fractured skull. She and her husband were in hospital for two days.

Philip Katz, prosecuting, claimed that Ayres had decided to pretend he also was a victim when he realised the plan had gone wrong.

Mr Katz told the jury: "Campbell will tell you that he planned to kill not just Mr and Mrs Ayres but this defendant also. It is right that the violence in the house against Mr and Mrs Ayres was perpetuated by Neil Campbell.

"However, the crown says Ian Ayres joined in with Neil Campbell's plan to kill Mr and Mrs Ayres. He encouraged it and he helped it along."

The case continues.

webTitle: Irish buy last chance for IRA

fields.headline: Irish buy last chance for IRA
fields.standfirst: Direct rule next week unless decommissioning begins
fields.trailText: Direct rule will be reimposed over Northern Ireland next week unless the IRA agrees to disarm, Peter Mandelson announced last night as the government moved to prevent the resignation of David Trimble.
fields.body:
Direct rule will be reimposed over Northern Ireland next week unless the IRA agrees to disarm, Peter Mandelson announced last night as the government moved to prevent the resignation of David Trimble.

At the end of a frantic day of activity, which saw the Irish government holding direct talks with the IRA leadership, Mr Mandelson said emergency legislation would be passed by next Friday if the IRA failed to deliver.

Hours after Mr Mandelson stood up in the Commons, the Irish prime minister Bertie Ahern flew to Cornwall for talks with Tony Blair in which he successfully petitioned for a delay on imposing direct rule.

Mr Ahern, whose officials held talks all day in Belfast with the IRA, took a new form of words from the IRA over disarmament.

Irish officials, who talked last night of "some progress", were hoping that this would be enough to persuade Britain not to pull the plug on the Northern Ireland executive next week - a move that would end any chance of IRA disarmament.

However, Mr Mandelson made it clear last night that the government would not shy away from direct rule if the IRA refuses to disarm. The Northern Ireland secretary was moved to issue such a blunt warning in an attempt to prevent Mr Trimble resigning as first minister today after General John de Chastelain reported that the IRA was still refusing to disarm.

"I hope you and your colleagues will not take precipitate action in relation to the executive and you will allow the events of the next few days to unfold before you make your final judgment," he told Mr Trimble.

In a gloomy statement to the Commons, Mr Mandelson condemned the IRA and the loyalist terrorists for refusing to give an undertaking to disarm. "It is a betrayal of the entire community of Northern Ireland, whatever their tradition, especially when it is clear from every opinion poll that unionists, nationalists and, I suspect republicans, overwhelmingly want to see decommissioning happen," Mr Mandelson told MPs.

"I appeal to the paramilitary organisations to heed the call of the people to get cracking and to enable self-government in Northern Ireland to flourish once and for all."

The Northern Ireland secretary will publish a parliamentary bill today that would reimpose direct rule by the end of next week in the absence of decommissioning. The bill will be rushed through the Commons early in the week, allowing the Queen to sign it at the end of the week.

"Nobody genuinely committed to the peace process will relish this prospect, but our purpose if it comes to this will be to preserve [the executive and assembly] from collapse and to create the time and space in which to rebuild the confidence required to sustain them," Mr Mandelson told MPs.

However, he attempted to strike an upbeat note when he said the IRA had made it clear to Gen de Chastelain that its guns were silent.

"The commission's report points to a number of positive factors," Mr Mandelson said. "The ceasefires remain in place, the silence of the guns and the unequivocal support of the IRA and the other paramilitary groups for the political process have played a vital part in recent advances."

Mr Mandelson said Gen de Chastelain would remain on standby throughout next week to produce another report if the IRA agrees to disarm.

Mr Trimble made it clear last night that he could no longer sit in government with Sinn Fein, though it was unclear whether he would resign today. It was thought he may put it on hold until next week.

Responding to Mr Mandelson's Commons statement, the Ulster Unionist leader said: "We feel disappointment, having taken the risk to proceed in advance of decommissioning with formation of an administration, that there has been a contemptuous response from the paramilitaries concerned. We cannot continue in an administration with those who have disappointed the hopes that were created."

Mr Trimble then asked Mr Mandelson for an assurance that he will suspend the executive unless the IRA disarms. Ulster Unionists are likely to have been discouraged when Mr Mandelson declined to answer his question directly.

Seamus Mallon, the deputy leader of the SDLP, underlined the deep opposition among nationalists to the prospect of direct rule. "I believe that suspension of any kind at this time would be unwise [because] it could do lasting damage to the new political dispensation which is beginning to work well," he said.

"It would make decommissioning immeasurably more difficult and would play into the hands of those who are opposed to the agreement."

His remarks were echoed earlier in the day by the Sinn Fein president, Gerry Adams, who issued an appeal to Mr Trimble for a meeting. "If the unionists spook the British government into suspending and collapsing the institutions - and suspending means collapsing - it will be difficult to put things back together again and decommissioning, which the unionists make such a great fuss about, is unlikely ever to be achieved," he said.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Teacher can fight blacklist
fields.body:
Teacher can fight blacklist

A primary school teacher who faced unproven allegations of sexually abusing his pupils has won the right to bring a high court challenge against his name being included on an official blacklist.

His QC, Cherie Booth, was yesterday given permission to seek a ruling that the health secretary's "draconian" index of people deemed unsuitable to work with children operates unlawfully.

Food for thought

Pupils in Liverpool are to be given lessons on the dangers of eating disorders in a pioneering initiative. The city council is encouraging schools to incorporate the issue into core curriculum subjects.

The department for education and employment is adopting the initiative as a model of good practice for other local authorities and schools to follow.

Ambulance ruling

The London ambulance service yesterday failed to overturn a high court ruling that it must pay more than £360,000 to a mother brain-damaged after one of its vehicles failed to arrive on time.

Lord Woolf, the master of the rolls, gave permission for the case to go to the House of Lords, but said Tracy Kent, 35, should get her damages whatever the outcome.

New school for Beatrice

Princess Beatrice will join 300 privileged boys and girls of 50 different nationalities when she arrives at the £17,000 a year Aiglon college in the Swiss Alps in September.

The headmaster, Richard McDonald, was educated at Gordonstoun at the same time as the Duke of York.

Beowulf on CD-Rom

The original text of the Anglo-Saxon poem Beowulf has been put on CD-Rom in a painstaking seven-year project by the British Library, which owns the original manuscript.

Publication marks the first time the work, which dates from the 11th century, has been accessible to most scholars.

fields.headline: Mowlam rebuts health rumours
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: The cabinet office minister, Mo Mowlam, yesterday admitted she had been deeply hurt by a reports of a whispering campaign against her and claimed that elements in Whitehall were trying to "put the knife in".
fields.body:
The cabinet office minister, Mo Mowlam, yesterday admitted she had been deeply hurt by a reports of a whispering campaign against her and claimed that elements in Whitehall were trying to "put the knife in".

Reports at the weekend pointed to rumours that a 1997 operation to remove a benign brain tumour had left her "without the intellectual rigour" to hold a cabinet post. That was unfounded, she said on Radio 4's Woman's Hour. "It hurt a lot." She had not needed treatment since July 1997.

"There are people that want to put the knife in, and this story enables them to do it. It is very difficult to answer," she said. She would not allow them to deflect her from her job.

She had "no idea" who was responsible. "If I knew I would stop it. All I do is get on with it. I have stopped reading the papers; I go swimming instead in the morning."

She refused to be drawn on reports that she did not want the cabinet office job when she left the Northern Ireland office in September, preferring health or the foreign office.

"I want to be a member of the cabinet. I will do what Tony tells me to do or asks me to do, and this was the job that was available. I hope in the years ahead I will do other departments, but don't underestimate the job I am doing now. If we can deliver the policies, it will make a big difference to the government's future."

She confirmed that she had applied for a government "grace and favour" flat while she and her husband, Jon Norton, who lost his job as a banker, searched for a smaller home.

"Him unemployed and me with my history of a brain tumour mean that it is difficult to get another mortgage," she said, "so we are going to go downmarket and pay for something that we hope, on the back of the house we sell, we can own."

fields.headline: Party dress
fields.standfirst:
Image tips for women who want to be Labour MPs

New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Would-be women Labour MPs have been told to take a friend to selection meetings to appear popular. The suggestion is one of a series of bizarre tips sent to female hopefuls by Labour women's officer Rachel Mclean.
fields.body:
Would-be women Labour MPs have been told to take a friend to selection meetings to appear popular. The suggestion is one of a series of bizarre tips sent to female hopefuls by Labour women's officer Rachel Mclean.

In are bright tops under sober suits. Out are dangling earrings because they could be distracting. Sisters are urged to practise speeches in front of the mirror to "elimate fidgeting and nervous tics". To counter criticism of android Blair Babes, personal statements should "include something that makes you human."

The two-page letter was sent to the 194 women on the list of 689 Labour members vetted by Millbank as suitable to apply for Labour seats.

The note says: "Tips - don't smoke, take a bottle of water, get a lift there, take someone with you to make you appear popular."

Women, encouraged not to let men "put them off" at selection meetings, are told to dress carefully.

"Dress appropriately - smart and tidy, not too much make-up (but some is better than none), wear a suit or smart skirt/trousers but try to include some colour which will make you memorable (eg a dark suit with a brighter top underneath), don't wear distracting earrings," says the memo.

"Some women asked if it was OK to wear trousers - many existing women MPs do, so it must be!" The female hopefuls are warned of "dreaded questions" at selection meetings.

"If asked a sexist or racist question, answer it tactfully - complaining won't win you any respect, but dealing with a difficult question will," says the letter. If the questions are frequently in contravention of party rules, you may wish to complain to the national executive representative afterwards."

But candidates are recommended to stay on-side despite growing unease about the direction of the government.

A senior Labour source defended the memo on the grounds the tips were for political novices and had been compiled from issues raised as training sessions.

But one long-standing female hopeful said: "Many of the points are sexist and to be told to tolerate sexist and racist questions is unacceptable. Any woman following such bizarre advice stands no chance of being selected as a Labour candidate."

fields.headline: Raising of lost trawler
fields.standfirst: Relatives prepare for funerals
fields.trailText: The wreck of the Solway Harvester, which sank last month with its seven crew, was lifted from the seabed last night in the first stage of an operation to tow it into calmer waters near the Isle of Man.
fields.body:
The wreck of the Solway Harvester, which sank last month with its seven crew, was lifted from the seabed last night in the first stage of an operation to tow it into calmer waters near the Isle of Man.

After some technical problems, the salvage vessel, the CSO Wellservicer lifted the scallop dredger to a height of five metres (16ft) off the seabed before pulling it towards the shore. It had been estimated the lifting operation alone could take 11 hours, but the boat was expected to be completely out of the water some time today.

Divers worked around the clock to secure the vessel, ensuring nothing could float out. Surveys of the boat under water established that three bodies were on board.

Once the wreck of the Kirkcudbright-registered fishing boat is raised and the bodies of the crew retrieved and identified by their families, who have travelled to the island, it is expected that an inquest will be opened and adjourned, possibly today.

The men who died were from the villages Whithorn and Garlieston, on the Isle of Whithorn, in the south-west of Scotland. Relatives have reportedly prepared for their funerals in the hope that all the bodies will be retrieved.

Their minister, the Rev Alexander Currie, said: "It is a long time without funerals taking place and our intention here is to establish and find our loved ones and bring them home so the grieving process may continue and move on."

webTitle: Portillo weighs in - with double u-turn

fields.headline: Portillo weighs in - with double u-turn
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo dramatically dumped Tory opposition to the minimum wage yesterday just two days into his new job as shadow chancellor and after only token discussion with William Hague.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo dramatically dumped Tory opposition to the minimum wage yesterday just two days into his new job as shadow chancellor and after only token discussion with William Hague.

In his first Commons appearance as Gordon Brown's opposite, Mr Portillo surprised Labour, the Liberal Democrats - and most Tory MPs - with the policy u-turn.

He also jettisoned Hague-ite opposition to the operational independence which Labour granted to the Bank of England when it took office in 1997.

Mr Hague had set up a commission to cover his expected retreat on the bank, but Mr Portillo was not prepared to wait. Until the last minute Conservative spokesmen had been denouncing the bank's control of interest rate policy as unwise and unaccountable.

The unexpected announcements signal Mr Portillo's determination to take a firm grip of Tory economic policy.

Although senior Tories spent most of the 1990s predicting that the minimum wage would cost up to 2m low-paid jobs, many had recently felt trapped by the party's opposition, believing it would be difficult to campaign in the election on the basis of wanting to take up to 2m workers' pay rises away.

Mr Portillo's statement came amid the ritual knockabout at pre-lunch Thursday question time. "I want to tell the House today that the next Conservative government will respect the independence of the Bank of England and legislate to enhance that independence and create more accountability of the bank to parliament," Mr Portillo told MPs.

He added: "And I want to tell this house that the next Conservative government will not repeal the national minimum wage."

As delighted Labour MPs waved their order papers, Mr Brown welcomed "the conversion of the Conservative party to Labour party policy".

The Liberal Democrats' economics spokesman, Matthew Taylor, claimed Mr Portillo's announcement meant "the Conservatives no longer know what they believe in. Michael Portillo has ripped up William Hague's economic strategy and replaced it with his alternative Conservative manifesto.

"The battle for the Conservative leadership has already begun," he forecast.

Labour MPs and trade unions predicted that the Tory u-turn would allow Mr Brown and Mr Blair the political elbow room to raise the minimum wage before the next election. It is set at £3.60 for adults and £3 for the 18 to 21 group. Labour MPs have grown increasingly restless over the rate - set to reassure business - and last night several Labour MPs with trade union links were privately pressing for an increase in Mr Brown's March budget, to come into effect on April 1, the first anniversary of the minimum wage.

Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, and Mr Brown have been warily examining the options for improvement, initially by bringing 21-year-olds onto the adult rate. On Sunday Mr Byers urged caution, saying it was a "huge change" that would take time to bed down.

Seeking to highlight Mr Portillo's about-turn, Labour last night circulated a press release he issued in 1994 on the perils of a minimum wage.

Mr Portillo, then the employment secretary, warned: "A minimum wage would push up inflation and could cost over a million jobs.

"For a great many workers it would replace modest pay with no pay."

The statement was headed: "A minimum wage could cost a million jobs, says Portillo."

About face:

"I think the minimum wage is a truly immoral policy. It masquerades as something caring but will actually damage people. Its main benefit will be to the better off. The worse off will lose their jobs."

Michael Portillo, during the election campaign, 1997

"A future Conservative government will not seek to repeal the national minimum wage..."

Michael Portillo, yesterday, in the Commons

fields.headline: Portillo adjusts to political reality
fields.standfirst:
Minimum wage U-turn Tories accept that 'modest' pay level set by Labour has caused 'less damage to jobs than feared'

Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Michael Howard should be spinning in his political grave at yesterday's sight of his party's new treasury spokesman, Michael Portillo, signing the Tories up for the national minimum wage.
fields.body:
Michael Howard should be spinning in his political grave at yesterday's sight of his party's new treasury spokesman, Michael Portillo, signing the Tories up for the national minimum wage.

The former employment secretary spent years trying to chill voters' blood with the cost of Labour's commitment to such a hare-brained concept. A "job destruction policy" that could put 2m low paid workers out of their jobs, he warned in 1991.

One of the shadow ministers he drove to distraction was a young thruster called Blair. But this was one controversial Labour policy to which the future prime minister stuck tenaciously with the result that 1.5m workers - mostly women, half of them part-timers - benefited when the national minimum wage (NMW) came into force on April 1 last year.

Far from cutting a swathe through the employability of unskilled workers - as, in an unguarded moment, even John Prescott once admitted that it might - it has hardly hurt them at all.

There is an explanation for that: Labour's cautious, consensual approach to the issue which involved both unions and managements giving evidence to the low pay commission chaired by Professor George Bain. Set at a modest £3.60 an hour and £3.20 for the 18-21 group (a late sop to the business lobby), it disappointed unions and rapidly became something the CBI now says it has "learned to live with" because of its "prudent" level. There were no regional variations or special deals for particular industrial sectors, no linkage to inflation or average wages, no promise even of an annual appraisal or uprating. The Bain commission's latest modest report (still not published) is about lowering the adult age threshold from 22 to 21.

All the same, as recently as January 20, the shadow DTI spokesman, Angela Browning, referred to it as one of the "horrors" Labour had imposed on business. But there were already signs that the Tories were bending on the minium wage, despite William Hague's gut hostility.

The Tory leader had not appointed a commission (as he had on the Bank) to pave the way for a U-turn. But John Redwood, once an implaccable foe, was privately saying that Tory opposition had successfully bullied ministers into setting the low £3.60 rate and it was now safe to accept it.

Aides would not say yesterday whether the sudden Portillo move was already planned by Francis Maude whose place he took as shadow chancellor. They said Mr Portillo consulted with William Hague and implied he took the bull by the horns himself - much as Mr Brown set free the Bank of England within days of taking office in 1997.

Even the US, bastion of capitalism, has had a minimum wage since the 30s. Britain had wages councils from 1909 to 1993 when John Major abolished the vestiges of what Winston Churchill had introduced. Labour has backed a minimum wage in theory since 1919.

So is Mr Howard, himself a maximum wage QC, ashamed of his exaggerated talk? Is the relentlessly free-market Institute of Directors, or the CBI which also made alarmist claims? Yesterday none was rushing to the TV studios to eat humble pie.

Nor was Mr Portillo exactly. After the new shadow chancellor had surprised MPs by using his first spat with Gordon Brown across the Commons dispatch box to announce the twin policy U-turn (he no longer opposes operational independence for the Bank of England either) he issued a brief statement to reporters.

"We do not think that the NMW is a well-targeted device for the relief of poverty. But at the modest level at which it has been set by the government, the NMW has caused less damage to employment than we feared. We remain concerned about compliance costs for business and we will seek to improve its administration," he explained.

Beneath the routine bluster of the political trade lies an important concession: Mr Portillo has cut the cackle and hints of the Hague shadow cabinet and made the necessary adjustment to political reality. Labour would have hammered the Tories over the NMW at the coming election. Now there is only Conservative opposition to Mr Brown's New Deal and his Working Families Tax Credit to hammer. The Tories still dislike both as costly and ineffectual, and promise to "reform" them.

Like the minimum wage, all are part of the chancellor's drive to make work profitable and attractive for low-paid working families, his closet socialism which seeks to shift resources to the poorest without upsetting the Daily Mail.

Mr Portillo's aides say that the NMW still has implications for jobs and that "exploitation at slave labour rates has never been our policy".

They also warn that compliance costs - monitoring and enforcing the NMW in small or dodgy firms - is expensive, a further burden to add to the cost of the EU's social chapter.

In reality, the NMW was set low enough not to threaten the jobs of marginal workers at a time of economic boom when even McDonalds is paying £5 an hour in prosperous southern towns.

That may change if the unions succeed in bumping up the rate to half the median wage, around £4.60 an hour, the sort of target which Neil Kinnock promised before the 1992 election. It is unlikely to happen easily, though the pressure will remain as long as the economy keeps growing - even in vulnerable regions and industries.

But what Mr Portillo did yesterday was the sort of thing messrs Blair and Brown, Kinnock and Smith before them, were doing for 10 years before they regained power - throwing discredited dogmas, bloated sacred cows and the rest over the side of the ship. They have a long way to go. According to a cartoon in yesterday's Times the ship is still called the Titanic.

fields.headline: Janine Gibson's TV gossip
fields.trailText: News fit to strike fear into the heart of any self-respecting pressure group reaches us of a dramatic breakthrough in the quality and quantity of sex on television.
fields.body:
News fit to strike fear into the heart of any self-respecting pressure group reaches us of a dramatic breakthrough in the quality and quantity of sex on television.

It seems that Sky has reached a deal to screen the arthouse flick Romance on its box office pay-per-view channels. The tastefully made French feature caused a stir far outweighing its box office take due to its scenes of bondage and sado-masochistic sex, according to sources who have actually seen it.

So eyebrow-raising is the content that Sky executives, while happy to add the to its 18+ adults-only films strand (general fare: Confessions Of A Victorian Schoolgirl), are believed to be hovering over the print with blue pencils. An ejaculation shot, just to take a random example, is believed to be unsuitable. There's no word yet from Sky on which particular individual is sweating over a hot video deciding on the cuts.

In other milestone news, the Simpsons is celebrating its 10th anniversary with what is believed to be a landmark event - the first on-screen death among the regular yellow inhabitants of Springfield. In recent history, Springfield has witnessed the near-fatal shooting of Mr Burns, in a Dallas-style season-ending cliff-hanger, by Maggie the baby; but happily he survived. This victim, scheduled for the Feburary sweeps week - when all the networks roll out their best programmes to boost ad revenue for the coming year - will suffer at the hands of a need to "shake up the show a little", according to the show's executive producer, Mike Scully.

Speculation as to who might croak is indelicately rampant, with fans at the Simpsons internet news group adamant that Ned Flanders' wife, Maude, is for the chop. However, enough rival theories about the future health of headteacher Seymour Skinner and bartender Moe have been floated that we don't think we're ruining anyone's fun by airing this particular spoiler.

However, enough rival theories about the future health of headteacher Seymour Skinner and bartender Moe have been floated that we don't think we're ruining anyone's fun by airing this particular spoiler.

fields.headline: The worm that turned
fields.trailText: Matthew (Joe Absolom) has a thin triangular face with a large eye at each corner. Well, not at each corner, obviously, for heaven's sake. The effect is like a praying mantis, cold, calculating, sizing up the fly. Last night in EastEnders (BBC 1) he was giving a fly the full benefit of this concentrated stare.
fields.body:
Matthew (Joe Absolom) has a thin triangular face with a large eye at each corner. Well, not at each corner, obviously, for heaven's sake. The effect is like a praying mantis, cold, calculating, sizing up the fly. Last night in EastEnders (BBC 1) he was giving a fly the full benefit of this concentrated stare.

When Steve (Martin Kemp) slew Saskia with an ashtray, he was acquitted of murder, but Matthew, his young accomplice, went to prison. Matthew now took his revenge with an ingenious sting, claiming that he had killed Saskia's sister and framed Steve for it.

It was one of those horn-locked, head-to-head encounters which EastEnders pioneered and does rather impressively.

I must say that Matthew is a proud advertisement for the educational value of the prison system. He went inside a whimpering lad and came out a few months later able to turn his hand to anything. He can booby-trap light bulbs so they explode when switched on ("it's simple when you know how"). He can vandalise lavatories ("Whoever did this knew what they was doing.") You can see those electrical and plumbing courses have paid dividends. Curiously, he even shows promise as a TV producer. A few months ago he did not know that an electromagnetic field wipes a video. Last night he videotaped the whole sting.

Matthew now leaves EastEnders for a promising career in plumbing or TV production. I would advise plumbing. It's regular.

The three scriptwriters of The Peter Principle (BBC 1) were ill advised to use lines like "Very amusing!" and "Ha, ha! Very amusing!" Even when it's true - and it wasn't - it isn't wise.

Jack Dee's Full Mountie (BBC 1), however, was funny, being a collection of young British comics who have appeared at the Montreal comedy festival, their acts and their opinions.

Mark Lamarr was interviewed while feeding ducks. You would not have had him down as a duck lover. Agents buzz around the festival but the ripeness of Lamarr's language deterred them all. Except one from Disney. Unfortunately, he left her card on the bar. "I might", he mourned, "have been Snow White." The American fondness for business cards was the cause of much British hilarity, particularly a laminated card for pressing on prospects in the jacuzzi. It wasn't clear where you were supposed to put it.

Lee Evans suckered his way around the stage in octopus skin shoes. Alan Davies flattened the Olympic field events ("Two weeks of events designed to incorporate all of the world's odd shaped people.") David Baddiel claimed a heckler had tried to shoot him but didn't say why. Perhaps it was Jerry Seinfeld's mother, as Baddiel was scathing about Seinfeld's aftershave.

The British seemed more likely than the Americans to go out on a limb and swing around by their tails. The great exponent of "He was here a moment ago. Where's he gone!" is Eddie Izzard, who did a wonderful and well received routine on relativity, the speed of light and the speed of sound. You wouldn't have thought it possible.

There was a time, gather round little children, when every other man had a throbbing scarlet boil on the back of his neck. (I don't know. Vitamin deficiency or neck clippers or something.) Sitting behind them on a bus, they hypnotised the horrified eye. Suppose the thing exploded? Then, one day, all the boils disappeared. Strike up the band, you thought, the wicked witch is dead.

Supervolcanoes (Horizon, BBC 2) are eruptions of such apocalyptic power the effects are felt worldwide. Some vulcanologists and geneticists believe that the last such eruption in Sumatra 74, 000 years ago virtually obliterated mankind. We are genetically closely related because we are all descended from a few thousand survivors. Because supervolcanoes erupt so rarely, it is easy to forget they are there.

America's stirring giant, a huge lake of molten rock, is under Yellowstone National Park. It bides its time and erupts roughly every 600,000 years. The last eruption was 600, 000 years ago and, recently, the ground has been seen to bulge.

A report to this effect was due to be presented to the House of Commons science and technology committee yesterday. Oh good, that's all right then.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: While André and Edouard Michelin were trekking all over France selling tyres, they acquired an unrivalled knowledge of local eateries which they thoughtfully passed on to anyone who bought a full set. As Kathleen Griffin recounts in Stargazing - The Story Of The Michelin Guide (11.0am, Radio 4), we have reached the centenary of this ultimate gastronome's delight, now compiled by 80 anonymous inspectors. Though they may effectively hand down a death sentence, there is no appeal.
fields.body:
While André and Edouard Michelin were trekking all over France selling tyres, they acquired an unrivalled knowledge of local eateries which they thoughtfully passed on to anyone who bought a full set. As Kathleen Griffin recounts in Stargazing - The Story Of The Michelin Guide (11.0am, Radio 4), we have reached the centenary of this ultimate gastronome's delight, now compiled by 80 anonymous inspectors. Though they may effectively hand down a death sentence, there is no appeal.

Over the past 40 years the Polish composer Krysztof Penderecki (pictured) has moved from neo-classicism, when his compositions enjoyed a wide audience, to the point where his output has been described as "straddling the border between music and mere noise". Performance On 3 (7.30pm, Radio 3) offers the chance to pass your own judgment, with the composer conducting the UK premiere of his Third Symphony. He describes its style as "a synthesis of all that has been happening for the last several decades".

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText:
The Plant Files
9pm, National Geographic
fields.body:
The Plant Files
9pm, National Geographic

There's a distinct flavour of Twin Peaks to this documentary about rare plants and the people who hunt them. In North Carolina, gun-toting cops march through silent forests, pursuing poachers of endangered Venus Flytraps. Lingering close-ups show the flytraps in action: a fly alights on one cup-shaped leaf, which snaps shut, its cruel spikes encasing the insect as the leaf squeezes the life out of its victim. Meanwhile, mushroom hunters in the woods, modern-day prospectors, speak dreamily of the riches which await them.

Camilla Redmond

Benny And Joon
(Jeremiah Chechik, 1993)
8pm, FilmFour

Wet romantic comedy with Aidan Quinn playing gooseberry to sister Mary Stuart Masterson and lover-boy Johnny Depp. She is a painter a few colours short of a full palette, while Depp's Keatonesque clown fails to impress Quinn's engine block-solid car mechanic. And in this whimsically charming world, you have to sympathise with the spanner-man.

Fallen
(Gregory Hoblit, 1997)
10.20pm, Sky Premier

Intriguing blend of crime thriller and ghostly chiller, reminiscent of Alan Parker's Angel Heart. Denzel Washington stars as a Philadelphia cop on the trail of a serial killer: in the murk it's hard to see that supernatural elements are at work. A strong cast - including Donald Sutherland, John Goodman and James Gandolfini - keep it interesting when the plot flags.

Myra Breckinridge
(Mike Sarne, 1970)
1.50am, FilmFour

Gore Vidal's book that couldn't be written became the film that couldn't be made, according to the blurb, though shouldn't be made might be nearer the mark. Vidal's acid satire is diluted into a sleazy romp through Tinseltown, with Raquel Welch as the sex-changed film critic having the hots for Roger Herren and Farah Fawcett. Mae West and John Huston are also present; director Sarne was better known for his dubious pop career - he'd recently had a hit with Come Outside.
