fields.headline: Blink and you'll miss it
fields.standfirst: Subliminal advertising is banned. In theory, that is. But in reality, it's alive and kicking and on a television screen near you, with advertising campaigns constantly straying nearer the limits of the law.  Belinda Archer  investigates
fields.trailText: If you were in Ireland a few weeks ago and had nothing better to do than watch TV really late one night, you may well have witnessed something rather sinister.
fields.body:
If you were in Ireland a few weeks ago and had nothing better to do than watch TV really late one night, you may well have witnessed something rather sinister.

A sequence of commercials for a new alcoholic energy drink was broadcast one night between 2am and 4am, specifically targeting the Irish clubbing fraternity. The ads were all a bit oblique, featuring a bottle of the product, called Agwa, surrounded by an increasing number of flies and a website address. But the really interesting thing was that each spot was just two seconds long.

This, my friend, is possibly the nearest you're going to get to subliminal advertising, that spooky kind of commercial communication that is meant to sneak into our collective subconscious and mess with our minds.

Strictly speaking, such things are banned. Most ads are either 60, 45 or 30 seconds long, and advertisers and agencies have to adhere to a stringent set of rules imposed by the Independent Television Commission controlling length of image.

These rules were apparently drawn up for the benefit of our health and safety, rather than to protect us from unscrupulous advertisers bent on getting us to helplessly part with our cash. Basically the rules outlaw "images of very brief duration" (Section 7 of the ITC Code) because of a condition called photosensitive epilepsy that is triggered by flashing images on TVs. This is particularly prevalent among young children.

The phenomenon was demonstrated rather graphically last year when a TV cartoon based on Pokemon, a computer game character with strangely flashing eyes, was broadcast in Japan. It led to an unprecedented number of children being hospitalised.

But despite the tight controls, agencies are always trying to experiment with the notion of subliminal communication. Trevor Beattie, the adman behind the Wonderbra posters and the FCUK work for French Connection, cheekily played with the idea in a controversial poster last year for the fashion chain. This actually featured the words "subliminal", "advertising" and "experiment" arranged in such a way, with the first letters highlighted, so as to spell out SEX.

Others have dabbled with reducing the length of ads as far as possible - down to half a second in one case, for a vodka brand in Australia - and playing with the use of flash frames and blipverts. When First Direct was launched, for example, their ads featured a series of short frames that were inspired by the quirky blipped images in the 80s student sitcom The Young Ones. The car giant Mazda, too, created an ad a few years ago in which viewers had to turn up the volume to hear the message and play it back to make sense of it, rather like with Guns N Roses lyrics.

Such experimentation originally began in the UK with a controversial ad for Pot Noodle in 1993. The commercial featured a manic US-style TV presenter with lots of flashing graphics and intense visuals. It triggered the introduction of the current ITC regulations and was in fact banned (although sources claim it was more the "subliminal" messages about "pot" than the visuals that caused the authority's hackles to rise).

Steve Henry, creative director of HHCL & Partners, the agency behind the Pot Noodle spot, comments: "We are all just trying new ways to get through to people, because they tend to have in-built defences against advertising. It's just an advertising game to entertain and stimulate and engage them. It's not a sinister thing."

Given that estimates suggest the average consumer is exposed to around 1300 commercial messages a day, it is not surprising that agencies are trying whatever they can to break through the clutter. But it would appear that even if they were able to sneak past the glare of the ITC, it is debatable whether their technically subliminal efforts would work.

According to Dr David Lewis, a consumer psychologist who has researched how advertising works on people, ads cannot operate below the level of awareness. The theory goes that if you are aware of something, then, erm, it's not subliminal - and if you're not, then it's not working.

"There is absolutely no scientific evidence at all to suggest that subliminal advertising works. If you are not aware of a thing then you are not going to respond to it. The brain just doesn't process information in that way. However, things can occur below the level of awareness that are not necessarily subliminal - our lifestyle and attitudes, for instance, will affect what we get out of an ad," he says.

Not that this is going to stop either ad agencies trying to push at the rules with hidden messages and flashed images, or indeed people thinking that they are being got at. In fact, if you listen really closely to a new Pot Noodle ad that has just broken, I'm sure there's someone in the background shouting "arse", for whatever reason. Maybe it's just me, but go on, have a listen. And don't forget: if you can't hear it, that doesn't mean it's not there.

As the US chatshow host David Letterman said recently: "I don't believe in subliminal advertising. Then again, I went shopping yesterday and bought a combine harvester."

webTitle: Who are you? What the Milk Tray ad says about you

fields.headline: Who are you? What the Milk Tray ad says about you
fields.trailText: The ad: This is a jokey update of one of adland's hardy perennials. Here our man in black ditches his trademark polo-neck in favour of a black jacket with white shirt and uses his wits instead of a series of death-defying stunts to reach his lady. Faced with tight security at a glitzy premiere, he ingeniously dupes the bouncers into letting him into the theatre and finds his way to the beautiful starlet's dressing room. As he prepares to leave his famous calling card and a box of Milk Tray, she spots him, likes what she sees and purrs: "Where do you think you're going?"
fields.body:
The ad: This is a jokey update of one of adland's hardy perennials. Here our man in black ditches his trademark polo-neck in favour of a black jacket with white shirt and uses his wits instead of a series of death-defying stunts to reach his lady. Faced with tight security at a glitzy premiere, he ingeniously dupes the bouncers into letting him into the theatre and finds his way to the beautiful starlet's dressing room. As he prepares to leave his famous calling card and a box of Milk Tray, she spots him, likes what she sees and purrs: "Where do you think you're going?"

The jargon: This ad "brings the Milk Tray Man into the 21st century and reflects the changing role of women in today's relationships", according to the PR guff. Basically his former Mission Impossible personality, which was created back in 1967, was no longer cutting it with today's blokes.

Personality: You are male, aged 25-44. You're not very big on the stuff of romance - flowers, chocs, silvery words etc, but you can respond well to a bit of a nudge.

Financial status: Milk Tray are not exactly fancy hand- made numbers, being mass- produced in Birmingham rather than rolled on the inner thighs of Belgian nymphs: at £4.99, a big box of Tempting Truffles and Hazlenut Heavens (sic) ain't going to break the bank.

Telling lifestyle detail: You've probably got an office job, own a car and go on regular holidays. Chances are you are not married yet (hence the need, possibly, to still make gestures like buying spontaneous boxes of chocs).

Other relevant data: Apparently Andrea Corr, the smokey-eyed singer from the Corrs, is a big fan of Milk Tray, as is Bridget Jones, Helen Fielding's unlucky-in-love heroine.

webTitle: Nasa considering suicide dive for Space Observatory

fields.headline: Nasa considering suicide dive for Space Observatory
fields.trailText: To avoid the dread of a 17-ton astronomy satellite tumbling at random out of the sky, Nasa is considering sending it on a controlled suicide dive over the Pacific in March.
fields.body:
To avoid the dread of a 17-ton astronomy satellite tumbling at random out of the sky, Nasa is considering sending it on a controlled suicide dive over the Pacific in March.

The 9-year-old Compton Gamma Ray Observatory is still on a scientific par with the newly mended Hubble Space Telescope despite the failure of one of three gyroscopes in December.

But Nasa isn't sure whether the Compton Observatory can function in orbit if another gyroscope breaks. And with 1-in-1,000 odds of such a big, out-of-control satellite hurting or killing someone, Nasa is loath to take any chances.

So engineers are scrambling to determine, by mid-February, whether Compton can manage with just one gyroscope for pointing. If one gyroscope is enough, the spacecraft will continue, perhaps for several more years, to collect gamma rays from such hot, violent objects as quasars, pulsars, supernova explosions and the areas surrounding black holes.

If not, ground controllers will use Compton's two remaining gyroscopes to guide the observatory down through the atmosphere over an empty stretch of the Pacific Ocean sometime around March 14.

Pieces that survive the fiery plunge will rain over an area estimated at 16 miles (26 kilometres) wide by 964 miles (1,550 kilometres) long, says Preston Burch, deputy program manager for space science operations at Nasa's Goddard Space Flight Center in Greenbelt, Maryland. Ships and planes would be warned to stay away.

Without a controlled re-entry, the debris could slam down anywhere between 28.5 degrees north and 28.5 degrees south of the equator. Bangkok, Calcutta, Mexico City, Nairobi, Rio de Janeiro, even Miami would be vulnerable.

"I'm sitting here looking at a map," says Burch, "and there are vast regions of South America and Africa, the whole northern half of Australia, most of India, a chunk of China and Southeast Asia, Mexico, all of our Central American friends. They sure would not appreciate that."

Statisticians have based the odds of the satellite coming down, in part, on Skylab's demise. The 78-ton Skylab, Nasa's first space station, came crashing down in 1979. Debris fell into the Indian Ocean and onto western Australia, but no one was hurt and nothing was damaged.

It was essentially a free-fall, with only some minor steering possible by ground controllers.

"We don't need another Skylab," Burch says with a laugh.

If Compton were to come down on its own, the free-fall would occur three to 11 years from now, says Burch. The timing would depend on the density of the upper atmosphere; an intense solar cycle would increase the density and put more drag on the spacecraft, hastening its end.

Unlike the much more expensive Hubble, the $600 million Compton was not built for servicing by astronauts even though it's in a 317-mile (510-kilometer)-high orbit, easily reachable by the space shuttle. As a result, Nasa planned for Compton's suicide dive from the start, stockpiling enough fuel on board for a controlled re-entry.

fields.headline: Space station Mir lives again
fields.trailText: A Russian cargo ship on Thursday faultlessly hooked up with the Mir space station, which has been orbiting unmanned since August, bringing vital supplies in the run-up to a new mission set to blast off in March.
fields.body:
A Russian cargo ship on Thursday faultlessly hooked up with the Mir space station, which has been orbiting unmanned since August, bringing vital supplies in the run-up to a new mission set to blast off in March.

In the past, automatic docking system have often failed and cosmonauts had to step in to perform the hook-up. Without a crew on board, there was a greater chance that the rendezvous could fail.

In 1997, there was a near-fatal accident when a cargo ship slammed into Mir, which was manned at the time, on a practice docking and punctured one of its modules.

Officials in Mission Control took a breath of relief when the Progress cargo ship docked with the station without a hitch on its first pass shortly after 11am Moscow time (08.00 GMT) Thursday. It brought fuel to raise Mir's orbit and oxygen to compensate for the dropped cabin pressure, essential operations to accommodate the next crew that is set to blast off on March 31 on a mission set to last at least 45 days.

If Thursday's docking had failed, space officials were prepared to send a crew to Mir earlier than scheduled and then have the cosmonauts guide the cargo ship in.

Mir is now orbiting some 320 kilometres above the Earth instead of the regular 400 kilometres, and the ageing station has been losing oxygen, although officials said the leak was minor and easy to compensate for.

Mission Control spokesman Vera Medvedkova said a series of manoeuvres to raise Mir's orbit will start Friday. The cabin pressure will be raised closer to the mission.

The Russian government last month approved the new mission, revising its earlier decision to stop financing Mir and abandon the nearly 14-year-old station unless private investors came up with funds.

The state-controlled RKK Energia company claimed that it had already received the first $7 million from $20 million promised by foreign investors. Space officials plan to use booster rockets and cargo ships intended for the 16-nation International Space Station in the new Mir mission, hoping that private investments would help build replacements.

The US space agency Nasa has long urged Russians to abandon Mir, which has been plagued by a series of accidents, and commit their scarce resources to the international station. The project has been behind schedule for more than a year because of the Russian failure to build a crucial component on time.

But Russian space officials are reluctant to part with Mir - the last symbol of the once-mighty Soviet space program - and insist that the station remains safe to fly.

webTitle: PM wants appointed Lords, says peer

fields.headline: PM wants appointed Lords, says peer
fields.standfirst: Lords reform: special report
fields.trailText: Tony Blair is privately opposed to the election of any members of the reformed House of Lords and admitted it during secret talks with the Tory peer, Lord Cranborne, it will be claimed this week.
fields.body:
Tony Blair is privately opposed to the election of any members of the reformed House of Lords and admitted it during secret talks with the Tory peer, Lord Cranborne, it will be claimed this week.

Apparent confirmation of Mr Blair's hostility to any challenge to the supremacy of the elected Commons - which he controls - comes in a television interview with Lord Cranborne, who was sacked as shadow leader of the Lords for doing the Downing St deal which reprieved 92 of the 650 hereditary peers.

The disclosure may embarrass Downing Street, which repeatedly denies wanting to perpetuate a half-reformed house of "Tony's Cronies".

Last month Lord Wakeham, himself a Tory peer, produced a royal commission report, designed to get both sides off the hook.

Up to 200 of the 500-plus peers in a fully-reformed lords could be elected, the report said. Ministers were polite, but cool.

No action is expected before the election - when Tories will exploit Sunday's BBC2 documentary, The Lady and the Lords.

Asked by the film-maker Michael Cockrell, to justify his claim that "Tony Blair wants a nominated House", Lord Cranborne will be seen to say: "Because he told me."

Asked to confirm that he meant that "Tony Blair told you that he wanted an all nominated Lords", the peer says: "Absolutely, absolutely. Mhm. Oh yes, there's no doubt about that."

In a speech in Hertford last night the current Lords leader, Lady Jay - the "lady" of the BBC title - insists that "the government is serious about long-term reform", but says it will take time to find consensus.

Lord Cranborne, dismissed by William Hague after serving in John Major's cabinet, has previously hinted that he has "proof" that Mr Blair harbours undemocratic ambitions for the Lords.

He has never admitted his claim rests on Mr Blair's own words. No 10 denies such claims - but many other ministers are open about wanting a wholly-nominated Lords

In the BBC film Lord Irvine, the lord chancellor and a Blair intimate, insists: "The prime minister emphatically does not want a House of Tony's cronies, and this is the first prime minister of this century who has indicated absolutely clearly that he goes along with a significant diminution in the traditional powers of the prime minister in relation to a fully reformed House."

webTitle: Norman bows to pressure to ends links with Asda

fields.headline: Norman bows to pressure to ends links with Asda
fields.trailText: Archie Norman yesterday bowed to pressure from Liberal Democrats and Labour to sever his business links with Asda, as Tory rumblings of discontent continued over the ousting of John Redwood, his predecessor as shadow secretary for the environment, transport and the regions.
fields.body:
Archie Norman yesterday bowed to pressure from Liberal Democrats and Labour to sever his business links with Asda, as Tory rumblings of discontent continued over the ousting of John Redwood, his predecessor as shadow secretary for the environment, transport and the regions.

Mr Norman, former Asda chairman, said he had ended a consultancy with the supermarket group five months before his contract expired.

In his first interview since his appointment on Tuesday, he rejected other parties' claims that his past business links, spanning transport and planning issues, represented a conflict of interest with his new portfolio, arguing that his experience would be valuable.

In the face of claims that he is a lacklustre Commons performer, he rejected suggestions that he would land few punches on the secretary of state, John Prescott, insisting that he was "right up for it".

Mr Norman, speaking on Radio 4's World at One, said his appointment had been "wholly unexpected", but he had acted swiftly to eliminate any potential conflicts of interest. He no longer owned shares in Railtrack, from which he resigned as a non-executive director, or in Asda-Wal Mart.

"If you want people with experience and a track record of achievement then you have to accept that we all come with a past," he said.

The shadow agriculture minister, Tim Yeo, said on Radio 4's Today that Labour was in no position to criticise the appointment, given the controversy over former paymaster general Geoffrey Robinson's business dealings.

Tory officials played down internal discontent over the sacking of Mr Redwood, whose Wokingham constituency party passed a motion "deeply deploring" it. Rightwing Tory MPs joined the criticism of Wiliam Hague's decision at a dinner held by their 92 Group.

Laurence Robertson, Tory MP for Tewkesbury, yesterday demanded an explanation from Mr Hague.

He said the decision had Labour MPs celebrating. "John Redwood had the recognition factor. He was the one who had made the most hits on Labour. He had the intellect and the energy, which is much needed in the shadow cabinet."

A senior Tory source last night rejected the suggestion that a lesser known, and less competent, member of the shadow cabinet could have been sacrificed instead. "This was a reshuffle at the top," he said. "These jobs have different ranks: you are either there at the top or you are out."

fields.headline: Yesterday
fields.trailText: Good day
fields.body:
Good day

Ronald Reagan. His endorsement was claimed, somewhat bizarrely, by chancellor Gordon Brown. Criticising their opposition to the working families tax credit, he told the Tories:"The policy you cannot support in Britain was a policy that was perfectly acceptable to Ronald Reagan in the United States."

Exhibition of day

Baroness Young's. The Tory former Lords leader has organised an exhibition of books and videos in a Lords committee room as part of her defence of Section 28, condemning the use of "materials that are depraving and corrupting, upon which public money has been spent, and which is being peddled around very young children in our schools and youth centres". Labour's Lord Whitty replied: "That material has not been produced by or for the education department, local education authorities, or schools in most respects. Some of that material is sensible, good guidance to teachers, social workers and youth workers and which I would very much approve of. There is other of that material I would not wish to see used in schools and youth clubs."

Today

Commons: Carers and disabled children bill, second reading. Export of farm animals bill, second reading.

fields.headline: Gil Kane
fields.standfirst: Illustrator who revived America's comic heroes
fields.trailText:
Gil Kane, (Eli Katz), illustrator, born April 6 1926; died January 31 2000.
Although he will long be remembered for his part in the reinvention of comic-book superheroes in the 1960s - and the revival of Green Lantern and The Atom - Gil Kane, who has died aged 73, was a creator who worked in the mainstream to improve the medium he loved.
fields.body:
Gil Kane, (Eli Katz), illustrator, born April 6 1926; died January 31 2000.
Although he will long be remembered for his part in the reinvention of comic-book superheroes in the 1960s - and the revival of Green Lantern and The Atom - Gil Kane, who has died aged 73, was a creator who worked in the mainstream to improve the medium he loved.

His career spanned the history of the American comic book from 1942, only four years after the arrival of Superman. He survived the postwar collapse of the industry, and US senate hearings which sought to link juvenile delinquency to comics. In the 1960s, he was critical of the quality of comic-book writing, and struck out in the new directions of self-publishing and graphic novels, trying to broaden the scope of comics, which, by the 1970s, were dominated once again by costumed heroes.

Tall and distinguished, Kane was a popular figure at comic conventions, knowledgeable, wry and honest. He was the first to admit that his early work was not that good. His best facility was speed, pencilling six to 10 pages of artwork a week; it was perfect for a production-line industry but was starved of creativity. He learned from the best artists around him - Lou Fine, Reed Crandall, Jack Kirby and Alex Toth - and evolved a style that married their design with dynamism. In the 1990s, he was still one of the master draughtsmen of comics, a storyteller surrounded by pin-up artists.

Kane was born Eli Katz in Latvia, arriving in Brooklyn at the age of three. An enthusiastic follower of hero pulps in the 1930s - Doc Savage, the Shadow, and the Spider - and a fan of the newly arrived comic books, he attended the School of Industrial Art, New York, but dropped out before his final term after getting a summer job with comic publishers MLJ erasing pencil lines and drawing in border panels. He was briefly hired by a sweatshop studio - with 50 pencillers, inkers and letterers - before being rehired by MLJ, who offered him his first comic strip, Inspector Bentley Of Scotland Yard, and the comic book, Shield. Six months later, Kane struck out as a freelance, making his first contact with National Publications, with whom he was to have his longest association.

Kane was drafted into the US military shortly after his 18th birthday and, although he served for only 19 months, he returned to a much changed comic industry - many of the smaller companies had folded, and superheroes were in decline. He found work where he could until he re-established himself with National, drawing romance comics such as Hopalong Cassidy, Rex the Wonder Dog, Johnny Thunder and the John Wayne lookalike Matt Savage.

His best work at this time was probably westerns, where he was allowed to ink his own pencils, although it was with superheroes that he emerged as a leading talent. One of National's editors, Julius Schwartz, revived the defunct superhero, the Flash, in the pages of Showcase, and, when it proved successful, Kane was offered a chance to reinvent Green Lantern.

Schwartz and writer John Broome threw away the old character, whose powers were derived from an Aladdin lamp of mystical origin, and gave the new GL, Hal Jordan, an alien power-ring granted to "one who is without fear". The Emerald Crusader, as he was nicknamed, became part of an intergalactic police force, the Green Lantern Corps. Kane's Lantern was lithe and good-looking, and based on Paul Newman, a one-time neighbour.

By the mid-1960s, Kane felt the stories were growing stale and, after 38 issues of The Atom and 70 issues of Green Lantern, moved on to other challenges, publishing the 40-page magazine His Name Is Savage in 1968, and drawing the Hulk, Conan and Spiderman for Marvel, including one of comic books' most poignant moments, the death of Gwen Stacy in the pages of Amazing Spider-Man.

Kane sold a sword and sorcery graphic novel, Blackmark, to Bantam Books, which failed to work in paperback size, and for four years drew the newspaper strip Star Hawks, as well as illustrating paperbacks, records, models and co-authoring the novel Excalibur! (1980) with John Jakes, completing his move away from mainstream comics. He spent most of the 1980s drawing character designs and layouts for animated TV shows, including the Superman cartoon.

In the 1990s, he suffered from cancer, but continued to work, producing the adaptation of Jurassic Park, and working regularly for DC Comics (as National had been renamed). His last work, scheduled for release next month, re-teams Green Lantern and The Atom in a two-issue story for Legends Of The DC Universe.

Kane is survived by his wife Elaine, a son and two stepchildren.

fields.headline: Bert Sproston
fields.trailText:
Bert Sproston, footballer, born June 22 1915; died January 27 2000.

The footballer Bert Sproston, who has died aged 84, was, for several years before the last war, acknowledged as one of the best defenders in England, a blonde, fast, strongly built (5ft 8in, 12st), hard-tackling right-back.
fields.body:
Bert Sproston, footballer, born June 22 1915; died January 27 2000.

The footballer Bert Sproston, who has died aged 84, was, for several years before the last war, acknowledged as one of the best defenders in England, a blonde, fast, strongly built (5ft 8in, 12st), hard-tackling right-back.

He forged his way into the national team at the expense of as accomplished a player as Arsenal's George Male, who for years had partnered his clubmate and captain, the left-back Eddie Hapgood, and would regain his place from Sproston in 1939. Curiously, however, neither Male nor Sproston would be chosen for England in their unofficial internationals against Wales and Scotland during the war years.

Born in Sandbach, Cheshire, Sproston made his name with Leeds United, and won the first of his 11 international caps against Wales in Cardiff, in October 1936, a game that England lost 2-1. He was capped seven times the following season, 1937-8, when he became the regular England choice at right-back.

Perhaps the most memorable of these games took place in Berlin in May 1938, against Germany; the Nazi regime very much wanted a home win. Before the game, a reluctant England team, at the behest of Sir Neville Henderson, the appeasing British ambassador, gave the Nazi salute. They then proceeded to play the Germans off the park, winning 6-3.

That season, Sproston had also played all three games in the British international championship. At the end of it, he moved south to Tottenham Hotspur, retaining his place in the England team and appearing against Wales and the Rest of Europe XI, beaten 3-0 at Highbury.

He was unhappy in London, however, and stayed at Tottenham for only a few months before moving back north - this time to Manchester City, a club that had just been relegated to the second division - a single season after winning at the league championship.

Sproston's last international cap came in November 1938, at Newcastle, where England beat Norway 4-0. During the war, he served in the army, eventually playing for Combined Services XIs on the continent, and turning out as a guest player for Millwall, who sometimes used him in the unaccustomed position of inside-right.

The transitional 1945-46 season saw him back with Manchester City, though neither he nor the then England goalkeeper, the celebrated Frank Swift, could save the club from a remarkable humiliation in the FA Cup, revived in 1946 as a two-legged affair. On their home ground at Maine Road, City were thrashed by a Bradford Park Avenue team which scored eight goals, four of them by A H (Jackie) Gibbons, once Tottenham's amateur centre-forward, and by then a professional.

The next season, when league football started, Sproston was a regular member of the Manchester City team which comfortably won the second division championship, and thus returned to the first division. He played on as the regular right-back for a couple of seasons, his last with the club being 1949-50, when he made just five first division appearances. Subsequently, he coached Bolton Wanderers.

fields.headline: Brief farewells
fields.trailText: James Tinn, who has died aged 77, was Labour MP for Cleveland, and then Redcar, for 23 years. The son of a Consett steelworks engine-driver, he began work in the coke ovens at 14. After serving as an RAF fitter in the second world war, he was active in his union and the Labour pary. He won a scholarship to Ruskin College, Oxford, and became a teacher in Middlesborough.
fields.body:
James Tinn, who has died aged 77, was Labour MP for Cleveland, and then Redcar, for 23 years. The son of a Consett steelworks engine-driver, he began work in the coke ovens at 14. After serving as an RAF fitter in the second world war, he was active in his union and the Labour pary. He won a scholarship to Ruskin College, Oxford, and became a teacher in Middlesborough.

Tinn entered the Commons in 1964, supported by the blastfurnacemen's union. He served as parliamentary private secretary to Arthur Bottomley and became a whip. A rightwinger (supporting Labour on Vietnam and opposing abortion), he focused on attempts to attract industries to the north-east. A quarter of a century before Camelot, his proposals to finance health care through a national lottery attracted little interest.

He resigned before the 1987 election, having been opposed by local activists, to make way for the present cabinet minister Mo Mowlam.

Born August 23 1922; died November 18 1999

Gyorgy Sebok, the veteran Hungarian concert pianist, has died aged 77. Born into a middle-class Jewish family, he was a child prodigy, playing Beethoven's complex first piano concerto in concert at 14. Studies at the Budapest Liszt Academy of Music followed. He survived the Nazi occupation - during which he was forced to do road-building work - to become professor of music at the Bela Bartok Conservatory, Budapest.

After the Hungarian uprising of 1956, Sebok emigrated to Paris, and in 1962 moved to America to head the piano department at Indiana University, Bloomington. He was much loved by students for his playing - especially of Liszt, Brahms, Schumann, Chopin and Bartok - and for his passion and encouragement. In 1987, he founded his own music festival in the Swiss village of Ernen.

Born November 2 1922; died November 12 1999

Pupella Maggio, who has died aged 89, was the last surviving member of a Neopolitan theatrical family, and won fame as a music-hall comedienne. In 1960, she appeared in Visconti's L'Arialda, which was later banned for obscenity. She played dramatic roles in actor-manager Eduardo De Filippo's company in Naples, and appeared in London in 1972. In the cinema, she was in Fellini's Amarcord, John Huston's The Bible and De Sica's Two Women. Her last performance was in a yet-to-be-shown film in which she played an old lady living alone. She insisted that the character be called Giustina, the name she was given by her parents. It was changed to Pupella (Baby Doll) when, as a baby, she was brought on stage in a basket by her father in the title role of a play, The Moveable Doll.

Born April 24 1910; died December 8 1999

webTitle: At least 161 injured in Spain as shop floor gives way during sales rush

fields.headline: At least 161 injured in Spain as shop floor gives way during sales rush
fields.trailText: At least 161 people were injured yesterday when the floor of a department store collapsed as shoppers queued for bargains in Dos Hermanas, near Seville in southern Spain.
fields.body:
At least 161 people were injured yesterday when the floor of a department store collapsed as shoppers queued for bargains in Dos Hermanas, near Seville in southern Spain.

Rescue workers spent most of the day retrieving victims from the rubble after around 32 square feet (10 square metres) of floor gave way under excess weight and dropped shoppers 13ft to the concrete basement. Five people were in serious condition last night and 138 people required hospital treatment.

The collapse came five minutes after the Muebles Peralta store opened at 10am, when 400 people lined up at a cash register to buy armchairs which were on sale at £11 each. When emergency services arrived they found customers carrying out the injured on makeshift stretchers and in the armchairs that had been on sale. A local government representative, Rocio Roche, said no one was trapped but police were searching with sniffer dogs as a precaution. AP

webTitle: Veteran, 94, holds balance of power in Dominican vote

fields.headline: Veteran, 94, holds balance of power in Dominican vote
fields.trailText: He is at least 94 years old, blind and cannot walk unassisted. But he still wants to be president of the Dominican Republic for the eighth time.
fields.body:
He is at least 94 years old, blind and cannot walk unassisted. But he still wants to be president of the Dominican Republic for the eighth time.

Joaquin Balaguer, once the right-hand man of the notorious dictator Rafael Trujillo, has announced that he intends to contest the Caribbean country's forthcoming election, his 10th presidential campaign.

The Dominican Republic - where 8m people live on an average yearly wage of only $2,000 (£1,245) - is already gripped by election fever, even though the country does not go to the polls until May 16.

As his die-hard supporters brandish the red flags of Mr Balaguer's Reformista party and chant his name, it seems the patriarch may yet decide the future of his country.

His opponents fear that his resurrection would put an end to moves towards reform under the current president, Leonel Fernandez, pointing to the activities of La Banda, a paramilitary group which killed hundreds of activists during Mr Balaguer's rule in the 1960s and 1970s.

They also recall that most of his electoral victories from 1966 to 1994 were marred by accusations of fraud. In 1994 the scale of alleged vote-rigging obliged international observers to insist that he stand down after only two years of a four-year term.

Mr Balaguer has dismissed charges of electoral impropriety and human rights abuses as a "myth", insisting that public demand had led him to re-emerge from retirement to rescue the country from economic and social collapse. In a recent interview, he presented himself as father of the nation, transcending the vulgarity of party politics.

But it is precisely within the labyrinthine Dominican political system that Mr Balaguer may indeed determine the result of the election.

Most opinion polls indicate that he will come third in the first round of voting, but neither of the leading parties - the Dominican Revolutionary party (PRD) and the Party of Dominican Liberation (PLD) - is unlikely to win the first round outright. Both are jockeying for his public endorsement for the second round.

Mr Balaguer commands 25% of voters who are renowned for their loyalty. That share could prove crucial.

However, when Mr Balaguer lent his support to Mr Fernandez in 1996, it is claimed that in return the president had to agree to consult the veteran politician on policy matters and give jobs to his coterie. The price that this year's eventual winner will have to pay remains to be seen.

webTitle: US impounds Russian oil tanker in Gulf

fields.headline: US impounds Russian oil tanker in Gulf
fields.trailText: Russia and the US were at loggerheads last night, with Moscow demanding the release of a Russian oil tanker intercepted by the US navy in the Gulf.
fields.byline: Ian Traynor in Moscow and Ewen MacAskill
fields.body:
Russia and the US were at loggerheads last night, with Moscow demanding the release of a Russian oil tanker intercepted by the US navy in the Gulf.

Washington suspects the vessel was smuggling Iraqi oil in breach of UN sanctions, but Moscow insists it was transporting Iranian fuel oil to the United Arab Emirates.

"Russia insists that the tanker be instantly released," said Russia's deputy foreign minister responsible for the Middle East, Vasily Sredin.

A spokesman for the Russian transport ministry said: "The word Iraq does not crop up in any of the documents."

Furious at the interception of the Russian vessel only hours after the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, ended a three-day visit to Moscow, senior Russian officials lodged complaints in Washington and Abu Dhabi while summoning US diplomats to the foreign ministry in Moscow.

Relations between the US and Russia are at their coolest since the 1980s.

Mr Sredin said the vessel, apparently stopped by the Americans for the second time in a week, had not entered Iraqi waters or any Iraqi port. Although Russian officials stressed the cargo had been taken on in Iran, the transport minister, Sergei Frank, said there was no way of verifying the origins of the 4,000 tons of oil on board.

The Russian oil industry, like western oil giants, is itching for sanctions on Iraq to be lifted. On Wednesday the Russian oil giant Lukoil announced it had completed planning work on a project to develop a huge western Iraqi oilfield with Iraq's state oil company, a project that should deliver up to 30m tons of oil a year and require investments of more than £2bn.

The White House was in intransigent mood yesterday. David Leavy, spokesman for the White House national security council, said: "The president made very clear we're going to vigorously enforce the sanctions. It is a top priority to us to continue to deny smuggling opportunities to the Iraqi regime."

The White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart, said this was the first time a Russian tanker had been detained under the international effort to enforce the embargo. He said inspectors had boarded ships 700 times last year and diverted them to port for further investigation 19 times. The US and Britain are the main enforcers.

The British foreign office adopted a wait-and-see approach to the standoff while a test was carried out to determine the origin of the oil. Either the US or Russia was going to end up looking sheepish, a spokesman said.

Sanctions were imposed after the Gulf war and are intended to force Iraq to destroy weapons of mass destruction. UN weapons inspectors were thrown out of Iraq after US and British raids in December 1998.

Questions about the effectiveness and humanitarian consequences of sanctions have been raised in the west. But US intelligence sources claimed this week that satellite photographs showed that Iraq has rebuilt military and industrial sites damaged in the 1998 raids, suggesting President Saddam Hussein is continuing his pursuit of biological and chemical weapons.

The sanctions regime has gradually been eroded, partly as a result of humanitarian concern. In 1996 the UN security council agreed to allow Iraq to export limited amounts of oil to pay for food and medicine. In December last year the ceiling on these exports was lifted as part of a British initiative aimed at trying to get Iraq to agree to allow weapons inspectors back into the country. All exports must still be approved by UN monitors.

The foreign office this week gave the go-ahead for the first flight between London and Baghdad since the Gulf war. A plane carrying medicine will leave London next month on a humanitarian mission organised by George Galloway MP. Most of the medicines have been approved by the foreign office but there is disagreement over proposals to take diphtheria vaccine, which the foreign office claims has a possible military use.

fields.headline: Storm over TV euthanasia guide
fields.trailText: Crush into a fine powder, mix with your favourite flavour of yogurt or perhaps apple sauce, wash down with a glass of vodka and die. This and other recipes for euthanasia shown last night on television in Oregon and to be repeated tonight have reopened the debate on suicide and the law.
fields.body:
Crush into a fine powder, mix with your favourite flavour of yogurt or perhaps apple sauce, wash down with a glass of vodka and die. This and other recipes for euthanasia shown last night on television in Oregon and to be repeated tonight have reopened the debate on suicide and the law.

Final Exit is a 34-minute explanation of the issues and practicalities of euthanasia. Broadcast on Channel 97, which can be seen only in Oregon, the programme is the first to give such information on US television. It is the work of Derek Humphry, author of the bestselling book Final Exit and founder of the Euthanasia Research and Guidance Organisation (Ergo).

"It talks about how not to get into trouble with the law," said Mr Humphry yesterday from his home in Junction City, Oregon, where his organisation is based. "I talk about the need to have someone with you. Our credo has always been not to do this alone but to have a family member present."

The relative would not be breaking the law unless they were "hands on".

Mr Humphry, a former Sunday Times journalist who became a campaigner on euthanasia issues as the founder of the Hemlock Society in 1980, said he explains the best ways for people to die. He stipulates the best drugs, advising that they should be crushed into a powder to be properly digested.

"I do add information on how to take life with a plastic bag if you can't get the drugs," he said.

The programme is aimed at people with a low attention span who might be unwilling to read a book on the subject. A video is also available. Mr Humphry said he had sent copies of the film, which cost $10,000 to make, to doctors, lawyers, psychiatrists and nurses and has had a positive response. He said the internet bookseller Amazon.com was also selling the book "at a jolly rate". Final Exit has sold more than 1m copies.

But the programme has been attacked by the Compassion in Dying Federation which suggested that someone who was mentally unwell or impulsive might act on the practical information.

Mr Humphry has been criticised in Oregon for "promoting suicide". But he stressed that the programme advised people who were mentally ill not to watch and to seek help. The techniques are aimed at people who have made a definite choice to avoid further pain, he added.

The film is being broadcast amid an attempt to change the law on euthanasia in the US. It has been legal in Oregon since 1997 and there were 15 such deaths there in 1998. Final figures for last year are unavailable but are thought to be similar. Under the law, two doctors have to agree to the process and there is a waiting time of 17 days. The person must be terminally ill and nearing the end of their life to qualify.

Maine is considering similar legislation. However, in November the house of representatives passed an act which would reverse the Oregon state law and jail a participating doctor for up to 20 years. This is likely to pass through the senate and would then be turned into law by President Clinton, who is against euthanasia.

If this happens, Oregon will go to the supreme court. If they were to lose there, "the people of Oregon would be furious", said Mr Humphry.

He said the right to die movement employs a paid lobbyist in Washington and runs a professional campaigning operation. "We now have very thrusting young lawyers arguing the case."

webTitle: Papal apology for errors riles Vatican hardliners

fields.headline: Papal apology for errors riles Vatican hardliners
fields.trailText: Pope John Paul II will next month attempt to purify the soul of the Catholic church by making a sweeping apology for 2,000 years of violence, persecution and blunders.
fields.body:
Pope John Paul II will next month attempt to purify the soul of the Catholic church by making a sweeping apology for 2,000 years of violence, persecution and blunders.

A document cataloguing the church's errors, including anti-semitism, is about to be published despite fierce opposition from Vatican hardliners who think it is a mistake to say sorry.

In the most ambitious mea culpa of his papacy, John Paul will seek forgiveness for violent evangelism, the inquisition and religious wars, including the crusades.

La Repubblica newspaper suggested he will go as far as to apologise for the failure to resist the Nazis, but without implicating Pope Pius XII, who has been accused of ignoring the holocaust during the second world war.

A team of theologians, led by Cardinal Joseph Ratzinger, head of the congregation for the doctrine of the faith, has spent three years drafting the report, titled The Church and the Mistakes of the Past. Its 50 pages will form a centrepiece of the Vatican's holy year, or jubilee, celebrations.

The ailing 79-year-old pope has accelerated attempts to reach out to other religions as his health has declined.

Conservatives in the Curia, the Vatican's bureaucracy, argued that an apology would erode the foundations of church authority. They were rebuffed and told the jubilee could be celebrated only with "purification of the memory".

Having failed to stop the report, they will concentrate on trying to dilute it before publication, predicted one source.

The Vatican hopes that the declaration, to be made during a ceremony on March 12, will smooth John Paul's potentially fraught visit to Israel and the holy land later next month.

He has dedicated the jubilee, which occurs every 25 years, to repentance and renewal. He rejected advice that other religions may interpret the apology as a sign of weakness, La Stampa newspaper said.

Apologies to Galileo, the renaissance astronomer persecuted for suggesting the earth was round, and Muslims for atrocities committed by the Crusaders, have distinguished John Paul from his predecessors, said Edward Yarnold, a Jesuit theologian at Oxford university. "But this is the most significant. He's going over the whole Christian era. Many Catholics will welcome it as a positive step; there's a momentum growing that we need to admit more faults.

"Some conservative Catholics will be offended, though. They will wrongly think that this apology is the thin end of a wedge which will eventually challenge doctrine."

According to Luigi Accattoli, a Catholic author, the pope has in the past two decades made efforts to atone for the church's role in schisms, racism, wars, crime, corruption and the Rwandan genocide.

Some initiatives have backfired, said Margaret Hebblethwaite, a theologian and Vatican expert. "Most were not apologies at all. He told the Jews that terrible things had happened to them but that it wasn't the church's fault. Many Jews were hurt by that. I welcome the apology that's coming, but suspect it won't go far enough."

In a separate development, the Vatican last night advanced the partial rehabilitation of Giordano Bruno, a Dominican priest burned at the stake 400 years ago this month for challenging orthodoxy, including the immaculate conception.

The investigating Cardinal, Paul Poupard, said the church was wrong to execute Bruno but right to reject his heresies.

fields.headline: News in brief
fields.trailText: Middle East talks in crisis
fields.body:
Middle East talks in crisis

Palestinian officials said talks with Israel were in crisis yesterday after the Palestinian leader, Yasser Arafat, and Israel's prime minister, Ehud Barak, abruptly ended a meeting and cancelled a press conference. Mr Arafat was said to be angry at perceived Israeli procrastination over troop withdrawals from the occupied territories.

The two leaders were due to reach a draft deal for a permanent peace treaty by February 13, but that now appears unlikely.
Ilene Prusher, Jerusalem

Bangladeshi law sparks fury

Opposition groups in Bangladesh plan fresh action against a new law they say is intended to curb street protests and persecute political opponents.

At least two people were killed and more than 200 injured during a 36-hour general strike that ended yesterday.
Arshad Mahmud, Dhaka

Monaco prince has surgery

Prince Rainier of Monaco, 76, is recovering after having part of a lung removed, a spokesman said yesterday. The operation was scheduled after a small growth was discovered.
AP, Monte Carlo

Pupil in grenade attack at school

A pupil in the Philippines, suspended for not wearing a uniform, threw a grenade at a school gate yesterday, killing a pupil and wounding 38, police in Manila said.
Reuters, Manila

Three years for dissident

A member of an outlawed Chinese pro-democracy party has been sentenced to three years in jail, the Information Centre of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China claims. Dai Xuezhong of the China Democracy party was accused of scuffling with a colleague.
Reuters, Hong Kong

webTitle: How to cheat at dinner parties

fields.headline: How to cheat at dinner parties
fields.standfirst: Afraid your cooking will let you down? There's no need to panic anymore...
fields.trailText: Are you ashamed that you can't cook? Embarrassed to invite your friends round? Have you ever been humiliated by serving inedible food? Well, panic over.
fields.body:
Are you ashamed that you can't cook? Embarrassed to invite your friends round? Have you ever been humiliated by serving inedible food? Well, panic over.

Dinner party anxiety may be a thing of the past thanks to Tesco's Cheater's Charter, published this week. Follow these 10 failsafe tips and you'll never be caught out again . . .

The so-called charter is a 10-point list of advice on how to cover your tracks if you throw a dinner party using ready-made meals. And it's classic stuff. "Wear an apron to greet your guests" is the first injunction. "It gives the impression of having slaved all day in the kitchen." Next: "Take clean pots and pans out of the cupboard and place them upside down on the draining board. Guests will believe that you've just washed up after cooking." And if the guests enjoy dinner, "Accept praise with a slightly bashful look and a seemingly modest reply, 'Oh, it's just something I popped into the oven'."

"I really don't understand why anyone would want to lie if they'd bought something in," says Nigella Lawson, author of the best-selling How to Eat. "It's a bit like buying cheap clothes and trying to pass them off as expensive ones. Why on earth would you want to pretend? It implies that the only difference between the food you make at home and the food you buy in the supermarket is the box it comes in and that obviously isn't the case.

"I'm quite happy to mix food that I cook with food that I buy. There's nothing wrong with buying a cooked chicken and putting other things with it. The pre-packed salad leaves you can buy now are great, for example, but you can easily fry up a few lardons or bit of bacon to toss with them rather than steeping them in some kind of sauce with coagulants in."

Psychologist Dr Gerald Hales believes there's still cachet in being able to produce "proper" food. "There is a certain snob value attached to it. It's saying, 'We have the time, skill and money to do things properly.' But not everyone knows what the proper thing is to do. According to Jacqueline O'Neill, the category manager for convenience foods for Tesco, many people are scared witless by having guests round. "A lot of young people don't have the skill to successfully host a dinner party and they get stressed. All we're doing is reassuring them that it's OK to cheat.

"There is a trend coming from the States that people increasingly prefer to have a more intimate evening with their friends than is possible in the mid-market restaurant chains, but they can't do it if they don't know how to or don't want to cook."

Supermarkets, of course, have a vested interest in removing our inhibitions about using pre-prepared food. Tesco claims that 30% of dinner parties are based on bought-in ready meals, a figure that might seem high but, put another way, there's 70% still to be won over. According to Mintel's most recent piece of research on home meal replacements (cooked foods that are available from the deli counter), the biggest take-up is among the 45-54 age group who are in full-time employment and fall into the category of "better-off empty nesters". In other words, those who have more dosh than the average customer.

The key to losing your inhibitions, as Nigella Lawson suggests, is to have some input into the meal, however modest. Marks and Spencer, which has been at the game longer than Tesco, says its customers pick and choose. "They might buy a pudding or a starter, for example, but they'll make the main course. Because they've done some of the cooking they don't have a problem saying, 'Look, this is Marks and Sparks' latest dish'," says a spokesman for the store.

The problem for Tesco could be that just as most M&S shoppers can spot a chicken Kiev at a thousand paces, visitors to the Tesco website will recognise the tell-tale signs of the practised cheat.

So next time you see a clean pan on the draining board or your host or hostess swans into the sitting room in a spotless apron, be suspicious. Be very suspicious.

fields.headline: A whole world of difference
fields.standfirst: When you buy your favourite brand abroad, the flavour may come as a nasty shock.  Julia Hartley-Brewer  investigates
fields.trailText: Wherever you are in the world - London, New York, Delhi or Manila - the billboards and supermarket shelves are saturated with the same brand names. There are few places left on the planet where you can't buy a Diet Coke, a packet of Kellogg's cornflakes or some Oxo cubes.
fields.body:
Wherever you are in the world - London, New York, Delhi or Manila - the billboards and supermarket shelves are saturated with the same brand names. There are few places left on the planet where you can't buy a Diet Coke, a packet of Kellogg's cornflakes or some Oxo cubes.

But just try tasting them. The packaging and the product may look identical, but the flavour may be far from familiar. And you're not imagining it: experts agree that the taste of globally recognised brands really does vary from country to country.

Since billions of pounds a year are spent on marketing these brands, this is not a fact that many manufacturers want to advertise. But probe a little and you'll find that most will admit to some tinkering with their original recipe on occasion. The main reason for this seems to be that what we think of as classic, simple flavours can cause revulsion in other parts of the world.

More often than not, even the most famous of brand names are specially formulated to appeal to individual national palates. Heinz, for instance, insists that its tomato ketchup - the most global of their 57 varieties - is "the same recipe worldwide" but admits that "there may be very subtle variations in the spicing". And even the ultimate big brand, Coca-Cola, accepts that not all its products are what they may appear to be.

"We go to great lengths to ensure that Coca-Cola is the same wherever you drink it," the company's British spokesman Ian Muir says. "But Diet Coke may change slightly from country to country because we use different sweeteners in different places."

Before a brand launch, manufacturers conduct extensive taste tests to discover whether a particular product, which may already be a leading name elsewhere in the world, conforms to the traditional culinary tastes and preferences of that country.

Americans, for instance, prefer many products, particularly chocolate, to be far more sugary than the Europeans. And the French perceive strawberry flavour in a different way to the British, so the artificial flavouring in France will not have a "proper" strawberry taste to Britons. Preferences for saltiness and colour often differ as well, says Catherine Reynolds of the Institute of Food Research, while most Japanese consumers dislike the taste of milk.

Even Nescafe coffee is subject to slight variations in blending to suit different markets. The French in general prefer stronger, fuller-tasting coffee than the British, Nestle UK's Marion Irving says.

"Products sold in the UK and France tend to be much more dairy-based, which is what people like. While those on sale in Spain are more oil-based," says Steve Milton of the Anglo-Dutch conglomerate Unilever, whose huge range of branded goods, including Flora, Magnum ice creams, Ragu sauces, Oxo, PG Tips and Birds Eye, is worth £27bn a year worldwide.

"We try to align the brand as closely as possible but, ultimately, we have to go with local tastes because consumers' preferences vary."

Those flavour differences may be due to different amounts of certain additives, spices or herbs, or even differences in the quality. "There is a higher cream content in a Magnum ice cream sold in Italy than in Britain because the Italians expect ice cream to have a much richer taste than we do," says Milton. "And tea brands sold in Europe tend to be weaker than the strong tea preferred by Britons."

Even famous brands like Oxo are blended with different herbs to complement each country's national dish; the version sold in Britain is tailored to suit the traditional Sunday roast beef.

Taste preferences can vary even within countries, with at least one well-known soft drink made to a sweeter recipe in the southern states of the USA than that on sale in the north.

With a successful brand able to reap millions - and sometimes even billions - in sales, it's no wonder that manufacturers spend small fortunes researching why consumers want and expect particular tastes.

Cultural and geographical factors are the chief explanation, according to Dave Mela, a consumer scientist. "There are regional differences in basic tastes or flavours but physiologically there are no huge variations in humans. Essentially, all preferences for certain flavours are acquired, not genetic."

Not every difference in a brand's taste, however, is deliberate. While licensing and franchising agreements allow multinationals to produce locally, this can also mean accidental variations in the product.

Local water and soil will both affect the taste of home-grown raw ingredients, while some key constituents may not be available, meaning alternatives must be found. Sometimes, especially in developing countries, premium-grade components, such as high-grade flour, are replaced with lower-quality equivalents.

Extremes in climate will also require different additives and preservatives to be used. Chocolate, for instance, requires an alternative recipe in hot countries if it is to maintain its texture and taste.

And while multinationals may be omnipotent in the marketplace, they must still conform to national laws and regulations concerning approved additives, flavourings, colourings and, particularly, artificial low-calorie sweeteners. Mars and Snickers bars, for instance, taste slightly different in Australia, where the use of vegetable fat in chocolate is banned.

Local religious sensibilities must also be observed. Even McDonald's, which proudly proclaims the homogeneity of its Big Macs around the globe, has to serve lamb rather than beef burgers to its Indian customers.

But often the difference in a brand's taste is due simply to consumers' expectations. Guinness, which sells 22 variants of its famous stout around the globe, varies hugely in alcohol content. In Nigeria (the brand's third largest market) Guinness is almost twice the strength of the pint on sale here and in Ireland. This anomaly dates from the 19th century when a higher alcohol content was used as a natural preservative for the long journey out to the colony.

"Nigerians wouldn't recognise the Guinness we drink as the same product," Jonathan Miller, spokesman for Guinness Worldwide, explains, and any attempt to reduce the alcohol content is unlikely to meet with approval.

After all, as Miller says,"If you provide consumers with something they don't like, they simply won't buy it."

fields.headline: No: 1570 Everest
fields.trailText: Status: Why, it's the highest mountain in the world, of course, rising to 29,028ft (8,847m). Or is it 29,035ft (8,849m)?
fields.body:
Status: Why, it's the highest mountain in the world, of course, rising to 29,028ft (8,847m). Or is it 29,035ft (8,849m)?

Sounds confusing: It is. The National Geographic Society in Washington says it's actually 7ft (2.1m) higher than previously thought, but the governments of China and Nepal are sticking with the old figure until they see "convincing proof".

Could it have grown? Most scientists think that it is growing. The movement of tectonic plates is apparently forcing it upwards at about the rate of 1cm (0.3in) a year. Only problem is, the new data suggest it's grown a whacking 7ft since it was first measured in 1857.

Well, could it have? Herein lies the problem. There's no way of knowing if the original measurements were accurate.

Any other theories? Perhaps all the rubbish from the mountaineers is piling up.

That sounds a bit far-fetched: Well, a recent report described Everest as "the highest junkyard in the world", and environmentalists reckon there's 50 tonnes of rubbish scattered across the mountain. This garbage includes climbing equipment, tins, aluminium cans, glass, cloths, papers, tents, and, er . . . dead bodies.

Sounds awful: It gets worse. As one female American climber recorded in her journals: "I'm sick of no toilets. I really hate the place we poop into. You have to hold on to parts of the rock wall and lean over the pile that is in a gully. One slip and it's disaster."

What would Sir Edmund Hillary make of all this? He's disgusted. Sir Edmund thinks too many people who have no love of mountains are allowed access to Everest. These people can pay up to £50,000 for an expedition in which ladders and ropes are already in place, ensuring an easy progress to the summit.

But could the rubbish really have anything to do with the height controversy? Well, no.

Do say: Keep Everest tidy.

Don't say: Just leave it there. No one will ever notice.

webTitle: How do you persuade an indiscreet friend to keep her mouth shut?

fields.headline: How do you persuade an indiscreet friend to keep her mouth shut?
fields.body:
I have been HIV positive for 13 years. I told no one for six years until I confided in a friend whom I have known now for 15 years. I told her that not many people know and thought I could rely on her. However, since then the number of people who know about my HIV status has grown exponentially as she brings it up at every opportunity. It all culminated at a recent dinner party where, again out of the blue, she brought up my HIV status in front of three people I had not met before. Afterwards, I reminded her that two years ago she had an abortion that no one else knew about, and asked how she would like it if I continually brought that up. She reacted violently, locked herself in the bathroom and cried, and now refuses to speak to me. By her own admission, she comes from a family of underachievers, and had the best year of her life 12 years ago. My partner says she uses people's personal information as social currency to make herself more interesting. How do I proceed?

With friends like that_

Your friend has behaved very badly towards you, betraying trust. Even allowing that she obviously has problems, you don't need this sort of hassle in your life.

In 1989, a close friend of mine told me he was HIV positive shortly after diagnosis, and before he had told his family. Since then he has been very "out" about it, choosing to tell most people he knows. He did not want it to be a secret - although his family did. However, none of this gave me any right to tell people. Whether or not they would be "OK about it" was irrelevant.

In the early days there were some occasions when mutual friends unexpectedly made a remark or asked me a leading question, out of concern for him, but the correct thing was to suggest they talk to him, not me.

Give her one last chance

If your friend doesn't know that you mind her telling strangers that you are HIV positive, she is extremely insensitive or inattentive. I think the problem is that she doesn't care. I think your partner is right about her using other people's private lives as social currency.

As for the current problem, I would suggest that you have one last attempt at making this woman realise how much she is hurting you. If this doesn't work, you should drop her from your life. On no account should you succumb to blackmail.

Name and address withheld

She's got to go

Your friend has behaved appallingly and no amount of mitigation (unhappy life, underachiever) changes that. I too have HIV and am discreet about who I tell. When, on one occasion, a friend of mine told others that I was positive, I was absolutely furious and she soon stopped being my friend. Why do you still have contact with yours?

I think you have to decide what is more important to you - your friendship with this woman or your privacy. I suspect that you can't have both. Do you fear that if you break off the friendship she will get revenge by telling everyone she can about your status? I think this is actually unlikely. From the way that you describe her, it sounds as if she is indiscreet about you mainly when in your presence. I would be inclined to celebrate the fact that "she now refuses to speak to you" - friends like that you do not need.

AB, Leicestershire

fields.headline: Money money money
fields.standfirst: One billion dollars to reform?  Stuart Jeffries  on why super troupers Abba are right to say no
fields.trailText:
The history book on the shelf is always repeating itself.
Waterloo, by Abba
fields.body:
The history book on the shelf is always repeating itself.
Waterloo, by Abba

Those were the days. Benny had the beard, Björn had the permanent smile. They were joined by Agnetha Fältskog and Benny's girlfriend, the Norwegian-born Anni-Frid "Frida" Lyngstad. Neither women had beards, but Agnetha could be immediately distinguished from Frida because she had blonde hair and caused outrage by waving her satin bottom from Glasgow to Granada. Frida, so far as one could understand, would not have stooped to that kind of thing.

On April 6 1974, at the Dome in Brighton, Abba trounced the British Eurovision entry, Long Live Love, by Olivia Newton-John. Which was just as well, on sartorial grounds alone: Olivia wore something that looked like a wincyette nightie, while Abba were swathed in outfits that were, so far as one could judge, what history experts reckoned would have been worn had the Battle of Waterloo been fought in Brighton in the 70s.

For a decade afterwards, Abba dominated the charts (23 hits in Britain alone) and became very rich Swedes indeed (£50m from songwriting; £250m from record sales, films and, quite probably, horrible silk scarves). In 1983, they split.

But why can't the history book on the shelf repeat itself? Why can't Abba take the $1bn offered by an Anglo-American consortium, play 100 gigs and teach a new generation of women how to tease their hair up and over the line of their woolly hats? Why can't they wave their fiftysomething bottoms seductively at a new generation of baffled pre-pubescents?

The answer lies in the lyrics to Abba's Winner Takes It All:

"I've played all my cards,
And that is what you've done too.
Nothing more to say,
No more ace to play.
The winner takes it all,
The loser standing small.
Beside the victory,
That's our destiny."

If you study this, you'll realise that what they mean is that Abba have no more aces to play, and that to reform would only traduce the memory of their hard-won chart victories. If you're a winner or a loser, there comes a moment when your hand is empty. So, surely, it is with Abba. "It was another time. I was another person," said one-time super trouper Björn Ulvaeus earlier this week. A reformed Abba could only be farcical. Today they embody 70s kitsch - which is no doubt why the Mamma Mia! musical in London is so successful, and why every camp sitcom (well, Gimme Gimme Gimme) alludes to Sweden's most lucrative entertainment-based export, and why every recent Australian rites-of-passage film (well, Muriel's Wedding) throbs with a soundtrack of Dancing Queen and Money Money Money. But back in the 70s, Abba were as serious as a Volvo estate.

If it would be unwise for Abba to reform, what about Tears for Fears? This week they offered to regroup, if that's the expression, for free. You remember them. One was fairly anonymous, the other had a curly mullet and Jerry Seinfeld's teeth. Two white soul boys. Like Wham! then, but with a more egalitarian distribution of talents between the principals. They played Live Aid at Wembley. Sowing the Seeds of Love. That was one of their songs. Never heard of them, have you?

Should they reform? Personally, I couldn't give an Andrew Ridgeley's. Surely the bigger question is: why don't music corporations spend their money more wisely? A remedial spelling course, perhaps, for the Lyte Funkie Ones. A large can of whoopass for Eminem. A few quiet words to Britney Spears and Mariah Carey about their marketing strategies. A few bob to crop those reverse mullets on the Gallagher brothers. Cheap, cheerful solutions to musical problems. We don't need old bands to reform so much as we need the new ones to get with the programme.

fields.headline: 'I have changed. Genuinely'
fields.standfirst: New Labour is gearing up for the next election with a raft of unlikely new candidates who a decade ago would have been happier canvassing for the Tories. And perhaps the strangest of this new breed is the former Tory MP Alan Amos, who was once anti-abortion and pro-flogging. Sally Weale profiles Millbank's next wave of hopefuls
fields.trailText: A little over 10 years ago, Alan Amos advocated flogging for rapists and muggers. He believed in birching in schools; he was vehemently anti-abortion (he was a member of SPUC, the Society for the Protection of the Unborn Child) and he bitterly opposed embryo experimentation.
fields.body:
A little over 10 years ago, Alan Amos advocated flogging for rapists and muggers. He believed in birching in schools; he was vehemently anti-abortion (he was a member of SPUC, the Society for the Protection of the Unborn Child) and he bitterly opposed embryo experimentation.

For five years he was Tory MP for the Northumbrian constituency of Hexham; Andrew Roth's book of parliamentary profiles described him at the time as "an abortion-obsessed bachelor"; ambitious, orthodox and right wing. An anti-smoking teetotaller, Amos served under Thatcher and Major and was once found to be the fourth hardest working MP in the house.

Today, he is a candidate for Labour - one of 700 members approved by Millbank and hoping to stand at the next general election for a seat in the House of Commons. Amos is perhaps the most unlikely of Labour candidates out of a list which includes individuals who, a decade ago, would have been regarded as equally unlikely. Among the more traditional Labour activists, the trade unionists and town councillors, there is an adviser to a City bank, a wealthy city accountant and a champion of small business - the list, commentators say, marks a swing to business and the right. The newly Labourite Amos is at least in familiar company.

That Amos is on the Labour Party's list of approved candidates speaks volumes for the personal transformation he has undergone. For him, it was not a case of shifting a few inches from one side of the political divide to the other, it was a volte-face. But perhaps it also tells us something about the party which has taken him in and adopted him as one of its candidates. For the Labour Party's transformation under Tony Blair is every bit as radical as that of Alan Amos - as the new breed of would-be Labour MPs illustrates.

Alan Amos's face, then, is the face of New Labour - pink, scrubbed, and it used to be the face of the Young Conservatives. Dressed in unremarkable green macintosh, dark suit, blue striped shirt and red tie with galloping donkeys (symbol of the American Democrats), he could belong to any political party. His shoes are polished, his hair freshly cut. He is ill at ease and self-conscious, but he is decidedly on-message.

Where once he called for flogging, now he preaches tolerance; no more corporal punishment, now it's social justice; more than a decade ago he named and shamed private gynaecologists carrying out late abortions, last week he was talking about understanding and how we all ought to be less judgmental.

The lives of Alan Amos and Tony Blair are curiously interweaved. Amos, 47, first began working for the Tories when he was 14. His parents were presidents of the Hendon Young Conservatives and the young Alan would distribute leaflets for his father who was a councillor in Harpenden for seven years. His political career gathered pace when he was elected president of the Oxford University Conservative Association; he was a contemporary of Blair's at St John's College, where he studied PPE. Blair, Amos remembers, was a popular student.

Their political lives flourished despite their tender years - in 1984 Amos became the youngest member on Enfield borough council, before succeeding Sir Geoffrey (later Lord) Rippon in Hexham in 1987. Then, in 1992, shortly before the general election, Amos suffered a fall from grace. He was forced to resign after being arrested and cautioned for alleged indecency on Hampstead Heath. He has always denied being gay and dismisses the incident as "a silly mistake".

But no matter how airily he might try to shrug it off now, his arrest had a devastating impact on him and his career. Amos lost his faith in the Tory Party, in the police and in the tabloid press. Even today he cannot disguise his contempt and loathing for all three - the party activisits at Hexham who forced him out are "dreadful people". The tabloid papers who revelled in his downfall are "the gutter press" who print what they like regardless of the truth - he refuses to speak to them now. And he loathes the police with a vengeance.

For a year after his demise, Amos worked for John Gummer ("a very nice man"), then decided to go travelling for a year to sort himself out. "The Tory party was going very fast and very far to the right. That process was unstoppable. The Conservative party always has to have a group to hate. Years ago there were the communists. Then there's gays, single mothers - now it's everybody in the European Union. I realised I no longer wanted to be part of a minority-bashing, foreigner-hating party."

At the same time the Tory party lurched to the right, Amos began to acquire a new sense of social justice. He was impressed by the transformation of the Labour Party under first John Smith and then Tony Blair, and soon his friends began to tell him he sounded more Labour than Tory. In 1994, he became a fully paid-up member of New Labour. It had nothing to do with opportunism - it was "a very courageous, very difficult decision to make". "It's not the case that the Labour party has moved so far to the right it can absorb Tory MPs," he insists. No? "No, my views have changed considerably and genuinely.

"What has changed in me is the fundamental way I look at situations and look at people. I like to think I'm a tolerant, understanding person. In those days I was more judgmental."

So what about flogging? "I no longer believe in that," says Amos. "At the time what I thought was if we had a deterrent that would stop a lot of crime. With more deterrent you could stop more crime. I've come to see we should be looking at the causes of these people's problems." What about abortion? He's no longer a member of SPUC but seems uncomfortable talking about his old hobby horse. "In principle, I think it should not be used as a form of birth control. But I think there are cases where people have to make that decision. Clearly in the case of rape, for example."

He believes life begins at conception but argues that it is not for others to pontificate. "We need to understand a bit more. When you are faced with a difficult personal situation, you have to make difficult decisions."

So who are Amos's fellow candidates and what can they tell us about New Labour second time round? Well, women currently make up a third of the approved list, but the NEC fears that few will be selected without some form of positive action. Much more likely to make it onto constituency shortlists are the like of Stephen Alambritis, 42.

Alambritis is the highly successful head of press and parliamentary affairs for the Federation of Small Businesses. It is not so long ago that the FSB was regarded as little more than an arm of the Tory Party.

"The natural assumption is that small business is in the Conservative camp," he says. "But that changed at the last election. The votes were up for grabs. The Conservatives had become complacent. They assumed that it would be theirs, but Labour made a big pitch for it.

"Before that we had millions of self-employed people who felt that the Labour Party was not for them - it was for the worker not the boss. But that started to change under John Smith. Then, in 1996, Tony Blair addressed our annual conference in Maidstone. We were beginning to influence the Labour party in the interests of small business."

Other candidates on the business side of the party include David Pitt-Watson, who gave up a £250,000-a-year job with accountants Deloitte and Touche to become Labour's finance chief, and Siôn Simon, associate editor of the right-wing Spectator. Simon has been writing in the Daily Telegraph recently about how no one's interested in the ethics of supplying Zimbabwe with spare weapons parts and how the only group truly outraged by the government's Mike Tyson U-turn was "politically correct women whom the rest of the population is amused to see offended".

Everyone knows New Labour has moved to the right; everyone knows about its cosy new relationship with bosses and businesses, millionaires and multi-nationals. Perhaps we should be more surprised at the continuing preponderance of traditional Labour candidates on Millbank's approved list - the trade unionists and the local councillors, rather than the businessmen and City types.

It's a mixed bag, but what this second generation of Labour hopefuls reflects most vividly - old Tory-New Labour Alan Amos included - is the colossal scale of change during the government's first term in office and hints at what might lie ahead in the second.
