fields.headline: Jackie Oh!
fields.standfirst: Brash, bestselling author Jacqueline Susann is the subject of a new movie biopic. Richard Covington on the ultimate schmoozer whose reputation is rising once again
fields.trailText: Brash, bestselling author Jacqueline Susann is the subject of a new movie biopic. Richard Covington on the ultimate schmoozer whose reputation is rising once again
fields.body:
Not too many comedies are based on the lives of people who come across as obnoxious, boorish and unappealing because not many people will pay to see them. One subject who at least partly fits this description is the late Jacqueline Susann, celebrated and reviled author of heavy-breathing immorality tales that turned the stuffy publishing business on its ear some 30 years ago.

The problem with chronicling the life of Susann - pill addict, cancer sufferer, mother of an autistic son, and gossipy author, who, in reality, could be aggressively overbearing, uncouth, insecure and frequently unpleasant to be around - was coming up with a script and an actor who could convey the brashness and yet manage to keep the character sympathetic, and funny.

The makers of Isn't She Great think they found the ideal choice in Bette Midler, who has made a career of being aggressively overbearing and uncouth - and, above all, very funny. In the hands of Midler, Nathan Lane, David Hyde Pierce, John Cleese, Stockard Channing and director Andrew Bergman, the hard-bitten, foul-mouthed and ultimately courageous Susann of Isn't She Great, which opened last week in the US, has become sweeter and funnier than she ever dreamed of being in real life.

A visit to the set during filming in Montreal in the summer of 1998 proved instructive. Cultures collide in a scene in which Hyde Pierce's fictional character, buttoned-down editor Michael Hastings, calls on Susann and her doting husband, Irving Mansfield (played by Nathan Lane, best known here for Mouse Hunt), in their palatial apartment overlooking Central Park.

"Mike!" blurts out Lane, as publicist and producer Mansfield. "Come in, take a load off. Jackie, it's Mike!"

A hallucination of powder-blue feather marabou and navy blue dressing gown, dangling pink velvet eyeshades, Midler's Jackie bursts out of the bedroom.

"What the hell is wrong with you?" she bellows. "It's fucking dawn!"

Hastings gingerly picks his way forward. "Miss Susann? I'm Michael Hastings, your editor. We have to get to work. I have a great many comprehensive notes."

"Notes?" asks Jackie, bristling. "Whaddaya mean, notes?" "Miss Susann, your manuscript is presently nigh on incoherent," Hastings replies. "And that's bad?" she asks ingenuously. "Yes!" he answers, exploding in exasperation.

"Well, Mr Picky! Buster, you just hold on," retorts Jackie, stalking out to change into another of many gloriously psychedelic Pucci concoctions, ready to do battle with the supercilious Connecticut Yankee publisher in Queen Jackie's court.

"Isn't she great?" chuckles Irving. "She's so excited. Thrilled. She's never been edited before."

Cut. Between shots, Hyde Pierce says of his character: "It's essentially like I've gone to Mars. I have never met people like this. The book that she's trying to publish is a complete mess, and they're talking about what kind of limousines they should be getting and what the cover of the book jacket is going to look like."

Part wisecracking comedy of manners, part rags-to-riches romance, Paul Rudnick's script captures what Midler calls "the Ed Sullivan of it all, the Stork Club, El Morocco and Delmonico's, that Broadway life" that Jackie and Irving lived for. They invented themselves as characters in a Runyonesque universe, holding court in Lindy's delicatessen and other showbiz haunts.

With the media now bristling with tell-all confessionals that Jackie's novels helped pioneer, something of a Susann renaissance is in the works. Her books - Valley of the Dolls, The Love Machine and Once is Not Enough, all number one bestsellers in the 60s and 70s - are back in print. In addition to the Universal feature with Midler and Lane, Fox has in development a remake of Valley of the Dolls, with Betty Thomas attached to produce and direct, and USA Network has already aired (in December 1998) a small-screen biopic about Susann starring Michele Lee.

Susann couldn't sing, she couldn't act, she couldn't dance, and she tried them all. Many would argue she couldn't construct a plot if her life depended on it, and, in a way, it did. But, boy, could she schmooze.

Up at dawn to bring coffee and doughnuts to the Teamsters, Jackie made sure the truck drivers got her books to the bookstores on time. Armed with a Rolodex listing booksellers' names, birthdays, the names of their children and pets, she and Irving toured the country, greeting salespeople like old friends, shamelessly enlisting a loyal following to flog her scandalous, hugely popular potboilers.

According to Michael Korda, Susann's post-Valley of the Dolls editor at Simon & Schuster, she reinvented that mainstay of the publishing business, the romance novel, making room for both "tears and oral sex", drug-addicted beauties and Hollywood heels, and paving the way for the likes of Danielle Steel, Jackie Collins and Judith Krantz.

"She reinvented the way books were sold, the marketing and packaging, which may or may not be good for the literary establishment, but it was a reality of the changing times," explains Mike Lobell, the film's producer.

A beauty-contest winner from Philadelphia, Jackie hit New York at age 18, hungry for fame. She was so self-absorbed that when the Japanese had the effrontery to bomb Pearl Harbor during an ill-timed audition, she flew into a rage, incensed that no one was paying any attention to her husky, off-key baritone. She tried modelling, acting, writing plays, appearing in radio and television commercials, and forming a singing group - proving a rousing failure in everything.

Ultimately she found her gimmick. Her books sold in unprecedented numbers, film tie-ins were box-office successes and she became a household name. With characteristic gall, she claimed that the 1960s would be remembered for three landmarks: Andy Warhol, the Beatles and Jackie Susann. Yet, by the 80s, the books were out of print and the self-declared icon was remembered vaguely for her big hair, big lips and heavy, raccoon-eye make-up.

Had Susann been only a tough-talking, Machiavellian creature of celebrity, she would have proved as one-dimensional as the pill-popping heroines in her novels. She was not. Beneath her carefully constructed illusion of the glamorous high life were two tragedies she kept deeply private. Part of the reason she drove herself so hard to achieve fame was to pay for institutionalising the Mansfields' autistic son, Guy, whose existence she and Irving hid from all but their closest friends.

To overcome her depression over Guy, Irving suggested she write a book. Eventually she produced Every Night, Josephine!, a dog's-eye view of life with Jackie. In yet another blow, however, on the eve of the book's publication in 1963, she was diagnosed with breast cancer, which, at the time was nearly always a fatal disease. She had mastectomies, underwent radiation therapy that forced her to wear a series of trademark wigs, and became addicted to sedatives, the cause of her slow-motion speech. Not until after her death from the disease in 1974 at 56 did the public learn of her cancer and the existence of the couple's autistic son (who remains institutionalised at an undisclosed facility).

"Her attitude was: 'Who's gonna buy a sexy book from someone who has cancer?' and I think she was right," director Bergman explains.

While her novels peeled away glamorous facades to reveal her characters' hidden miseries, she felt the same candour about her own suffering was out of the question. "In an age where people make whole careers about going public about their private lives, it's ironic that someone so bold, flashy, upfront and in-your-face as Jackie was really completely private," says Channing, who plays Susann's best friend.

"Jackie and her crowd had a kind of nobility because they kept up a front. They put on the make-up, the hair, they went out into the world and had fun and entertained other people and didn't moan and groan. There was something fabulous about that."

Based largely on Korda's alternately painful and hilarious account of working with Jackie, published in August 1995 in the New Yorker magazine, the film also draws on background from Irving's own sanitised biography and Barbara Seaman's less than flattering portrait of the Mansfields in Lovely Me.

While Rudnick's script sticks closely to anecdotes in the Korda article and from other sources, it is far from purist biography. The film version tones down some of the couple's grasping nastiness and the more sordid details of their life together, skipping Susann's numerous affairs, principally with Borscht Belt comics and, more scandalously, with Ethel Merman.

"Rudnick captures what made their marriage work and concentrates on the most charming aspects of Irving and Jackie, who I think could be a handful in reality and a little less than charming," says Lane. Although still brassy enough to fill Carnegie Hall, Midler's Jackie is a far more sympathetic character. "In reality, Jackie was a tough, foul-mouthed woman and totally controlling," says Bergman. "Bette is a far more bravura kind of personality than Jackie was and has much more humour than she did."

"People said things about her that if they had said them about me, I would've just died," says Midler. "She must've had a hide like an elephant."

It's nearly midnight on the set in Montreal, but the Mansfields are still waiting for breakfast. A punchy Midler and Channing sing Kurt Weill songs between takes to keep themselves alert.

When filming resumes, Channing's Flo, a tipsy, blissfully self-centred actress, charges into the room for the seventh time, trailing a fur stole over her pink sequinned dress, her hair staying as defiantly erect as the Chrysler Building in a towering bouffant. "They fired me!" she rages.

Suddenly, Jackie materialises, wearing a flamboyant Pucci gown, wig curls bobbing.

"Flo!" brays Jackie. "Jackie!" booms Flo, rushing to her, nearly knocking over the bannister from the landing.

From offstage, the director yells cut. "Stockard, you got to her too soon," he says. In this double-time ballet, it's a wonder everyone isn't crashing into one another more often.

Once again, Flo sweeps in, Jackie flutters in, and, this time, the choreographed blocking runs like clockwork.

"You wanted changes?" Jackie challenges a dumbfounded Hastings. "How's this for editing?" she says, thrusting her head triumphantly to the ceiling, swishing the gown dramatically.

"They fired me," Flo repeats. "They fired ya?" parrots Jackie, who commiserates, loudly and vulgarly unprintable.

Her outburst finished, Jackie pauses to reflect. "This is wrong. Too subtle," she says, looking down dizsapprovingly at her dress, and turns on her heel to change.

Ruthless and bereft of talent as this fairytale Jackie is, she may not be great; but there's no doubt that she's an original, right down to her pink IBM Selectric, the insults as colourful as her endless costumes, and her own wacky brand of bygone dignity.

 Isn't She Great opens in the UK on March 31.

fields.headline: Magnificent obsession
fields.standfirst: Brian Pendreigh meets James Coburn, Oscar winner and knife-throwing star of his favourite movie
fields.trailText: Brian Pendreigh meets James Coburn, Oscar winner and knife-throwing star of his favourite movie
fields.body:
The first time was special, one summer's evening a long time ago in a chilly seaside resort on the east coast of Scotland. I'll never forget those moments of sheer physical pleasure. Seeing The Magnificent Seven was a seminal experience for my generation - like first sex, but more fondly remembered now. And for me more important.

I'm not sure if it was the first film I ever saw in the cinema, but it is the first I remember seeing. Its images, dialogue and music seared themselves in my memory - Yul Brynner dressed in black, Steve McQueen riding shotgun on the hearse, and James Coburn unwinding himself from his slumbers to accommodate the foolish gunman who thinks he can draw quicker than Coburn can throw his knife. He was wrong.

The Playhouse in North Berwick is long gone. But The Magnificent Seven is very much alive, 40 years after it first appeared. It changed the nature of the western, but its influence went way beyond the genre. Without it, there would have been no Bug's Life, which relocated the story in the insect world, and no Westworld, in which tourists were terrorised by Brynner as an out-of-control robot version of his Magnificent Seven character.

James Coburn a tall, slim, silver-haired figure in black jeans and blue jumper extends a hand twisted by the arthritis that took 10 years out of his career, and left him unable to walk for 18 months at the start of the 90s, before he managed to alleviate it with dietary sulphur. But his blue eyes sparkle as brightly as ever.

"Forty years," he says, in that deep, laconic tone that rumbled across a string of great films in the 60s and 70s, including The Great Escape, Charade and Pat Garrett and Billy the Kid. He went on making westerns even after the genre's death notice had been published and in the 90s, he was in Young Guns II and Maverick. He survived Hudson Hawk as well as debilitating illness and finally won an Oscar last year for his performance as Nick Nolte's embittered father in Paul Schrader's little-seen drama Affliction.

He can work again now, but admits he is very choosy. The Magnificent Seven is an awesome yardstick. "Is it really 40 years?," he wonders as we settle into a booth in Hollywood's Polo Lounge, where multimillion dollar film deals are a part of the routine. It is Coburn's local and a small army of attendants dance attendance.

Coburn is now 71. He got the part in The Magnificent Seven, after a chance meeting with Robert Vaughn. Coburn had been a huge fan of Seven Samurai, the 1954 Japanese film on which The Magnificent Seven was based. He was studying with Stella Adler and working in television in New York when he saw Akira Kurosawa's film. "I hadn't seen a film like that, ever," he says "To see all these characters... the big fight in the rain and the mud... He just blew me away." Coburn saw it 15 times.

He remembers reading in the trades that Brynner and Anthony Quinn had acquired the rights to remake it as a western in which a bunch of poor Mexican villagers hire seven gunmen from north of the border to protect them from bandits. He was under the impression that the pact had fallen apart and the project was abandoned, until he met Vaughn in the street one day.

"I said 'Hi, man, what are you doing?' And he said 'I'm going to do The Magnificent Seven.' And, like, my heart just fell." Shooting was only weeks away and Coburn feared all the parts would be cast. And they were, more or less. Coburn had recently made his film debut as a bounty hunter in Budd Boetticher's western Ride Lonesome and seemed a more natural candidate for the film than Vaughn, whom he had met on the drama course at LA City College.

Coburn was born in Nebraska, but his father moved the family to LA during the Depression in pursuit of work. Vaughn came from a very different background. "He had come up from Minnesota, very erudite, carrying everything in a briefcase. He looked like he was a golf pro... red pants, checkered shirt."

Vaughn was to play Lee, the southern gent who has lost his nerve. Brynner, McQueen, Charles Bronson, Horst Buchholz and Brad Dexter were also in place. The role of Britt, the most skilled knifeman and gunman of them all, was written as an older man and was destined for either Sterling Hayden, the rangy star of The Asphalt Jungle and Johnny Guitar, or John Ireland, whose western credits included Red River and Gunfight at the OK Corral.

Coburn says they were quibbling over money and he managed to set up a meeting with director John Sturges just in case. "This was on a Friday afternoon and it had to be cast by Saturday night because an actors' strike was going to take place then. Any film that wasn't cast by Saturday midnight, you couldn't do it... He said 'Well,' [Coburn adopts a high, screechy whine of a voice] 'we'll let you know by three o'clock.' And duly I get a call saying 'Well, run over and pick up your knives'... It was a real thrilling gig to get that, because it was a role that I always coveted."

It took him no time to learn the rudiments of knives. "I learned how to throw them one afternoon," he says, "and just practised from then on." A laugh issues from deep in some subterranean cavern. There were stories of friction from the Mexican location, with one newspaper reporting a feud between the icy Yul Brynner, who had recently won a best-actor Oscar for The King and I, and the volatile Steve McQueen.

McQueen had grown up on a farm and was at home with guns and horses, whereas Brynner was a Russian emigrant who felt more comfortable discussing philosophy in sophisticated nightclubs. Legend has it that for one scene Brynner chose to stand on a mound of earth, which McQueen tried to kick away during the take. Coburn plays down the animosity, but admits there were some ground rules, as far as Brynner was concerned. "He was the king. Heh-heh-heh... When he would march on to the set, nobody could come within 12 feet of him."

Coburn got on well with McQueen, though he acknowledges he had a fiercely competitive streak. "He was a giant egoist," says Coburn, who had worked with him on the TV western series Wanted: Dead or Alive and made several other films with him. "We were shooting Hell is For Heroes and he said 'Why don't they just make a film about one guy - me?' "

Coburn became a major Hollywood leading man in the role of Our Man Flint, which briefly rivalled James Bond in the 60s, and he became the very epitome of cool (Austin Powers watches the sequel, In Like Flint, in his sequel). Vaughn went on to become co-star of TV's The Man from UNCLE, a 60s sensation. And Bronson made the unlikely transition from heavy to superstar-hero thanks to Michael Winner and the Death Wish films.

No other western managed to assemble so many actors destined to become stars. "Well, eh," says Coburn, "what's his name, the guy that nobody can remember, didn't." He means stock heavy Brad Dexter. "He got the part because of Frank Sinatra. He saved Frank Sinatra's life out in Hawaii islands... swimming. A big wave took him out and Brad went out and got him... John Sturges had worked with Frank Sinatra, so Frank asked John to give Brad a part."

Coburn had reservations about the German actor, Horst Buchholz, as the young Mexican who fancies himself as a gunslinger. "John was enamoured though... He shot a lot of film of Horst. I thought he missed there, but that was the one place. I think everybody else was cast quite well." McQueen's manager, Hilly Elkins, subsequently became Coburn's manager too. "I met Hilly on The Magnificent Seven, because Steve always had problems. He creates problems, so he had Hilly come down and solve these problems. Of course they were just imaginary, heh-heh. That was one of Steve's great things: he would create a situation and call somebody else in to solve it... something to do with the script probably."

Coburn and McQueen shared many similar interests and became close friends. "We would always hang out together, smoke grass, get high and go up the mountains and drive fast cars."

One of the biggest problems on The Magnificent Seven was the Mexican official who insisted the Mexican peasants' outfits must always be pristine white. "They didn't want Mexicans to look like they had dirt," says Coburn, which explains why they look as if they have just stepped out of a Persil commercial.

It was a great script. In the Guardian's Cinefile column, Colin Bateman, author of Divorcing Jack, cited "We deal in lead" as his all-time favourite piece of movie dialogue. Mine is Brynner's closing speech: "The old man was right. Only the farmers won. We lost. We always lose." Then Brynner and McQueen ride off into the sunset. And Buchholz, the only other survivor, unfastens his gunbelt and joins the women in the cornfield. Is there a more powerful, scene in cinema?

Clint Eastwood gets the credit for pioneering the taciturn western hero, but Coburn has only four words in that unforgettable, four-minute introductory scene in The Magnificent Seven, where he is challenged to a duel, knife against gun, first for sport - "You lost", and then for real - "Call it".

The other guy did all the talking, but the audience is focused on Coburn. Sturges was a former film editor who knew exactly what he wanted and storyboarded every scene. Sturges also directed The Great Escape, which reunited Coburn, McQueen and Bronson, Ice Station Zebra, Gunfight at the OK Corral, Bad Day at Black Rock, and Last Train From Gun Hill, a neglected western masterpiece.

And yet, as Coburn puts it, "you've never heard of a John Sturges film". But why should Sturges's name remain so obscure when Ford, Leone and Peckinpah are lionised? "Peckinpah!" Coburn worked with him on a string of films and was his Pat Garrett opposite Kris Kristofferson's Billy the Kid. "Difficult is not the word... Sam created a lot of chaos. He liked chaos. He liked to work with it and keep everybody on edge, where John was just the opposite way round - he liked everything under control. "He didn't impose a directorial style on any picture. He imposed more of an editorial style, which is getting the shot, telling the story clearly. Sam liked ambiguity. He didn't like it on the nose. If it was on the nose, it was wrong. If it was right, it was wrong in his language. He liked to have the audience work."

And yet The Magnificent Seven was an ambiguous western. Far removed from High Noon, its heroes were not lawmen but professional gunfighters, ready to die, not for the forward march of civilisation, but for adventure, gold and, maybe, some tenuous notion of honour. "These guys sacrificed themselves to be who they were, because they didn't have anything else to do," says Coburn. "They were the samurai of the day - the era of the gunfighter was over."

When I grew up no one was looking for adventurers to ride across the Rio Grande any more. But for me, and for many of my generation, it's not over. In our imaginations, we still saddle up with Brynner, McQueen and Coburn.

Seeing The Magnificent Seven was a seminal experience for my generation - like first sex, but more fondly remembered now. And for me more important. I'm not sure if it was the first film I ever saw in the cinema, but it is the first I remember seeing. Its images, dialogue and music seared themselves in my memory - Yul Brynner dressed in black, Steve McQueen riding shotgun on the hearse, and James Coburn unwinding himself from his slumbers to accommodate the foolish gunman who thinks he can draw quicker than Coburn can throw his knife. He was wrong. The Playhouse in North Berwick is long gone. But The Magnificent Seven is very much alive, 40 years after it first appeared. It changed the nature of the western, but its influence went way beyond the genre. Without it, there would have been no Bug's Life, which relocated the story in the insect world, and no Westworld, in which tourists were terrorised by Brynner as an out-of-control robot version of his Magnificent Seven character. James Coburn a tall, slim, silver-haired figure in black jeans and blue jumper extends a hand twisted by the arthritis that took 10 years out of his career, and left him unable to walk for 18 months at the start of the 90s, before he managed to alleviate it with dietary sulphur. But his blue eyes sparkle as brightly as ever. "Forty years," he says, in that deep, laconic tone that rumbled across a string of great films in the 60s and 70s, including The Great Escape, Charade and Pat Garrett and Billy the Kid. He went on making westerns even after the genre's death notice had been published and in the 90s, he was in Young Guns II and Maverick. He survived Hudson Hawk as well as debilitating illness and finally won an Oscar last year for his performance as Nick Nolte's embittered father in Paul Schrader's little-seen drama Affliction. He can work again now, but admits he is very choosy. The Magnificent Seven is an awesome yardstick. "Is it really 40 years?," he wonders as we settle into a booth in Hollywood's Polo Lounge, where multimillion dollar film deals are a part of the routine. It is Coburn's local and a small army of attendants dance attendance. Coburn is now 71. He got the part in The Magnificent Seven, after a chance meeting with Robert Vaughn. Coburn had been a huge fan of Seven Samurai, the 1954 Japanese film on which The Magnificent Seven was based. He was studying with Stella Adler and working in television in New York when he saw Akira Kurosawa's film. "I hadn't seen a film like that, ever," he says "To see all these characters... the big fight in the rain and the mud... He just blew me away." Coburn saw it 15 times. He remembers reading in the trades that Brynner and Anthony Quinn had acquired the rights to remake it as a western in which a bunch of poor Mexican villagers hire seven gunmen from north of the border to protect them from bandits. He was under the impression that the pact had fallen apart and the project was abandoned, until he met Vaughn in the street one day. "I said 'Hi, man, what are you doing?' And he said 'I'm going to do The Magnificent Seven.' And, like, my heart just fell." Shooting was only weeks away and Coburn feared all the parts would be cast. And they were, more or less. Coburn had recently made his film debut as a bounty hunter in Budd Boetticher's western Ride Lonesome and seemed a more natural candidate for the film than Vaughn, whom he had met on the drama course at LA City College. Coburn was born in Nebraska, but his father moved the family to LA during the Depression in pursuit of work. Vaughn came from a very different background. "He had come up from Minnesota, very erudite, carrying everything in a briefcase. He looked like he was a golf pro... red pants, checkered shirt." Vaughn was to play Lee, the southern gent who has lost his nerve. Brynner, McQueen, Charles Bronson, Horst Buchholz and Brad Dexter were also in place. The role of Britt, the most skilled knifeman and gunman of them all, was written as an older man and was destined for either Sterling Hayden, the rangy star of The Asphalt Jungle and Johnny Guitar, or John Ireland, whose western credits included Red River and Gunfight at the OK Corral. Coburn says they were quibbling over money and he managed to set up a meeting with director John Sturges just in case. "This was on a Friday afternoon and it had to be cast by Saturday night because an actors' strike was going to take place then. Any film that wasn't cast by Saturday midnight, you couldn't do it... He said 'Well,' [Coburn adopts a high, screechy whine of a voice] 'we'll let you know by three o'clock.' And duly I get a call saying 'Well, run over and pick up your knives'... It was a real thrilling gig to get that, because it was a role that I always coveted." It took him no time to learn the rudiments of knives. "I learned how to throw them one afternoon," he says, "and just practised from then on." A laugh issues from deep in some subterranean cavern. There were stories of friction from the Mexican location, with one newspaper reporting a feud between the icy Yul Brynner, who had recently won a best-actor Oscar for The King and I, and the volatile Steve McQueen. McQueen had grown up on a farm and was at home with guns and horses, whereas Brynner was a Russian emigrant who felt more comfortable discussing philosophy in sophisticated nightclubs. Legend has it that for one scene Brynner chose to stand on a mound of earth, which McQueen tried to kick away during the take. Coburn plays down the animosity, but admits there were some ground rules, as far as Brynner was concerned. "He was the king. Heh-heh-heh... When he would march on to the set, nobody could come within 12 feet of him." Coburn got on well with McQueen, though he acknowledges he had a fiercely competitive streak. "He was a giant egoist," says Coburn, who had worked with him on the TV western series Wanted: Dead or Alive and made several other films with him. "We were shooting Hell is For Heroes and he said 'Why don't they just make a film about one guy - me?' " Coburn became a major Hollywood leading man in the role of Our Man Flint, which briefly rivalled James Bond in the 60s, and he became the very epitome of cool (Austin Powers watches the sequel, In Like Flint, in his sequel). Vaughn went on to become co-star of TV's The Man from UNCLE, a 60s sensation. And Bronson made the unlikely transition from heavy to superstar-hero thanks to Michael Winner and the Death Wish films. No other western managed to assemble so many actors destined to become stars. "Well, eh," says Coburn, "what's his name, the guy that nobody can remember, didn't." He means stock heavy Brad Dexter. "He got the part because of Frank Sinatra. He saved Frank Sinatra's life out in Hawaii islands... swimming. A big wave took him out and Brad went out and got him... John Sturges had worked with Frank Sinatra, so Frank asked John to give Brad a part." Coburn had reservations about the German actor, Horst Buchholz, as the young Mexican who fancies himself as a gunslinger. "John was enamoured though... He shot a lot of film of Horst. I thought he missed there, but that was the one place. I think everybody else was cast quite well." McQueen's manager, Hilly Elkins, subsequently became Coburn's manager too. "I met Hilly on The Magnificent Seven, because Steve always had problems. He creates problems, so he had Hilly come down and solve these problems. Of course they were just imaginary, heh-heh. That was one of Steve's great things: he would create a situation and call somebody else in to solve it... something to do with the script probably." Coburn and McQueen shared many similar interests and became close friends. "We would always hang out together, smoke grass, get high and go up the mountains and drive fast cars." One of the biggest problems on The Magnificent Seven was the Mexican official who insisted the Mexican peasants' outfits must always be pristine white. Mine is Brynner's closing speech: "The old man was right. Only the farmers won. We lost. We always lose." Then Brynner and McQueen ride off into the sunset. And Buchholz, the only other survivor, unfastens his gunbelt and joins the women in the cornfield. Is there a more powerful, scene in cinema? Clint Eastwood gets the credit for pioneering the taciturn western hero, but Coburn has only four words in that unforgettable, four-minute introductory scene in The Magnificent Seven, where he is challenged to a duel, knife against gun, first for sport - "You lost", and then for real - "Call it". The other guy did all the talking, but the audience is focused on Coburn. Sturges was a former film editor who knew exactly what he wanted and storyboarded every scene. Sturges also directed The Great Escape, which reunited Coburn, McQueen and Bronson, Ice Station Zebra, Gunfight at the OK Corral, Bad Day at Black Rock, and Last Train From Gun Hill, a neglected western masterpiece. And yet, as Coburn puts it, "you've never heard of a John Sturges film". But why should Sturges's name remain so obscure when Ford, Leone and Peckinpah are lionised? "Peckinpah!" Coburn worked with him on a string of films and was his Pat Garrett opposite Kris Kristofferson's Billy the Kid. "Difficult is not the word... Sam created a lot of chaos. He liked chaos. He liked to work with it and keep everybody on edge, where John was just the opposite way round - he liked everything under control. "He didn't impose a directorial style on any picture. He imposed more of an editorial style, which is getting the shot, telling the story clearly. Sam liked ambiguity. He didn't like it on the nose. If it was on the nose, it was wrong. If it was right, it was wrong in his language. He liked to have the audience work." And yet The Magnificent Seven was an ambiguous western. Far removed from High Noon, its heroes were not lawmen but professional gunfighters, ready to die, not for the forward march of civilisation, but for adventure, gold and, maybe, some tenuous notion of honour. "These guys sacrificed themselves to be who they were, because they didn't have anything else to do," says Coburn. "They were the samurai of the day - the era of the gunfighter was over." When I grew up no one was looking for adventurers to ride across the Rio Grande any more. But for me, and for many of my generation, it's not over. fields.headline: Going for a song
fields.standfirst: Mike Leigh may be breaking new ground with his period piece Topsy-Turvy, but, he tells Danny Leigh, there are a few familiar smacks in the gob too
fields.trailText: Mike Leigh may be breaking new ground with his period piece Topsy-Turvy, but, he tells Danny Leigh, there are a few familiar smacks in the gob too
fields.body:
Mike Leigh, so the legend goes, doesn't suffer fools. Forget about gladly, he just doesn't suffer them. Which is why, with hindsight, it was stupid to ask after his leg when he limped in on a crutch. Maybe he'd have a funny, quotable answer - something about a slapstick on-set mishap, something to break the ice.

"It's not my leg," comes the reply. "It's my hip. I've got chronic arthritis in my hip."

The pause which follows is brief: a second, maybe two. It seems far longer.

Still, despite his reputation for brusqueness and my uncanny way with a faux pas, he chooses not to pass further comment, happily scattering files around his Greek Street office, grabbing a cardboard box to use as an impromptu coffee table. He's already discussing his latest feature, Topsy-Turvy - "I've always eschewed films about actors, but this time I thought OK, let's just bite the bullet" - as he balances his crutch against a chair and takes a seat, bright-eyed and apparently unabashed by either physical discomfort or journalistic gracelessness. He looks on good form.

It's probably just as well. After all, Topsy-Turvy - ostensibly a portrait of Gilbert and Sullivan struggling through the gestation of The Mikado - isn't short on talking points; not least what this most doggedly egalitarian of directors is doing in bed with the late 19th century kings of light opera. No matter how convincingly he details his long-standing enthusiasm for his subjects, incongruity still hovers over the idea of Leigh, champion of the ordinary ever since 1971's aptly-titled Bleak Moments, mixing it with Three Little Maids.

"Well," he explains, "that in itself is obviously part of the attraction - the naughty attraction - of doing it. It's precisely that particular piece of subversion. And, you know, the whole thing, taking this chocolate box subject matter and treating it perfectly seriously, is full of subversions. So, to tell you the truth, I do think of it as quite a radical film."

And, when you think of what a Mike Leigh film is supposed to be, all anoraks and awkward silences, he's right. So he must be aware that at least some of his audience - what he calls "the Naked/Meantime punters" after the two most emotionally visceral films of his career - will already be recoiling at the mere thought of Jim Broadbent's WS Gilbert waxing his handlebar moustache. "Of course," he admits, "a core constituency of punters are going to have something to deal with. But the bottom line is, fine, they're going to be able to deal with it. Or they won't. But, actually, if they approach it in the right spirit, they will."

He shrugs. "I mean, people always have a bee in their bonnet about something. There was a lot of rubbish talked about misogyny in Naked, and I dare say that put some people off but, you know, I've been around long enough to weather these storms..."

Ah yes, the storms. He'll return to them later. For now, we'll stick with Topsy-Turvy, a film that, despite its rigorous attention to period detail, none the less raises two sly fingers to the dread conventions of costume drama. For a start, there's none of the creepy, thinly-veiled ardour for Victoriana which oozes through the works of, say, Merchant-Ivory. ("One of the main reasons for doing a period film," he confirms, "was doing one which wasn't like a period film.") Moreover, in both cast (including such Leigh regulars as Broadbent, Timothy Spall and his former wife Alison Steadman), and gently mordant humour, this is - once you get past the frock coats - still an entirely Mike Leigh movie.

"It is a very idiosyncratic film," he says, staring into the middle distance, "full of me sort of things, jokes and juxtapositions and all of that. And one of the things I tried to do - as I always do - is put in the stuff you normally never see. I mean, I wasn't ever concerned with trying to bring film reality to the world of the opera. The issue was to take an objective look at this industrial process. And, in the context of a period film, I wanted to show what isn't generally shown - someone bellowing down the telephone, someone having their teeth out and so on. Because, ultimately, it's a film about people, and relationships and, you know..." - Leigh's famously hangdog expression cracks into a smile - "all the usual things which skulk around in my films. The real things. The moments in between."

The moments in between; it's as apt a summary of what makes Leigh's films special as you're ever likely to hear. Because for much of his career Leigh told the stories no one else would. His devotion to the minutiae of the seemingly mundane, his grasp of life at the business end of the class divide - these things marked him out.

Which made the acclaim that greeted his 1996 opus, Secrets and Lies, all the more gratifying. The only problem was that, to many commentators, the combination of the film's profound warmth and the partial approbation of Hollywood (five Academy nominations, although sadly no gongs) gave Leigh's personal narrative too happy an ending. A lot of them would probably have preferred to see him bow out with his plaudits and his Palme d'Or then and there. Instead he made Career Girls, a slightly mannered comedy concerning two young women reviewing their student days.

The critical reaction to Career Girls was tepid, occasionally venomous. Now, with Topsy-Turvy, he must see the danger that when Gilbert reacts in fury to the sniffy notices awarded his and Sullivan's abortive Princess Ida, audiences are simply going to see Mike Leigh up onscreen. "In all honesty," he counters, "that thought never entered my head until you just said it."

There's another pregnant pause; eventually his features soften. "Look, quite rightly you've got a tendency to ask if there's a danger in these things. And the answer, of course, is yes - but there's a danger in every bloody thing. Look at Naked, it's an absolute minefield. I mean, if I get talked about in this gobshite sort of way, that's the way it crumbles. But, yes, if people look back on what I've done in the future, Career Girls runs a serious risk of being squashed." He's suddenly animated, endearingly genuine. "How do you get along with it?"

I tell him I liked it a lot more when I watched it a second time, without the long shadow of its predecessor. "Right. Yeah. I mean, that's the thing, people tell me they liked it, and it really said something to them, and it was something they really related to. There was just this feeling I was due for a bollocking. It was the same with Naked."

This is the third time he's mentioned his dense mid-90s sketch of a loveless, broken London which brought equal parts eulogy and vitriol down on its director, the latter inspired - however erroneously - by the film's supposed hostility to women. You wonder if that still rankles. "Well, when people call me a misogynist," he replies, "I either think they're extremely naive - and therefore not very bright - or I don't trust where they're coming from. To walk away from Naked and only have that to say... I mean, even if one were to take on those kind of criticisms, which I did endlessly at one stage, there's a deliberate spectrum of women dealing with their lives in quite different ways..." He trails off, exasperated. "Maybe we should move on."

So we do. But there's no getting round the fact that Topsy-Turvy finds Leigh in a strange position: on the one hand removing the dents in his reputation left by Career Girls, on the other trying to keep himself interested. He's also got what many people see as an obligation to reflect the spirit of the times (as reflected in the pathological social climbing of his 1977 classic Abigail's Party, or the grim, bloodied defiance of Naked); having trekked back to the 1880s for his latest thematic, has he run out of things to say about the here and now?

"Just for my own sanity," he responds, "it's important not to parody myself. And I'm very aware what I do is fraught with the potential for self-parody. Anyway, the question is, does Topsy-Turvy deliver an unproblematic journey through the jolly old niceties of late Victorian comic opera, or do you get a few smacks in the gob along the way? And I think the answer is clear. I mean, the thing is to make films about ordinary people who are in the end very extraordinary, whereas with this... well, I used to get a huge buzz when the Transport Museum was still in Clapham, because there in Queen Victoria's garage was her personal toilet. And I enjoyed that immensely, standing next to where Queen Victoria used to crap. And that philosophy of looking at apparently remarkable people at their most deeply ordinary has always appealed to me."

Sure enough, Topsy-Turvy's novelty lies less in its setting than its director's inversion of his trademark MO, taking his glittering subjects and rendering them as bad-tempered, selfish and occasionally inspiring as the rest of us; just as - in reverse - the monstrous Beverly in Abigail's Party or the disastrously inventive chef Aubrey in Life is Sweet crossed the line from mere screen characters to modern British icons.

It's part of the process which has seen Leigh become a credible name to drop among the young and gifted (and you can see his influence now in everything from Todd Solondz's dyspeptic Happiness to the small-screen antics of The Royle Family). Yet while everyone craves respect, no one wants to become an institution, gladhanded into history. How does he feel about his status as a walking film school tutorial?

"Nothing bad," is his response. "But on the other hand, it doesn't make me feel in any way disposed to pack up and go home - ie, retire. It's fine, it's good, it's very nice, but it doesn't solve my problems. And my current problem is my next film. I mean, I have worries, not least that I've got to get a new hip, and it's actually terribly important that I get on with things, because if I can't bloody walk then I can't make films. These are the things which preoccupy me - you don't spend your time thinking about legacies. You've got a job to do."

He gazes out of the third-floor window. "The only thing I can compare it to is that I sit on the tube every day between Leicester Square and Wood Green, and it remains a surprise if, as sometimes happens, someone comes up and tells me how much they like my films. Because you don't sit there thinking, 'I am Mike Leigh, I am Mike Leigh, look at me, aren't I fantastic, I'm famous and look, I'm sitting here on the tube with you oiks.' You sit there thinking 'Oh, it's getting a bit late, what am I going to do when I get home, shall I go out for a drink, what shall I have for my dinner, shall I have the same as I did last night?'."

And so life goes on, full as ever with its Mike Leigh moments; the moments in between.

 Topsy-Turvy opens on February 18.

You sit there thinking 'Oh, it's getting a bit late, what am I going to do when I get home, shall I go out for a drink, what shall I have for my dinner, shall I have the same as I did last night?'." And so life goes on, full as ever with its Mike Leigh moments; the moments in between.  Topsy-Turvy opens on February 18.

fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: A Simple Plan | Place Vendªme | The Lost Son
fields.trailText: A Simple Plan | Place Vendªme | The Lost Son
fields.body:
A Simple Plan
Rental
Universal Pictures Cert 15
****

Nature gets the plot of A Simple Plan going. A fox, fresh from a hen coop, causes a car crash and crows, looking wonderfully malevolent in the Minnesota snow, lead our trio of characters towards a small plane buried in a drift (there's a not-while-you're-eating scene as the crows get to work on the dead pilot). The plane also contains $4.4m, and after that human nature takes over, as flawed and inevitable as a James Cain plot: large amounts of money leading to vast amounts of bad behaviour.

If it didn't say on the box that the director is Sam Raimi, you'd never guess. The master of hyperactive camera and inventive gore just turned 40 and he's in reflective mood here in a moody piece which, unusually, combines irresistible narrative drive with a subtle character piece.

The three men in the car are Bill Paxton, a slightly superior store owner, and the only one with a job; Billy Bob Thornton, unrecognisable with woolly hat and taped-up glasses as his brother; and Brent Briscoe as the aggressive town drunk who is Thornton's best friend. None of the three is a stereotype and the messy way their lives and personalities rub up against each other is the real centre of a very satisfying film, tightly edited with a tense, spare score from Danny Elfman that's his best yet and leading up to a terrific pay-off for us too.

From the moment Paxton says pompously: "You work for the American dream, you don't steal it," to his needy, greedy cohorts, little goes according to their plan or our expectations. In an excellent cast, Thornton is particularly fine as a complex character, intellectually challenged but emotionally grounded. Inevitably compared to Shallow Grave for its plot and Raimi's old muckers the Coens' Fargo for desperate deeds in the cold, this still comes over as startlingly fresh as a snowball in the gob.

Place Vendôme
Retail £15.99
Artificial Eye Cert 15
***

A subtly anxious movie which won Catherine Deneuve a best actress award in Venice. She plays a respectable jewel dealer's wife whose husband suddenly commits suicide, leaving her to try to reconstruct her life with the help of some stolen diamonds. She's also trying to conquer a drink problem, but being Deneuve, the tippling is done with a degree of elegance.

This is not boozing as Oliver Reed would have recognised it: it's skilful enough and unobtrusively directed by former actress Nicole Garcia. But it's strangely uninvolving as its bourgeois felons scheme towards an elaborate denouement. I was distracted enough to notice that while co-star Emmanuelle Seigner (32) looks visibly older than in Frantic and Bitter Moon, Deneuve (56) doesn't look much different from her Polanski role, Repulsion in 1965.

The Lost Son Rental and DVD £19.99
Metrodome Cert 18
***

Another French lead actor, Daniel Auteuil, but this is set in England. Auteuil is the ex-cop hired by a former colleague now married to Nastassja Kinski, to find her brother. This is a Chandleresque tale of a grubby gumshoe hired by a super-rich family and finding himself knee-deep in a morally desolate terrain, in this case child prostitution.

Auteuil is barely ever offscreen and Chris Menges's film depends greatly on his doggedness and likeability in a grim tale. It's obviously sincere in its anger against exploitation of childhood innocence. The subject gets the careful treatment it needs before turning into a more orthodox thriller as Auteuil's past is revealed and he turns into a Gallic avenging angel. Menges has been a consistently fine cinematographer from Kes to The Boxer, but this is not a patch on his subtle directorial masterwork, A World Apart. Only a Frenchman could understand why it ends with M Cantona gibbering about seagulls and trawlers.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: The British Board of Film Classification is currently asking the nation whether we want age classifications relaxed for films: sex and violence are, as ever, key areas. Since 1998, says the BBFC, it has become more open. Its website (www.bbfc.co.uk) shows the guidelines governing how it rates films; draft guidelines up for discussion now; and a questionnaire where the board wants everyone to give views on what the new rules should be.
fields.body:
The British Board of Film Classification is currently asking the nation whether we want age classifications relaxed for films: sex and violence are, as ever, key areas. Since 1998, says the BBFC, it has become more open. Its website (www.bbfc.co.uk) shows the guidelines governing how it rates films; draft guidelines up for discussion now; and a questionnaire where the board wants everyone to give views on what the new rules should be.

Enter our February 1 coverage of The End of the Affair affair: producer Stephen Woolley and colleagues believe their film should have been classified 15, not 18. An opinion piece on page 7, G2 (Women), made it appear that the BBFC director, Robin Duval, had written to Mr Woolley saying a key reason for the 18 certificate was that "Ralph's [Fiennes] bottom was pumping too many times" in sex scenes. In fact, this was the producer's line. Beside our news story on the controversy, page 14, a panel showed draft guidelines, instead of those that determine BBFC decisions now.

A leader on page 19, January 31, was corrected in later editions to show that April's World Forum on Education for All is to be held in Dakar, Senegal, rather than Dacca in Bangladesh. If it were in the latter, we should be spelling it Dhaka, anyhow.

In a precis of a Kenneth Baker piece, page 6, The Editor, January 7, Britain's cartoonists of yore were declared the clear winners in their medium's long Anglo-French war of mutual mockery. "Hoggart," said the precis, portrayed cross-Channel dwellers as "pest-ridden, eating thin gruel and roasting frogs" in contrast to plump beef-fed John Bull. Hogarth, of course, was the "cartoonist" in question. (Simon Hoggart, who uses words to produce our political sketches today, is reserving his position on the French but says: "Hogarth's father's name was originally Hoggart. He changed it because it sounded so yokelish.")

Contrary to what was implied in Pass notes, G2, January 24, proceeds from sales of the "Little Red" rag doll (aka, The Fergie) are due to go entirely to the Duchess of York's charities for children.

Readers have been directing a few pejoratives at us since an article on the former Labour junior defence minister Peter Kilfoyle, page 11, February 2, misspelled the word as "perjorative" - in text and in a headline.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: The FTSE 100 ended a volatile session in the black yesterday, aided by bid talk surrounding a trio of second-tier telecoms companies.
fields.body:
The FTSE 100 ended a volatile session in the black yesterday, aided by bid talk surrounding a trio of second-tier telecoms companies.

On a day dominated by record trade in mobile telecoms operator Vodafone, the benchmark index closed 21.5 points higher at 6,324.3.

Bid hopes boosted Colt Telecom, Energis and Telewest Communications by as much as 16%, together giving a 28 point lift to the index.

By contrast, Vodafone's progress towards a deal to swallow Germany's Mannesmann saw heavy trade in its stock, taking it to 371p at the close, down 14p - equivalent to knocking 22 points off the FTSE 100.

The hugely liquid share saw its busiest day ever, with almost one billion changing hands from a total 2.5bn shares traded.

Another big faller was Amoco which dropped 20p to lop a further 19 points off the Footsie as investors bailed out following the hostile US ruling on its plans to buy Atlantic Richfield. Losses in those two heavyweights were enough to leave London's leaders trailing continental European markets.

But a strong start in technology stocks on New York's Nasdaq market powered London's techMARK index 3% higher to a record close of 4,238.8.

Mid cap stocks on the FTSE 250 index posted a more modest performance, rising 46 points to 6,166.

Shipping group P&O shot up nearly 16% after it announced the demerger of its cruises division to a separate group.

Another gainer was news and information company Reuters Group, 8% higher on news of a deal with telecoms group Equant to merge certain communications assets into a new joint company offering financial firms the world's biggest secure internet-standard network.

There was a burst in Carlton Communications, with the price jumping 88p to 686p as the market awaited news on whether its planned merger with United News & Media is to be referred to the competition commission. Some in the market believe that if it is, a foreign predator will step in with a counter-bid.

Among the tech stocks, oneview.net jumped from 650p to 720p and Affinity Internet surged 575p to £48.00. The two companies have completed a strategic alliance announced in November, aimed at providing small and medium size businesses with improved access to the net.

Shares in Affinity have jumped from a post-flotation 2p, while oneview.net is up a less dramatic sevenfold.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Britannic to cut 350 jobs
Britannic, the insurance group, is to cut 350 jobs after contracting out its home insurance business to Cornhill Direct and centralising its administration to head office. Most of the job losses are expected to occur in the branches, as a result of the focus on the Wythall head office, and will involve a one-off restructuring charge of £3.3m. The move by Britannic, which has considered a merger with rival United Assurance, is expect to result in full-year savings of £5.3m. FSA consults on new budge
fields.body:
Britannic to cut 350 jobs
Britannic, the insurance group, is to cut 350 jobs after contracting out its home insurance business to Cornhill Direct and centralising its administration to head office. Most of the job losses are expected to occur in the branches, as a result of the focus on the Wythall head office, and will involve a one-off restructuring charge of £3.3m. The move by Britannic, which has considered a merger with rival United Assurance, is expect to result in full-year savings of £5.3m. FSA consults on new budge

Financial services budget up
The financial services authority will have a £162.5m budget for this financial year, up 2%, although this does not include any provision for the additional responsibilities it will take on this year.

The FSA will consult on its new fees - £68m of the current budget is paid by banks and other financial firms - later in the year to cover the cost of regulating Lloyd's of London, credit unions, mortgages and professional firms such as accountants.

"This means that in future years there will be one or more step changes in the control total budget, with the new total spread over a wider constituency of fee payers," Howard Davies, FSA chairman said.

EU directive hits car makers
The European parliament yesterday adopted a directive which proposes manufacturers bear "the whole or a significant proportion" of costs of recycling used cars.

The British motor industry immediately said it was "very disappointed" with the directive. The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) said the result of the parliament's decision meant that "750,000 employees working in the UK motor industry will have to share the burden of the £300m annual bill which this directive will impose".

Chief executive Christopher MacGowan said: "We believe that this decision will potentially cripple an industry already facing the challenge of an overvalued pound and tough competition in the global economy."

EU officials countered that the recycling scheme will encourage car makers to produce more environment-friendly vehicles.

The commission said the directive will not hinder competition among European car manufacturers, and estimated the cost of recycling a used car at 1% of the cost of a new car.

The directive plans for a recycling rate of 85% by 2015. By 2006, car manufacturers will have to foot the whole bill for recycling.

BSkyB soccer stake approved
The office of fair trading said that British Sky Broadcasting Group's acquisition of a 9.08% stake in Leeds United cannot be considered a merger and cannot be referred to the competition commission.

The decision follows an agreement by the parties to revoke the ability of BSkyB to appoint a director to the Leeds' board.

The OFT has been looking at several acquisitions by broadcasters of shares in premier league clubs. A similar decision was reached after Granada's acquisition of a 9.9% stake in Liverpool FC.

The fair trading act 1973 requires that to be a merger a company should acquire, or at least have the ability "materially to influence" the policy of another.

fields.headline: Amvescap surges quietly onward
fields.standfirst: Market forces
fields.trailText: Amvescap yesterday proved the adage that size does matter. As Britain's largest listed fund manager, the group continued its dream performance yesterday with the announcement of a sparkling 38% surge in 1999 pre-tax profit to £319.8m.
fields.body:
Amvescap yesterday proved the adage that size does matter. As Britain's largest listed fund manager, the group continued its dream performance yesterday with the announcement of a sparkling 38% surge in 1999 pre-tax profit to £319.8m.

Analysts were already scratching to upgrade their 2000 forecasts for the group, which revealed that full-year revenues had jumped from £802.2m to £1.1bn.

Amvescap's chief executive, Charles Brady, would certainly not put it all down to size, however.

He listed an impressive investment strategy by the staff of the fund manager and private investors' insatiable appetite for piling into the stock market, particularly following the start of the dot.com boom.

These factors drove the large inflow of funds into Amvescap which saw its cash under management increase by £82bn to a whopping £357.4bn in the year.

Mr Brady said the company's Aim and Invesco subsidiaries were producing solid results, with investments in infrastructure stocks helping boost returns.

In 1998 Amvescap merged Invesco with GT Global, a fund management operation owned by the royal family of Liechtenstein, at a cost of £48.6m.

Robert Mumby, analyst at ABN Amro, said that the news was exceptionally good but had attracted little interest from the City.

Amvescap's shares rose a measly 5p to 677p yesterday. The stock has soared from below 450p in the past year. "The markets are rather preoccupied by other things," Mr Mumby said. "It's quite surprising really because it's a very strong set of results."

He said the company's star should shine even brighter in the coming year. "It's a very good story because it's a financial stock that's geared into the technology boom through its funds. I think the share will do well."

Amvescap's final-quarter profits did suffer a hiccup in with the additional £50m related to the millennium bug and staff bonuses being allocated because of the company's exceptional returns.

Shareholders were rewarded with a 9p final dividend.

fields.headline: Focus: Capital Invest
fields.trailText: When the share price of your company triples on its first day of trading it is usually a cause for celebration. But New Capital Invest's Aim debut yesterday was a bit of an embarrassment.
fields.body:
When the share price of your company triples on its first day of trading it is usually a cause for celebration. But New Capital Invest's Aim debut yesterday was a bit of an embarrassment.

The cash shell had spent the past few weeks quietly placing 8m new shares at 25p each with private clients and institutions. Its aim was to secure a low-profile listing from which to acquire a significant stake in a single company working in new media and e-commerce.

The management didn't want a JellyWorks or a Knutsford, both of which soared away on hopes of a big bid or investment. But amid the euphoria surrounding dot.coms and retail investors' appetite for small stocks there is no such thing as a quiet arrival. By the close of trading the shares had risen almost fourfold to 92.5p.

New Capital's cover was blown as the market focused its attention on two individuals behind the company. The first is its chairman, Nigel Whittaker, a retail guru and one of the original four man management team at Kingfisher and later chairman of B&Q.

The second is non-executive director Oded Zucker, vice-president of investments for Prudential-Bache, a Luxembourg fund that handles high net worth clients. He is understood to have extensive contacts in Israel's burgeoning hi-tech industry.

Sources suggest New Capital has a tentative list of three or four companies in the region and would like to take a stake of 20%-50% in one of them. The value of the firm could be between £50m and £300m and the investment would be funded through the issue of new shares to institutions.

However, a third individual appears to have gone unnoticed. Command Fund Limited, a Geneva-based, Grand Cayman incorporated company that owns 40% of New Capital, is understood to be the vehicle for Stephen Tucker, a low-profile multi-millionaire. He and associates want to use New Capital to expand a portfolio of new-media investments.

This is one to watch.

fields.headline: Baan confirms $289m loss
fields.trailText: Shares in Baan, Europe's second-largest software group, rose almost 5% yesterday after it confirmed warnings that it had slumped deep into the red last year.
fields.body:
Shares in Baan, Europe's second-largest software group, rose almost 5% yesterday after it confirmed warnings that it had slumped deep into the red last year.

"Most of the pain is priced in and [the shares] have reached bottom," according to a trader at a Dutch bank.

Full-year losses amounted to $289m (£180m), slightly down on the previous year's loss of $315m. The bulk of the damage came in the final quarter when the group took a $168m charge for restructuring, asset write-downs, and increases in reserves and allowances.

The group had warned early last month of heavy restructuring costs.

Revenues for the final three months of the year were up 9% to $143m, while licence income almost doubled to $49m.

Baan, which has headquarters in Holland and the United States, is still looking for a new chief executive to replace Mary Coleman who left at the beginning of the year.

Interim chief executive Pierre Everaert is reported to have held talks with a number of potential candidates but Baan chief marketing officer Katrina Roche said: "We are really concerned with not rushing forward just to tick a box. We want to make sure we get the right person."

According to Mr Everaert the restructuring programme will cut the current cost structure by up to $25m a quarter "to help provide us with the financial resources to maintain our investments in research and development, and customer support capabilities".

Baan has retained investment bank Lazard Freres to help it look at raising additional finance, however, the company said that it had no immediate need for extra money.

"We have close to $200m in cash and marketable securities and, when you look at the fact that we only burned $9m in cash in the fourth quarter, our cash balance is adequate right now," Ms Roche said.

Analysts took the view that the figures were broadly in line with market expectations. "There were no major surprises. The restructuring charge was lower than they originally announced but that's not so important ... You can't figure out from these figures what the next few quarters will bring," said Delta Lloyd Bank analyst Marco Schram.

fields.headline: Factory seals games revolution
fields.trailText: A group of computer programmers in south London are putting the finishing touches to new software that could revolutionise the way computer games are developed.
fields.body:
A group of computer programmers in south London are putting the finishing touches to new software that could revolutionise the way computer games are developed.

David Bailey, finance director of Black Cactus Games, and his colleagues are trying to apply commercial discipline to the chaotic and unpredictable process of games creation. Set up by games developers formerly at Eidos, Black Cactus is aiming to cut costs and the development time needed to bring new games to market.

If successful it will be able to produce games much more reliably than in the past and hold on to a much larger proportion of royalties by cutting its dependence on finance from the publishers who market and distribute games.

Jamie Thomson, Black Cactus's managing director, says: "In the old days publishers gave developers a pot of money and the designers disappeared into a room for up to four years, at the end of which there may have been a useable game. We are applying much more focus to that process."

The company is close to completing what Thomson calls an"object-orientated soft architecture" made up of a set of development tools, some software utilities and 3D engine technology. Taken together these form a Windows interface which the games designer can use to develop games quickly and with little need of a programmer.

In the past games were developed by programmers working alongside designers. But developing the software for each game was an unpredictable process.

Now the core software is the same for each game, leaving programmers free to develop the fastest core software they can. The new software is then released to the games designers only as it becomes ready.

Thomson says: "We have replaced the code monkeys of old with a software factory. It is like a car factory. We have invested in the factory processes, procedures and tools to build a game."

So far Black Cactus is concentrating on real-time strategy games, but is confident of applying common technology to the creation of other genres.

The new technology will enable Black Cactus to deploy smaller teams on games development - typically about four artists on each game - responsible for creating the main elements of warriors, siege engines, castles, monsters, and two designers responsible for building the game.

A programmer will also be on hand for each team to tweak software to give each game individuality, and as the firm can develop games quickly, it should be able to keep up with fashion changes.

Ian Turnbull, the commercial and marketing director and former director of development at Eidos, says Black Cactus's approach means games can also be adapted quickly to new circumstances. This has made the technology of great interest to the defence industry, which may use it to simulate battlefield scenarios.

Thomson adds that the technology will also liberate Black Cactus from dependency on publishing advances. Instead of asking a publisher to put up the risk capital, Black Cactus is talking to venture capital funds and banks about raising its own risk capital.

This in turn will allow it to negotiate higher royalties from publishers than the industry norm - royalties can be as low as 10% - and spin off other multimedia products from the core game.

The company is also keen to develop its content for wireless devices and interactive television, and is in talks with the interactive services company Intelfax, which carries out work for the ITV network.

Further ahead, Bailey wants the company to develop games for play on the internet. Ask him about flotation, and he says the board is concentrating on the first round of financing and the games it has in the pipeline but that an offering is a long-term ambition.

fields.trailText: • Debut Shares in Oxygen, the internet incubator fund set up by Knutsford's Michael Edelson and advised by Elisabeth Murdoch, are expected to soar when dealings in the company start this morning. Advisers to the company say demand from retail investors for stock in the tightly held company ahead of its admission to Aim has been "unbelievable". Oxygen is a vehicle for Mr Edelson's 25-year-old daughter Emma. • Payback Software firm Alphameric said it has returned to paying a dividend, due to "unprecedented" levels of secured orders at the end of last year and the unprecedented funds available to support future growth. fields.headline: 3i makes £105m dot.com buy
fields.trailText: Venture capital company 3i continued to show its newfound affection for hi-tech companies yesterday by buying a German dot.com investment firm for 333m German marks (£105m).
fields.body:
Venture capital company 3i continued to show its newfound affection for hi-tech companies yesterday by buying a German dot.com investment firm for 333m German marks (£105m).

Brian Larcombe, chief executive of 3i, said the acquisition of Technologieholding represented a quantum leap in the group's ability to invest in Germany, where it already has five offices.

The move takes 3i towards its goal of making 30% of its new investments in hi-tech firms, which has caused controversy among some of its more traditional manufacturing targets which fear the company might withdraw investment from them.

However, 3i had also faced criticism for being too slow to embrace the technological age - 10% of its portfolio was in technology three years ago - which it responded to in September when it set up a new operation in Silicon valley.

Mr Larcombe said 3i and Technologieholding had started talks 15 months ago. The German company, set up in 1987, had an "excellent" in vestment record with 10 of its companies having obtained stock market listings.

Gert Kohler, one of the founders of the German company, has signed a three-year employment contract and will take responsibility for the whole of 3i's investments in early-stage technology firms.

Mr Larcombe said 3i might be interested in similar acquisitions in the future.

Under the terms of the arrangement, Technologieholding will reinvest some DM166.5m of the price paid by 3i and retain the investment for two years.

fields.headline: ICI on rebound after revamp
fields.trailText: ICI's arduous three-year restructuring programme has borne fruit for the speciality chemicals group with it almost halving its net debt to £2.3bn and reporting a 17% leap in annual pre-tax profit, before exceptionals and goodwill, to £376m.
fields.body:
ICI's arduous three-year restructuring programme has borne fruit for the speciality chemicals group with it almost halving its net debt to £2.3bn and reporting a 17% leap in annual pre-tax profit, before exceptionals and goodwill, to £376m.

The 1999 profit was at the top end of analyst forecasts, prompting immediate earnings upgrades, and saw ICI's share price rise 10% to 539p.

Charles Miller Smith, chairman of ICI, predicted more good news in 2000 for the former industrial conglomerate. "The current positive economic outlook should enable ICI to deliver further sustained profit growth during the coming year," he said.

ICI's profit and share price performance have suffered through the restructuring with the stock still hovering near 12-month lows.

"The record performance in our core businesses validates our strategic change," Mr Miller Smith said. "Excellent progress was made in reshaping the portfolio and restoring balance sheet strength."

The former bell-wether of the UK industrial sector slimmed further in 1999 with the sale of four of its operations, the largest of which was a $2.8bn sale of most of its industrial chemicals to US group Huntsman Corporation.

Those proceeds helped to reduce debt from £4.2bn to £2.3bn.

ICI is expected to begin to look at bolt-on acquisitions in speciality chemicals now its debt has reached a level more acceptable to the market.

It's turnover during the year increased 2.6% to £5.6bn, with only some sales affected by millennium bug worries in the last quarter.

Trading in core businesses of speciality products and paints jumped 7.8% to £582m. Industrial chemicals remained loss-making.

The group held its final dividend at 32p.

fields.headline: Reuters in deal with Equant
fields.trailText: Reuters yesterday joined forces with US-based Equant, a data network group, to create a $6bn (£3.7bn) joint venture company that would deliver a trading and e-commerce platform tailored to the needs of financial services companies.
fields.body:
Reuters yesterday joined forces with US-based Equant, a data network group, to create a $6bn (£3.7bn) joint venture company that would deliver a trading and e-commerce platform tailored to the needs of financial services companies.

The global platform would provide a secure niche network for financial groups to undertake mainly e-commerce, equity transactions and other communication services, estimated to be worth £13bn.

Reuters said it would own 51% of the joint venture company which is not yet named but will be operating by June and headquartered in New York.

The British information group will transfer its Reuters Connect Services Division into the joint venture as well as $130m of its telecommunication network assets and 400 staff, in return for $25m.

Equant will contribute 100 staff, $230m in cash and a further $150m of other services and contracted revenue.

The announcement yesterday precedes a wider strategy statement that will be made by Reuters next Tuesday on the internet, which may see it floating off some of its divisions such as Instinet, the online broker.

David Ure, an executive director of Reuters, said: "This deal is about putting together elements from two leading organisations to create a great new business - we hope. This new company will allow our clients to extend links with counterparties and others in financial markets. This will be a very secure global network for e-commerce in the financial community."

Mr Ure will be non-executive chairman of the joint venture company while Doug Gilstrap, chief operating office of Equant's Network Services, will fill the chief executive position. Both Reuters and Equant said they may consider an eventual public float of the joint venture company.

Reuters shares soared 80p to £10.46, with some analysts stating that the joint venture could add 127p to the British group's share price.

Patrick Wellington, analyst at Schroders, said the $400m in estimated sales of the joint venture company, could give it a market capitalisation of $6bn when compared with peers such as Energis and Colt.

"Reuters are now beginning to leverage their assets and to work their share price," Mr Wellington said.

He has a target price on the stock of £13.

Reuters said the joint venture company would also work closely with its 63%-owned Tibco Software to enable the delivery of its applications over the network.

Neither company would comment on cost savings created from the joint venture or the new company's growth prospects.

However, it was speculated that the new company would have growth targets of up to 30% annually.

Equant also warned yesterday that its 1999 operating profit would be lower than expected.

fields.headline: Hitching a ride
fields.standfirst: DaimlerChrysler buys into McLaren
fields.trailText: Car group DaimlerChrysler yesterday exercised its option to buy for an undisclosed sum 40% of shares in Formula One racing group TAG McLaren. Ron Dennis and the TAG Group - each owning 30% in the Group - will continue to be in charge of operational management. McLaren, along with Ferrari are touted as the front runners in the up coming grand prix championship starting in March.
fields.body:
Car group DaimlerChrysler yesterday exercised its option to buy for an undisclosed sum 40% of shares in Formula One racing group TAG McLaren. Ron Dennis and the TAG Group - each owning 30% in the Group - will continue to be in charge of operational management. McLaren, along with Ferrari are touted as the front runners in the up coming grand prix championship starting in March.

The announcement follows the decision by DaimlerChrysler and McLaren Cars to develop jointly the Mercedes-McLaren SLR super sports car and bring it to the market in 2003.

Mika Hakkinen in his Mercedes is seen, above, at a practice for the San Marino Grand Prix last year.

DaimlerChrysler was yesterday reported to be in talks before merging its car business with the dominant Italian car maker Fiat. Newspaper La Repubblica reported that the Agnelli family, which founded the company at the beginning of the last century, are buying Fiat shares with voting rights, including preference shares, to strengthen the family holding. The family is thought to want 51% of voting rights in before a scheduled extraordinary shareholders meeting. Such a level of voting rights would allow the family to carry out "without excessive difficulty" the spin-off of the car business. Fiat refused to comment on the reports which have driven its share price up 5% to €34.50 (£21.50). It has seen its share of the car market in Italy grow in the past year. It had 39.1% of the new car market in last month, up from 32.7% in January 1999.

fields.headline: Intrinsic chief urges investor caution
fields.trailText: Luke Johnson's investment trust, Intrinsic Value, has warned of the "extreme volatility" in stock markets and says "the potential for significant setbacks is considerable".
fields.body:
Luke Johnson's investment trust, Intrinsic Value, has warned of the "extreme volatility" in stock markets and says "the potential for significant setbacks is considerable".

The pizza entrepreneur turned professional investor believes the stock market is heading towards a major correction, and his words are likely to be heeded among the army of retail investors who follow his investments.

Intrinsic Value - which Mr Johnson co-manages with entrepreneur Mark Horrocks - said it would "proceed with caution" after announcing its maiden interim results from July 17 to December 31 1999.

The trust was listed in July to make investments in smaller and unquoted companies which offered long-term shareholder value.

Chairman James West said Intrinsic Value had made "solid progress" during the period but warned that the second half of 1999 was a difficult time for value investors. Turnover was £582,000 and earnings per share 16.8p.

Net asset value per share climbed from 98.2p to 113.5p. There will not be an interim dividend.

Mr West said that approximately 30% of the £25m Intrinsic Value raised at the flotation remained in cash on December 31. "It was not possible to invest the entire proceeds of the placing at sensible prices," he said.

Intrinsic's most notable recent transaction since then has been the acquisition of a 20% stake in the recently refinanced MediaKey for £750,000. Mr West said it has materially benefited the net asset value per share and a similar type of deal is likely to be announced shortly.

Other positions include a small stake in Arlington, an Ofex-listed technology investment company which counts Kerry Packer and David Rowland among its backers.
