fields.headline: Vindication for Anglo-Saxon ethos
fields.standfirst: Mannesmann poorly rewarded
fields.trailText: The battle by Vodafone AirTouch for Mannesmann has been a hard-fought affair. Though the bid itself was of blockbuster proportions its importance has gone beyond sheer size. It came to be seen as a struggle between Anglo-Saxon and Rhineland capitalism, between unfettered market forces and corporate consensus. It was a hostile bid launched into an environment where such things were just not done. Even Chancellor Schröder got involved.
fields.body:
The battle by Vodafone AirTouch for Mannesmann has been a hard-fought affair. Though the bid itself was of blockbuster proportions its importance has gone beyond sheer size. It came to be seen as a struggle between Anglo-Saxon and Rhineland capitalism, between unfettered market forces and corporate consensus. It was a hostile bid launched into an environment where such things were just not done. Even Chancellor Schröder got involved.

So which side has won? Vodafone appears close to victory. Although the talks over better terms for Mannesmann shareholders in exchange for an agreed deal were still going on last night, Vodafone's Chris Gent has, if only just, kept the Mannesmann shareholders' slice of the merged company below 50%.

It will be his view, rather than that of Mannesmann boss Klaus Esser, which will help determine the future of the telecoms market in Europe and beyond.

As to the conflict between rival brands of capitalism, the Anglo-Saxons can claim victory here, too. Although Vodafone and Mannesmann were last night negotiating an agreed deal it is clear that hostile offers in Germany will become a fact of life not a freakish exception to the norm.

Greater internationalisation of the shareholder base of corporate Germany is helping to create the right circumstances. Capital gains tax changes that will allow German companies to unwind long-held positions in other German companies without incurring hefty liabilities will help, too.

There were plenty of people in Germany who wanted the battle to go the distance to point the moral that hostile approaches are winnable. Vodafone was pushing at a door that was already beginning to swing open, although it might not have enjoyed the experience.

So a comprehensive victory for free market forces? Not quite. Whether or not takeover bids, especially hostile ones, enhance or diminish shareholder value is an argument which will run and run but one justification is that they provide an essential discipline to ensure managements are kept on their toes. Poorly run companies get an appropriate market rating which quickly has the predators circling.

Mannesmann, however, is not a poorly run company. It is an exceptionally well run one. At a time when corporate Germany is being told to adopt shareholder value, Mannesmann management has not just paid lip-service to the concept; it has delivered, turning a well-regarded engineering operation into a highly rated telecoms company. Its reward, barring a late snag, is to see the company taken over. Some reward.

Forex zz

Although Vodafone's successful assault on Mannesmann might have more than a few German executives atremble over what the future holds the outcome could be cause for celebration at the European Central Bank headquarters in Frankfurt. Yesterday the euro, the lead balloon of the foreign exchange market, rallied. No doubt the ECB's decision to increase interest rates had something to do with the rise but, in some quarters at least, credence was being given to the idea that Vodafone's success will encourage capital flows into Euroland's biggest economy, helping to underpin the currency.

That aside, the ECB has a tricky path to tread. The ostensible reason for yesterday's quarter-point rate increase is concern about inflation. The strategy has a "stick and carrot" aspect. A quarter-point now leaves the bank with at least another quarter-point rise in reserve if the wage round in Germany turns out badly.

The question is whether the ECB's real target was inflation or the exchange rate. Of course, the two are linked. A stronger euro would help curb imported inflation, not least in terms of dollar-denominated oil prices. If the markets believe the ECB's move was driven by worries about inflation then they might be forgiven for being baffled. After all, the ECB's own monthly report noted in January that unless the oil price continued to rise the effect of last year's increase would prove transitory. So a rate rise would hardly be seen as policy-making at its best.

But if the markets take the view that the bank does care more about the exchange rate than just its impact on inflation then the way is open for the forex market speculators to try to test its resolve.

In the long run, however, a growing perception that the ECB does care about the euro might be no bad thing. The bank cannot be indifferent to the exchange rate, not only for domestic economic reasons but also because it needs to respect the sensibilities of the euro zone's trading partners. But it might be better still if the bank were to acknowledge such concerns openly.

fields.headline: IMF hiring policy faulted
fields.trailText: Aid agencies from around the world have complained to Gordon Brown about the "highly secretive and undemocratic" way in which the new managing director of the International Monetary Fund is being selected by rich industrialised countries.
fields.body:
Aid agencies from around the world have complained to Gordon Brown about the "highly secretive and undemocratic" way in which the new managing director of the International Monetary Fund is being selected by rich industrialised countries.

In a letter to Mr Brown, who chairs the IMF's international monetary and financial committee, the agencies say it is not justifiable to continue with a system which allows a minority of rich countries to appoint the head of an institution wielding so much influence in developing countries.

"It is disgraceful that the millions of people living daily under IMF influence have absolutely no opportunity to engage in the process of choosing the managing director," says the letter signed by a wide range of non-governmental organisations including Friends of the Earth, Jubilee 2000, the Bretton Woods Project and the World Development Movement.

The job of IMF managing director, to be vacated by Michel Camdessus later this month, traditionally goes to a European, while the organisation's sister institution, the World Bank, is run by an American.

Neither job is filled through an open process of application and interview.

The letter says: "Given the lack of representation of poorer countries on the executive board, it is particularly critical to ensure that high-level managers represent the interests of users of the IMF resources equally with the interests of the major shareholders.

"Moreover, since much of the IMF's daily work is conducted in developing countries, it is imperative that the new managing director understands and is sympathetic to the needs and problems in developing countries."

The letter says the process for selecting and appointing candidates should be as transparent as possible and include making public the list of candidates, the criteria by which they will be judged and a statement of their views on the IMF's role. It adds that the winning candidate should be selected by a recorded vote of the board.

webTitle: Rate increases fail to slow pace of house price rise

fields.headline: Rate increases fail to slow pace of house price rise
fields.trailText: House prices are rising at their fastest pace for more than 10 years, despite the Bank of England's attempts to take the froth off the market with higher borrowing costs.
fields.body:
House prices are rising at their fastest pace for more than 10 years, despite the Bank of England's attempts to take the froth off the market with higher borrowing costs.

The price of the average house rose by 2.4% in January to £85,168, according to figures issued by Halifax, the largest mortgage provider.

Last month's rise took the annual rate to 16% - the strongest rate of growth since August 1989.

"The recent interest rate rises appear to have done little to slow the pace of the housing market so far," Halifax said. However, with further rises expected, house price inflation should ease later in the year.

The strength of the housing market in the depths of winter is worrying economists. January is usually a quiet month for property transactions and this is the first time since the index began 15 years ago that prices have risen in the first month of the year.

"Even in the peak of the 1980s boom, prices fell by 0.2% in January 1988," said Ciarán Barr, senior UK economist at Deutsche Bank. "This puts further pressure on the Bank of England to raise interest rates at next week's meeting."

Growth in the service sector is starting to slow, according to separate figures from the Chartered Institute of Purchasing and Supply.

Its monthly snapshot of the market showed business activity dipping in January and, while the sector is still expanding, growth rates have eased from their peaks of a few months ago.

"Higher interest rates and a stronger pound are already producing a loss of momentum," said Richard Iley, UK economist at ABN-Amro.

With the rest of the economy cooling after the three increases in interest rates since last September, the news that the housing market shows no signs of coming off the boil poses a dilemma for the Bank's monetary policy committee.

But some analysts think the rise in house prices is not spilling over into the rest of the economy, where inflationary pressures are subdued. Shop prices fell in January for the ninth month in a row, according to the British Retail Consortium's monthly index, published today.

"[The housing market] is not having the inflationary impact it would have had in the past," said David Hillier, UK economist at Barclays Capital. "If [it] were rampantly inflationary, you would expect household goods prices to be rising."

fields.headline: Pfizer has $85bn merger in sight
fields.standfirst: Warner and AHP discuss expensive divorce
fields.trailText: US drug groups Warner-Lambert and American Home Products were last night locked in talks after the two companies - which announced a merger last November that valued Warner at $65bn - seemed on the verge of an acrimonious and expensive split.
fields.body:
US drug groups Warner-Lambert and American Home Products were last night locked in talks after the two companies - which announced a merger last November that valued Warner at $65bn - seemed on the verge of an acrimonious and expensive split.

According to sources close to the two companies, Warner-Lambert has now agreed an $85bn takeover with larger rival Pfizer. Pfizer had launched the world's biggest hostile bid for Warner-Lambert immediately after its friendly deal with AHP had been announced.

However, Warner-Lambert could face a huge bill for jilting its initial partner, because it signed a penalty clause which could give AHP some $1.8bn if it pulls out of the merger.

Last night AHP spokesman Lowell Weiner confirmed talks were under way between the two companies but declined to specify whether AHP planned to improve its offer to acquire Warner- Lambert.

If the Pfizer and Warner-Lambert deal goes ahead, the enlarged group would be the world's biggest drug company, valued at some $220bn, with a portfolio of blockbuster treatments that each rake in sales of more than $1bn a year.

These include Pfizer's famous and controverisial impotence treatment Viagra, anti-depression treatment Zoloft and Lipitor, a cholesterol-lowering drug marketed by both Warner-Lambert and Pfizer, which is tipped to become the world's best-selling prescription medicine.

The combined company would have joint sales of $28bn a year and has estimated it could achieve merger savings of $1.2bn a year.

The merger would also mark the latest round of consolidation in the worldwide pharmaceuticals industry. Last month Glaxo & SmithKline Beecham resurrected the merger they proposed two years ago but which fell apart amid an executive spat over who got the top jobs. Novartis and Roche of Switzerland are also said to be keen to clinch a merger.

Warner-Lambert chief Lodewijk de Vink fought hard to pull off the deal he had set up with AHP, which would have given him the top job, even threatening Pfizer with legal action. But he eventually caved in under pressure from shareholders, who insisted he hold talks with the higher bidder.

If AHP is left out in the cold, it will be the third time the company has been jilted. It held merger talks with SmithKline and Pharmacia & Upjohn - which eventually chose a deal with Monsanto instead - before reaching agreement with Warner-Lambert.

webTitle: P&O shares rise as shipper unties cruise operations in £6bn demerger

fields.headline: P&O shares rise as shipper unties cruise operations in £6bn demerger
fields.trailText: P&O, Britain's premier shipping and transport group, topped off a radical four-year restructuring yesterday with the £6bn demerger of its cruise business.
fields.body:
P&O, Britain's premier shipping and transport group, topped off a radical four-year restructuring yesterday with the £6bn demerger of its cruise business.

The move, long called for by City investors, will create a stand-alone cruise shipping business that will rank in the world's top three. Chairman Lord Sterling said the demerger would also allow the remaining logistics and ports business to expand at a pace which would almost certainly mean an improvement on its 15% return on investment.

Shares in P&O raced up to a high for the year as the strategy was unveiled although the market's enthusiasm was tempered by the end of the day and the gain was reduced to a more modest 129p, or 15.5%. The substantial gain will, however, benefit the recent lacklustre performance of the group's biggest investors such as Phillips & Drew, which owns nearly 10% of P&O, Mercury Asset Management with 6%, Prudential and Schroders.

The deal follows the disposal of P&O's construction company, Bovis, the sale of Earls Court and Olympia together with the shedding of its Australian services company and some £400m worth of investment property.

The group has also merged its container shipping business with that of Nedlloyd of Holland and has pledged to pull out of bulk shipping when market conditions are right.

Lord Sterling said yesterday that it had been right not to gallop into the divestment of the P&O Cruise operation in Britain and the US-based Princess Cruise businesses two or three years ago because the companies would not have been sufficiently strong to stand alone. He admitted he had turned down repeated offers to buy the businesses from Carnival Cruise Lines - the world's biggest player in the field - and said he was confident shareholders would remain loyal so long as its growth prospects and performance were superior to those of rivals.

The P&O chairman, who denied feeling under pressure from shareholders to de-merge the cruise business said: "If we had thought of doing this two to three years ago the company's focus would have been pretty blurred. And we couldn't have got the right results from selling the real estate side of our business because we would have been chucking it away. We have decided to do this now because the programme of rationalisation which I announced last year has gone vastly better and vastly quicker than we thought."

The cruise shipping operation, which has capacity of nearly 20,000 berths, will double in size over the next few years when 11 ships on order are delivered. The vestiges of today's P&O group will include its 50-strong ferry operation, a business which runs 30 ports and 21 container terminals as well as a logistics company which Lord Sterling said was being increasingly driven by e-commerce.

Despite the market enthusiasm for yesterday's deal, Lord Sterling denied it was his business swan song. "Following this I feel more like a cygnet than a swan," he said.

webTitle: Mannesmann won over by last minute concessions

fields.headline: Mannesmann won over by last minute concessions
fields.standfirst: German group to receive 49.5% in agreement that will reshape telecoms sector
fields.trailText: Vodafone Airtouch finally landed its arch-rival Mannesmann after last minute concessions won over the German group's board for a friendly merger.
fields.body:
Vodafone Airtouch finally landed its arch-rival Mannesmann after last minute concessions won over the German group's board for a friendly merger.

Vodafone's chief executive, Chris Gent, flew to Düsseldorf to put the finishing touches to a £103.4bn deal which secures majority control of the merged company for his group's shareholders.

The crucial concession which finally ended a three-month long hostile assault on one of Germany's top companies saw Vodafone offer Mannesmann 49.5% of the combined group. It initial bid had been 47.2%.

Under the deal agreed by both the management and the supervisiory boards of the German group, Mannesmann shareholders will now get 58.9 Vodafone shares for every Mannesmann share, up from the first offer of 53.7 shares.

The proposed deal will have a dramatic impact on the shape of the European telecoms market and will open up Germany to further foreign takeovers.

A crucial part of the telecoms realignment will be the disposal of Orange - bought by Mannesmann last year for £20bn and now up for sale in order to secure regulatory approval.

The European commission has already said it would be studying how the sale of Britain's third largest mobile phone operator would be handled.

Interested parties could include France Telecom - recently thwarted in its efforts to buy Germany's E-plus and Holland's KPN. The sale could also present American operators with the opportunity to establish a European bridgehead.

But the key role in the corporate power plays which will follow Vodafone's success is likely to lie with Vivendi, the French utilities and media group, courted by both sides during the recent bid battle.

Mr Gent has agreed a deal with Vivendi's Jean-Marie Messier which will see the enlarged Vodafone dispose of half its 15% stake in Cegetel, the French mobile phones operator, to Vivendi which already owns 44%, effectively handing it control.

Last weekend's agreement between the British and French groups, effectively putting an end to Mannesmann's fight to retain its independence, also included the proposed pooling of their fixed-line networks and the creation of a new internet portal.

Though Mannesmann put up a vigorous struggle, Vodafone's strategy, with its global focus, won out over the German's concentration on a pan-European approach based on the integration of fixed-line and wireless networks. The Mannesmann acquisition will crown a lightning series of purchases by Mr Gent. As well as the $60bn merger with Airtouch in the US, Vodafone has added significantly to its stake in Spain's Airtel.

Vodafone is now strongly placed in Britain, Germany, Spain, Italy - where Mannesmann brings a 55.1% stake in Omnitel Pronto Italia - and France as well as in the US. It already has equity stakes in 24 operators in 23 countries.

The prospect of rapid growth in the mobile phone markets on both sides of the Atlantic has done much to ensure shareholder approval for Vodafone's aggressive approach.

Mannesmann, which had initially demanded 58.5% of the combined group as the price of an agreed merger, settled for a minority holding after the markets drove up its share price close to the value put on the group by its chief executive, Klaus Esser.

Its advisers last night claimed that the spirited defence had helped drive the group's value up from €155 (£96) share last October when it bought Orange to last night's close of €325.50.

As Mannesmann more than doubled in value in the past five months foreign and indeed many German institutions were keen to accept the Vodafone bid, fearing that Mannesmann's share price would fall back if the takeover did not go through.

Initially, the combined group will have some 130,000 employees, though the numbers will fall sharply after the sale of Orange and the disposal of Mannesmann's engineering operation.

Mannesmann itself had said it planned to float off the engineering and automotive businesses - forged more than a century ago - and expected to raise £2.5bn. Vodafone is expected to follow a similar strategy.

In terms of the mobile phone business, the combined group will have some 54m subscribers, with Mannesmann accounting for around a third of the total.

But a series of new alliances with internet service providers and software specialists is expected to boost the combined group's global reach to more than 500m.

Main players - Klaus Esser

A very passionate European, lover of poetry and amateur historian, Klaus Esser, 52, could go down as the business executive who finally opened the doors of post-war Germany to the Anglo-Saxon model of market capitalism.

Small, dapper, very cerebral, this man with an MBA from MIT, who got his first job in a New York law firm, has spent the past few weeks defending a century-old but very modern German group's pan-European ambitions against the global dreams of Vodafone AirTouch.

Mr Esser, born and raised in the Ruhrgebiet, Germany's industrial heartland and home of its consensual post-war culture, could not be more different from his flamboyant rival. But he has masterminded Mannesmann's metamorphosis into the country's fastest growing corporate group - and could yet re-emerge as one of its post-modern business leaders.

He claimed that Vodafone's bid seriously undervalued his group but in the end he fell victim to that very Anglo-Saxon concept of shareholder value that is beginning to sweep German boardrooms.

ChrisGent
Chris Gent, Vodafone's chief executive, yesterday emerged as Europe's leading business executive. But he could easily have been a failed Tory minister had he not, wisely, opted for corporate riches.

This former Young Conservative chairman, friend of John Major, devotee of cricket (he's known as Herr Cricket in Germany) and warm beer has shown an astonishingly undiplomatic touch in his dealings with German political and cultural sensitivities and a classic Anglo-Saxon ruthlessness in securing his goal.

In his ubiquitous red-rimmed glasses and braces, he has orchestrated - often from a box at cricket grounds around the world -Vodafone's rise to among the world's biggest companies from its time as part of Racal - now in the hands, ironically, of the French.

Last weekend's agreement between the British and French groups, effectively putting an end to Mannesmann's fight to retain its independence, also included the proposed pooling of their fixed-line networks and the creation of a new internet portal. Though Mannesmann put up a vigorous struggle, Vodafone's strategy, with its global focus, won out over the German's concentration on a pan-European approach based on the integration of fixed-line and wireless networks. The Mannesmann acquisition will crown a lightning series of purchases by Mr Gent. As well as the $60bn merger with Airtouch in the US, Vodafone has added significantly to its stake in Spain's Airtel. Vodafone is now strongly placed in Britain, Germany, Spain, Italy - where Mannesmann brings a 55.1% stake in Omnitel Pronto Italia - and France as well as in the US. It already has equity stakes in 24 operators in 23 countries. The prospect of rapid growth in the mobile phone markets on both sides of the Atlantic has done much to ensure shareholder approval for Vodafone's aggressive approach. Mannesmann, which had initially demanded 58.5% of the combined group as the price of an agreed merger, settled for a minority holding after the markets drove up its share price close to the value put on the group by its chief executive, Klaus Esser. Its advisers last night claimed that the spirited defence had helped drive the group's value up from €155 (£96) share last October when it bought Orange to last night's close of €325.50. As Mannesmann more than doubled in value in the past five months foreign and indeed many German institutions were keen to accept the Vodafone bid, fearing that Mannesmann's share price would fall back if the takeover did not go through. Initially, the combined group will have some 130,000 employees, though the numbers will fall sharply after the sale of Orange and the disposal of Mannesmann's engineering operation. Mannesmann itself had said it planned to float off the engineering and automotive businesses - forged more than a century ago - and expected to raise £2.5bn. Vodafone is expected to follow a similar strategy. In terms of the mobile phone business, the combined group will have some 54m subscribers, with Mannesmann accounting for around a third of the total. But a series of new alliances with internet service providers and software specialists is expected to boost the combined group's global reach to more than 500m. Main players - Klaus Esser A very passionate European, lover of poetry and amateur historian, Klaus Esser, 52, could go down as the business executive who finally opened the doors of post-war Germany to the Anglo-Saxon model of market capitalism. Small, dapper, very cerebral, this man with an MBA from MIT, who got his first job in a New York law firm, has spent the past few weeks defending a century-old but very modern German group's pan-European ambitions against the global dreams of Vodafone AirTouch. Mr Esser, born and raised in the Ruhrgebiet, Germany's industrial heartland and home of its consensual post-war culture, could not be more different from his flamboyant rival. But he has masterminded Mannesmann's metamorphosis into the country's fastest growing corporate group - and could yet re-emerge as one of its post-modern business leaders. He claimed that Vodafone's bid seriously undervalued his group but in the end he fell victim to that very Anglo-Saxon concept of shareholder value that is beginning to sweep German boardrooms. ChrisGent Chris Gent, Vodafone's chief executive, yesterday emerged as Europe's leading business executive. But he could easily have been a failed Tory minister had he not, wisely, opted for corporate riches. This former Young Conservative chairman, friend of John Major, devotee of cricket (he's known as Herr Cricket in Germany) and warm beer has shown an astonishingly undiplomatic touch in his dealings with German political and cultural sensitivities and a classic Anglo-Saxon ruthlessness in securing his goal. In his ubiquitous red-rimmed glasses and braces, he has orchestrated - often from a box at cricket grounds around the world -Vodafone's rise to among the world's biggest companies from its time as part of Racal - now in the hands, ironically, of the French.

fields.headline: Rail authority invests £265m in tracks
fields.trailText: A 70-minute rail journey between London and Birmingham will be made possible by a £265m investment scheme headed by the strategic rail authority to quadruple the track from Birmingham to Coventry.
fields.body:
A 70-minute rail journey between London and Birmingham will be made possible by a £265m investment scheme headed by the strategic rail authority to quadruple the track from Birmingham to Coventry.

The SRA's first investment into the railway was confirmed yesterday by an authority spokesman who said that a final decision about financial liability would be made after talks with Railtrack and the west midlands passenger transport authority.

Most of the money will be borne by the taxpayer through the SRA, although Railtrack has agreed to bear part of the cost. The project is designed to show that the government is putting money into new rail schemes before the election.

Chris Green, chief executive of Virgin Trains, said last night: "This is exactly what the SRA should be doing. We are at last expanding the railway because up to now we have been trying to squeeze a quart into a pint pot."

Delays on the line for fast trains are caused by local stopping trains, which add 20 minutes to the Birmingham to London intercity service.

fields.headline: Tax aversion therapy
fields.standfirst: Labour's pledge to stick to the Tories' budget was based on fear of being perceived as the tax-and-spend party. But times have changed
fields.trailText: Many of the Blair government's recent difficulties seem to arise from its refusal to increase public spending in its first two years of office above levels projected by the Tories. This is why health, education and other services have not noticeably improved since 1997. Before the election Gordon Brown also gave a commitment not to increase income tax within the life of the present parliament.
fields.body:
Many of the Blair government's recent difficulties seem to arise from its refusal to increase public spending in its first two years of office above levels projected by the Tories. This is why health, education and other services have not noticeably improved since 1997. Before the election Gordon Brown also gave a commitment not to increase income tax within the life of the present parliament.

As Philip Gould, Labour's chief pollster in the 1997 campaign, makes clear in his book (The Unfinished Revolution, Little Brown) those promises were the direct response to evidence, culled from focus groups, that voters were nervous about how Labour might handle the economy. In particular former Tory voters, who were key electoral targets in 1997, were worried about Labour's "tax and spend" image. Labour strategists felt their surprise loss in 1992 could be explained by shadow chancellor John Smith's detailed promises on tax and spending.

On the face of it this concern about tax is puzzling. Opinion surveys in recent years have shown large majorities in favour of increased tax and more public spending when offered the alternatives of lower taxation and spending cuts. Has the Blair government been timid - resulting in the present discontents?

Our analysis is based on British election study surveys of voters done shortly after polling day. It concentrates on Tory and Labour voters only since there is a weak relationship between attitudes to taxation and spending among Liberal Democrat voters.

The first thing it shows is that attitudes to tax did have a strong influence on voting in both 90s' elections. In 1992, 81% of those favouring tax and spending cuts voted Tory; only 19% of this group voted Labour. At the other end of the scale only about a third of the group favouring increased taxation and spending voted Tory; two-thirds of them voted Labour. In 1992 the "anti-tax" group comprised 13% of the voters and the "pro-tax" group 44%.

But even though the anti-tax voters were outnumbered by the pro-taxers by a large margin, the Tories did much better than Labour on this issue because they secured the lion's share of both the anti-tax voters and those voters who supported the status quo of keeping taxes and spending the same. The status quo-ers made up 43% of the electorate - and were Labour's achilles heel in 1992. The conclusion had to be that while many voters prefer tax and spend policies, it does not necessarily mean that the party supporting these policies will automatically win an election.

The research also shows there was a significant swing to Labour in all three attitude groups between 1992 and 1997. The shift is particularly evident in the group favouring the fiscal status quo. Labour took 26% of this "middle ground" group in 1992, whereas its share in 1997 was 54%. It looks as though the Blair-Brown pledges on tax and spending did have an important electoral effect, even if they have come back to haunt New Labour.

Of course other factors influence how people vote, apart from their attitudes to tax: how they feel about party leaders, the parties' public images, their views about non-financial issues. Thus it is important not to overestimate the decisiveness of tax. Even so, taking everything into account, attitudes to tax do remain important as a predictor of how people vote - and did assist the Tories, though the degree to which they benefited was considerably greater in the election Neil Kinnock lost in 1992 than in 1997. In fact the weakening of the issue by May 1997 is a measure of the extent to which Labour neutralised opposition thanks to its promises on tax and spending.

Our analysis does not uncover a third factor: how Labour benefited from a swing in opinion during John Major's government distinctly in favour of higher taxation and more spending. If some 44% of voters favoured increases in 1992, this group had grown to 53% of the electorate by 1997. In parallel there was a reduction in the proportion of voters who favoured tax and spending cuts. It looks, given contemporary arguments about spending on health, education and transport, as if that trend in opinion in favour of more spending has gone on and may continue into the future. Unless the Tories change their spots, this should give Labour an advantage in the next election.

For their part, the Tories recently adopted an election pledge to make cuts in taxation during the lifetime of one parliament, regardless of the state of the economy. This promise was widely criticised, but it did follow a period of extensive public consultation undertaken by William Hague and colleagues using private polls and focus groups. This reminds us that taxation is still a potent issue. The "tax burden" may yet return to haunt the government if the economy gets into difficulties.

It is sometimes argued that voters are irrational: they seem to want both better public services and lower taxation at the same time. It is not true. It is perfectly rational to want better services for oneself and higher taxes for someone else. So it is the way beneficiaries get separated from contributors that makes taxation so intractable a political question.

If the electorate continues to believe that the Blair government is competent in handling the economy, then it will secure political space in which to raise taxation and spending. But it would be a mistake to think that this can be done without limit, simply because a majority tell pollsters that they prefer it.

Paul Whiteley is professor of politics at Sheffield University

fields.headline: Notorious British villains
fields.standfirst: ... to save you the burden of reading them
fields.trailText: ... to save you the burden of reading them
fields.body:
Mad Frank and Friends, by Frankie Fraser with James Morton (Little, Brown, £6.99)

Buy it at BOL

Francis Fraser may be pushing 80 but, rest assured, he has lost none of his trademark clout. A life spent doing "bird", and working with the Krays and the Richardsons has ensured that he is still feared and revered. So don't be naughty - otherwise, he might send the boys round to "see things are right". And you wouldn't like that.

Criminally improbable moniker: "Rubber Bones" Webb.

Stop the Ride, I Want to Get Off, by Dave Courtney (Virgin Books, £16.99)

Buy it at BOL

The man who was the inspiration for the Vinnie Jones character in Lock, Stock & Two Smoking Barrels needs no introduction, but "My name is Dave Courtney and despite whatever you've heard of me...I'm worse", does sum things up rather nicely. "Dodgy Dave" is now legit, although with form like his, he cannot help worrying that those "of the flat-footed persuasion" will not leave him alone.

Criminally improbable moniker: Stevie Two Pints.

Respect, by Freddie Foreman with John Lisners (Arrow, £6.99)

Buy it at BOL

Freddie 'fesses up to the murders of Ginger Marks and Frank "the Mad Axeman" Mitchell, attributing his violent behaviour to the "respect" that he craved "at any cost". Having killed for the Kray twins, and been extradited kicking and screaming from Spain, Foreman deserves the title of "managing director of British crime". Whatever you do, "Don't mess with Brown Bread Fred - or you're dead."

Criminally improbable moniker: Jack the Pie.

Running with the Krays, by Billy Webb (Mainstream Publishing, £6.99)

Buy it at BOL

Dedicated to those who "vanished from the face of the earth during the Krays' reign", and detailing Ronnie's fondness for pictures of "nice boys in swimming costumes", Webb makes it clear that he is no longer one of the twins' fans. His own hobbies included banishing "ponces" from London, and annoying "notorious landlord" Peter Rachman by beating up his rent collectors and kidnapping "his hookers".

Criminally improbable moniker: The "Sus Brothers".

Pretty Boy, by Roy Shaw with Kate Kray (Blake, £14.99)

Buy it at BOL

A word of warning from Roy: "If you're unlucky enough to have me come after you, beware - 'cos hell's coming with me." And it probably is. Shaw has spent most of his life in prison (Borstal, Broadmoor, Parkhurst, etc), mixing with Frankie Fraser, Reggie Kray and assorted members of the IRA. Robber, bouncer, killer and bare-knuckle fighter, he now counsels against crime: "I survived, but only just."

Most criminally improbable moniker: "Mad Dog" Mullins.

webTitle: Mariella Frostrup's top 10 books to impress a prospective lover

fields.headline: Mariella Frostrup's top 10 books to impress a prospective lover
fields.trailText: Mariella Frostrup is a film critic, journalist and TV presenter
fields.body:
Mariella Frostrup is a film critic, journalist and TV presenter.

She writes: "Your favourite books are the best you can hope for on a prospective lover's shelves: it means you have much in common, in terms of both interests and emotions. Obviously, along with the books you recognise you also hope there will be many you don't - the books I've read and enjoyed over the years have always been personally recommended rather than purchased on the back of a good review. Meeting a fellow booklover is always exciting because it means an opportunity to expand your own library (amongst other less elevated pursuits!). It's a wonderful bonding moment when you discover a mutual enthusiasm for a book."

1. Chronicle Of A Death Foretold by Gabriel Garcia Marquez

My favourite book by one of the world's greatest authors.The sense of foreboding that builds through this simply written but incredibly powerful story confirms you're in the hands of a master.

2. Under The Volcano by Malcolm Lowry

Another beautifully written, incisive and to my mind classic piece of literature.

3. Cloudstreet by Tim Winton

A beautiful tragicomic tale of two dysfunctional families sharing a dilapidated house in a Melbourne suburb. Winton writes with a highly individual voice and the story is laced with love and hope and all the things that make life worth living.

4. Four Letters Of Love by Niall Williams

A romantic, windswept, glorious piece of magic realism set on the west coast of Ireland.

5. Anyone Here Been Raped And Speak English by Edward Behr

One of the funniest and most fascinating examples of the foreign correspondent genre. Sadly frequently out of print which is a tragedy.

6. Into The Heart Of Borneo by Redmond O'Hanlon

Redmond O'Hanlon is one of my favourite travel writers and this book was my introduction to his work. His self effacing tales of an unlikely, unfit adventurer are always unusual, illuminating and hilarious. Billy Bunter meets Wilfred Thesiger.

7. Naples '44 by Norman Lewis

Set in my favourite European city, Norman Lewis's experiences there during the second world war provide a unique and illuminating portrait of the extraordinary Neopolitans. To this day it remains a seething metropolis full of rogues, ruffians and humanity at its best and worst! Norman Lewis captures it magnificently.

8. Tourist Season by Carl Hiaasen

A columnist and environmental campaigner for the Miami Herald, this is Hiaasen's first novel in what has evolved into a series of blackly comic and utterly readable satires set in his native Florida. Those who saw the dreadful screen adaptation of his novel Striptease shouldn't be put off the author himself. Essential holiday/aeroplane reading.

9. The Moor's Last Sigh by Salman Rushdie

In my opinion Rushdie is the only author in Britain today who can compete on the world stage with writers like Marquez and Don DeLillo. He's a master storyteller and this novel sees him at the height of his powers with its multi-layered, captivating and frequently comic story.

10. The Complete Cookery Course by Delia Smith

There are few sexier things than a man cooking you dinner. This book is the perfect instruction manual for novices and experts alike. A top scorer on any prospective date's shelves!

webTitle: John Hegarty's top 10 books for would-be advertisers

fields.headline: John Hegarty's top 10 books for would-be advertisers
fields.trailText: John Hegarty is the Chairman and Creative Director of BartleBogleHegarty.
fields.body:
John Hegarty is the Chairman and Creative Director of BartleBogleHegarty.

1. Adventures in the Screen Trade by William Goldman

Even though this is a book about Hollywood by one of its foremost screenwriters, you'll learn how to write TV commercials.

2. Easy Riders, Raging Bulls by Peter Biskind

Indulgence has always been the creative person's worst enemy. This book chronicles its rise and fall.

3. Fatherland by Robert Harris

Nothing to do with the media. But everything to do with lateral thinking.

4. Living on Thin Air: The New Economy by Charles Leadbeater

What's happening, why and how to make sense of it.

5. Final Cut: Art, Money and Ego in the Making of Heaven's Gate by Steven Bach

Creativity out of control.

6. Fountainhead by Ayn Rand

A reminder that we are nothing but the ideas we develop.

7. Barbarians at the Gate by Brian Burrough

An incredible insight into the world of high finance and corporate takeovers.

8. From Those Wonderful Folks who Brought you Pearl Harbor: Front Line Dispatches from the Advertising War by Jerry Della Femina

A humorous, personal view of Madison Avenue at work by one of its great copywriters.

9. 100 Greatest Advertisements by Julian Lewis Watkins

Where modern advertising started and what it looked like. Understanding the industry's past helps you to understand its future.

10. The Tortilla Curtain by T Coraghessan Boyle

Absolutely nothing to do with the media, but a wonderful read about hopes, dreams and disappointment.

fields.headline: OFT in Abbey fight
fields.trailText: A spat broke out between Abbey National and the office of fair trading last night over claims by the regulator that it had won a "landmark" multi-million pound action against a subsidiary of the bank.
fields.body:
A spat broke out between Abbey National and the office of fair trading last night over claims by the regulator that it had won a "landmark" multi-million pound action against a subsidiary of the bank.

The OFT said the court of appeal had ruled that First National Bank, the Abbey unit, was acting unfairly in the way it charged debtors interest on top of instalments which they had been ordered to pay by county courts.

"This is the first case in which I have had to resort to legal action since the regulations came into force in 1995 ... I felt it was vital to bring this case in order to prevent other lenders adopting the same practice," said John Bridgeman, director general of fair trading.

First National is the largest independent provider of consumer finance and largest provider of home loan improvement credit in the UK.

fields.headline: Piers will stay at large
fields.standfirst: The Mirror's editor would never be convicted of insider dealing, even if he were guilty. The law doesn't work
fields.trailText: The Mirror's editor would never be convicted of insider dealing, even if he were guilty. The law doesn't work
fields.body:
Sun editor David Yelland might like to see Piers Morgan, his rival round at the Mirror, locked up. If nothing else, it would be good for circulation and it would be rude not to kick a rival while he's down.

The pressure on Mr Morgan to explain why exactly he invested £20,000 in a company run by his friend Sir Alan Sugar just before his newspaper tipped the shares and sent the price up 100% - more or less doubling the Mirror editor's money - is growing rather than fading. But Mr Yelland might as well stop dreaming of that front page picture with the banner header - Guilty! It is just not going to happen.

Mr Morgan, it should quickly be pointed out, is protesting his innocence in the strongest possible terms. Lots of people had tipped Sir Alan's Viglen Technology. It was widely known that it was bolstering its internet business and, in any case, Mr Morgan didn't see the piece of journalistic puffery on his paper's City Slickers page until after he had bought the shares. It just made him smile.

If he had, there might be a case to answer under part five of the criminal justice act, 1993 - a breach of which carries a recommended sentence of up to seven years and/or an unlimited fine.

Yet it is almost nine years since anyone went behind bars for their stock market dealings. The last soul to go down was one Ivan Goodman, a company director trading in a little known company called Unigroup. He got 18 months, nine suspended.

There is no guessing how many times the crime of insider dealing has been committed since then. Every single business day in the City of London share prices rise or fall in advance of official news announcements which prove to be "price sensitive".

Insiders, whether they be company executives, corporate financiers, stockbrokers, publicans or even journalists, are dealing on the stock market in the knowledge that a piece of news is about to emerge which will affect the relevant share price. So when the law says this is a criminal act, why is no one brought to book these days?

The answer is sad and simple. The authorities have discovered, to their deep embarrassment, that the legislation doesn't work. On too many occasions, while armed with what on paper looks like a water-tight case, the defendant has slipped off the hook - more often than not because the judge has thrown the case out, declaring that the Crown has failed to argue its case.

The problem for the department of trade and the financial services authority, which together police the City, is that as things currently stand insider dealing is nothing short of a criminal act. Prosecutors have to convince a jury of the defendant's guilt beyond all reasonable doubt. And in the complex world of the stock market, where pieces of hard information, rumours and downright lies are pinging around at lightning speed, doubts are easily raised.

So the authorities have given up trying to bring anyone to book and they are instead sitting and waiting for parliament to pass the financial services bill - now at the second reading stage.

The new legislation aims to clean up the situation by introducing a new offence on top of the insider dealing provisions called "market abuse". This will be a piece of civil legislation, allowing the City's watchdog, the FSA, to go for a "balance of probabilities" judgment against suspected insiders. These new powers of legislation are loosely based on the American model, where irregularities in the financial markets are pursued with real passion.

But the financial services bill is having a rocky ride through the Commons, with questions raised over whether the legislation breaches the European convention on human rights. Already badly delayed, even a smooth ride from here will not see an entry in the statute book until late spring at the earliest. And none of the regulators charged with implementing the new powers expects to be able to wield them until this time next year.

In the meantime, the punishments on offer to the financial police amount to little more than causing public embarrassment.

Each year, the surveillance department at the London Stock Exchange undertakes about 300 individual investigations, with probes triggered automatically by abnormal share price movements. If real evidence of abuse of information is found, the case is passed to the DTI, which then has the option of appointing inspectors to carry out their own investigation.

About 30 cases reach the DTI each year - and Stock Exchange sources say that each and every one of these looks like a blatant breach of the law. The DTI appoints inspectors in just a small handful of cases. These are never publicised and the resultant report never reaches the public eye. And then? Well, nothing happens at all. The DTI, the Stock Exchange and the FSA just have to hope that the fear of being dragged in front of one of their inspectors, and watching the fact leak out among City colleagues, is enough to shame alleged insiders. They simply hope they are providing some sort of deterrent.

Piers Morgan, on current evidence, does not need to feel shame. As for the real insiders, they have a window of opportunity that is still a year wide.

webTitle: Vodafone's £103bn deal is Europe's biggest merger

fields.headline: Vodafone's £103bn deal is Europe's biggest merger
fields.standfirst:
E-finance: special report
www.vodafone.co.uk
www.mannesmann.de/english/
fields.trailText: Vodafone last night won its three-month battle for its German rival Mannesmann with an agreed £103.4bn bid, the biggest corporate merger in Europe and close to AOL's record-breaking purchase of Time Warner last month.
fields.body:
Vodafone last night won its three-month battle for its German rival Mannesmann with an agreed £103.4bn bid, the biggest corporate merger in Europe and close to AOL's record-breaking purchase of Time Warner last month.

The British company's victory paves the way for an explosive growth in new-generation mobile phones.

The deal, masterminded by Chris Gent, Vodafone's flamboyant chief executive - who ruffled German feathers by launching the country's biggest hostile bid and earned the disparaging sobriquet of Mr Cricket - opens the way to a wave of foreign takeovers of German companies.

The former Young Conservative chairman and friend of John Major is now set to dominate the market not only in the US and UK but in Germany, Italy, and Spain. It will also be a big player in France.

The deal, giving Vodafone 50.5% and Mannesmann 49.5% of the combined group, will see the demerger and probabable flotation of Orange, Britain's third-largest mobile phone company -bought by Mannesmann last October for £20bn and now worth at least £24bn.

Consumers can expect a quantum leap in mobile phone capability, as Vodafone and Mannesmann have both entered agreements with internet service providers and software specialists that could swiftly transform everyday life.

The deal brings closer the day when individuals will be able to download video clips, music and other web-based products and services on new-style mobile phones.

It will also hasten the time when consumers will be able to use mobile and fixed-line screens to obtain combined monthly statements for telephone and bank accounts, and possibly other services such as domestic fuels and water.

Vodafone, which took over the US group Airtouch for $60bn a year ago, is already poised to launch the first stage of a global internet service in July.

Later this year subscribers should be able to trade shares, play games, get the day's news, and up-to-date weather forecasts and travel details.

webTitle: Mirror faces new row over shares

fields.headline: Mirror faces new row over shares
fields.trailText: The share-dealing controversy surrounding Piers Morgan, editor of the Mirror, deepened last night when it emerged that Anil Bhoyrul, one half of the paper's self-styled City Slickers team, has 10,000 shares in a company repeatedly tipped by the newspaper.
fields.body:
The share-dealing controversy surrounding Piers Morgan, editor of the Mirror, deepened last night when it emerged that Anil Bhoyrul, one half of the paper's self-styled City Slickers team, has 10,000 shares in a company repeatedly tipped by the newspaper.

Mr Bhoyrul holds the shares in the restaurant group Belgo, which is run by the former Pizza Express entrepreneur Luke Johnson. In yesterday's City Slickers column, the paper's readers were called on to buy the shares and boost their price, currently at just 5p.

The column refers to "our old mate Luke" and suggests "it might be time to get back into Luke Johnson's Belgo Group of restaurants". With typical chutzpah it added: "We were strong followers of the share when it was 10p. A year on, we look a pair of prats with the shares at a pitiful 5p. The strange thing about Belgo is the concept and brand is bigger than ever."

The company owns a Belgian restaurant chain and the celebrity haunt The Ivy.

The revelation will pile further pressure on Mr Morgan who is subject to a Press Complaints Commission inquiry after he bought £20,000 of shares in Viglen, a technology company run by Sir Alan Sugar, the day before the Slickers ran a positive story on the business. The stock exchange and department of trade and industry are also investigating Mr Morgan's share dealing.

Belgo was one of the Mirror's share tips of 1999 and has featured in the City Slickers section of the Mirror on repeated occasions in the past year.

The Belgo shares are registered in Mr Bhoyrul's name and to his address in north London. Yesterday he said he had forgotten about the stock and that it belonged to his father. "I bought the shares in May 1998 at 11p a share which was about the highest they have been and sold half around eight months ago because I got fed up with them. I do not feel I have done anything wrong by tipping shares I bought a long time ago. I do actually believe the share price is very low because I know Luke Johnson and how good the company is."

Mr Bhoyrul also admitted holding £500 of shares in the hi-tech firm Dialog.

The stock exchange looks at stock market tips as part of its investigations into potential insider dealing.

The PCC said it would investigate the matter if it received a complaint. Its code states that financial journalists must not write about shares or securities in which they or their families have interests without disclosing them to their editor.

A Mirror Group spokesman said the newspaper had been unaware of Mr Bhoyrul's shareholdings. "We expect all our staff to behave ethically. We are looking at the general issues surrounding share dealing among staff."

Mr Morgan laid himself open to a potential criminal investigation when he bought shares in Viglen last month the day before a story in City Slickers disclosed the company's intent to expand into the internet market - a sure way to boost a share price. Mr Morgan maintains he had no prior knowledge of the story.

fields.headline: RBS poised for NatWest victory
fields.trailText: NatWest bank's survival was in doubt yesterday following mounting speculation that the Royal Bank of Scotland could be victorious because the major bank investors would prefer Bank of Scotland to remain an independent.
fields.body:
NatWest bank's survival was in doubt yesterday following mounting speculation that the Royal Bank of Scotland could be victorious because the major bank investors would prefer Bank of Scotland to remain an independent.

As the top management of all three banks continued their charm offensive of leading institutional investors, one of the City's top banking analysts, Michael Lever at HSBC, added to the confusion by backing the continuing independence of NatWest.

While shareholders have until Valentine's day to decide whether to back either of the Scottish banks' bids or go with NatWest's new management team, they are expected to start reaching their decisions as soon as today.

Any confirmation about the views of NatWest's biggest shareholders - such as Prudential, Mercury Asset Management, Schroders and Phillips & Drew - is considered to be crucial in determing the fate of NatWest.

None of them has yet stated publicly its opinion - although the City was yesterday mulling the implications of apparent sales of BoS shares by Mercury.

Amid conflicting recommendations from the few analysts able to make their views public, shareholders remained concerned that the decision was far from clear-cut and the vote would end up being split, which might allow NatWest to escape both bidders.

"We don't have to decide just yet but [it seems] that the vote will be split," a senior fund manager said.

"There are signs that some of the institutions are trying to take leadership so that [a split] doesn't happen, but it is a struggle to get that going," he said.

"Yet I still don't detect a huge appetite for NatWest remaining independent."

A theory began to emerge that big shareholders in NatWest who also hold shares in its two Scottish assailants might end up backing the Royal Bank's bid by default.

A number of senior fund managers indicated that, while they might have a positive view of Bank of Scotland, they were starting to lean towards Royal Bank's bid.

"There's a view that you don't spoil a decent bank," one banker said.

Analysts said it remained difficult to extrapolate any outcome from the four-month tussle, looking at movement in all three banks' shares.

NatWest's shares gained 50p to £11.84 - still below the offers by both Scottish banks - while BoS gained 24p to £6.09p and Royal Bank rose 27p to £10.06.

Michael Lever, the higly regarded banking analyst who yesterday backed NatWest, said he was surprised the Scottish banks' shareholders were supportive of their bids.

He admitted that it had not been an easy decision to back NatWest but he had concluded that the both bids involved "unacceptable risks".

His views echoed those of Sir David Rowland, the chairman and chief executive of NatWest, who said yesterday: "At NatWest we are in no doubt that the risk for our shareholders outweigh the claimed rewards".

Both Scottish banks are anxious to build up support behind their bids so shareholders can exert enough pressure on Sir David to recommend one of the bids. BoS believes there will be a "cascade effect" to prevent a split vote.

fields.headline: Libby Brooks's top 10 women's novels
fields.trailText: Libby Brooks is the Guardian women's editor
fields.body:
Libby Brooks is the Guardian women's editor.

1. The Women's Room: Marilyn French

A feminist classic. French's fictional examination of gender, power and radicalism through the life of one woman is as timeless as it is superlative.

2. Beloved: Toni Morrison

A haunting story of love, loss and rebirth in America's black community after emancipation.

3. The Bell Jar: Sylvia Plath

Plath's semi-autobiographical account of a successful young women's nervous collapse - funny, real, and not a word wasted.

4. The Bone People: Keri Hulme

Language, myth and tradition meld in the story of the relationship between a mute little boy and a lonely woman.

5. Wuthering Heights: Emily Brontë

Passion and romance written like they ought to be.

6. The Handmaid's Tale: Margaret Atwood

An apocalyptic vision of the future, with too many present resonances for comfort.

7. The Voyage Out: Virginia Woolf

Woolf's first novel, written simultaneously with her own bouts of madness.

8. Rebecca: Daphne du Maurier

The young nameless wife palls in the shadow of Rebecca, her dead predecessor.

9. Frankenstein: Mary Shelley

Fertility, man playing God and unconditional love.

10. The Trick Is To Keep Breathing by Janice Galloway

A woman loses a lover, and finally regains her heart. A jewel of a book.

fields.headline: ECB rate rise lifts euro
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The euro mounted a spirited rally on the foreign exchanges yesterday after the European Central Bank came to its defence with an increase in interest rates.
fields.body:
The euro mounted a spirited rally on the foreign exchanges yesterday after the European Central Bank came to its defence with an increase in interest rates.

Reversing its recent slide, the euro surged more than 1 cents against the dollar to close in London at just over 99 cents following the ECB's decision to raise rates by a quarter-point to 3.25%.

Wim Duisenberg, the ECB's president, said the increase in the bank's three key rates was the result of mounting inflationary pressures and denied that it was a knee-jerk response to the single currency's decline to below parity against the dollar in the past week.

Mr Duisenberg said the euro's fall was "not decisive" in the bank's decision to raise interest rates, but accepted that recent developments in the exchange rate were looked at closely as part of its assessment of risks to price stability.

He stressed that the single currency had plenty of scope to appreciate. "We did and do believe that the euro has strong upward potential for reasons we've given to you so often," he said.

Dealers said the euro had been supported by the ECB's rate rise, by attempts to talk it up by ECB officials and by the fact that many investors had been left short of the single currency when it started to rise on the foreign exchanges.

Amid fears in Frankfurt about inflation-busting pay deals this year, Mr Duisenberg said the rate rise was meant both as a warning to wage bargainers and a reassurance that the ECB would remain vigilant on inflation.

Higher oil prices have sent Euroland's inflation rate to 1.7% but Mr Duisenberg said he did not expect it to breach the ECB's 2% ceiling. Adrian Schmidt of Chase Manhattan in London said: "I don't think they have done the right thing. In the past they have said that they don't like fine tuning but this looks like fine tuning. They should have waited and done 50 basis points. The danger is that the markets will see this as a move to protect the euro. The markets would rather see nothing or 50. I think they would rather see something decisive."

Andrew Snowball of Bank Julius Baer said: "I think what they are doing is trying to prop up the euro and I don't think that will work."
